Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 06:42PM Binney4 wrote: Hi all, just wanted to add a couple of thoughts that may be helpful. For those using cornstarch, you can dump some into the toe of a clean cotton sock, close the top with a rubber band, and pat it on just where you want it. Keeps it from puffing all over and from spilling on the floor, where it's awfully slippery. If you're using any of the solid crystal products, do be watchful for sharp edges from dropping it or banging it on something. It can chip off and leave really sharp places, which are a risk for nasty little nicks -- something you want to avoid even after rads because of the lymphedema risk. If you chip it, you may be able to smooth it again with pumice. Otherwise, toss it and get a new one. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2018 03:04PM Binney4 wrote: Npreece, welcome! Sorry about your reasons for being here, but glad you found us. It's always a good idea to hook up with a well-trained lymphedema therapist BEFORE surgery, for baseline arm measurements, personalized tips on reducing your lymphedema risk, and to learn a gentle self-massage for reducing swelling. And to help determine what's up with the swelling! If this is your left arm that's swelling, and your port is on the left side, then it's possible the port is pressing against the main lymphatic vessel and reducing lymph flow to that area. It is rare, and can affect both legs as well, since that vessel drains the left arm and the legs. If so, it will resolve when the port is removed. Lymphedema is also possible when cancer blocks lymph flow, but since you are being treated for that, we'll look forward with you to that resolving as well. As buttons points out, chemo itself can sometimes cause swelling, but that is not usually restricted to one arm only. Best bet is to get any doctor on your team to refer you to a qualified lymphedema therapist. In the meantime, we're all rooting for your smooth sailing through the rest of your treatment. Please let us know what you discover, and tell us how we can help! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2011 08:48AM Binney4 wrote: lilylady, we WANT the rads to be damaging -- that's the way they kill the cancer cells. At present there's no way to do that without the collateral damage, unfortunately. But even rads to the axilla doesn't guarantee LE. And refusing the rads doesn't give you a LE pass either. So the decision is not, "Should I treat the cancer and get LE, or not treat the cancer at all." It's "Should I risk not killing off the cancer that has the potential to kill me, or should I do everything I can and gamble on a less-than-50% chance of LE?" If you add to that equation that you can see a LE specialist right away for baseline measurements and risk-reduction education, and follow a few simple guidelines for using the arm, you have an excellent chance of avoiding it all together, or keeping it easy-to-manage if you should develop it. Consideriing that any surgery puts us at risk already, it's only a matter of degree anyway. Just another way of thinking about it. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 12:33PM Binney4 wrote: Smile, you may have a special reason why your garments need to be replaced every three months, but most of us go six months between replacements. If your LE is "fussy" enough to need new garments every three months, then do check with your therapist about wearing the retired ones for any other use, since it could cause you problems if the swelling is that sensitive. If your insurance limits you to one set at a time you could try appealing, because most insurance companies will consider two sets of garments necessary so you can wash one and wear the other. Do you have a glove (or gauntlet) that you wear with the sleeve? If not, that's something else to consider. Here's the reasoning on that, from Dr. Andrea Cheville, one of our leading LE doctors: http://lymphedivas.com/lymphedema/gauntletandsleeve/ With my insurance I get two sets of garments every six months, but for me they're actually wearable for around nine months, so I have some carry-over that allows me to do the stupid laundry a little less often. (My current brand of garments holds up well, but others I've tried haven't, so maybe it depends a bit on the brand you're using too.) Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 10:27PM Binney4 wrote: Aw, tomatojuice, I hear you. Right at first it feels like a real insult. I've done the shower thing, arm straight up in the air, trying to wash one-handed. Definitely an athletic event! You did great with the dishes and dinner -- good for you! Listen, wrapping it yourself can be pretty frustrating, so sit down somewhere where the stupid bandages can't roll away from you (I use the center of my bed), allow yourself plenty of time, and crank up your sense of humor. It really does get easier, but right at first it can bring you to your knees. But it truly is possible, and you can do this! The therapist did the Manual Lymph Drainage massage, yes? And she'll be seeing you regularly for awhile? The standard course of therapy to bring the swelling completely down (or as down as it'll go for now) and encourage your lymph system to develop some alternate routes is at least a couple of weeks, and during that time you wrap all the time (except when showering and applying lotion).  THEN you get fitted for the sleeve and glove when the swelling is all reduced. The sleeve and glove can only maintain loss, they won't help you reduce it. It's the therapy and wrapping both that will reduce the swelling. Does that make sense? I will sure be thinking of you tomorrow, shower and rads and wrapping and all. Hang in there, tomatojuice! Big hugs, and chocolate wishes, Binney

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2013 06:13AM Binney4 wrote: barb, why not?! You need to protect yourself from sunburn, and if the surf is rough you have to be careful not to get your arm skinned while body surfing. But aside from that, the water's good for LE. Stand about chest deep and move your arms around in the water, swim a bit (any stroke except maybe butterfly). Breast stroke is especially nice.  The only real contraindication would be if you've recently had cellulitis, or if you're subject to repeat bouts of it. Then you want to be super careful about the cleanliness of whatever body of water you're swimming in.  Of course, like everything else with LE, we need to plan ahead. Be sure to take along your usual antiseptic wipes and bandaids in case of cuts or scrapes, sun protection, and lotion to use after rinsing off from your swim. Then don your garments whenever you're going to be out of the water for awhile. Are you planning a beach get-away? Enjoy! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 01:02AM Binney4 wrote: LindaLou, thanks! This is really interesting. This wasn't a study to find out if weight training helped leg LE, but to find out if people with leg LE from cancer surgery (prostate, gynecologic, melanoma all come to mind as possibilities for leg LE) could be expected to follow through on the weight-training protocols for the full five months. They found out they COULD follow through, but also noted that there was a surprising rate of cellulitis and that the exercise didn't help the swelling or improve their quality of life. This is in contrast to this researcher's previous (widely trumpeted) study which showed that under some restricted circumstances women with arm LE from bc treatment who did supervised weight-training didn't have a lot of trouble with infections, and by their own report their quality of life improved.  So, what's the difference? Really an interesting question. Since the sample was so small the rate of cellulitis may be just a quirk, but it's surprising to me that this intervention didn't improve their quality of life like it did for the women with bc-related LE. When I read Dr. Schmitz's initial study with bc-LE patients I assumed the quality of life boost had to do with these women getting so much positive attention and encouragement for their LE, which is otherwise so off the medical radar. Yet the patients with other kinds of cancers and LE didn't seem to get that boost from being part of the study. Their legs did get stronger, which is no surprise. But that alone didn't improve their outlook. Odd, yes? Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2011 11:19PM Binney4 wrote: Aw, Nipi, I'm so sorry! But I think there's more hope than you're currently feeling. The point of reducing the swelling through therapy is not cosmetic (though that sure helps!), but to lower your risk of infection. Lymph fluid is warm and protein-rich, so when it sits stagnant in our tissues it's like an incubator for bacteria. A well-trained and experienced lymphedema therapist will be able to get the lymph flowing out of the area, and teach you to keep it that way. After that you can cautiously consider (with your doctor's help) how you can work toward getting off the antibiotics. On the other hand, those of us with lymphedema do run a life-long risk of infection from even tiny skin cracks. So vigilance (and a prescription of antibiotics to have on hand) will always be needed. But proper self Manual Lymph Drainage massage, excellent skin care, and gentle exercise should help you improve your outcome considerably. Here's how to find a well-trained therapist near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm And here's some information about truncal (breast/chest) lymphedma: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Keep us posted! We all learn from one another's experiences, and we're sure here to help any way we can. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 08:21PM - edited Apr 23, 2008 08:23PM by Binney4 Hi, Sally, I'm really sorry you're dealing with this now. You must be so discouraged with the swelling -- and that pain is no fun either! If your sleeve is causing indents in your arm you'd be better off not wearing it until you can get some therapy for your hand and arm. Indents indicate that it's too tight now, and that'll just make the swelling worse. Until you can get help, try elevating your arm as much as possible (on the back of the couch or car seat during the day, on a pillow at night). Instead of the too-tight compression sleeve, try a long-sleeved tight sport-shirt (like bike racers wear, y'know - some are called something like Body Armor) or a leo, in a size smaller than you'd normally wear. Wear it inside out so the seams don't irritate your skin. It won't reduce the swelling, but it might keep it from progressing for now. Drink plenty of water, and avoid heat (hot tub, hot shower, dish water ). Because the stagnent lymph fluid is warm and protein-rich, bacteria love it. So use a good lotion to keep your skin from cracking and be extra careful to avoid injuring your hand or arm. You don't mention a glove, but once you have some therapy and get your swelling back in control do make sure you get a compression glove as well as sleeve, and wear them together to avoid more hand swelling. My therapist saw me four days a week for five weeks, but some women don't take that long to get their LE back in control, so it depends. Each time I saw her she did complete Manual Lymph Drainage massage and wrapped my hand and arm. Sally, I hear you on not being able to work wrapped, and I agree it's a real bear. But unfortunately wrapping is the route to regaining control. Are there accomodations you and your employer can make to keep you productively engaged while you complete the Therapy Intensive that you need? Doing it now will definitely save you considerable grief down the road, including those rotten hospital stays for IV antibiotics when everything's out of control. So please do see if there's some way to make room in your life to take good care of you -- you're worth every minute of it! Okay, I agree with Bobbie that a 60-mile trip is a bad idea. But I absolutely believe you need a well-trained LE therapist to help you get this down as quickly as possible, give you the skills and resources you need to keep it that way, and be available to you for occasional re-measuring and consults. So I hopped on over to the Therapist Locator (www.mylymphedema.com, then click on the Therapist Locator) and looked at just one of the links (for Klose School) and they have 52 LE therapists listed in Indiana. Maybe one is nearer than 60 miles to you. Vodder School, which I was also able to check for Indiana as a whole, has only three therapists in the state, but maybe one of those might be near you as well. There are two other therapist schools listed on that site that ask you to enter your zip code and they email you a list of their fully-qualified therapists in your area, so try those too and see what you come up with, and what your insurance will cover. Please take care of yourself, Sally -- this LE stuff is rotten, and you just can't let it get the best of you. Get a therapist you can team up with and you'll soon have your life back. Be well! Binney  Okay, Bobbie, how'd I do?

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 10:13AM - edited Apr 21, 2010 10:16AM by Binney4 Just want to re-post LindaLou's statement above for those of you with no visible signs of lymphedema, because IT'S IMPORTANT to know that LYMPHEDEMA CAN BE PRESENT BEFORE ANY OF THESE SIGNS APPEAR (emphasis mine). Here's what LindaLou said: Just a few comments up front to be clear. LE can be present long before there are any visible or measurable changes noted.  Early stage 0 LE may appear only as a sense of heaviness or achyness in the limb without any visible signs of swelling. There are still tissue changes occuring in the interstitial spaces of the limb, however... Treating lymphedema at the earliest stage (even before any of these indications can be seen) greatly improves the outcome and future management. Do request a referral for evaluation by a well-qualified lymphedema therapist at the earliest indication of heaviness, fullness, aching, or just plain feeling "funny." Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: May 6, 2012 05:30PM Binney4 wrote: Lisa, you most likely won't need to transition from right-handed to left except on a very temporary basis, while in treatment. The point of lymphedema therapy is to return our arms to usable condition and teach us how to keep them that way. While waiting for treatment, though, I found it easy to avoid over-using my right arm, because I was so worried about it. You can certainly use it, even while waiting -- just be careful about straining it. Most of us are careless of simple body mechanics, like holding heavier loads with both hands and keeping them close to our bodies instead of extended outward where they strain our arms more. So just being thoughtful about those things is usually enough to get you through until you can find your way to a good lymphedema therapist. If you're doing something that is repetitive (knitting, say) just plan to take a break now and then and do something else for a while, then return to it later. If in the long term you find you need to modify your right-arm use, there are loads of simple and effective ways to do that, but for now it shouldn't be an issue. And hopefully never! Hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: May 28, 2010 01:37PM Binney4 wrote: Sherry, I'm so sorry! Kind of a lot to get your head around, isn't it? Please know it gets easier. Here's a page about lymphedema garments that will show you what they look like and explain a bit about how they should fit and feel: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_lymphedema_garments.htm The garments are flexible, and you will be able to bend at all your joints. But they're tight and frankly they feel weird, especially at first. We just aren't used to being squeezed all up and down our arm and hand. You don't mention therapy, so I'm wondering if you've been seeing a therapist daily or several times a week for the past weeks? Have you learned self-Manual Lymph Drainage massage and self-wrapping with layered short-stretch bandages? The garments cannot reduce swelling, they can only help maintain the reduction that comes from intensive lymphedema therapy. If that hasn't happened for you, do ask why not before getting fitted for garments. The following information page has sections to click on about Manual Lymph Drainage and Wrapping/Bandaging that can help explain the process. www.stepup-speakout.org/treatm... Sorry you had to join us "swell" Sisters, but glad you found us. Please keep us posted! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: May 29, 2010 08:27AM Binney4 wrote: Sherry, the itching could be serious, as it can be an early symptom of infection. Do please keep a very close watch for any signs of infection: warmth to the touch, redness, increased pain or swelling, or a temp. (If there's redness, circle the area with a permanent marker so any progression can be followed.) If any of those symptoms start, go right away to critical care or the ER and be sure to tell them about the lymphedema, and that you suspect cellulitis. Sherry, I'm sure your onc's office and his PA are excellent at what the do, but most onc's don't "do" lymphedema. The suggestion that you be fitted for a sleeve and see what happens is completely backwards. Especially if there may be infection brewing, a sleeve is not a good thing. Also, I can see where the doc might want to rule out other causes for your symptoms, but those other causes (blood clot, for instance) should NOT wait two weeks to be investigated.  On a strictly practical level, if you need lymphedema therapy, then the sleeve you order on Tuesday will no longer fit once any swelling is reversed.  But even more to the point, if what you're dealing with is, in fact, lymphedema, then the quicker you get help with it the better your outcome, the lower your risk for serious systemic infection, and the easier it is to control over time. My suggestion would be first, that you go directly for emergency help at any further sign of infection. DON'T WAIT!!! And second, if your arm is stable, on Tuesday skip the fitting and find a doctor on your team who will move forward with helping you get the proper treatment. But that's JMHO. Here's a page with information about cellulitis: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Please keep us posted, Sherry. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: May 31, 2010 06:19PM Binney4 wrote: Sherry, I'm so glad to hear you're doing okay! Most insurance will cover sleeves and gloves to some extent (not Medicare, though). Mine considers it Durable Medical Equipment and covers it the same as crutches and such. But here's the problem: they will only cover so many a year (commonly, since they need to be replaced every six months at least, they'll cover one or two changes every six months). If you go out and get a sleeve and glove now, then go into lymphedema therapy, the garments won't fit after the swelling has been reduced, and your insurance won't necessarily pay for more until the six months are up. The medical professionals who evaluate and treat lymphedema are well-trained lymphedema therapists. It's their specialty. Here's information about how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm The process of lymphedema treatment is to reduce the swelling first through an intensive phase of therapy that includes Manual Lymph Drainage massage, wrapping with layered short-stretch bandages, specific exercises, and careful skin care. When the swelling is reduced to normal or plateaus, then you're fitted for garments to maintain the reduction (garments will not reduce the swelling, only maintain the loss, so wearing them now will not solve the underlying problem). Most of us need to continue to wrap our arms at night or wear special night garments that are designed to maintain reduction or even help reduce it while you're not moving around or exercising. This whole thing is very confusing to all of us, Sherry. It's a very steep learning curve that is not helped by the fact that doctors and nurses are not generally well-informed about diagnosis or treatment. I am not a medical professional and certainly wouldn't urge you to ignore your doctors and PA, but you sure might try a dialogue with them about getting a prompt evaluation from a lymphedema therapist. Let us know how it goes! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 11:50AM Binney4 wrote: Simplymarvelous, welcome! I'm so sorry for the reason you've had to join us, but glad you found us. How frustrating to be swelling and not be able to start therapy! Hang in there, though, and you'll get there! In the meantime, elevating your affected arm will help -- on the back of the couch while watching TV, on pillows at night, and whenever else you can. Drink PLENTY of water (it helps dilute the lymph fluid) and pause from time to time to take deep abdominal breaths (it stimulates the largest lymph vessel in our bodies). A light sports bra or cami that comes up high in the axilla might help provide some comfort and support without adding too much compression. A Maidenform Control It cami, for instance. I take it your doctor is treating the thrombosis, yes? Until s/he gives you the green light to go ahead with lymphedema therapy, do try to take it easy and not overdo with activity, lifting or exercise, as that can make the swelling worse. Avoid hot showers or baths, as heat can cause swelling as well. Treat any nicks, scratches, burns, cuts, insect bites or hangnails with topical antibiotics promptly, and keep your skin well moisturized with a low-PH lotion (Eucerin or Vanicream, for instance). Watch for any signs of infection (redness, rapid swelling, pain, warmth to the touch, itching, fever) and get help quickly. Stay in touch, and tell us how we can help! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2010 02:26PM Binney4 wrote: Sherry, I woke up in the middle of the night thinking about you and realized I hadn't answered your question about typing and crocheting. The fact is I use a left-hand-only keypad (had to relearn how to type!) and I've taken up the Knifty-Knitter in lieu of the crocheting I loved. But THAT'S NOT USUAL. What happened to me should not happen to any woman who develops lymphedema. I had some truncal lymphedema to start with. My doctors took a "wait-and-see" approach instead of sending me for prompt treatment. When I finally got a referral, it was to an inept therapist who had only a three-day training in lymphedema therapy (I didn't know any better). Far from reducing my truncal lymphedema, she was responsible for it's spreading to my right arm and hand. Still without adequate help, it eventually developed in my left hand and arm as well. Recent research shows that prompt treatment can prevent progression (not to mention reducing the risk of serious infection). I wish I had known that, because if it had not progressed I would not have lost the ability to type and crochet with my right hand. Yours does NOT need to get to that point. Get GOOD help SOON. And by the way, I can stil do dishes, fold clothes, and mop . Too bad! While you wait for help with your lymphedema, keep your arm elevated as much as possible (even on pillows at night), drink PLENTY of water, and do some gentle deep abdominal breathing from time to time. Anxious to hear how it went today, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 03:30PM Binney4 wrote: SeaFoobs, it's definitely NOT a must. There are only a handful of lymphologists in the U.S., and lago happened to live near one so she took a detour through that route. They normally see patients whose lymphedema is problematical for one reason or another. Evaluation and treatment of lymphedema is normally done by well-qualified lymphedema therapists, not by doctors who specialize in conditions of the lymph system. There's a project going forward in the U.S. (and separately in Canada) called the Lymphedema Framework Project that intends to draw together specialists in many medical fields to determine protocols for the best treatment of lymphedema and other lymphatic disorders. Perhaps once that happens a specialty in Lymphology will be recognized here, but currently doctors interested in lymphedema specialize in other fields.  Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 11:36AM Binney4 wrote: Bestock, do you have lymphedema already or are you just trying to reduce your risk? If you already have it, then wrapping with your short-stretch bandages is recommended. If you're trying to prevent it you can stay REALLY well hydrated, do some gentle arm stretches at intervals, do some deep abdominal breathing at intervals, and if you wear a sleeve be sure to wear some hand protection as well, either a glove or gauntlet (fingerless glove). Also, compression garments should be well fitted. Be careful about lugging suitcases or jerking them off the carousels or out of the overhead bins. I have never heard that blood clots are more common with lymphedema, though they are more common with some of our breast cancer treatments. Bon voyage! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2008 06:44PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Harley! Geesh, I am really sorry about the Neulasta fiasco . What a bummer! I wonder if you let your onc know what happened? My experience is that most nurses get into the business because they want to make things better, not worse, but they aren't well taught about LE. So if their patients (us) don't tell them what's up, they're not likely to know. We really can help the bc Sisters who come along behind us if we're willing to gently help our health professionals learn the realities. Just a thought. Any ideas, you ask? The first one that comes to mind is decking the therapist for her tree-trunk comment. Oops, sorry! Don't know how that managed to slip out! Seriously, though, I am wondering about your therapist's qualifications. Do you know if she's had the requisite 135 hours of specifically LE training from a reputable institution? Does she have at least a year's experience treating LE? And, well hey, even if she does, she sure didn't follow treatment protocol for your LE in the first place. Here's the National Lymphedema Network web site, where you can find and copy their Position Papers on Therapist training and on Therapy: www.lymphnet.org. If you like and trust this therapist (or conversely, if she's the only one within a hundred-mile radius so you're stuck with her), you can take the Therapy paper in with you and tell her you'd like her to follow that protocol. Because short of that you're going to continue to have trouble. The machine you're describing sounds like a pump, which some therapists use in conjunction with their own hands-on massage and wrapping of your entire hand and arm. (Other therapists use it INSTEAD OF hands-on massage, but that's not okay). The blockage causing your hand to swell was caused at your axilla, so even if your arm does not appear to be swelling yet, it's not just your hand that is struggling here. The entire arm needs to be treated. In fact, where the massage is concerned, your entire neck, chest, and back need to treated. Okay, one other thought (are you still with me? I do tend to run on, sorry! ) The idea in treating LE is NOT just to get the swelling down so it's tolerable, but to get as much of the fluid out of your entire hand and arm as possible and to keep it that way. Stagnant lymph fluid invites serious systemic infection, and it also continues to do internal damage that may eventually reduce hand and arm strength and range of motion. Obviously, the DoughBoy look is bad, but so is any fluid accumulation that has not been treated adequately. If your hand is still visibly bigger than the other hand, you need and deserve complete LE therapy. And besides having the therapist massage and wrap you daily for a couple of weeks or however long it takes, you should also be taught self-massage and how to wrap your own arm (the wrapping, by the way, is what you'll use at night after all the swelling is gone, to help keep it that way.) Those are your tools, and you need them. Hmmm. Guess that hit a nerve. Can't help it -- I had a short-cut therapist myself at first. I didn't know any better, of course. And she did a lot of damage. So be it. But I don't like to see it happen to anyone else. Harley, get good help -- you're worth it! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 05:46PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Doe, Here's one site reporting on the study, so that you can read the reportage and the study funding information: http://www.news-medical.net/news/20090812/Weight-training-reduces-lymphedema-symptoms-after-breast-cancer-surgery.aspx Kathryn Schmidt's study was not biased, but you're absolutely right that it will not likely be interpreted correctly. In this story you'll note that she gives specific warnings: It is recommended that women start with a slowly progressive program, supervised by a certified fitness professional, in order to learn how to do these types of exercises properly. Women with lymphedema should also wear a well-fitting compression garment during all exercise sessions. We might reasonably ask who's got that sort of LE-savvy supervision available. But aside from that, the real problem here is that this is a "myth-buster" study, and the tendency with myth-busting is to go way overboard. The myth in this case involves the fact that for many years the standard medical recommendation was to NOT exercise the arm at all and to not lift anything more than five pounds. There are still doctors telling some women that routinely, even though it's been known for years that muscle movement is the primary lymphatic pump. I've been both looking forward to Schmidt's results and dreading them, because the PR is bound to be all about "get out there and lift those weights!" and not about knowledgeable supervision, slow progression, and well-fitted garments. So I'm afraid you're right -- the next wave of serious LE misinformation will be about dashing out to the gym and going for the gusto. When really it's all about doing what's right for YOU. Hopefully a reasonable balance will soon prevail. Good topic, Doe. Thanks for bringing it up. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 04:05PM Binney4 wrote: Abby, ugh! Have to admit I relish the title of your post. Just got my new garments today and, though they all fit really well (took me a loooong time to find the company and measurements that work best for me, but now we've got it down to a science--whew!) I still find compression garments disgusting! My fitter (who is a darling) came dancing into the fitting room with all my stuff today and said, "New garments -- exciting and suspence-filled!" True, but also utterly unwanted! Don't wear the darn thing anymore, and tomorrow take it back and kindly-but-firmly demand a fix. We need compression; we don't need pain and aggravation. It's their job to get it right or eat it.  On the other hand, do I remember correctly that yours are coming from Germany and it takes them weeks to swim here? If so, consider ordering from a closer company -- say, Gottfried, which gets them to you within a week or two and if they're not right manages to fix them. Nice people to work with, professional. On the other hand, if the bigger size works, that'd be great news. The point is, it takes a couple of days (at least) to tell if new garments are going to work or not, so even a glance in the mirror isn't enough to assure you of a good fit (although that sure does seem like a basic start!) Next time, only wear new garments an hour or two before removing them. If all's well, move up to three hours the next time. Then maybe six. But DO NOT wear them for a whole day straight right off the bat, for reasons you now understand all too clearly.  :-(   Night garment sizes don't necessarily coordinate with day garment sizes, sadly enough. At all. But night garments are a different sort of compression altogether and are less likely to cause you grief (just my experience!)  Still, best to wear them for a few hours in the evening the first day, working up to a whole night with them. And of course you also have to work out any possible skin reaction issues too, so go real easy. There are night garments that are adjustable -- Circaid is a nice one. You might want to look into that, since it gives you the freedom to adjust and readjust as needed.  I'm so sorry that this is such an ordeal. Trial by compression! It DOES get better with time and experience. Hang in there! Hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2011 07:30PM Binney4 wrote: Crystal, there are lots of options for breast/chest compression. I need compression at night but wear a night vest by Solaris or JoviPak (I've used both). They're quilted with directional stitching to help steer the lymph fluid out of the area, and they're stuffed with chipped foam (like a swell spot). They're reasonably comfortable and last about two years. I'm not sure a tank would be real comfortable. Mine tend to end up wrapped around my waist even during the day, so I don't know how well they'd stay in place at night. On the other hand, if by "compression tank" you mean something like an Underarmor tank top, that probably wouldn't shift and bind as you flop around in your sleep. But how you'd keep Swell Spots in place with a tank I don't know. JoviPak has a couple of new "swell spots" that are for armpit swelling. One of them might work for you, but again, I don't know how you'd keep it in place. Did they say anything about that? Maybe ask about ordering night garments -- a sleeve/glove and vest. Anyplace you'd get lymphedema garments from would have to be a "specialty store," but if this one can't fit you for a night garment to address your needs, you need to find one that can. My insurance only covered one place, and it didn't handle all the LE products I needed, so I had to get their approval for a place that did. Took some time and a lot of stupid phone calls, but I now have a great fitter who knows her business. Keep us posted, and please tell us how we can help. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2014 09:58AM Binney4 wrote: Carol, I hear you. Or maybe, since he travels widely, Rockson has actually met and discussed these things with Dr. Vignes, the author of the French study citing the results of these surgeries that are so often swept under the carpet when doctors are advertising for patients: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23305787 Since many insurance companies have now caved and are paying for unproven LE surgeries, we're sure seeing a lot more advertising out there. I think what has alarmed me the most is my recent discovery that there is no requirement on the part of the surgeons doing these surgeries to demonstrate either the effectiveness or safety of the procedures, and there's no one looking for the long-term complications, much less making them known. It's all based on an agreement between patient and surgeon, so when I see doctors advertising it sure makes me worry about the protections that are not in place to assure full disclosure of the risks and potential. There are not even any standards regarding who is most likely to benefit from the surgeries and who might be most likely to be further damaged by it. It's all up to each individual surgeon to decide for himself--based on no research and sketchy lymphatic science (and let's face it--a hefty surgery fee). I'd like to think the women undergoing these surgeries are brave pioneers making a cure possible for all of us, but without the research backing up the work, it's a lot more about their vulnerability than anything else.  FIRST transparency and full disclosure, not to mention actual on-going research of a high quality. THEN we can talk about who are the brave ones willing to give it a try. As it is, we're all at risk, hoping against hope for relief and a cure, and being offered ads instead of studies.  WE NEED TO STAND UP TOGETHER AND SHOUT WITH ONE VOICE FOR RESPONSIBLE RESEARCH AND REPORTING!!! Binney, sick of seeing the damage happening to women I care about and not being able to do anything about it

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 07:29AM Binney4 wrote: Good morning, all! Shari, want to add my best wishes for a great day on the new job. Distraction is right! There's nothing quite as distracting as that whirl of first-day-at-work. Enjoy! I wanted to answer your lymphedema question, and give you some resources for finding out more. The risk of lymphedema is for life, so do protect your left arm from blood pressures, injections, IVs and blood draw always. There are medic-alert bracelets available to alert the medical folks and remind yourself about it as well! They're available on-line from both the American Cancer Society at www.tlcdirect.org, or from the National Lymphedema Network at www.lymphnet.org. Also available on the National Lymphedema Network site are their Position Papers on Risk Reduction, Air Travel, and Exercise. All of those are well worth reading and following as a way to protect yourself from this distressing and disabling condition. Those of us with lymphedema in the bc.org community meet on the "Lymphedema After Surgery" board just a couple of boards down from this one. The women there would be happy to answer any questions you have, as we're all anxious to help our BC Sisters avoid this nasty sidetrip of the BC journey. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2009 11:41AM - edited Oct 10, 2009 11:47AM by Binney4 Oooh, Virginia, great question! This is a favorite subject of mine, because I believe we bc Sisters are in a position to bring awareness not only to our bc-related lymphedema, but to those with other forms of lymphedema as well -- all of whom have an even harder time than we do getting diagnosis and treatment. As Otter explained, there's "Primary lymphedema," which can be either hereditary (which means the genes that control it are passed down from generation to generation -- it's usually present at birth or develops in early childhood), or congenital (which means some damage occurs to the lymph system in utero -- it commonly shows up either at puberty or in middle age). Hereditary LE is of course very hard on moms and dads, who have to massage, wrap, and struggle garments onto busy little bodies -- and the little ones have to go without garments for periods of time throughout the day or their sensory systems fail to develop properly. Congenital LE that shows up at puberty can do tremendous emotional damage, especially because it's rarely diagnosed properly and young teens are told they need to diet because they're "fat." Many, many people with congenital LE go for a decade or more without a proper diagnosis, during which time they can develop incredible fibrosis, infections, and skin that weeps caustic lymph fluid. Growing up in this manner wreaks havoc, to say the least. Our own brand of LE is Secondary, which as Otter points out is "secondary" to other causes. It includes the largest group of lymphers in the world -- those infected with filariasis. They are generally in developing (tropical) countries and have limited medical resources, so they become completely disabled by their disease, unable to work at their subsistence-level jobs. The result is, of course, devastating -- their circumstances make our LE look like a romp in the park. A 2008 study of Dominican women with this brand of LE has a title that tells it all: "Can It Be That God Does Not Remember Me?": A Qualitative Study on the Psychological Distress, Suffering and Coping of Dominican Women With Chronic Filarial Lymphedema. Other causes of Secondary LE include LE from trauma (auto accidents, orthopedic surgeries, contact sports, etc.) and other kinds of cancer surgeries: melanoma, head and neck cancers, prostate cancer, and all the gynecologic cancers. These folks have a MUCH harder time getting a diagnosis than we do, since the medical community is even more dismissive of their risk than of ours. All of this just to say that WE CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE for EVERY form of lymphedema if we are willing to keep these others in mind as we advocate for our own needs. There's another thread here about the Women's Health & Cancer Treatment Act that forces insurance to help out those of us treated for bc. Our sisters with ovarian cancer have no such protection, and primary lymphers have even less than that. Nearly all the LE research being done concerns upper extremity LE in women treated for bc, leaving the moms and dads of the wee ones with little or no new information to help them cope. Even the study we've been discussing here has no application at all to any other lymphers than those of us with bc. Believe it or not, we're the lucky ones. So...that was my rallying cry. We've got our work cut out for us, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2007 11:21AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, sharebear, I don't have a for-sure answer to that, but I sure can understand your concern. Just guessing, but I'd say it's not a problem, since I know some therapists who use very wide ACE bandages for the chest/breast. In fact some of the LE supply places sell them for that purpose. You don't want to put something like that around your arm because it interferes with the lymph pathways out of your hand and arm. But your chest is another matter because the lymph can go up to the neck and axilla nodes, or down toward the groin. JMHO, anyway. To be safe, do pay attention to any irritation in the axilla area, and any tingling or heaviness in your arm. Well, and of course any swelling in your arm or hand. Let your PS know at once if you have problems like that. But otherwise I'd say it's worth it to get the benefits you're hoping for from it. Keep us posted and let us know how it works out. Hope you get real healing and relief, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 07:01PM Binney4 wrote: What an interesting discussion! Lisa-e, I hear you on wanting better evidence for every aspect of lymphedema. Which part(s) of Complete Decongestive Therapy are essential and which may not be? How can we predict who's most likely to develop lymphedema following bc treatment and who isn't? Why didn't Pitanga develop lymphedema with 22 nodes removed, and why did I with only one node removed? Why do some of us have more trouble than others controlling their lymphedema? The list of urgent questions is endless (and the research is still in its infancy!) But the issue here is Susan Love's "analysis" of Schmitz's study. Perhaps the fact that she is not in practice explains why she doesn't realize that the number of weight trainers in this country who know anything about lymphedema is far less than even the number of qualified lymphedema therapists. She suggests we can go to our YMCA and get help like that the women in the study received, but that's ludicrous. In the real world, even finding an adequate lymphedema therapist is often a real trick. But how many patients know that? And for that matter, how many doctors know that? There are a number of other such "unrealities" in Schmitz's study, but that doesn't diminish the lovely news that for some women with lymphedema, and given expert garment-fitting and oversight, weightlifting may not be any more hazardous to their condition than not weightlifting, and it'll for sure make them stronger. My question for nsykes, though, is, if Dr. Love is so receptive and responsive and available, how come she hasn't answered my email to the address posted? It was not angry or argumentative, and it offered both a question and a suggestion for tracking down the information she's missing from professionals in the lymphedema field. Of course Dr. Love is busy, but then, so am I. And I consider that the cavalier manner in which Dr. Love's article encouraged women to question current risk reduction precautions (based on zero research) is going to cause some women to develop or exacerbate lymphedema. If that happens to even one, it's one too many. That is not a small thing. The article needs to be removed promptly, period. Then again, that assumes that women are listening to Dr. Love, and perhaps they aren't. In this case, that's a good thing. Lisa-e, are you familiar with the Lymphatic Research Foundation? Excellent organization, lots going on. They're here: http://lymphaticresearch.org If you visit their site you can sign up for their newsletter, which is helpful for keeping up with progress in finding some of the answers we need. And Lisa/Pitanga, there is some very interesting research being done in the UK by Stanton, et. al. that suggests there are some physiologic considerations that may lead to one woman developing lymphedema while another does not. If we knew that, and if we could then develop a pre-test to determine which of us are physiologically prone to lymphedema, there might be a better basis for suggesting targeted risk reduction practices. That's one study direction I'm really anxious to see developed. Until then, though, risk reduction has to be generalized to everyone who's potentially at risk, and naturally there will be some for whom it's overkill. As for your flying, garments MUST be well-fitted, and anyone who wears a sleeve should also have a hand garment (for the reason you explained). Again, in the real world, finding a garment fitter who knows how to fit sleeves and gloves properly is often a real dilemma.  I am so very sorry about the mets, and especially that the research to guarantee a cure for that is still to be done. That's certainly on a whole 'nother scale of importance! Be well, Lisa! Hugs all around -- you too, nsykes. Do please carry our message to Dr. Love -- we'd be gratified if she'd take seriously the experience of those of us who deal with this condition. Thanks! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 10:20AM Binney4 wrote: Lisa-e, I'm not worried that you were going to take Dr. Love's comments as license to stop taking the risk precautions you're taking, because you know what they are and you understand your risk, and you're smart and highly motivated, too. Fortunately we'll know that when we see some careful revisions to her article. I'm really hopeful on this one -- an influential former doctor taking up an informed and heartfelt cry for adequate LE research, based on a clear-eyed understanding of what the stakes are for all of us, would be a real encouragement. Hopefully she's entirely sincere about learning to be that person! Binney
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2009 01:48PM Binney4 wrote: Goodness, this just gets more interesting by the hour! And to think we have Susan Love to thank for launching this discussion!  Happy29, I wanted to acknowledge your comments about the usefulness of Susan Love's book to you along your breast cancer journey. Your experience has certainly been shared by many, many women, and I don't think anyone here is discounting that. I'm really glad you found her book at the time you needed it. The issue here, though, is not whether Dr. Love is an acknowledged voice of breast cancer treatment and cure, but whether her opinions about lymphedema are responsibly expressed -- and the discussion has even moved on to the question of whether she has any real expertise in lymphology. Even if she were currently a practicing surgeon there's certainly no guarantee she would be a reliable resource regarding lymphedema, because it is definitely the abandoned step-child of oncology, cancer surgery, and the medical field in general. THAT, at least, has been shown to be the case by research conducted by Stanley Rockson at Stanford. So...no particular reflection on Dr. Love if she is not savvy about lymphedema. In fact she unfortunately has plenty of company! The rest of this discussion veers in a lot of different directions, much of it "apples and oranges." Prevention is different from treating a diagnosed condition. Pre-clinical lymphedema is different from advanced lymphedema. Research-based evidence is different from anecdotal experience. Well-fitted garments are vastly different from poorly-fitted ones, just as short-stretch bandaging done by a well-trained therapist or patient is vastly different from any application of an ACE bandage to an arm either with lymphedema or at risk for it. And a careless statement by someone who is not likely to be listened to anyway is a whole lot less of a problem than the same statement when it's made by someone with influence in the breast cancer community. Whew! Anyhow, for what it's worth, all we currently have (or are likely to have in the next many years or forever) is the advise of experts in lymphology -- all of whom agree, by the way, that poorly-fitted garments are not a good thing for anyone. Beyond that THEY all agree exercise is good for people with lymphedema, and that it should be done very gradually and preferably with expert supervision. The only ones who don't agree with that are lymphedema-uninformed doctors who didn't learn it straight in med school and haven't looked into it since -- a category that sadly includes some of the best breast surgeons and oncologists, in some of our finest cancer treatment centers. That is not a matter of settling controversies, but of education of medical personnel -- a very different matter than encouraging women to ignore risk reduction practices. Dr. Love's rather cavalier treatment of the subject (and let's give her due credit for treating the subject at all!) illustrates some of the worst fears of those of us with lymphedema: a dismissal of our condition and its treatment by the doctors who are supposed to be overseeing our care. Few of us fit the criteria of the women in this study, so this cheerful news of "myth-bashing" truly does not apply to us. We will not ever be able to lift weights (or even our children/grandchildren) with impunity again. Kathryn Schmitz's study does nothing to change our reality, but it does have the potential to make our doctors even less understanding of our very real limitations. Love's article careens back and forth between ideas of prevention and of the possibility that for some women with lymphedema weight lifting may not be worse than not weight lifting. That is unfortunately typical of the broad generalizations OUR doctors are likely to draw about OUR lymphedema. This was not in any way a study about risk (that one is still to come). It's about one specific form of exercise for a very narrow range of women who already have lymphedema, and who are not in any form of cancer treatment at the time and are attended by expert therapists, trainers and garment fitters. It's good news, but it's sure not big news. Not nearly as big as Dr. Love implies, nor as big as so many women at risk for lymphedema would like to make it. In fact, it doesn't have a single thing to do with women at risk for lymphedema, and certainly not with blood pressure cuffs or IVs. Dr. Love's conjuction of those topics is truly unfortunate, and very probably, for some of us at least, dangerous. Sorry this is so long, but I wanted to make sure Happy29 was not slighted as the discussion rolled on. As your Sisters in this crazy bc diagnosis, Happy, we're really glad for this resource that strengthened your hand. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 08:22AM Binney4 wrote: I say yes, too, just because there's only so much we should give up of our lives. And definitely yes to the sleeve and gauntlet, keeping in mind that when they're wet they might be tighter, so do be aware and don't let them constrict at the wrist or top of sleeve.  And yes to staying well hydrated. Hard to do when you're of on an adventure and concentrating on other things, so make it a priority. The difference between Debbie's kayaking and your white water trip is probably conditioning. And possibly jerking. A steady and well-practiced paddling is different from holding on for dear life and having your arm jerked. So two things: strengthen your arm as much as comfortably possible (no strain!), and use your unaffected arm in preference to your at-risk arm for hanging on. In any case don't use the at-risk arm alone at all. Traveling itself means lugging gear too, so be mindful of that arm and lift carefully. Other than that, go out there and make beautiful memories! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2011 03:25PM - edited Jul 26, 2011 03:26PM by Binney4 Alicia, if the fit is not good, compression garments can do more harm than good (like a blood pressure cuff, they could be too tight in some places and cause a constriction of the lymph vessels, for instance). When you have new compression garments you wear them the first time no more than an hour, increasing the time gradually until you know how they affect you over time. Since you don't mention a glove or gauntlet (fingerless glove), I just wanted to comment also that wearing a sleeve without hand protection can cause any swelling to become trapped in the hand, where it's harder to deal with. Here's a brief article that explains why: http://lymphedivas.com/lymphedema/gauntletandsleeve/ Hopefully the remainder of the summer will be less of a heat problem than these last couple of weeks have been. Stay cool! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2007 03:19PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, DianeMarie, Yow! That really is a dilemma. I've had problems with prostheses too because of lymphedema (LE), but it's chest LE and I couldn't find a bra I could wear over my chest compression vest. It sure is frustrating, especially after you've already gone to the trouble of being carefully fitted for a bra and prosthesis, and then...stupid LE! But I'm willing to bet there's a reasonable solution. Do you have a good and experienced bra/prosthesis fitter? There are styles out there that have very wide straps to help distribute the weight and keep it from cutting into your shoulder, and wide, supportive sides and bottom band to spread out the job of supporting and take some of the stress off the shoulder. These might also stay in place better, and perhaps make it possible for you to switch to a lighter-weight prosthesis (such as whipped silicone).  If you're going to go without your prosthesis all day at home you're still going to have the problem of counterbalancing the weight of the single breast. I had the same situation and developed shoulder and posture problems. I wish someone had warned me to see a PT for help with strengthening exercises to avoid those problems. It takes some hard work to be a single-breasted woman warrior! (I eventually had to have a second mastectomy because of repeated surgical biopsies, which at least solved the unbalance problem!) The Bellisse bra (www.bellisse.com) is made for breast/chest LE, but it might provide you with the support you need, and it doesn't shift. (However it does tend to mash the breasts together into a sort of "uni-boob." Sigh!) Also, you could check out the Breast Free web site for other resource ideas (http://breastfree.org). Has your LE therapist suggested any solutions?  Please keep us posted. I sure hope you can find a quick and comfortable way to handle this. Hugs! Binney
Posts.Title: Left Breast Prosthesis Dilemma and LE DianeMarieWA Binney4

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 06:01PM Binney4 wrote: Alicia, the business of heat triggering lymphedema has to do with raising your core body temperature. So you want to plan as many ways as possible to stay cooler. Stay really well hydrated -- don't wait until you feel thirsty. Avoid alcohol and caffeinated beverages, which tend to dehydrate. Consider using one of those cooling bandanas on your neck; keep your wrists cool by rubbing them with your cup of ice water. Wear a sun hat (or carry a pretty parasol); stay out of the direct sun; duck indoors to the AC often. Look for any outdoor fans or misters and stick close to them. Pay attention to how you're feeling and if necessary call it quits early. In some ways it's easier for those of us who already have lymphedema to make these judgements -- we've already dealt with the diagnosis after all, and we know how to get things back in control if we push it too far. We can also judge how much effort we're willing to make to do that, and what it's worth to us to have to spend a few days (or more) regaining control. But trying to avoid LE when you don't already have it is a one-shot deal, where if you push it too far you could go from no diagnosis to LE-for-life. So let me remind you that no matter what they do, MOST women who have been treated for breast cancer will never develop it. And that if you are unlucky enough to be one of those who do, we're here for you. Go, enjoy, be wise! Binney
Posts.Title: Can very hot weather bring on lymphedema? Alicia moogie

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 04:19PM Binney4 wrote: Vikki, the quadrant of her body that has been treated for cancer (surgery and/or radiation) is all at risk for lymphedema (side, back and chest as well as arm and hand), and any compromise of the skin integrity is a problem. It's not just the infection risk (since after treatment there may be excess lymph fluid in the tissues even without visible swelling, and lymph fluid is very bacteria-friendly), but the fact that our bodies react to the insult of needles or other pain-producing trauma by sending lots of lymph fluid to the site -- which can overwhelm an already compromised lymph system. Other sites than that quadrant are safer, at least from the standpoint of lymphedema. Trust me, she doesn't want to deal with lymphedema. Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 09:56AM Binney4 wrote: Actually, MOTC, that's an irresistable invitation, and one we all need to take seriously. So how about if we all pitch in with suggestions for: 1. this study she's proposing that will include LE development as an add-on What questions should she be asking? 2. the lymphedema section of her breast book. What do you wish you'd known about LE before you even started bc treatment? How did you get a diagnosis, find a therapist, get well-fitting garments? I have some thoughts about the study, starting with the fact that from her comments it appears she's considering LE development as an afterthought. Very little will be learned that way, even from a study on a million women. There are some built-in problems, like, how will LE be measured and quantified -- circumferencial measurements, volume measurement, water displacement, lymphoscintigrapry, perometry, bioimpedance, self-reporting? Who will diagnose it -- doctors (surgeons, oncs, rad oncs, PCPs) who have real training in LE, well-qualified LE therapists, the patients themselves? What about breast/chest (truncal) LE, which goes undiagnosed sometimes for years? Will they include measures of skin breakdown, infection rates, days of work lost, quality of life? And apparently this is not just a study of people with breast cancer, so what about lower extremity LE from prostate and gynecologic cancers, or from melanoma. Head and neck cancers? What about pre-clinical LE (which some LE experts are now beginning to believe describes every woman and man treated for breast cancer)? If they're looking at the effectiveness of various risk reduction techniques, how will they know how compliant the individuals are, who moved a whole case of books last weekend, or who developed arm swelling only after their 15th flight? If women are wearing arm protection for exercise or travel, are they protecting their hand as well? Who is judging the proper fit of the garments, or the proper use of them, or how heavy their suitcase was and how many times they jerked it off a luggage carousel? How much water they drank, how religious they were about keeping their arm exercised? How fit they were before the the LE, how much they weighed and how rapidly they gained weight? Whether any doctor on their team was even willing to diagnose it?  What other medical conditions they have, previous surgeries or trama to the area, the drugs they're currently taking, what their treatment plan was, how their surgeon went about the surgery, what they did (or did not do) with their arms (or legs) in the days and weeks immediately following surgery? Seroma and hematomy development, post-op infections, Axillary Web Syndrome? Any study that fails to take in all the suspected factors will only give us more of the self-experimentation that Lisa-e so rightly finds frustrating (not to mention the dangerous oversimplifications that have resulted even from Dr. Schmitz's much more focused study).   And as far as revising the book is concerned, I'd strongly encourage Dr. Love to attend the next National Lymphedema Network international conference for medical professionals, which is less than a year away. The opportunity to mingle with and learn from researchers and lymphologists from all over the world will provide her with the foundation she needs to write an accurate, up-to-date and safe section on LE. Other suggestions, gals? You're all a wealth of information on this very important subject, and a terrific resource for Dr. Love to draw on. Thanks, hugs, Binny

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2009 11:19PM Binney4 wrote: MOTC, that's a good question, and Linda put the problem well. I too have gotten emails today telling me all will be well if I just go out and lift weights. Personally, I can't even begin to tell you how incredibly frustrating that is to me. As a person with lymphedema, I am already humiliated by the lack of understanding of well-meaning friends and relatives, and this interpretation -- which is certainly and without question what's coming across in the media -- is not making my life any more dignified. In fact, it's humiliating. But that's just me. The implications are actually much broader. Rockysmom has already hinted here at the possible job-related problems that this particular media blitz is likely to produce. If she can lift weights, then doggone it she should be pulling "her share" at work -- no more of that whimpering about what you can't lift! And how far will this misunderstanding of LE work limitations go? MANY women lose their careers with this diagnosis. Think musicians whose arms swell when they play their violin. Artists who can no longer build clay pottery. Nurses who can't wear their gloves at work in sterile conditions. Women who do fine motor tasks not possible with compression gloves. And on and on. These women often need to apply for disability, which is ALWAYS a battle with LE because nobody's ever heard of it, or they think it's "just a fat arm." How will this perception affect their disability applications and appeals? If you can lift weights with impunity then, woman, you're not disabled! Then there are the surgeons and oncologists and PCPs. They've "known" all along that we swell gals are making a mountain out of a molehill, and now they have "proof." Just get out there and quit being a couch potato and your LE problems will disappear! Or they've pooh-poohed our insistence on taking precautions with our arms and rolled their eyes when we try to tell them all our bc Sisters need LE education for risk reduction. What the articles are saying is that, just like past major medical misunderstandings, risk reduction for LE is senseless. If we get out there and lift those puppies we'll all feel lots better and quit our fussing. I've been cruising the bc boards today, and I'm truly shaken by what I'm seeing. One woman says she's not sure how to start exercising again after bc surgery because she's afraid of LE, and another responds that she just read today that if you lift weights you won't get LE, so just go ahead to the gym and get your life back. That kind of post is popping up all over the web. There is no sense in my pointing out that the article refers to women with "stable LE" (whatever that may be) wearing expertly fitted compression garments and being supervised by a fleet of fully trained LE therapists and several of the few trainers in the country who have been made aware of LE, because doggone if they didn't read it in the news that weight training will keep them from getting LE. MOTC, none of that is what the study was supposed to be about. But all of that is what is happening already because of it. All of us already knew we could exercise, using careful attention to our arms, help from a LE therapist, compression of one kind or another. So this study has "liberated" no one. What it's done is expose many more women to the nasty surprise of new LE because they were once again misinformed about their risk. It's made our fight to get safe medical care far harder than it already was. And it's set our advocacy efforts for disability coverage back at a time when we sure as heck didn't need any more barriers. I have to add that what Linda said a few posts up is SOOOO true. To be accurate and careful the reporting should add that women with LE feel a whole lot better when someone is taking the time to encourage, direct and talk to them, to check up on them when they don't show up or follow through, to simply acknowledge that, indeed, they do have a serious chronic condition that is sapping the life out of them and that no one -- friends, relatives, employers, doctors -- is even acknowledging. At the NLN conference last year there were several researchers who commented on the effect Linda mentions -- that when this unacknowledged and unsupported LE population experiences the support and sense of recognition that a LE study involves, that alone positively influences their perceptions of their symptoms and their quality of life. The full study does not list that as one of the possible problems with their study outcome, but it's obvious to anyone who has felt the sense of abandonment that LE creates in us. So, yeah there's a kernel, at least, of good news in here. But it's very small, and it's not even new since we all knew it anyway. What concerns me is the bc Sisters who are being misled, and the life-long consequences for them -- and the sense that even the researchers, in their eagerness to be seen as liberating myth-busters, are throwing us under the bus. I hope that helps, MOTC. Basically we all need to understand the issues here, because our job of increasing accurate LE awareness and educating new bc patients about their choices for risk reduction practices just got a little bit harder. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 08:29AM Binney4 wrote: LOL! Please feel free, Sharon. MOTC, not sure exchanging one piece of dangerous misinformation for another is particularly good -- wish to goodness they'd care enough to get it right! That's where we all come in, having that conversation with our doctors, getting their attention to it even if they're in their usual hurry to get on to the next patient. Gotta find a way to get the word out to them! But, hey, MOTC! The good news is there IS some research in process regarding prevention. Mostly they're looking at prevention by educating patients early -- in other words, essentially risk reduction once the damage has been done. What we need is for surgeons and rads oncs to begin looking at measures to prevent the damage in the first place. Did you notice on the new post my "MomsDaughter" on the EnCourage thread <community.breastcancer.org/for... that the surgeons were aware that using a blade for surgery does less damage to the lymphatics? Several years ago, when I was first diagnosed, I read a small study in a surgery journal about that being the case, but I haven't seen it mentioned since. So there are things that could be researched that might lead to preventing the damage in the first place, and that's not being done to my knowledge. We all need to use every opportunity to increase awareness of LE at every level.  Okay, climbing down off my soapbox! Keep getting carried away... Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 01:47PM Binney4 wrote: Oh, Harley, how discouraging! You're sure right -- the stupid glove is supposed to KEEP it from swelling, not make it worse. Good grief! And I agree, if it's doing that, for goodness sake don't wear it again. But there are still a LOT of things to try that'll help bring the swelling down. For starters, it's possible the glove is a bad fit, or if it was a good fit at first it's a bad fit now. I had the same problem, though, of my hand and fingers swelling, and the fit was great. But it turned out the fabric was wrong. (Who knew?)  Besides compression, there's another factor involved in making our garments, called "containment," and most LE garment fabrics have way more of the containment factor than my vasculature can deal with. This is a rare problem, but not unheard of, for sure. I have to have my garments made of a fabric normally used for infants and the very old (sigh!). The point is, the compression is the same, but the "containment" is much lighter. I don't pretend to understand that, but being able to say it gets me the right fabric every time! And of course the opposite may be true: you may need MORE containment, and there are garments for that too. Same compression, more containment. Elvarex is one, and Juzo makes another but I don't remember what it's called. If you need to know I can find out (or hopefully somebody'll come along and tell us both) Anyway, another hand-swelling problem some of the gals here have had seems to be sheer stubbornness on the part of the lymph system. Either a part of the hand or the whole hand just won't reduce. Therapists get vigorous about using chip bags and with a bit of trial and error they come up with a workable solution so the women haven't been reduced to wrapping for the rest of their lives. (Aaaaaugh! ) When an area around the base of my thumb wouldn't reduce, my therapist got creative with the wrapping and got the swelling down in a few days, after which it's been much easier to keep that way. Harley, there's no way any of us can go on doing the massage or the exercises day after day when it isn't even working, so for goodness sake don't beat yourself up over that! The point of all these idiot therapies is to reduce the swelling, when they don't accomplish that there's nothing to be gained from doing them. Please go easy on you, because the LE is bad enough without having to feel defeated and guilty. But hopefully we can at least encourage you that there ARE ways to get the swelling down, and if you and your therapist can work together to find them, then it WILL be worth doing whatever steps you need to in order to have your own hand back. (If your onc nurse tells you different come back and let's talk about it.) As Sharon said, Harley, we hear ya'! Hang in there, and let us know how we can help. Sharon, congrats on a drama-free night! May there be many, many more! Hug all around! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2009 06:29PM Binney4 wrote: MOTC, how about just going in to Urgent Care so you can get the stress off your head? Cellulitis usually looks red or splotchy or streaky, usually warm to the touch, sometimes itchy, eventually becomes quite painful. If you anticipate a wait at Urgent Care, take a good book along. If it's not an infection you go home relieved, and if it is you start an antibiotic before it gets out of hand so the rest of the week is a breeze instead of a nightmare. If, on the other hand, you decide not to do that, at least take a permanent marker and draw around the redddened area so you can judge whether it grows or shrinks overnight. If you wake up in the night with pain, go get help. Cellulitis spreads quickly and it's nasty. Nipping it in the bud is not only less stressful, but it makes lymphedema control easier too. Here's a page about lymphedema emergencies: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm I hear you on sending your son off for the first time. They have no clue how much we stress over their adventures! Prayers for peace for you and a fabulous experience for him, Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 08:32AM Binney4 wrote: Sunflower, Lago's experience is unique -- mostly surgeons aren't responsive to lymphedma at all. You can get a referral from any member of your healthcare team, even your PCP, but between your surgeon and your oncologist, my bets are all on the oncologist. Here's a page about how to find a well-trained lymphedema therapist near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Lymphedema is more than a bothersome arm -- it's staged, just like breast cancer is, and without treatment it will progress. The progression isn't necessarily in the size of the arm, which may not change much or may go up and down. Progression actually involves what's going on INSIDE your arm: hardening of the tissues, inflammation, fat deposition, skin changes, and very high risk for cellulitis (a fast-spreading infection).  Prompt treatment is also key to ease of managing the lymphedema over time, so please don't be put off by any doctor who wants to take a "wait-and-see" approach. The medical professionals who evaluate and treat lymphedema are the well-trained lymphedema therapists, not our surgeons or oncologists, so you want to get in for evaluation as soon as possible. I'm so sorry you're dealing with this -- one thing after another! But with good care you'll soon be on top of it and moving forward again. Please do keep us posted. Gentle hugs, Binney

There are some pictures on this StepUp-SpeakOut page that show what kinds of things you might look for: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Truncal lymphedema is often painful, sometimes very painful, so that's another possible sign. Indentations that remain in the breast or side after removing a bra can be an indication. Hope some of that helps! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 03:35PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Sheila, and welcome to BreastCancer.org. Our lymph nodes are part of our immune system, and when they're hard at work they sometimes swell noticeably. Usually that swelling just means they're doing their job, fighting some infection or other that may have entered your body. An injury, any sickness--whatever. Swollen lymph nodes aren't related to lymphedema, though, and are not an indication of it. Check in with your doctor just to be on top of it. Not likely to be a serious problem, but once we've had bc every body change can feel really ominous.  Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2011 03:38PM - edited Oct 5, 2011 03:42PM by Binney4 Babs, there is a movement within the medical community to discredit lymphedema risk reduction practices. It's not new, but it seems to be spreading, and it is not based on any actual evidence at all, just on the convenience of health-care providers. So it's certainly your call, but it's worth looking into yourself before you decide how much risk is too much for you individually. I, too, believed what my doctors told me, and I developed lymphedema in my left arm and chest (only one node removed) after a blood pressure on that arm, more than three years after my surgery. If it happens to you, the risk is 100%, and it's for the rest of your life. Here's an information page addressed specifically to doctors and nurses about this issue of mythologizing the reality of our risk: www.stepup-speakout.org/essent... You might want to copy it off and discuss it with them at your next appointment. Stay well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 10:15AM Binney4 wrote: Barbara, unfortunately nobody knows what the percentages are from a research standpoint because it's not a subject that's ever been studied. Some people who have had bilateral surgeries and want to continue to use their arm instead of a foot or leg, offer the arm with the fewest number of nodes removed; others offer their non-dominant arm (since lymphedema in a dominant arm is harder to deal with and more limiting). It's a tough choice. The current thinking by researchers in the field is that about 40% of women who have been treated for breast cancer will eventually develop lymphedema. (Because more women are surviving breast cancer these days, more of them are developing lymphedema, which can show up at any time post-treatment, even years later.) So I guess what I'm saying is, it's your call. With bilateral surgeries both arms are at risk, the one with more nodes removed probably at more risk (though other factors affect risk as well). You can insist on their not using either arm, but they're likely to roll their eyes and tell you it's not a "real" risk. But in fact the risk is yours, not theirs. Best suggestion available is to ask any doctor on your team for a referral to a well-trained lymphedema therapist for base-line arm measurements for future reference, personalized risk-reduction assessment, and possibly fitting for compression sleeves and gloves to use prophylactically for travel, exercise, or any unusual activities. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm No easy answers to this one! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2011 10:17AM Binney4 wrote: Hmmmm. Comes out to 13% for my left arm, 12% for my right. Guess I'm just really good at going for the low percentages. Maybe I should take up gambling... Seriously, this doesn't take into account anything but "external" issues -- the things that happen to us in treating our bc. But a lot of very serious researchers consider that there may be an inborn component to our risk -- a lymph system with only a limited capacity, say. No way this chart can take that into account. It would be interesting if he included things like whether we're prone to our hands swelling when we hike even before any surgery. In other words, for this to be more accurate we need to know what indicators there may be that our lymph system is less than optimal to begin with. This is also not taking into account previous trauma to the area, and we know from other situations (like LE in football players) that repeated trauma may play a part in developing LE. There are also other pre-conditions that have been implicated: diabetes, other vascular problems -- that are not touched on in this survey model So, interesting, and a promising start. But if anyone tried to use this as a way of steering bc patients into special risk-reduction practices, I'd still be in the "no-worries" group, and we know that's not the case! Take-home thought, at least from my point of view: risk reduction education and referrals should be standard procedure for ALL bc patients, starting from before surgery even happens. Dream on! Binney
