Posts.Content: Binney4 wrote: Hi! Here's an article about an opportunity to help out with LE research: med.stanford.edu/news_releases...  The whole article is worth reading, but here are a few quick quotes that were interesting to me (comments in parentheses are mine): "There is no cure yet for lymphedema, a chronic condition that affects 10 million people in the United States and 135 million worldwide." (That's 10 million people in the U.S. alone who are flying under the medical radar. Yikes!)  "In an ongoing effort to find a cure for this disorder, a team of researchers led by Stanley Rockson, MD, associate professor of cardiovascular medicine at Stanford University School of Medicine, will study the effectiveness of anti-inflammatory drugs on lymphedema patients. The goal is to eventually find a cure for people who struggle every day to live with this often misdiagnosed and misunderstood disorder." (He's actually talking CURE!!!)  "We're searching for medical treatments as opposed to just physical treatments," said Rockson, one of the leading experts on lymphatics. "The physical treatments are like the iron lung for polio. They work, but this is certainly no way to live." (Do I hear an 'Amen!'?)  "For the new study, Rockson's team is looking for lymphedema patients, primarily breast cancer survivors, with swelling in the arm."  "Lymphatic biology may be one of the missing links to a lot of the unsolved mysteries of human diseases like cancer or AIDS," Rockson said. "A better understanding of lymphatics may unlock some of those mysteries." "Most medical schools don't teach the lymphatic system at all. A national survey conducted by Rockson showed that the average time spent on teaching the lymphatic system during a four-year medical education is 15 minutes." (Why are we not surprised...?)  Now, doesn't Dr. Rockson sound like our kind of hero? You betcha! Binney  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 03:12PM - edited Jan 30, 2008 03:21PM by Binney4 Hi, Climber, Sometimes it's hard to determine exactly what precipitates the start of lymphedema. That's because it can develop at any time after any breast cancer surgery, so if it happens to show up during rads it may still be because of the surgery rather than the rads. At present we have no way to know who's most at risk for it either, though certain things do increase your risk, including: number of nodes removed (though a prophylactic mastectomy with no nodes removed is still a risk), whether the surgery is on your dominant side, radiation (especially axillary and supraclavicular), overweight (especially weight gained after surgery), diabetes, prior vascular problems, prior trauma to your chest or axilla (auto accident, playing tackle football ), diabetes. There are other theories as well: an inflammatory response, a genetic predisposition, etc. Fortunately there are lots of easy lifestyle adjustments you can make that will help prevent lymphedema, and they're well worth the effort to learn about and practice. You can find infomation about that in the Position Papers at the National Lymphedema Network web site: www.lymphnet.org. The papers on Risk Reduction, Air Travel, and Exercise are especially useful. Also, bc.org plans an Ask the Expert On-line Conference on lymphedema prevention in April -- yes!  Hoping you remain swell-free! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2010 07:39PM Binney4 wrote: Suzy, I'm sorry there isn't some "Board of Garment Fitters" that hears complaints about these people and removes their garment-fitters license. And I'm really sorry there's no such thing as a garment-fitters license so somebody could remove it. And I'm REALLY, REALLY sorry that this moron made you cry. I've run across some brazen fitters who made me cry too (but then, LE is a sensitive subject with me), and I currently drive a LONG way to see a great one. I've had fights with my insurance. But this isn't some once-in-a-lifetime relationship, it's on-going, so it's worth the battle -- and the travel, and the inconvenience -- to find someone who can help you intelligently. Why does this have to be so blasted hard?! I have both Jovi and Solaris. Jovi is beautiful, the fabric is yummy, and it comes in colors. Solaris looks less polished but they fit me better. So I wear Solaris sleeves and a Jovi vest most of the time, but I switch off from time to time just to keep the ol' LE guessing. Like Revkat, my arms and hands are smaller in the morning. I wear them sometimes for traveling as well, especially by car (I wrap for the plane). They're much easier than wrapping, and when I get to my destination I can wait a bit and then change into day garments easily, without having to roll up the bandages. I also use them during the day for flares if I'm going to be hanging out at home. The feel good, they're washable, and they work well. Either company can probably steer you to a fitter within a reasonable distance of you, and you can terrorize your insurance company until they let you go there to get a decent fit without the sick, sick sales pitch. Another thought: I get my garments from Hanger, which is a large prosthetic/orthotic place that's covered by my insurance. I called their area office and asked them if they had a fitter anywhere in their chain of stores in AZ that was an expert at this. Of course they told me they all were, but I persisted and they finally admitted there was one woman (a long way from me but what the heck) who actually knew what she was doing. Those were not their words exactly, but you get the idea. Sure enough, she's a treasure. I send everybody around here to her. At first they refuse to go that far, but after trying a few others closer they eventually decide it's worth the trip. Maybe we should car-pool... Keep us posted! Special, stupid-fitter-recovery hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2010 08:31AM Binney4 wrote: KC, good morning! Directionality depends on a couple of factors. One is where your scars are, because it's hard (or impossible) to get the lymph to flow smoothly past a scar. So some mapping has to be done to take that into consideration. If you have only one side that has been operated on, then the fluid from the affected side can be redirected to the opposite armpit area. But if you've had surgery on both sides (even prophylactic), then the opposite armpit is also at risk if you overload it, so then the direction would be downward to the groin. That means clearing the groin and abdomen well as part of the initial steps of the MLD. Then when you try to move the lymph fluid downward the area is ready to receive it. Clear as mud, right?! In a nutshell, we're all different, which is one reason MLD is not a do-it-yourself learning experience. BUT, if whatever you're doing is causing more swelling (it should NEVER cause bruising!) then your therapist should reassess what she's doing and find a better route. It's possible she's breaking up fibrosis first (which requires a firmer massage and can sometimes be, uh, uncomfortable). But the actual MLD should not end up hurting. (Let me clarify that a bit: early on with MLD some of us experience a deep aching, or even a touch of nausea, as the process begins to work. It can last several days but shouldn't be a regular, on-going feature.) Definitely let your therapist know what's happening and ask her to explain it to you. Communication between you is really important because this is a long-term relationship and you need to be comfortable asking her for info or clarification. Any condition that takes this much continual self-care requires that we understand each step. Let us know what you discover. Hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Binney4 wrote: Hi, all, As we're all suffering with the Haitians and their towering needs for all life's basics, I just wanted to share with this special "swell" group about the LE needs in Haiti. Before the earthquake, Haiti had (by some estimates) nearly a quarter of their population affected by lymphedema -- the kind that is transmitted by filarial parasites through mosquito bites. In 2003, Emory University in Georgia began a program of reducing LE there. This involves distribution of medicines to kill the parasites, distribution of mosquito netting for nighttime use, and, most importantly, eradication of mosquito-breeding standing water. By all reports the program has had substantial results and new LE was becoming far less common. This is important, because without therapists, bandages, and garments, people there with LE became hugely swollen (elephantitis) and disabled as far as employment or subsistence farming. What we have now, though, since the earthquake, is thousands of people sleeping out-of-doors with no mosquito protection, the destruction of the medical supply system, and the rainy season due in a few short weeks -- so, lots and lots of standing water for mosquitoes to breed in. In other words, a LE disaster in the making. Though it's hoped that a whole lot of antibiotics are being flown into Haiti as part of the rescue efforts, it's not clear that there will be sufficient supplies for the cellulitis we could expect with this level of LE. And as if that isn't enough, what the people of Haiti are dealing with in the aftermath of the quake is thousands of crush injuries and consequent amputations. The need for prostheses to assist these amputees is obvious, and hopefully already in the plans of the medical teams. What's less obvious to everyone but us is that crush injuries are a major cause of secondary LE, due to the wholesale destruction of fragile lymph vessels near the surface of the skin. I heard a doctor at a clinic in Haiti on a news report this week mention the swelling in the leg of one of his patients. He said it was permanent and nothing could be done to reduce it. Which, in the absence of both trained therapists and compression supplies, is unfortunately accurate. So these people, too, will find themselves hopelessly handicapped by a condition that in our country can be treated and managed. Again, untreated, their lymphedema will lead to cellulitis and from there... I've written to the National Lymphedema Network, urging them to use their resources to find trainers for new Haitian therapists, and hopefully donated supplies for wrapping and compressing these thousands of new lymphers. I don't know what else to do, but if any of you have suggestions of ways we could influence the provision of personnel and supplies for coping with this, please share your ideas. If you're a praying person, please join me in pleading for help for these folks. We struggle to get what we need here, but for the most part we succeed. Without help, though, these people will soon be dying...of lymphedema. Binney Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2011 07:34AM Binney4 wrote: Shortlady, what a crummy dilemma! In answer to your question, you need to know that this is your call, even though some health professionals may try to make you feel silly for protecting yourself. We can give you some suggestions, and hopefully that'll help you make your own decision. If you already have some lymphedema in your left arm, it is at very high risk for infection, so you definitely want to avoid aggravating it with either blood pressure or any skin breaks at all, no matter how small or "sterile." In terms of IVs, there is also the problem of your adding fluid to the mix with the IV, which your nodes are no longer able to handle, plus the fact that since the lymph circulation is sluggish there it will be hard to predict how you body will handle whatever is being infused. So, left arm's a bad idea. Lymphedema is a distressing condition anywhere, but in your dominant arm and hand it's even worse. How much you want to risk that is up to you, but I can tell you that you sure don't want it in your right hand. Alternatives are a bit of a bother, but not as much of a bother as bilateral lymphedema. You can get blood draws done in your feet and IVs in your feet or neck. It requires that your doctor write "Draw from foot only" on the order sheet. (The contraindication to that would be if you have blood clotting problems.) Shortlady, if you already have some lymphedema in the left arm, what you need is not an OT "with lymphedema experience," but a fully-trained lymphedema therapist. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Just like breast cancer, lymphedema is staged, and it will progress without treatment. Even if the swelling is still minor, the accumulation of lymph fluid causes tissue changes inside that can lead to hardening (fibrosis) and serious infection (cellulitis). With prompt and proper therapy, though, you can keep your arm in good shape and lower your risk of permanent tissue distortion. Keep us posted on what you decide to do, and tell us how we can help! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2017 06:07PM Binney4 wrote: ItFinallyHit, yes, it's a possible indication of cellulitis, and because that possibility makes it an emergency you don't want to wait on this any longer. Hop on over to Urgent Care or the ER and have them check it out. Be sure to tell them about the surgery in August and that you are at risk for lymphedema, and so for cellulitis. Say it often, to everyone, repeatedly, so they'll think about it: LYMPHEDEMA; CELLULITIS. Here's information about cellulitis when we're at risk for lymphedema: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Med... The great thing here is, if it's cellulitis you'll be on top of it quickly, no further problem! :-) But no matter what, next week find a well-trained lymphedema therapist, get a referral to her/him from anyone on your healthcare team, and get in for baseline arm measurements, tips on lymphedema risk reduction, and post-bc treatment self-care information. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified... Do let us know what you discover. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2008 10:08PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, otter, There are a lot of stockinette sorts, and they come in lengths or rolls. The rolls are cheaper in the long run. Mine's a looser knit than the one you show. What matters is to get the right size (width), as there are tubes for larger arms and for assorted sizes of legs as well. The soft "cast padding" is probably Artiflex. I use a foam roll for wrapping my arms (lasts forever), but I do use pieces of Artiflex to protect places where I may be having irritation -- especially under my arm where a garment may rub against my truncal swelling. Nice stuff. I don't put anything over my bandages and have never had any problem with them getting dirty, with the exception of my hand bandage, across the palm where that tubular arrangement would probably not cover it anyway. My therapist did put a lengh of the stockinette over the bandages of one of her patients, though, because she rode a motorcycle and had problems with her bandages unraveling and flapping along behind her in the wind. For more ordinary folks like me, though, a couple of pieces of tape on the last bandage works fine, with no tubular thingy needed over the top Does that help any? Steep learning curve here! Be well! Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 10:03PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, carenilene, and welcome! Thanks for posting about your interest in lymph node transplant surgery. We're all anxious to learn more about this, especially in the form of on-going research that can substantiate the effectiveness -- and long-term safety -- of this surgery. Will you be doing this in conjunction with reconstruction? As you're consulting with the surgeons who are doing this in the States now, it would benefit all of us if you'd encourage them to take responsibility for structuring a research arm to this procedure and publishing their outcomes -- at the present time they don't have plans to do the accompanying research, but that could really help us understand if, when and why this surgery works. It would add important information to our understanding of the lymph system that could lead to better treatment and management, as well as help us determine who may or may not be a suitable candidate for this treatment. As Jane mentions, lymphedema research is proceeding in a number of fascinating directions. A recent UK study offers some hope that we may some day have a better way of determining who's most likely to develop lymphedema and who isn't, and it points to reasons why some of us have it and others don't. Very exciting possibilities from that kind of knowledge! Do keep us posted as you learn more about this. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 04:34AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Carla, and welcome! I'm so sorry you're dealing with so much, and all of it painful too. I wanted to give you a couple of sites to research if you'd like. The first is a brief article from LymphNotes about carpal tunnel and lymphedema (LE): http://www.lymphnotes.com/article.php/id/324/ And the second is www.lymphedemapeople.com, where you should be able to find information on the subject, usually research-related. A number of women here have dealt with this, and I hope they come along soon to share their experiences with you. There's been some research evidence lately that problems like CTS, rotator cuff problems, trigger finger and tennis elbow may be related to LE. The theory is that pre-clinical LE (that is, excess fluid in the tissues that is not yet measurable as swelling) may put stress on these joints and nerves, actually causing the problem. Some reports suggest that LE therapy (called Complete Decongestive Therapy (CDT) that involves special manual manipulation, compression, exercise, and skin care) can actually relieve the CTS in some cases. It certainly would be worth a try, at any rate. You'll want a fully-trained LE therapist and a referral from your doctor. Here's a site for finding a well-trained therapist in your area: www.mylymphedema.com. Only such a therapist will be able to tell you if the swelling you're experiencing is LE. It's important to get an LE evaluation, at any rate, since this is an at-risk arm and any treatment for CTS is likely to cause problems with LE (and therefore with infection and further swelling). There's also some evidence that LE itself is an inflammatory response -- your refererence to "flaming CTS" made me think of that. As to gabapentin making you feel crazy, I'm sorry I can't help you with that as I haven't ever been on it. But for sure this entire BC journey has made me more than a little crazy, and LE is the craziest part of it. I sure hope you get on top of this soon and get the pain to stop! Big but real careful (((((HUGS))))), Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2010 09:28AM - edited Apr 7, 2010 09:29AM by Binney4  KC's question: "With the arrows pointing to the armpit, and there being one-way valves within the system, it makes no sense to me that any massage would be in the opposite direction of natural flow." KC, as I mentioned in a PM, I've never thought about this question of the valves in the vessels stopping the flow when we try to move lymph in the direction opposite to the way it's worked all our lives. So I consulted with a couple of lymph-expert friends. (They thought this was an excellent question, by the way, and one no one had thought to ask them before) First, the excess fluid we're trying to remove is not in the lymph vessels, it's in the tiny spaces between body cells -- the interstitial spaces. It's this fluid we're moving across the watersheds to where it can be picked up by functioning lymph vessels and ferried through functioning nodes, cleansed, and pumped back into the circulatory system. So we're not trying to make the lymph fluid flow backward in the vessels, but to get it to another part of the body where it has a better chance of getting back into the vessels and going on its way. (Which is why, if you've had bilateral surgeries, you don't want to direct the fluid to the non-lymphedema armpit, because you're dumping a lot of extra fluid there for the nodes to process, and they're already compromised.) One of my friends, therapist Tom, added a couple of points that I'll just quote here for you -- just because they're interesting to me and might be to you as well: "In the upper abdomen (just above the groin) you have numerous collateral lymph vessels that travel in all directions." In other words, the groin area can pick up excess fluid from the tissues coming into the area from many different directions. Thank goodness!  And then this: "Those valves in the lymph vessels are not like the valves in your veins. They can allow fluid to move bi-directionally if forced to do so (hence the problem with lymph reflux when the system becomes overloaded)." Which is not what your therapist is trying to do, of course, but I thought it was interesting that lymph vessel valves are not quite what we envision. Hope some of that helps. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2014 08:41PM Binney4 wrote: Jo, what a shocker! We're all warned about the possibility, but as you say, it's so rare. That must make you feel pretty lonely, and I'm so sorry. Just really glad the surgery was so successful--wonderful! You're right--I for sure don't want to steer you wrong on this, so I went and gave Kira a shout-out and hope she'll weigh in soon. In the meantime, if it were me I'd go for the MLD. The general guideline (conservative, because there's no real evidence one way or the other) is not to do MLD directly over an area of active cancer, but this is obviously not the case for you now. In any case cancer spread is far more complex than just encouraging sluggish lymph flow--in fact, if we didn't want to move lymph fluid we'd have to sit perfectly still and not move a muscle! Not real practical, and lymph flow is important to our immune systems anyway. So, guarded opinion is, go with it. Gently, of course.  And of course there's always chocolate… Please do keep us posted. Hugs, prayers too, Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2007 08:23AM Binney4 wrote: Oh, hooray, Liezel, a bit of progress! That sure helps. (And I think it's funny I hit your therapist on the first try! Really glad you have one already.) I'm not sure what she told you about using your arm (and if she said not to use it more than necessary, that's what you should do), but IF your hand and arm is wrapped it's generally very helpful to move and exercise your arm. That's because the action of your muscles against the compression bandages acts as a pump to move lymph fluid along. So unless she told you otherwise, WHEN YOU'RE WRAPPED, do move your hand and arm often throughout the day. Flex your fingers, then flex and rotate your wrists, then your elbows, and finally stretch your arms from the shoulder in all directions. If you can do this with your hands above your head, so much the better, but if not any movement at all should help. It's summer where you live, yes? That's a bit of a bummer, for sure. I've had to wrap one of my arms the last few days because I've over-used it lately, and just this morning as I re-wrapped I was thinking how glad I was it's winter here (well, as winter as it gets in the Arizona desert!) So I'm feeling your frustration with the wrapping and the heat . Hang in there - it gets better, honest! Tell Rika we're all rooting for her! Hugs and prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2008 11:36AM Binney4 wrote: Yikes, Pam, I never meant to imply you were uninformed about your risk -- just wanted you to know there are ways to do everything on some other body part without using your affected arm, if that's what you choose to do. I'm really sorry I put that so poorly. Here's the thing: it's not a bit good to cut your arm or be stung by a wasp, either. Or a mosquito, for that matter. Any of those events (even a paper cut) can trigger lymphedema. In fact, there's recent research evidence that the effect of these "insults" to an at-risk arm is cumulative. That is, even if the first or fourth or fortieth event doesn't trigger it, the next one might. But of course no one knows for sure. MOST of us who are treated for breast cancer won't ever get lymphedema, no matter what we do. We just don't know which ones of us are most at risk. Just want to reiterate that the compromises we each make about our lymphedema risk are ours alone to make. No one should feel guilty either way. The good news is there's treatment available for anyone who develops lymphedema, and by being aware of the possibility we can seek treatment quickly, when it's most effective. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 01:28PM - edited Apr 3, 2008 01:29PM by Binney4 Welcome BKF! Nine years is awesome -- I just LOVE good news! Ouch! Sorry about the tennis injury. I'm not sure why it would take longer to heal than it would have before (unless you actually had LE present), but depending on what exactly got injured it sure can take a long time for sports injuries to heal. Pain draws lymph fluid to the site, which can put a strain on your compromised lymph system, so you do want to reduce pain as much as you can. But not with any temperature extremes. WARM is okay, but not hot. If you use cold, be sure to pad the area well so it's not icy, and don't leave it on longer than 15 minutes. (Both heat and cold can cause swelling - sigh!) I'd guess anti-inflammatories would help with the pain and any swelling too -- ask your doctor what's best for pain relief. I'd sure lay off the tennis until this is healed. You don't want to risk increasing the pain or the extent of the injury. Once it's healed do go back to it, but carefully, working back up gradually to full activity. The good news is, exercise is good for reducing LE risk. I sure do agree with Debbie that an appointment with a fully-qualified LE therapist would be a great idea. S/he can take baseline arm measurements, teach you Manual Lymph Drainage massage that can help prevent LE, fit you for compression garments, and give you tips for on-going self-care. (When you get a sleeve for exercise, be sure to get a glove as well, and always wear them together.) You'll need a referral from your doctor, and then you'll need a well-trained therapist. You can use the Therapist Locator at www.mylymphedema.com to find one near you if that's a problem.  You'll find other tips for prevention in the Position Papers on Risk Reduction and Exercise on the National Lymphedema Network web site at www.lymphnet.org. Hope the healing goes smoothly and fast. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 05:41PM Binney4 wrote: Momine, the lotion has to do with keeping your skin healthy and moist. Lots of things dry it out (for instance, in the summer it'd be sun, wind, swimming--in winter it's cold and the general dryness of the air). The reason that's especially important for us is because of our infection risk. Even micro-cracks in dry skin can allow bacteria to enter and create havoc. Lotion also keeps cuticles from drying out (so they don't cause cracks and pulls) and helps avoid chapping of knuckles and elbows.  Some lotions are greasier and grosser than others, but all of them are supposed to be absorbed by the skin (some quicker, some slower). So waiting a few minutes after applying lotion makes it easier to put the garments on over the lotion. I use Vani-Cream lite from Walgreens, which goes on without that greasy feel and absorbs quickly. But there are lots of choices. Before LE I never used lotion at all. Now it's a couple-times-a-day routine. Can't say I like having to use it, but it saves a lot of potential grief. Lymphedema--BAH! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2008 12:13PM - edited Apr 14, 2008 12:14PM by Binney4 Here are a couple of options for identifying an at-risk arm when you have to do a test, procedure, or surgery. A hot-pink hospital-style wrist band that identifies the arm as off limits for sticks or blood pressure, free from: http://www.lymphedema.com (they take awhile to get - if it takes too long send them an email to prod them about it) A pink arm cover that states NO BP/IV, NO BLOOD DRAWS and costs $4.99: http://www.g-sleeve.com BUT, don't count on either alone! As Lisa suggests you can write on your arm with permanent marker (it comes off later with alcohol), and you can even have your doctor sign the arm with your marker. You should have those instructions written on the orders as well. Especially for blood draws, labs won't do a foot draw unless it's written on the order sheet. Before any procedure talk, talk, talk to everyone who comes within range about leaving your arm alone. When you call to make an appointment for something requiring special consideration, do tell them what you'll need so they can have an appropriately skilled person on hand. Hope that helps! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 02:25AM Binney4 wrote: Cowgirl, hello. It's hot here too. In fact it'll be 112 this weekend when our kids who live in Alaska will be visiting--they are going to MELT! If you live someplace dry you might want to use a spray bottle to wet your sleeve down occasionally (allow it to dry in between wettings). If it's humid and the garment takes longer than 15-20 minutes to dry that's not such a good idea, as lingering dampness can create a fungal infection risk. Still, if it's hot/dry enough, the water feels really good. Short of a spray bottle, I've been known to wet my arm down in a drinking fountain. We also use the spray bottle to keep our necks wet, and if it's not enough, even our shirts and shorts. Extreme weather calls for desperate measures! Taking my sleeve off when it's that hot, as attractive as that sounds, really isn't workable for me. Heat causes increased swelling, so my garments are more important than ever in the heat. But other cooling methods are available. Cooling vests like construction workers wear can really help, as they keep the core temperature down. Other cooling items keep head or neck cool, and there are even cooling packs to stuff in your bra. These are NOT ice packs, just cool packs--extreme cold is no better for LE than extreme heat is. Ya' gotta stay hydrated, and that can be hard to remember to do. There are all kinds of tote-along water containers, some with straws. Whatever works. Of course stay in the shade as much as possible, and early morning hours are best to be outdoors. For us that means getting up early -- our current rise-and-shine time is 5:00. Where we live many stores accomodate the temperatures by opening much earlier this time of year. Even our zoo opens around 6:00 in the summer. This stuff sure isn't easy! Stay cool! Binney

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 09:52AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Shirley, You can win this, but unfortunately the insurance company can make you work for it. If you don't already have information packets from your insurance, call and ask them to send you complete info for filing both an appeal and a grievance. You'll need a calm and organized statement (outline form helps - you want it clear and easy to reference) stating the problem, the steps you've already taken, the exact action you want the insurance company to take, and all the reasons why they should do that. You also need as much supporting documentation as you can find: anything to do with reconstruction, skin-sparring techniques, usual ps protocol, etc. (assume they're as dumb as stumps and find information on EVERY aspect). Also include a copy of the complete 1998 Women's Health and Cancer Treatment Act (or whatever it's called) that provides for recon or other surgery. Highlight the crucial parts, but include the whole of each document. Also, attach letters from as many of your doctors/therapists/NPs/PAs as you can convince to support you. On your outline, note each document and letter where it's appropriate. THEN take the entire stack of papers, in order and neatly labeled, and HAVE YOUR DOCTOR FAX IT. If you fax or mail it they're not obliged to read the attachments, but if your doc faxes it they must read it all, every page. Good for them! They'll learn something! And one of the things they'll likely learn is not to mess with you again. Win-win! Be sure to also file a grievance at the same time, stating exactly the anguish they are causing you with this delay and the impediment to adequate health care, recovery, and healing that they're causing. State that the action you wish to see is promp approval for the clean-up surgery they owe you. I know this is a lot of work, but it's got its satisfying aspects. When I hand my doc's nurses a thick stack of documents to fax for me I always think they're going to balk, but they hate insurance companies at least as much as I do, and they rub their hands together in glee and chuckle as they retire to their fax machine. Go get 'em! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2008 05:31AM Binney4 wrote: Wow! You gals are so well-informed about not using an at-risk arm. Jeanne46, the choice to continue to use an affected arm is certainly yours to make, but just so the decision you're making is an informed one: anybody can do a blood pressure on your calf, using the pulse near the outside of your ankle. It may register slightly higher, but if you make sure you're laying flat for 5 minutes before they take it that will increase its accuracy. And with planning and determination it's possible to make sure someone who can access your port is available before any appointment where that's necessary (or talk to the nurses at your onc's office). When they say they "have to" it's almost always their excuse for not wanting to take the trouble to keep you safe. If you develop lymphedema from it, not only won't they even know about it, but it sure as heck won't be them with the fat arm. So if you'd rather not take that risk, you're entitled to stand your ground. blue16, I do hope your friend's healthcare team will get creative about finding a less risky way to deal with her herceptin. Because of our bc treatments, there can be as much as 30% more fluid in our arm (or chest) tissues than is normal before any swelling is even noticable, so an at-risk arm can already be lymph-compromised well before diagnosis of lymphedema is possible. Besides possibly triggering lymphedema, an infusion can well be inefficient at distributing the infused drugs because of the backed-up lymph flow. So even technically, it's an unsound practice to use that arm for infusions. Which explains, Pam, why even careful disinfecting of an infusion site is not entirely effective -- the infused fluid itself can overwhelm the lymph system just by its sheer volume. It's so cheering to hear so many of you talk about sticking to your guns and educating your sluggish medical teams to be aware of our risk. Hopefully the newbies traveling this road behind us will face less lymphedema risk because of you! Hear! Hear! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 01:35PM Binney4 wrote: Aw, Chicago, I'm really sorry your weekend get-away had to end with so much worry and discomfort! At the moment, I've gotta say it sounds like a bad sunburn, but you're right that lymphedema may be a concern. Just in case, do try to keep your arm elevated as much as possible (supported, not just holding it up in the air -- and on pillows at night). Also stay REALLY well hydrated, and pause throughout the day to take in a few deep, abdominal breaths (that helps to stimulate the lymph system.) Whether this is lymphedema or not, it would be a great idea to get a referral from anyone on your medical team to a well-trained lymphedema therapist. S/he can evaluate your situation (and yes, BTW, your dominant side would normally be slightly larger than your non-dominant side), give you some risk reduction tips, and fit you for a sleeve and glove you can wear for travel and exercise. [A word of warning, here: strange as it may seem, compression garments DO NOT protect from sunburn, so always protect yourself from sunburn when wearing them!!] Here's a page about finding a well-trained therapist near you: www.stepup-speakout.org/Findin... Because of the damage a sunburn can cause, do be especially watchful for any signs of infection, like fever, new redness or swelling, increased pain, itching, warmth to the touch. If you suspect it, get help promptly, as it can spread rapidly. And for goodness sake keep us posted! Hoping everything subsides quickly and you have nothing left over from this trip but happy memories! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2010 05:04PM Binney4 wrote: Littletower, the choice about using your at-risk arm is yours, so stand strong -- even if they roll their eyes at you! There was an article published recently regarding IVs and bloodwork on an at-risk arm, from a study done in Sweden, and it showed that there was indeed a risk from those things -- about 6% of women developed some swelling following those procedures. But the researchers (who were nurses) concluded that the risk to a "few" women was not enough to justify the clinical inconvenience of having to avoid the arm when they wanted to draw blood or place an IV. They also concluded that women should not be told about their risk because it would make them anxious. That is possibly the study your doctor is referring to. As patients, we're more than entitled to draw very different conclusions: if WE find ourselves in that 6% that have to deal with the distress, disability and disfigurement of lymphedema for the rest of our lives, then the problem of their inconvenience is really not even worth considering. Shame on them! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2012 02:44PM Binney4 wrote: Hildy, the VES pump is the "new kid on the block," developed recently by a therapist who (JMHO) appears to have her own enterpreneurial interests at the top of her priority list. She has long had a business "training" LE therapists with a particularly lacking short course, and some of us have had the misfortune of running into these under-trained therapists. She now has this new pump business, and she claims there has been research done with it to show its effectiveness, but she has yet to produce the results. I have heard her brag that the engineers she hired to create her pump had never even heard of lymphedema, which she says is an advantage because that way they'd have fresh ideas. Helloooo?!! Lymphedema is a whole lot more than a plumbing problem, so if it were me, I'd want a pump developed by people with a passion for LE and a deep working knowledge of its dynamics. Just by way of balancing this rant, I will say that I have seen a therapist who was trained by her who actually became an excellent practitioner, principally because she's the sort who keeps on learning on her own. All that just to say you might want to do your own research on this. As far as the research is concerned, Flexi has a lot behind it. No pump is standard treatment--they are just a substitute for home self-MLD. Therapists should be doing hands-on MLD during LE treatment appointments, not relying on pumps. We're paying for their skill and experience, which can only be of help to us if they're using their own hands to assess and manipulate our actual skin and tissues. Like I say, JMHO. Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2010 07:38PM Binney4 wrote: Linjea, goodness yes -- brownies and a good lymphedema therapist! Unfortunately, lymphedema massage (Manual Lymph Drainage, or MLD) and wrapping are not do-it-yourself. That's because learning the proper pressure, direction, and order of the massage is very critical and it depends on your own individual needs -- for instance, whether there is fibrosis or scarring present, what kind of surgery you've had, and the condition of the skin. Only a therapist can assess your particular needs and help you learn a technique that is workable for you. The point of the wrapping (which must be done with the proper pressure throughout or it will do more harm than good) is to help reduce the swelling by promoting lymph vessel function. Exercising or even just the ordinary movements of daily living help the wrapping work, but it also works well at night. Like Manual Lymph Drainage, this can only be taught in person, one-on-one with a really good therapist. The sleeves and gauntlet that you order are only for use AFTER the initial therapy (regular MLD and wrapping by a well-trained therapist). They don't reduce the swelling but only help maintain the reduction that happens with therapy. When you already have swelling in your hand a gauntlet is a bad idea, because it will cause the lymph fluid to be trapped in your fingers, where it is very difficult to get it out. And any sleeve that does not fit well on ANY PART of your arm will make matters worse, as the compression needs to be greater farther from your axilla and less as it moves up the arm. If it's looser at your wrist and then tighter in your forearm that will trap fluid around your wrist. When the off-the-shelf garments don't fit, it's time to be fitted for custom garments. BUT, again, that is only after you've had the therapy by a well-qualified therapist. Early stage lymphedema does sometimes reduce and then swell again. This is the stage where it is VERY IMPORTANT to begin therapy, because otherwise it will progress and produce fibrosis (hardening of the tissues inside) and more serious skin changes that may then be permanent. Please don't let that happen, as it's discouraging and disabling and will eventually affect your arm strength and range of motion. The achiness and pain are early indications of a need to get help with draining the stagnant lymph fluid and keeping it reduced and healthy. This will not only feel better and be much easier to manage, but it will help prevent the cellulitis infections that are so common in lymphedema. Here's a page of information about how to find a well-trained lymphedema therapist near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Hang in there -- there's help for this, and it makes a BIG difference. And please let us know how we can help. Big, gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 02:23PM Binney4 wrote: Hello, Erick, I had to take a few moments to read back over some of your other posts on the boards here to see where you're coming from on this and wanted to say I appreciate yours and Lynda's interest in doing things that will help you move through this chapter of your lives in a healthy and responsible way. I think you'll both be delighted to know that lymphedema is treated without drugs or even surgery, in ways that help our bodies repair damage already done and prevent further stress. That said, I gotta tell you that 22 lymph nodes removed is a lot of lymph nodes, and three surgeries of whatever description also amounts to considerable opportunity for scarring that can block lymph flow. In short, Lynda is indeed at risk for lymphedema of her arm and her chest (called truncal lymphedema). Seeing as how you're both completely serious about researching and receiving the best of care for you, it would seem like a great idea for her to find a well-qualified lymphedema (LE) therapist close by and make an appointment for: an evaluation baseline arm measurements instruction in prophylactic Manual Lymph Drainage massage (MLD) instruction in risk reduction practices measurements for a sleeve and glove that she can live with to use when exercising, traveling, and any strenuous activity The fact that she was in good physical condition before surgery is helpful, but is no guarantee of missing this particular bullet. The risk will remain for life, and there is some evidence that damage to the lymph system is cumulative, so doing something risky without developing LE once, or twice, or fifty times will not assure that it won't develop the next time. Being active and valuing her health, flexibility, and stamina, Lynda DOES NOT want lymphedema, which is distressing, disfiguring, and very often disabling. Doctors do not generally receive training in diagnosing or treating LE, and they often downplay the risk and the reality. Not all therapists who call themselves LE therapists have the training to treat it adequately or even correctly. So you both need to take on that self-advocacy role with LE that you've honed through the bc experience. Here are a couple of places to start: Position Papers of the National Lymphedema Network, www.lymphnet.org A list of links for locating a QUALIFIED LE therapist near you, www.mylymphedema.com If we can help, tell us how. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 07:18PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Chicago, So glad to hear you're doing so well! Whew! As to whether you can assume LE is not a problem? A couple of thoughts. First, a visit to a well-trained lymphedema therapist for instruction in Manual Lymph Drainage (lymphatic massage) and fitting for a sleeve and glove or gauntlet (for exercise, travel or any strenuous activity) would still be an excellent idea. Then, if you sense any "funny" feelings in that arm or notice any new swelling, tingling, heaviness or achiness, you'll have a way to deal with it. And second, there are lots of PTs and OTs out there with "experience in LE" that really have not been thoroughly trained. And since it's such a complicated condition and deals with a unique and little-understood body system, that thorough training is important to your future well being. If you're not sure about his/her training, ask. And don't hesitate to get a second opinion if necessary. I'm sure hoping you never again have a moment's worry about LE! Lexislove, what a cute avatar! Who's the adorable little bug? Your very best (safest, happiest) bet is to find a well-qualified lymphedema therapist near you (there's a site mentioned in a post above about how to find one), get a referral, and pop in for a visit and evaluation. S/he'll take baseline arm measurements, teach you some risk reduction practices, and if necessary begin therapy to get it and under control and keep it that way. Please do keep us posted, and let us know how we can help. Gentle hugs to you both, Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2010 01:32AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Sher, I don't know about the tubular padding bandage, but if I were you I'd call BandagesPlus and ask THEM why not. North American should send you what you ordered. Period. Especially since it's what your therapist uses. It's not up to them to decide what you need. But as for the Mollelast, I use that and wash it. Doesn't last as long as the short stretch bandages, obviously, but it does many, many wraps before it gives out. I toss them into a lingerie bag, then run them over the top of a folding chair, smoothing them with my fingers as I go. I hang them, all smoothed out, from the shower curtain rod to dry -- doesn't take long at all.  If you wrap very often and toss out the finger bandages every time it could begin to make a dent in the budget. (I've heard of women ironing them with very low heat after washing, but that seems pretty extreme to me!) When I get new short stretch bandages I write the date on that hard little end with a magic marker (Jennifer gave us that hint a long time ago, and I think of her whenever I do it!) Helps a lot when you have several sets from different times and need to know which ones are ready to be retired. I write the date I get them on the tag of my garments too. This does actually get easier as you settle into which brands and dealers you prefer. Do let us know what you discover. Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 09:45AM Binney4 wrote: SL, I always have blood draws from my foot. I drink a LOT the day before and with my doctor's approval take an aspirin the night before. Then I wrap it in a microwavable heating pad for the trip to the lab (NOT too hot!) I keep my feet moving while I wait, bouncing my leg up and down, tapping my foot (the other people in the waiting room keep stealing glances at the crazy lady with her weird gloves who can't seem to sit still -- I smile back! I don't use Emla or anything for pain, because for me it doesn't seem to hurt any more than any other blood draw. You can tell them you want to lie down for it if you want -- easier for them and you both. If you call the lab they'll most likely tell you they can't do it in your foot, so instead just take the lab sheet (where your doctor has written "draw from foot only") and go to the lab, smile calmly, and they'll find a tech who can do it. My favorite tech often has others come in when she does mine so they can learn. She tells them it's easier in the foot, because the veins are bigger. There are veins on the top of your foot and above the ankles. Not really a problem to find them. Keep us posted! Binney

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2012 05:19PM Binney4 wrote: I'll stick by my post above, Gma--they're not gradient compression, not made for LE, may contain swelling okay for truncal, but the arms are a problem. As for Dr. Oz, there's a pop "lymph system" thing going on, even at spas, where they do massage to "stimulate the lymph system" and "detox" the body. This is not MLD and not intended for a compromised lymph system. We require gradient compression on our arms to move the fluid upward against gravity, otherwise we risk pooling. For those with a fully-operating lymph system pooling isn't the issue it is for us. As we saw in an earlier telecast, Dr. Oz is just about clueless where LE is concerned, so we can be pretty sure he's only referring to this pop phenomenon. Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 02:55PM Binney4 wrote: Let's see -- you have to start with a VERY long piece of dental floss. You put one end of it UP under the ring and leave a short amount sticking out. Then take the OTHER end of the long string and wrap it around your finger just above the ring, moving up your finger with every wrap so the wraps lie right next to each other, hopefully up past the knuckle. Then start gently but firmly (and slowly) pulling the SHORT end. It'll gradually unwrap the string and go around and around your finger, hopefully moving the ring up over the wrapped string. Is that any better? The thing you want to avoid at all costs is irritating the skin, which can become an infection risk. So don't do it if your skin gets bothered. Definitely need to remove the sleeve if you don't have a glove, Brenda, so the sleeve doesn't push more fluid into your hand and fingers. Since finances are a problem, you might try something less expensive until you can afford a glove. An isotoner might help, for instance. Also, try keeping your arm elevated as much as possible, even at night on a pillow. If you can get the finger swelling reduced you can remove the rings. Extreme temperatures (like icing your hand) should be avoided too, as it may reduce the swelling briefly, but then it'll swell worse. We've had a couple of discussions here about wedding rings. Because my swelling is well controlled, I wear mine under my glove, but I take it off when traveling or doing other things that might give me trouble. Other women have them sized larger, have a clasp attached to the back, or wear it on a chain around their neck. Lymphedema's nasty. Be well! Binney
Posts.Title: Tight wedding ring solution Binney4 Kate33

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 12:01PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Shrink! You're right about LE being a very individual thing! Usually, though, if five or six weeks of treatment don't solve the problem you're fitted for compression garments to maintain the loss, and treatment is suspended for a few months to give everybody a rest (well, actually to give your lymph system a break, I think, but enough is enough anyhow!) Then after a few months you start in again, and most of the time see real improvement after a rest. (Often, if you use compression garments during the day and wrapping at night after active treatment stops you'll continue to see improvement, even if it's very gradual). The fact that you've seen so much improvement with treatment  is a good sign that you can expect further reduction down the road. Before stopping for a break, be sure you've been taught well how to do self-MLD and wrapping. That way you have some control when you overdo it, or overheat, or the weather changes, or whatever may make your LE flare. Very nice feeling to have all those tools in your own hands! Some of the gals here have talked about some unresolvable swelling that remains after everything has been tried (Jennifer comes to mind). As long as you are careful to maintain your arm as it is and not allow it to continue to swell, that's the best and safest thing to do. All of us with LE are in danger from systemic infection at the slightest provocation (a paper cut, for Pete's sake!), so carry those antiseptic wipes, bandaids and  topical antibiotic with you, and ask your doctor for oral antibiotics to have on hand for quick response to infection. Actually, MLD massage by a well-trained therapist and wrapping are generally more effective at resolving stubborn swelling than a pump. Chip bags or shaped pieces of foam included in the wrapping over those stubborn places can sometimes break up fibrosis and soften the area to promote good lymph drainage. Ask your therapist about trying some option: "chocolate bars", "spaghetti foam" and shaped grey foam are some of the choices. (I'm not making that up, either!) If you "graduate" from wrapping to compression garments, be sure to continue with the wrapping at night and see if the swelling gradually resolves. In other words, you sound like you're doing really well. Congrats on the progress -- hang in there! Be well! Binney
Posts.Title: How long? shrink Binney4

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 04:44PM Binney4 wrote: Diane, hello and welcome! I'm so sorry your mom is running into these crummy problems! Pain under the arm is sure possible with lymphedema. Most people think of lymphedema as swelling in the arm, but the swelling can be in the breast or chest, back, side, shoulder or axilla as well. Usually (but not always) it's more painful when it's on the trunk than when it's just in the arm. The hardness also goes along with lymphedema sometimes, as the swelling makes the tissues feel hard and full. I hope she can get into the lymphedema clinic for an evaluation soon, as it's helpful and reassuring to get a firm diagnosis and get started on treatment (which is gentle and non-invasive, by the way!) Lynda, being an RN doesn't necessarily make a therapist better qualified, but the LANA after her name means she's had at least 135 hours of specifically LE training. RN's can no longer be paid by insurance for LE therapy so most RN therapists are out of business. You're lucky yours is still working. Let us know how it goes! Just because we all need to know these things, let me explain that a couple of years ago a lobby group sponsored by the PT professional association (APTA) managed to get RNs and MTs disqualified as therapists for insurance purposes, even those who are fully trained to provide LE therapy. This rotten and self-serving move eliminated a great many well-trained therapists and closed many clinics across the country, especially in rural areas, making it harder for patients to find good care. PTs support this sort of destructive legislation because they want to be the only ones who provide this service and because they DON'T want to have to get the additional 135 hours of specifically LE training in order to do it. (The OTs have their own fairly strong lobby, which is why the PTs couldn't get them eliminated as well.) And here's the rub: the PTs have now attacked the new H.R. 4662 legislation that originally contained provisions to reinstate RNs and MTs as therapists and to demand the full135-hour training. Our "advocates" who are attempting to push the legislation in D.C. have buckled to their pressure on these points. The new proposals for this legislation have been watered down to suit the PTs, not the patient needs. I'm still in support of the original wording, but it seems to me the watered-down version is potentially more damaging to us than no legislation at all. JMHO, Binney

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 09:42AM Binney4 wrote: Lynda, feel free to "go on about this" as much as you need or want to. It's confusing and frustrating and even a bit frightening, and not being able to get good information makes it even more stressful. We all tend to blubber on about it, as you can see! You're not jumping the gun! You can wake up from surgery with lymphedema or develop it 15 or 20 years later, so the timing is no issue at all.  As for there being only six nodes removed, several of us here had fewer than that or developed it after prophylactic mastectomy with no axillary nodes removed.  The fact that your arm "feels funny" is more than enough reason to request an evaluation by a well-qualified LE therapist (like the one you found). It will either start you on the right foot toward LE risk reduction if you don't have it yet, or get you started on LE treatment promptly, which is the very best way to control it on into the future. Win/win! There aren't any tests to determine if you have these conditions (if you have AWS you may be able to see or feel the "cords"), but sometimes doctors do tests to determine it's not something else (doppler to rule out blood clots or imaging to rule out tumors for instance). A well-trained lymphedema therapist will be able to tell you if it is by history and physical exam. I can't think of any questions to ask your onco's nurse, because she's not the medical professional who treats this. But do let us know what she has to say. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 10:15PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Sher, Good for you for getting back in the water! Sounds delicious! How to recognize what's enough and what's too much? Man, that's not easy! If your arm feels tired, achy, tingly, strained -- stop at once. You can go back to it next time, but again stop if you have any of those feelings, or stop BEFORE you start to feel that way. If you feel fine when you're doing it but later on your arm feels achy or tired, you've done too much -- next time stop sooner. It takes longer to work up your strength this way, but it can be done safely and effectively. Stay well hydrated too. What's really hard about this is stopping. Who wants to stop just because you feel a little tired? We're not used to that, and it's tempting to just finish out the set before you stop. And it's frustrating to feel like you have to stop when everybody else is going on. My problem is gardening. My arm has had it, but I only have a couple of feet to go to finish thinning this row. It's almost impossible for me to stop, so I go faster and try to get it done before it does any more damage. Which is nuts, of course, but I don't think clearly when I'm in that situation. I'm getting better about it, but that's just because I've caused myself grief enough times that I KNOW I don't want to do that again. Geesh! Does that help any? Hope so! Do enjoy the class! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 07:54AM Binney4 wrote: Interesting paragraph today from an article in the NLN e-newsletter about The Guilt of the Caregiver: As you begin to read this article, you might find yourself wondering just what is this author talking about? The guilt? Well, I truly don't believe that I'm alone out there. I don't think that I'm the only one who feels the guilt that only a caregiver can feel. I'm 28 years old, and I take care of my mother who is 58. She has stage three lymphedema. It's difficult for me to see her the way she is, especially since she was always a rock. She didn't gave in to being sick, always fought everything, and I never seen her cry. I'm angry now; I'm angry because this disease has taken my mother from me, and while she's still here physically, a good part of her has been taken away. I feel guilty for being angry. I feel guilty for wishing that she was different. I'm jealous of my older sister, because my mother was able to play with her children, and now that I have my own one year old child, she cannot play with my son. She can hold him and verbally interact with him, but it's not the same. She can't run after him, or tickle him, or just be with him the way I know she wants to be with him. I'm angry with myself for feeling this way, but I know that it's alright to feel this way. I know that I can feel angry and jealous, because I'm not jealous or angry with her, the person with lymphedema, but rather I'm angry with and jealous of the disease itself. Lymphedema is a selfish, cruel, ugly thing that threatens my mother everyday, daring her to take a faithful step outside. A bug bite, a scratch, a knick of anything can make her world a nightmare. So yes, I do believe that guilt is the perfect title for this article. By Crystal Bass Type of Lymphedema: My mother suffers from Primary Lymphedema Maybe that's helpful. I'm sure the feelings are more complex than that, but it's a good start on understanding. Be well, Binney PS - For those unfamiliar with Primary LE, it's a congenital condition that can appear at birth or at any point in life, often in the teen years but also can show up in later adulthood. It can, and does, sometimes take years or even decades for Primary Lymphers to get a diagnosis and medical help -- and we thought WE had trouble getting a diagnosis!

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2008 04:46PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Lorena, Sorry about the "swell" hand and fingers! I'm wonderiing if your PT was also a fully qualified LE therapist. That'd be someone with at least 135 hours of specifically LE training beyond her/his PT certification, and a year's experience treating LE. Since no state currently enforces training standards for LE therapists it can be hard for us to find one with the knowledge and experience to treat it adequately. In other words, I'm wondering if you had Complete Decongestive Therapy (massage, wrapping, skin care, exercise, LE care instruction), which would be the protocol for your situation. LE is staged, like bc is, and without proper treatment it will progress to a more advanced stage. That doesn't necessarily mean more swelling, but it does mean internal tissue damage from the presence of too much protein in the lymph fluid, which will result in hardening (fibrosis), further lymph blockage, much higher risk of serious infection, and eventual loss of both strength and range of motion. So "mild" LE needs to be treated seriously, even if it doesn't seem to bother you much. As otter notes, that would include (preferably) wrapping of your arm for exercise sessions. Not only will wrapping protect your arm from further swelling, but it will actively reduce the swelling in your hand and fingers as you exercise. Win/win! Recent research is showing that no particular weight limit needs to apply, but as otter says, the progression should be very gradual -- no strain or stress to the arm, backing off at once if the arm feels tired, tingly, or achy. A compression sleeve should not be worn without a glove if you already have some swelling in your hand, as it can cause fluid to be trapped in your hand. As for blood pressure, that can be a real problem (it's how my LE started in my left arm), but you'd know that within a couple of days. When I first got a medic-alert for LE it was to remind MYSELF not to let that arm be used! The habits (and freedoms) of a lifetime can't be changed overnight, for sure. More information in the position papers on Exercise and Therapy (also one on therapist training) at the National Lymphedema Network: www.lymphnet.org Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 03:22PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, all, Just wanted to pop in for a moment to mention that if you're planning to wear a compression sleeve for air travel, you need to wear hand protection with it. The reason is that if you should develop swelling in your arm, the sleeve could push it into your hand, where it's even harder to deal with. Here's an excellent short article about using hand protection along with arm sleeves: http://lymphedivas.com/lymphedema/gauntletandsleeve/ And here are the guidelines for air travel from the National Lymphedema Network, an organization of lymphology professionals: http://www.lymphnet.org/pdfDocs/nlnairtravel.pdf The LymphNet.org site also offers general guidelines for lymphedema risk reduction, and for protecting yourself when exercising. Any compression garments used for lymphedema protection need to be VERY well-fitted. Best bet is to get help with fitting from a well-trained lymphedema therapist (who can also do an evaluation, take baseline arm measurements for future reference, and give you personalized risk reduction tips.) Here's a page with pictures illustrating what to look for in a good garment fit, so you can judge the fit before you buy: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_lymphedema_garments.htm Happy travels, and may you never have any "swell" days, ever! Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 02:38PM Binney4 wrote: Alyson, what a year you've had! So sorry you're now dealing with more, but gotta say your spirit is inspiring! I'm not sure from your post if you've already seen a PT for your arm, or whether you have a glove as well as a sleeve (or perhaps a sleeve with attached glove?) At any rate, if you have no glove, for sure don't wear just the sleeve. There are a few things you can do for relief and to limit further swelling until you can see the therapist for help. Since your arm seems to be involved as well, keeping it elevated as much as possible (at night on pillows, too) may help, but wearing a sleeve that's already aggravating the chest swelling is probably not a good idea. Instead, you might try one of those tight sport shirts like bike racers wear, long sleeved (here in the States they're called something like BodyArmor). Get one a size smaller than you'd normally wear, for gentle compression, and wear it inside out so the seams don't irritate your skin or block lymph flow. If it helps, wear it at night as well. Limit any strenuous activity until you start therapy, but do practice deep abdominal breathing throughout the day, and simple arm exercises like raising your arm and making cat-clawing motions. Avoid heat and hot water (hot showers or baths, dishwater, hot packs, spas), and be extra careful not to damage the skin in any way: burns, hangnails, paper cuts, insect bites, sunburn. Use a good lotion on your arm and chest a couple of times a day to keep the skin moisturized. Watch for any redness on your arm or chest, and warmth to the touch, fever, or itching, as these can indicate infection. If anything like that appears get to the doctor or ER at once, as infection is a big problem with uncontrolled lymphedema, and it spreads quickly. Hopefully others will be along soon with ideas I've forgotten to add. But I just wanted to say that this can be distressing and depressing, and I really want to encourage you that with good therapy you'll soon have all the knowledge and skills you need to take back control over your life. Hang in there! Be well, Alyson! Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 02:34PM Binney4 wrote: Oh, whoops! I forgot to mention that bandaging for lymphedema treatment or prevention is a unique and specific process that must be taught. There's under-layering involved, as well as gradient compression with special short-stretch bandages. These apply the correct kind of pressure to the skin which allows for the muscles below to pump lymph fluid more effectively. (The lymph system, as you probably realize, has a vasculature as extensive as the circulatory system, but without a pump of any sort like the heart. Lymph is "pumped" in part by the action of the muscles against the pressure of the skin.) ACE bandages can be useful in preventing or controlling edema after sprains or other injuries, but in LE they can strangle the lymph vessels, which lie directly under the skin. With a compromised lymph system you don't want to do that. A fully-trained LE therapist can teach LE wrapping, and with Lynda's experience it should be fairly easy to learn.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2010 02:49PM Binney4 wrote: Linjea, did either of those therapists actually do MLD on you? Just curious, as it's nearly impossible to learn without some hands-on, but there are a lot of therapists out there who are not making the time/effort to do that. If you've had bilateral surgeries (don't know if you have or not), you don't want to move the fluid from the bc side to the "good" side, because both are at risk. There are several good lymphedema therapist training schools, and they each have their own unique take on this, though they all do basically the same thing about clearing nodes, then massaging the chest, etc. The differences come in the kind of strokes used (though all have to be very gentle). There is even one very good school that recommends that their patients not do self-mld at all, because we so often get it wrong anyway -- whether we forget a step or two, or we go too fast (the lymph system has a very slow rhythm), or we press too hard when we get frustrated or hurried. The issue really is, which works best for you? Two things to consider: which is more effective at reducing swelling, and which are you more likely to be able to pull off every day on an on-going basis. Keeping up this routine over time is a big part of the challenge, so we do need to be realistic about what we can actually do. There are a number of "short-cut" routines that help some women (and not others). For instance, using the first three sections of the Lebed exercise DVD is as effective for me as doing self-mld, but it may not be that way for others. For some, several short versions (that include node clearing and a few key massage strokes and/or some deep breathing or exercises) throughout the day work better than one (or two) whole self-mld routines. And just as an aside, therapists call self-mld "Simple Manual Lymph Drainage" or SMLD, but I sorta resent the term -- nothing simple about it! Others will no doubt be along with their own versions of mld coping. Be well! Binney

Water aerobics are the best, but don't do anything that strains your arm. Grace and AZDarleen both swear by the water aerobics, but Darleen tells me she has to modify some of the exercises or work up to them slowly. There's some research going on now to help determine why some people get LE and others don't, and hopefully that will help us to be able to make better risk assessments for each individual. Some researchers are looking at genetic factors, some at ways of assessing the state of the lymphatics even before bc treatment, and some at other possible factors like inflammatory response. Still others are working on better assessment measures (like bioimpedence measures) that can detect the presence of intracellular fluid even before any swelling appears. That would certainly help women keep their LE in managable shape. There's a lot of hope on the horizon. Now all we have to do is educate our docs and nurses...! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2010 03:34PM Binney4 wrote: Kira, thank you so much for that heartfelt post. Stunning, really. What an opportunity we have to educate! Katey, you only mention elevation, so I'm wondering if you've had recent help from a well-trained lymphedema therapist. Unless you've already learned Manual Lymph Drainage, self-bandaging, directed exercises and therapeutic skin care, you need more "tools" to deal with your lymphedema than you currently have. It's a progressive condition -- it's staged just like breast cancer is. The stages don't have to do with the size of our arms, but with damage going on inside our bodies -- inflammation, fibrosis formation, abnormal fat deposition, further lymph blockage, loss of strength and range of motion, and greater risk of serious systemic infection. The progression is slow, but in later stages elevation will no longer work to reduce the swelling, and fibrosis will make the needed therapy more strenuous. Good therapy now will save grief down the road. Blood pressure readings from the leg are higher than the arm, but if you do it regularly at first you can establish your own baseline, and then you'll have a way to track your blood pressure. You do need to be lying flat for a few minutes before they take your leg bp, or it's simply a useless exercise. Your call, of course, but the lymphedema in my left arm (one node removed) started with a blood pressure reading on that arm, and all I can tell you is, bilateral LE is a real bear to deal with. If you call the labs they'll invariably tell you they can't do a foot draw. But if you show up with the blood test order sheet in hand and "Draw from foot only" written on it by the ordering office, they'll almost always do it. At my lab I have a phlebotomist who does it regularly, and she often has other staff members watch to learn how to do it. The last time, the new tech watched and looked confused. She said, "But I didn't see you do anything different from the way we do it on an arm. What's different about it?" To which my tech answered, "Nothing, except it's a lot easier on the foot because the veins are bigger." So -- no mystery there, just ignorance! I do ask to lie down for blood draws -- easier on the tech too so she doesn't have to bend over to get to my feet. Make sure your foot is warm, drink loads of water, and if it's okay with your doctor take an aspirin the day before. Go for it! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2008 02:46PM - edited Sep 28, 2008 02:48PM by Binney4 Aw, tj, you said it: lonely. Sending you hugs, hot cyber cocoa, a box of cyber-kleenex, and maybe a sisterly giggle or two afterward. How do you know if it's too tight -- hmmm. Well, a little pinker may be just fine, but real red, or white, or purple are not good. Tingling, like your fingers are asleep -- not good. If the tips swell, that's also time to re-wrap. Do exercise some while you're wrapped: reaches with your arms, elbow bends, wrist twists, cat-claw motions with your fingers. If your fingernails turn blue, then it's too tight. One other way to judge:  if your arm or hand swells pretty quickly after you remove the wraps, it was probably too tight. Looser next time! Part of the problem is that you have to make the compression less as you go up the arm, so what's too tight in one area may be just right a little further down.  As you so aptly say, this ain't easy. Good news is, it does get easier with practice. And the loneliness and distress get easier with time too. And there IS some satisfaction when you get it right, and you look at it and see it's a great job and you've actually gained the skill you need to take your life back into your own hands. So watch for that golden moment and pause to celebrate it, because we deserve to appreciate the fruits of our struggles! Be well, tj! Binney
Posts.Title: Wrapping-how if know if you did it right? tomatojuice Binney4

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2008 07:48PM Binney4 wrote: Otter, you're cracking me up, and I even know how completely un-funny this is! I'm not sure how your therapist does it, but I'll describe how I do, and maybe that'll help. You've got the stockinette and some Artifllex (or foam) on your hand, right? Okay. Put your hand out in front of you with the palm toward the floor. Spread your fingers apart so you don't squish them all together when you wrap them. Take the short-stretch roll in your other hand and begin to unroll it across the top of your wrist TOWARD YOUR BODY, not away from you. Go around your wrist at least twice to make sure that little bugger end stays in there. (Don't yank it tight in an effort to keep the end from unraveling because with the hand wrap it's the LAYERS that create the compression you need, not tugging it tight.) Once it's good and secure, as you come up around your wrist, move the roll up so it unrolls across the back of your hand and goes down between your thumb and first finger. Go slow and remember to keep your fingers spread. Continue across your palm, and when it comes up on the other side of your hand go around your wrist again. Then when it comes up, go around between thumb and first finger again. Then around the wrist. Then around between the thumb and first finger. And on and on... As for going up your arm, I try to imagine there's a line down the center of the short-stretch (actually they do sell them with lines printed on them, but I can't remember where I saw that). As I wrap up my arm I lay each round on the row before it with its edge on that imaginary line. So the overlap of each wrap-around is exactly one-half the width of the bandage. Rolling up bandages makes me crazy, so my husband took pity on me and bought a rechargable electric screw driver. On the base of the Phillips-head attachment he brazed on a length of welding rod so it runs parallel to the screw driver shaft just a fraction of an inch away from it. I insert the end of a bandage between the rod and the shaft and push the on button and it winds up the bandage for me. Saves a few tears of frustration here and there. Clear as mud, right? Ah, well, Tuesday isn't very far away! Hugs, Binney

If your fingers are wrapped, the finger gauze doesn't last as long as the arm and hand bandages, but you'll still have enough time to order them on-line before you need to replace them. Most insurance doesn't cover bandages, but it doesn't hurt to check. Everything's washable, but you need a lingerie bag so they don't wrap themselves around the washer thingy. The massage is wonderful, so do relax and enjoy it. Learn to do it yourself and do it right, with soft lighting, your favorite music and a peaceful mind and heart. The wrapping is bizarre, but doggone if it doesn't work like a charm. And the precautions really do become second nature. You can do this, otter. It'll be good! Hugs, prayers, Binney

When cording is on the trunk it's usually called Mondor's Disease rather than Axillary Web Syndrome (when it's in the axilla and arm). It's believed to be a thrombosed vein rather than a lymph vessel, though that's what they thought AWS was too until they actually studied it and found it involved lymph vessels. The literature says it's self-limiting and doesn't need any treatment except simple pain relievers, but I'm wondering if a lymphedema therapist with experience in treating AWS would be able to help bring relief of this as well. Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2013 02:45PM - edited Apr 21, 2013 02:48PM by Binney4 Tammie, I just went and read your original post about this on the Stage IV board and note that you mention warmth to the touch. In that case the immediate need is to determine if there is an infection called cellulitis in your leg. Both sudden unexplained swelling and warmth to the touch are symptoms. Cellulitis can "percolate" for a few days or a week, but when it takes hold it spreads rapidly and requires immediate antibiotic treatment to avoid systemic involvement. Please read my post to you on the other thread and get help right away. MUCH better safe than sorry. http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Be well! Binney
