Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2010 04:11PM Binney4 wrote: VickiLynn, hello! What your doctor is probably doing with the tests he's ordering is ruling out other problems that could cause swelling, such as blood clots or (ugh!) new tumors. Happily, the CT scan showed no such problems. If it's lymphedema, the PET scan won't show that either. Neither will an ultrasound, or a doppler. That's because lymphedema is not a pool of fluid that can be seen with these imaging techniques, but an accumulation of fluid in all the teensy spaces between the cells, where it can't be detected. Once he has ruled out the other causes, the next step would be to refer you to a well-trained and experienced lymphedema therapist, who will be able to tell you if it's lymphedema by your medical history and a physical exam (s/he has been trained to recognize the unique feel of lymph in the tissues beneath the skin -- my therapist says it feels like marshmellow fluff). Arm lymphedema can also be diagnosed by measurements comparing one arm with the other, but truncal lymphedema can't be measured because...well, because we breathe in and out and keep changing our chest measurement. So, likely no one short of a well-trained lymphedema therapist will be able to give you a definite diagnosis of lymphedema. Here's a page about how to find a well-trained therapist near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Do please let us know what you discover! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 09:28AM - edited Nov 16, 2010 09:31AM by Binney4 Oh, goodness! First, let me say that the NLN international professional conferences happen every two years. I went to the one two years ago (not as a professional -- as a patient in a special NLN program that trains LE advocates in lymph science). Two years ago was the first time pain with LE was even beginning to be acknowledged, and that came about because of patients like us raising a hue and cry about it. Yes, pain can sometimes indicate another underlying condition, and that should be considered, but pain is too often also from the LE -- period. But I mention this because it might help to know that the notion of LE being painful has only very recently been acknowledged by the professionals (lymphologists, researchers, therapists). Nicole Stout is behind the ball on this one. Sometimes words and concepts get in professionals' way, and this may be one instance of that. I've heard therapists argue that it's not the LE that causes the pain, it's the pressure that the swelling puts on the nerves, so it's actually the nerves that are acting up. Well -- hellooooo! The nerves would be all happy again if the LE went away, so I think we might be allowed to say that LE causes pain. We'll have to think about how to approach this with Nicole, but for myself, I'm not too worried about this specific problem, since in the last two years I've seen how the idea that LE is painful has caught on among professionals. Eventually she'll get it. One other item of concern here, though. Nicole Stout is, in fact, a very prominant LE researcher, and she's the LE point person that bc.org has turned to in the past for their "expert discussions" on LE. So you'll find her archived here on the information pages. My squawk with her is that in my opinion (humble and unprofessional as it may be) she's wrong in her statements that LE doesn't limit us in what we're able to do -- that we can "work up to" whatever we want to do or did before. In my own personal experience that is so not true, and many others here have said the same. I've stood on my head trying to "work up to" any number of activities I'd love to be able to do again but, no matter what, they make my arm and chest swell. So I'd say she has a sort of cloudy history of denying our reality. And to make matters worse, if bc.org is really revising their LE info pages like they say they are, this may be the expert they're consulting. So if anyone has any suggestions on how we might intervene here before bc.org comes out with outrageous claims, either about our pain or our unlimited abilities, let's hear it! Together we can make a difference! Binney

Research shows that weight gain, especially weight gained since the bc surgery, is a risk factor for lymphedema development. BUT! On the positive side, losing weight (even 5 or 10 pounds) benefits LE control, so as you lose weight you'll be working toward making this whole thing easier to manage. Yes! Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 08:45PM - edited Apr 16, 2008 09:01PM by Binney4 Welcome Bohara, Mackie, Kaymc and Bobo! Goodness, yes, Bohara! If it's too loose anywhere it's time to replace the sleeve. Six months is, as Bobo says, the usual guideline for replacement if you're wearing it daily, but if you gain or lose weight or have trouble controlling the swelling you may need to replace them sooner. New measurements should be taken each time so you're sure of a good fit. There are some ways to help make compression garments last well. Washing them every couple of days with a gentle soap can help them last. Avoid using a dryer. Don't wring them out. Just press the water out gently, then roll them in a towel (without wringing), then and lay them out to dry. Using a skin lotion that doesn't contain lanolin can help too, as lanolin is hard on the stretch fabric. The National Lymphedema Network (www.lymphnet.org) has a new program for providing garments for those who can't afford them, but it's so new the guidelines aren't clear yet! If you're on Medicare there's an advocate who will help you appeal for payment for your garments. He usually wins, but it's a long process. If you'd like his name and email address just ask and I'll be happy to give it to you. He is actively looking for Medicare patients willing to appeal, so that the rulings in his favor can be used as a precedent for changing the Medicare provisions. Mackie, at the moment there is no research showing that bioflavonoids help lymphedema, and I don't know of any in progress either. If you know of some, please share them with us. Thanks! Kaymc, redness is usually not a symptom of lymphedema, but swelling is. If the swelling is recent and wasn't there immediately following the surgery it may well be lymphedema. The medical professional who can evaluate that and tell you for sure would be a well-trained lymphedema therapist. You can get a referral for an evaluation with one from any member of your medical team. Here's a web site for finding a well-qualified therapist near you. Click on the Therapist Locator and follow all the links: www.mylymphedema.com  Again, welcome! I'm really glad you've all joined us! The Expert discussion tonight was really helpful, yes? Kathryn Schmitz is a real lymphedema research hero, and Nicole Stout Gergich is for sure on our side in dealing with all the lymphedema struggles. Neat! Thanks bc.org! Be well, all! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 02:11PM Binney4 wrote: Ruthbru, the guidelines for lymphedema risk reduction are not always well understood by our doctors, for the reasons Kira mentions. (What Dr. Rockson found in his survey was that many med schools don't teach it at all, and the average amount of time spent teaching about the lymph system across all the med schools, is a total of 15 MINUTES during the doctor's four-year medical training. So, no help there.) The issue of how much to lift, and how long to wait before lifting, is a lot more complicated than it sounds. There are no studies that show any guaranteed safe (or unsafe) limits or levels, and we're all different in the degree of fitness we started out with, the adequacy or inadequacy or our individual lymph systems, and a whole host of other risk factors (both known and unknown). So instead of mentioning specific weights or times, the guidelines have to do with building up your strength VERY gradually -- much more slowly than you might have before your bc treatment. You should pay close attention to your arm, stopping at once if it feels strained, achy, heavy, tingly, or just "weird." Stop, rest the arm, elevate it, drink plenty of water, breathe deeply from your abdomen -- and next time go even more gradually. Here are a couple of web sites with risk reduction information: http://www.lymphnet.org   (See their Position Papers on Risk Reduction, Exercise, and Air Travel) http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_lymphedema.htm Notself, hello! Checking your arms is a good idea, but early swelling is almost always missed by eye-balling. A visit to a well-trained lymphedema therapist for baseline arm measurements and help in learning to measure your own arms accurately might give you better protection. Also s/he would be able to teach you a gentle lymph self-massage, because direction, order, hand position and pressure are all important. It is not something anyone can learn without one-on-one direction and training. You mention aerobic exercise, which of course is great for any number of reasons. But depending on the exercise it can also send extra lymph fluid to the muscles and overwhelm an already-compromised lymph system. So careful attention to your arm and upper quadrant while exercising is very important. You might want to consider well-fitted compression garments for any exercise, whether aerobic or weight-bearing. A therapist can assist you with that as well. Here's a page for finding a well-trained therapist near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Eight nodes is actually quite a lot, Notself. Many women here have lymphedema with only SNB or even with prophylactic mastectomy. (I have bilateral lymphedema with one node removed on the affected side and  a prophylactic mastectomy on the other.) So, you're really wise to be thinking about your risk and simple ways to reduce and control it. Just wish our doctors would be our advocates in all of this! Since they so often aren't, though, do consider copying off helpful material and sharing it with them at your next visit -- we need to do all we can to protect the BC Sisters coming along behind us! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2010 01:43PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Keela, It certainly is alarming when we discover that our doctors know next to nothing about a side effect of treatment that is as monumental as this. We often have women who are shocked enough to contemplate changing doctors. It's everyone's own choice, of course, but the truth is that even some of the very best surgeons and oncologists don't know anything much about lymphedema, and few if any actually assume oversight of it even if they diagnose it and refer to a therapist. So changing doctors because of their lack of knowledge of lymphedema could be a very serious mistake. Instead, do consider educating your doctors and their nurses. If you're not defensive, and if you come armed with information they can use, from sources they respect, you will help not only yourself but also all the bc Sisters who come along behind you. Here are some resources you can use: The Position Papers of the National Lymphedema Network on Risk Reduction, Exercise, Air Travel, Treatment, and Therapists. They're here: http://www.lymphnet.org The pages from StepUp-SpeakOut about "What We Need Our Doctors to Know": http://www.stepup-speakout.org/what_we_need_healthcare_providers_to_know_about_lymphedema.htm Jobst (a garment company) has a free booklet for professionals called "Lymphedema -- Management Today." It's graphic, so if you order it for your medical team please be aware that those of us who are taking care of our lymphedema will NEVER face the extreme cases illustrated in the pamplet. You can order copies by calling BSN-Jobst toll-free at 1-800-537-1063. Go get 'em! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 12:40PM Binney4 wrote: Welcome, Nitocris! I'm so sorry for all the worries that bring you here, but I'm glad you found us. Like you, I had a prophylactic mastectomy on the other side, no nodes removed from the axilla, and I developed lymphedema on that side also. Dawn and Kira really covered the subject, but I'll just chime in with a couple of thoughts. Dawn's description is the same as my MLD routine: above the scars I massage toward my neck, below the scars and on my side and back I massage toward the groin. Your therapist should be able to help you make those changes to the MLD. From your description it does seem likely that you have some lymphedema on the prophylactic side. The redness that is still hanging on there may be an inflammatory reaction to the stagnant lymph fluid, and swelling is hard to measure, even with your eyes, after a surgery that changes the whole area so drastically. After surgery the scars can block the lymph flow, and delicate lymph vessels have been cut and may be unable to repair themselves with so much scar tissue and the oedema that resulted from the surgery. Are you using arm protection (sleeves and gloves or gauntlets) on BOTH arms? After bilateral mastectomies both arms are at risk, so wearing well-fitting compression garments when exercising or traveling or doing anything strenuous may help keep them in control. Neither arm should be used routinely for blood draws, blood pressure, or IVs. (Blood draws and IVs can be done in the foot, and blood pressure on the leg. It sounds worse than it is!) Here's an information page about chest lymphedema (it's called "truncal" lymphedema), with some ideas near the bottom of the page for bras, camis, binders and shapers that can help: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm In answer to your question about swelling on both sides of your chest, I have to say that it's no harder to treat both sides of my chest than it is to treat just one. The MLD takes longer, of course, but anything you wear for compression on one side works for both sides, whether you have lymphedema or not, so there's no extra compression garment problems. Nitocris, your English is wonderful, but if I've said anything that you don't understand please tell me and I'll try to explain it better. We're all here to help each other, so do let us know how you're doing, and how we can help. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2008 06:14PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Bearman, I wanted to address your concern about lymphedema (LE) with further radiation exposure. First, lymphedema might just as well result from blockage of lymph flow due to the cancer in the axilla, so it's a toss-up. Certainly relieving the discomfort is a serious consideration as well, since pain draws more lymph fluid to an already compromised area. I'd like to suggest an evaluation by a well-trained lymphedema therapist. Since there's currently no state mandated LE certification requirements you'll need to be sure that any LE therapist you see has had at least 135 hours of specifically LE training and preferably at least a year's experience treating LE. If the therapist is also a PT (rather than an OT) s/he should be able to help with the frozen shoulder as well. Here are two sites for finding therapists with those qualifications in your area: www.mylymphedema.com (click on the Therapist Locator and follow all the links) www.clt-lana.org (click on "LANA-certified therapists" on the left-hand side of the page) A LE therapist should take baseline arm measurements, give you plenty of prevention and coping tips, perhaps fit your wife for a sleeve and glove that may help relieve pain and/or teach her a simple LE massage to ease discomfort. There has in the past been some controversy over lymphedema therapy in the presence of active cancer, so I'll refer you to this thread from the LE board here where the subject was recently discussed: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/64/topic/708977?page=1#idx_14 (If that link doesn't work try copying it into your browser, and if that doesn't work we'll try something else). Hugs, prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 03:57PM - edited Mar 8, 2011 04:00PM by Binney4 CanDsmom, hello! I agree with KC and Kira that your next step needs to be either a heart-to-heart with your present therapist to discuss implementing the NLN treatment guidelines, or finding a new therapist. Treating it promptly and well makes a big difference in ease of management on-going. If you haven't yet ordered those new garments, you might want to hold off until you get proper treatment and all swelling is reduced -- or until you have a clear understanding with your therapist about why she's skipping the therapy in your case since there's already swelling present. Garments do not reduce swelling, they only contain it, and you want it gone. Here's how to find the options for therapists near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Yikes on the burn! Glad it's not looking angry at present, but do keep an eye on it and get help immediately if you notice any of the symptoms of infection. Keep us posted! Here's a page on lymphedema emergencies: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm As for exercise, the weight-lifting study has been seriously misinterpreted nearly everywhere. Better infomation is available by Kathryn Schmitz, the study author, at the National Lymphedema Network website. You'll find her warnings there regarding misinformation about her weight-lifting study. Best exercise for lymphedema remains water exercise, but any exercise at all needs to be started very slowly, and only once the swelling has been reduced and controlled, and while wearing well-fitting compression garments. Weight-lifting is NOT a cure or a preventative, but certainly exercise is an important part of both therapy and care for lymphedema. So, how were the cookies? Yum! Hug your little guy for us. Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2017 01:06PM Binney4 wrote: Lyn, the routine you described in your original post is considered the desirable standard. However, there are a couple of factors that change that. The first is the lymphedema stage. For instance, it's now considered acceptable to treat pre-clinical (or Stage 0, with early symptoms of discomfort and occasional mild swelling) with nothing more than a well-fitted sleeve and glove or gauntlet to be used for exercise and travel; and early Stage 1 (with more consistent mild swelling) is sometimes managed with just a few sessions with the therapist. The second consideration of how rigorously to treat is what's actually possible for an individual patient. If their insurance doesn't cover PT or (like you) their treatment exhaustion makes it unthinkable, there are modifications that can be made to suit your own situation. During your first visit, be up-front about the things you've mentioned here and work with your therapist to set up a schedule that works FOR YOU. That may mean, for instance, taking remedial measures now and putting off "the full whammy" until you're up for it, or making an effort to teach you self-care quickly so you can handle Manual Lymph Drainage (massage) and (if necessary) wrapping at home yourself. A lot of LE care is up to us, so speak up and expect some flexibility that fits your own needs. Let us know how it goes! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2012 12:52PM Binney4 wrote: Aw, Mimi, I'm so sorry! As if a mammo isn't bad enough without any other issues--what a rotten "surprise"! But brava to you for recognizing it quickly and taking prompt action. Is your therapy and the compression bra helping? As for next time around on the mammo, a breast MRI is a possible alternative, but insurance companies don't like paying for them. So you might want to start now to request that for next time, since you'll likely have to appeal it. Get whichever doctor on your team is most willing to listen to you and ask him/her to write you a letter of medical necessity for an MRI as an alternative to a mammo. Failing that, if a mammo turns out to be your only option, be sure your swelling is as reduced as it can be immediately before the mammo (see your LE therapist for help with that), and expect to do more frequent self-MLD afterward. (If you haven't learned self-MLD, see your therapist and insist on being taught--really important "tool" for self-management!) Stay especially well-hydrated in the days before and after, and plan to rest afterward as well. You may find that now that you're treating it, it will be fairly easy to get everything back in control, even with the stress of a mammo. Still, obviously best avoided! Do please keep us posted. Real gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 04:32PM Binney4 wrote: Yes, thanks, LindaLou! That's really helpful, especially the picture. Also your information on Joanne and her work over the years. Kira, I didn't hear the comment you mentioned about re-measuring to see if you still needed to use compression, but I'm assuming it referred to re-measuring and reassessing often, not just that if your arm is a normal size, then you don't need compression. I can sometimes go without compression on my left arm and hand (as long as I watch what I'm doing). But with my right, even though it's usually not measurably swollen, I can't go without compression at all or it swells again. About the "waffle" look (love the term, Jane!), I just wanted to add that the directional stitching on custom night garments is designed to match your own massage direction. Because of bilateral surgeries, for instance, my vest for truncal LE is different from one designed for someone with a single mastectomy. BUT, if you're using the Swell Spots, which also have directional stitching, you MUST be careful to place them so that the stitched seams go in the direction you want the fluid to flow. They're not just padding, they're for moving fluid in a certain direction. For those of you with more scientific minds than mine, the directional stitching (and consequently the amazing patterns we find on our bodies in the morning ) was invented by an engineer according to the Law of LaPlace, which has to do with fluid dynamics and the interior pressure of fluids against the walls of cylinders (that is, the pressure of lymph fluid inside our lymph veins). Exactly WHAT it has to do with that is well beyond me , but I'll bet some of you will get it, so I pass that bit of trivia on. If nothing else you can boggle the guests at your next dinner party by bringing it up during dessert, thereby distracting them from the gravy you slopped all over your compression glove... Isn't LE fascinating? No, huh? Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 05:42PM Binney4 wrote: Ouch! Hate to burst this particular bubble, Kira, but these garments aren't a substitute for therapy, just for night wrapping once therapy's over. The reason the custom garment won't work before therapy is that the swelling is reduced by therapy, so the garment doesn't fit the same. On the other hand, there are similar off-the-shelf garments (one by Solaris is called "Caresia") that you can use under the short stretch bandages instead of stockinette, foam, etc. It might help in your situation, but you'd need a good therapist to help you evaluate if that's best for YOU. (I meant to add to the other thread that even if a therapist is fully trained, that doesn't mean s/he's following the protocol she was taught, or that you'll hit it off with him/her. And this is a long-term relationship, so you definitely want someone you can be comfortable with.)  Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 10:36AM Binney4 wrote: Well phooey, mittmott! What a merry-go-round this bc treatment is! I'm so sorry you're having to worry about this now. I've gotta tell ya' that it's not normal to have swelling in your arm this long after surgery. And the swelling of lymphedema (LE) can start anywhere. A single finger, the upper arm, the breast -- you name it, we're all so different. But I also want to reassure you: if this is LE there is good treatment available. It's not invasive and doesn't involve any more drugs or surgeries. And doggone if the gentle massage involved isn't plain lovely! And what's more you've caught it early and can hope for a quick and probably complete response from treatment. Yes! So Tina's absolutely right: you can avoid panic on this one. You'll want a well-trained LE therapist (that'd be someone with at least 135 hours of specifically LE training beyond her OT or PT certification, and at least a year's experience -- preferably supervised -- treating LE. Call and ask before you go.) To find one near you, check out the links at the Therapist Locator, www.mylymphedema.com. Yet more great information about LE treatment at the National Lymphedema Network web site: www.lymphnet.org If it turns out to be LE, that's a steep learning curve, but you can do this, and you come out the other end with all the tools you need to manage this on your own, so you get your life back. Hang in there! Any way I can help? And let me know what you discover, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2011 12:04AM Binney4 wrote: Annette, there's a local therapist here who also believes she's doing something "new" with her rougher massage technique. She prides herself on doing things differently and thinks it's ridiculous to be so gentle with such a troublesome condition. But her patients do very poorly, and the better therapists in our area often end up having to undo the damage. I agree with Kira: the proof is in the results. It's great that you had that first session as a comparison. Can you get the first therapist back again? When you take off the bandages and get quick return of swelling it could be from several causes. Most likely is that the bandages were too tight, and the swelling you get when you remove the wraps is rebound swelling -- your body's over-reaction to the too-tight compression. Another cause could be uneven wrapping, with an area of tighter compression or more layers of wraps higher up your arm, which is the opposite of what it should be. When that happens it can create areas of swelling below the constriction that may not appear until the wraps are off. A third reason could be that you just happen to be a person whose LE needs constant compression, but since that's pretty rare it's more likely a wrapping problem. Good for you for raising these questions! Don't be afraid to insist on answers from the therapist team that's treating you. Let us know what you discover. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 04:20PM Binney4 wrote: Ah, Kane! So sorry for the official verdict, but I gotta tell you that with therapy and learning you will feel so much better, and so much more in control. Life-altering, yes -- but not life-destroying. It gets better! You're right that fitting a Michelin-Man arm into clothes can be a challenge. T-shirts work best for me, but I have a couple of shirts with wider sleeves (short sleeves) that work too. Jackets and coats are more of a challenge, though for short periods you can just leave your arm out of the sleeve (like you would if it were in a cast). Your DH's hoody sounds like a winner (assuming it's not hot where you live!) Night wear is also a consideration. You could cut a sleeve off an old pj top or just wear a t-shirt. For me, oddly enough, the nightwear was the toughest to deal with -- you just want to go to bed and be comfy and cozy and leave all these adjustments for the waking hours, y'know?  Wrapping experience with horses should definitely put you ahead of the game. This requires a careful compression gradient (more at the hand to less at the axilla), but if you're already skilled at using wrapping that will all come easily enough. What's more of a challenge, of course, is that you have only one hand to do this with. But this, too, is only a matter of practice. (Well, and patience!) Having your husband learn along with you will be a huge help and support, and it allows him to ask the questions he needs to to understand what lymphedema is all about. And he'll be able to help with the areas you can't reach to massage yourself, too. Cheers for him! Stay in touch with us, Kane, and let us know how it's going. Good for you for trying to stay up, but please do give yourself room to be sad or mad or frustrated too. We've all been there. So glad you could get an appointment so promptly! Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2010 09:41AM Binney4 wrote: Definitely, MOTC. And they're downright comfortable, too. They have gauntlets to match, but no gloves. Still, the sleeves are NICE. I recently discovered that if I pay for my custom garments out-of-pocket and buy them from the fitter, they are three times as expensive as if I buy them directly from the manufacturer. So if I were going 50/50 with my insurance company, I'd be better off buying them myself than using my insurance benefits. We need to ask questions. Jaysmom, custom garments are not a rip-off for me, because I can't wear most fabrics and the compression has to be low or I'm in trouble. Custom is a serious consideration also for any stubborn areas of swelling or places that flare frequently. Women with arms that are longer, thinner, or in other ways somewhat off the "norm" are not well served by off-the-shelf garments either. The technology involved in making garments (especially gloves) to fit the multiple complex planes of our hands, and still provide the proper gradient compression, is no small thing. (Which is why it's important to deal with both a fitter and a manufacturer who will care about making the fit right -- and also why it's frequently necessary to try, try again.) So it's understandable why custom garments are so much more expensive than off-the-shelf.   On the other hand, the mark-ups created by both the middlemen and the insurance industry are definitely way out of bounds, whether custom or off-the-shelf. But getting a proper fit is not a do-it-yourself project, so at least some of the time the help of therapists and fitters is essential (assuming, of course, that they know what they're doing!) The search for a competent fitter can be as taxing as the search for a great LE therapist. <sigh!>  Any change in arm measurements or weight, or any general dissatisfaction with the fit of the current garments calls for a re-measure. There's a product called "It Stays" which is a liquid adhesive you can apply to keep a sleeve top in place, because sometimes they can slip. But if it's a matter of the fit being off (either because of fabric fatique or reduction of your arm measurement), then it's time for a new garment. Lexislove, do you know how to wrap your arm? If not, you might want to consider spending your limited funds on a therapist who can teach and supervise you as you gain that skill. Wrapping is cheaper and more effective than garments, and it can be used whenever problems develop with garments. Just a very important tool to have in our LE toolbox! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2007 11:32AM - edited Nov 30, 2007 11:34AM by Binney4 Hi, all, Just wanted to add a few suggestions from your "Sisters of Swell" up on the Lymphedema board. The post-breast cancer wisdom is to use only electric shavers, due to the risk of nicking yourself with a razor and provoking lymphedema. But like Stressin', some of us have found the electric shaver burn and pinching just as irritating to the skin, and just as risky. So some use razors, either new or freshly sterilized in the dishwasher, but never dull or dirty ones. And we all keep a tube of topical antibiotic handy for nicks or scrapes. Personally, I've found the Conair Silky Soft electric shaver to be...well, silky soft, and safe for skin that's at risk. Helen, if you're wanting to mix up a batch of cornstarch/baking powder, you might want to put it into the toe of a clean cotton sock, close the top with a rubber band, and just pat it on where you want it. Saves on those messy spills that make the floor so slippery. You can keep the powder-filled sock in a pretty bowl on your dresser, where you can use it when you think of it. Somebody's going to come along and recommend Crystal Stick-type deodorant. I do use it, even now several years after rads. But being a klutz I sometimes drop or knock it onto the floor, where little shards break off, leaving sharp edges on the stick. These can be smoothed carefully with a piece of pumice, but do be careful not to use it when it's sharp, as you run the risk of nicking your skin. Just for easy reference, since we are ALL at risk for lymphedema (yes, even with SNB - in fact, even with a prophylactic mastectomy) here's the link for the National Lymphedema Network, where you'll find expert Position Papers on Risk Reduction, Exercise, and Air Travel for all of us who are at risk for developing lymphedema. (You're doctor didn't tell you this, right? Well, hey! What are Sisters for!): www.lymphnet.org Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2013 03:16PM Binney4 wrote: Kitty, the short answer to your question is: yes. But not necessarily as a result of the sleeve and glove. Truncal LE has its own reason for being--usually both node removal and scar tissue formation from surgery and/or rads. Pain is fairly common with truncal LE, doesn't usually respond well to pain meds, and can shift around from place to place and be hard to pin down. It's great that your doctor is acting so quickly on it. Treatment, which involves Manual Lymph Drainage and some kind of compression (bra, cami, sport shirt), eases both the swelling and the pain, and it reduces your risk of serious infection. Here's more information about it, including (at the bottom of the page) a lot of compression options: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm There are many of us here dealing with this, so please tell us how we can help. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2012 10:33PM Binney4 wrote: Purple, the largest lymphatic vessel in our bodies (the thoracic duct) is a big, deep vessel that runs vertically, belly to just below the shoulder, through the area of the diaphragm. Deep breaths stimulate that vessel and help to pump the lymph fluid. And since the lymph system has no heart-like pump to keep it thumping, the deep breaths are one way to affect the whole system. Besides, it calms us down--what's not to like?! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 02:44PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, MOTC, Thinking of you! Lymphedema gets to feeling like a mind game, partly because the early symptoms do seem to come and go, but mostly because our health-care providers take it so lightly. It's not a small thing, either medically or emotionally. But it's not something our docs treat, either, since there's no surgery or drugs involved, so they don't always know much about it. Shoot, most of the time they don't! The professional you need to see is a well-trained LE therapist. Earlier's better than later, because neglected, it progresses. That makes it harder to get control, longer therapy, more fuss.  The genetic thing has been suspected for a long time, but there's a recent study done in the UK that found that women who develop LE have lymph systems that are already working at top capacity, so surgery alone can trigger it, nodes or no nodes. We can't identify those women beforehand yet, so it's only an interesting discovery, not anything especially helpful. Except that maybe it explains this unfortunate link between you and your aunt. By the way, I've read conflicting studies on age as it relates to LE development. One says older age increases the risk, the other that young age is a risk. Maybe the conflict has to do with the younger ones having longer to develop LE, since the risk continues for life. Sigh! MOTC, I know you're swamped with the bat mitzvah, but your health is precious -- you're precious. You don't want progression, and you sure as heck don't want infection either (in tandem with LE, that can put you in the hospital on IV antibiotics for a few days or more). Your call, of course, but do think about getting help -- it could save you a lot of grief. Hope the plans are going well! Big hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 10:16PM Binney4 wrote: Jodi, hello! Have you consulted with your doctor yet? There could be several possible causes for this, and your doctor definitely needs to decide how to proceed. Some of them are emergencies, so if the swelling you're describing is new today or the last couple of days, please call your doctor right away and get his/her opinion on whether you need to be seen immediately. Since you posted this on the lymphedema board, there are a couple of lymphedema-related situations that can cause swelling in both arms and legs. If you have a port placed on your left side it's possible (but rare) for the port to compress the large lymphatic vessel called the thoracic duct, which can result in swelling of the left arm and both legs. It would not involve the right arm, which is drained by a different duct, and it usually disappears when the port is removed or adjusted. The second possibility is that bc surgery can (again in very rare instances) act as a trigger for primary lymphedema (that means lymphedema caused by a congenital weakness in the lymph system). In that case, all four limbs can be included, and the trunk can be involved as well. Such trama-triggered primary lymphedema is almost always a complete surprise (and not at all a nice one!) I do know women this has happened to, but none who had it happen this soon after treatment (I don't know of any reason why it couldn't happen this soon, but I've never run across that myself).  Since both those instances are quite rare, and there are other possible explanations, I'd suggest you check in with your doctors today and see if they're okay with waiting until after the weekend to diagnose it. You must be so stressed over this, and especially over not finding others here who have experienced it. Please know we're here for you. Do let us know what you discover, and if there's anything we can do to help. Real gentle hugs, Binney
Posts.Title: Lymphedema in all extremities? raincitygirl somanywomen

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 05:10PM - edited Sep 16, 2008 05:12PM by Binney4 Hi, Doe, I have LE in my arms and hands and both sides of my chest, back and sides. It was Stage II by the time I got a decent therapist. I had only a prophylactic mastectomy on my right side, where it started. The chest LE is painful whenever it swells, but when the swelling's controlled it's livable. On the left I had both a mastectomy with a single node removed and rads (due to the tumor being close to the chest wall. I have had fibrosis, but at the moment everything's soft and not stiff. I've had it since June of 2004, and I only had a Therapy Intensive once, but I see my therapist a couple of times a year for remeasuring and asking a zillion questions. She's a jewel! Blast me with a list of things you can still do without suffering because of it! Doe, I've been thinking about this question ever since you posted it. It's a really compelling one, because there are a number of things I can no longer do. Handstands, for one. And crocheting for hours at a time. Typing too -- a couple of years ago I bought a left-hand-only keyboard (called a FrogPad) and relearned key-boarding, so I'm back up to my former speed. I can remember the frustration and rage I felt with all these limitations right at first, but I no longer feel that way. There are a couple of reasons why I don't. For one, I'm actually proud of the creativity that I've managed in finding ways around the problems. The FrogPad is a great little thing, tiny but with full-sized keys and all the functions of a full-sized keyboard, and I'm tickled that I can use it well. I've gotten back into sewing in lieu of crocheting (though I use a rotary blade instead of a shears on most everything). Not everyone would value those things, but I've always enjoyed creative problem-solving, so it works for me. After breast cancer, we're all at risk for LE. The women who are trying to prevent it actually have more worrisome restrictions on their lives than I do. I don't have to worry about what I might do that will trigger it, I don't have nearly as much problem arguing with medical folks about using my arms (not that I don't have to watch them like a hawk, but they don't try to tell me LE isn't going to happen!) And when I want to try something that might make me swell, I can go ahead and do it. Sometimes there's no swelling, so I know that's a GO. And if there is swelling I know exactly how to get it back into control. So I'm free to choose to do things I wouldn't risk if I were trying to avoid LE in the first place. And finally, I had a funny experience watching the gymnastics at this year's Olympics. I was enjoying Nastia's incredible performance on the uneven parallel bars, all that swinging from her arms, and felt a pang I'd never felt before, a sudden realization that "now I'll never be a teen-aged gymnastics star"! Took my breath away for a moment -- and then I absolutely cracked up. I'm several decades past any such aspiration, but guess I'd never come to grips with that until I had that completely nutty thought. Poor me! No gymnastics! My life is ruined! (I do remember feeling something similar after my mastectomies -- I'd never be able to wear the super-tight, low-cut styles that I've never wanted to wear in my entire life, and I actually had a few moments of grieving over that. ) While the losses we incur from LE are very real -- and poorly understood by those who treat us -- in the end they're more like directional signs than red lights. It's not that the bridge back to our lives has been washed away and we'll never get back again, but that the route we're traveling is no longer as straight as we thought it was. We'll still get where we're going (well, maybe not to the Olympic gymnastics team, but it's not the LE that's holding me back from that!), but we'll see a lot more, experience more, understand more, and have a whole lot better idea of the lay of the land. So to answer your question, I can still do whatever I want to do. Everything. I'm not missing out on a thing. My Olympic aspirations aside, anything is possible. Soooo, what'd'you want to do? Go for it! Binney
Posts.Title: A Needed Focus lionessdoe lionessdoe

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 05:47PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Kerry, It's a matter of paying attention to your body. With power tools that'd mean stopping from time to time to let the sound and the vibration stop so you can sense what's going on. If your arm or hand is aching or feeling full or stressed, back off and try again later, for a shorter period of time next time. See what works and what you can work up to. Also body mechanics is important -- if you're hefting a heavy tool don't stretch to get it off the bench at arm's length, and lift with both hands whenever possible. And of course you have to work on remaining focused (not so easy to do with kids around!) so you don't saw your finger. What are you making? Let us know how it goes! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2010 01:27PM Binney4 wrote: Tina, this is a really important topic. I always feel that LE should exempt us from all other problems, but sure enough, it doesn't seem to work that way. The knee walker is a great help (and my son thought it was so much fun he was jealous and begged us to rent one for him to play with -- not!), but it doesn't work for things like knee replacements or anything higher than the calf. There's also a kind of "crutch" that you can bind to your bent knee and walk on -- kind of like a single stilt that you kneel on with the one knee. It gives you a lot of mobility, but again it only works for lower-leg injuries. Coming out of my (purple!) cast, my leg was pale, wasted and weak, but it sure did take the opportunity to swell once it got loose. So I did a LE compression wrap on it for a couple of weeks with some of my Artiflex and short-stretch bandages, and that took care of both the swelling and the pain. The ortho was amazed and called in his assistant to see how rapidly it had healed -- but when I told him about the LE wrapping his eyes glazed over and he lost all interest.  Wha'?! I did try crutches, but even with careful fitting and instruction about how to use them, my arms swelled and my chest immediately hurt. They said if you do it right you don't put pressure on your axilla (that was a surprise to me!), but just the weight on my hands caused swelling, so that was a no-go. Until I got the knee walker I was  stuck with a wheelchair, which in the house is like steering an ocean liner through an irrigation canal. Along these same lines, a few years back we had a Swell Sister, "Trixiegram," who fell and tore her rotator cuff on her good arm, so that was the end of her being able to wrap or do self-MLD on her LE arm, or even pull her garments on. She ended up with a nightsleeve with a zipper for easier donning, and a Flexitouch pump to use daily for MLD. Just a nightmare, but she figured out what had to be done and got on with it. I sure will be interested to hear what others have to share here. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2012 04:33PM Binney4 wrote: Diann, welcome to bc.org! Glad you found us, really sorry for the reason you had to! Do you mean the doctor is removing fluid with a syringe, or that your lymphedema therapist is moving it out of the breast with Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD) Massage? You don't say what you've been doing to deal with your arm lymphedma, but if you don't have a lymphedema therapist (or the one you have hasn't done a Therapy Intensive with wrapping and MLD), here's how to find a well-trained one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm The fluid build-up that happens with lymphedema isn't the sort that pools, like a seroma, so it can't be removed with a syringe. If what you're talking about, though, is lymphedema in your breast, then here's information about that (and at the bottom of that page are links to lots of different compression ideas for breast swelling): http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Since you mention that the swelling was sudden and extremely painful, please do watch for any possible infection and get help AT ONCE if you suspect that. Here's a page about infection with lymphedma: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Diann, I sure hope some of that is helpful. Please let us know how we can help. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2015 05:50PM Binney4 wrote: Anna, the trick is GETTING to a higher altitude. Usually once there your body will acclimate to the pressure change and you can manage your lymphedema in the usual manner (whatever that may be). After traveling to a higher altitude (wrapped, or with day or night garments) keep them on for a few hours (or until bedtime, if they're your day garments). One problem with travel is the unusual activities that often presents--lugging suitcases, new activities or, especially at a family reunion, hefting toddlers. �So be watchful for things like that. Stay really well hydrated, do some deep abdominal breathing throughout the day, wash out your day garments every evening so they're clean and fresh, and be careful of sunburn and insect bites. Oh, and have a GREAT time--anyway! Please do let us know how it goes. Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 10:15PM Binney4 wrote: Etherize, I agree with Cathy that this is not likely a big health issue. Lymph nodes can swell for any number of benign reasons -- infection of some kind is one possibility. But done correctly, MLD is more likely to reduce infection risk than cause it. It's hard to get MLD pressure right, partly because we're so earnest about it. It just seems as though more pressure is better for moving the stupid lymph fluid along. But in fact, the lymph vessels are delicate and they lie just below the skin, so too much pressure smushes them instead of opening them up the way we hope to do. The right amount of pressure is just what you'd use to pet a kitten -- not even a full-grown cat. Think kitten, and think slooooooow. As Kira's therapist famously says, the lymph system is slow and stupid. Kitten-petting gentle and stupid-slow is what's called for. Sometimes it's easier if you turn the lights down, light a sweet-smelling candle and play some slow mood music while you do MLD. Make it a home spa treatment! Let us know what the doc has to say. Hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2012 11:04PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Cindy, Really glad you've got that surgery behind you! Hope you're resting up, getting some pampering and healing well.  Do you already have a lymphedema therapist? If so, she's taken arm measurements all along, right? She should have the record of your other arm as well. You'll want to see her on a regular basis for follow-up, so you can track your progress with your LE arm and keep track of the other side as well. If you DON'T have a well-qualified LE therapist, you can ask any doctor on your team for a referral. Here's how to find a well-trained one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm S/he will take baseline arm measurements that you can use for follow-up comparison, each arm being compared over time with the earlier measurements. And s/he can also evaluate your current swelling and help you learn to get it under control and keep it that way. All good! Best of all, LE care is non-invasive, and there are no drugs involved--whew! Quite a relief after all we go through with the bc. Please keep us posted. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 05:38AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, dlt and Julie, I'm really sorry you're dealing with worries about this stuff. I have lymphedema on my prophylactic side, no lymph nodes removed. It started in my chest and side and underarm. I didn't get good help from a well-trained lymphedema therapist promptly and it spread to my arm and hand. I still wasn't aware enough of what was going on to take the necessary precautions, and I now have it on both sides of my chest, back and sides, and in both arms.  The medical professional you need to see for this is a fully-trained lymphedema therapist. You can find one near you by checking out this page: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Not every lymphedema therapist has a lot of experience with truncal lymphedema (which is what you call it when it's in your chest, back, side or axilla), so make sure the one you see has experience with it. Here's an information page about truncal lymphedema: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Dlt, do ask any member of your medical team for a referral to a lymphedema therapist and get help soon, so you can hopefully prevent further problems. Early lymphedema does come and go, but if you get early help you can hope to prevent progression. Julie, it is very soon after surgery, but that's no guarantee you're not dealing with lymphedema, or won t be in the future. A referral to a lymphedema therapist can be a real help. S/he will do baseline measurements for future reference and help you with personalized lymphedema risk reduction tips.  Do please let us know what you discover, and tell us how we can help. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 01:27PM Binney4 wrote: Tamantha, I'm so sorry about the fear and the pain. Achiness and heaviness are early signs of lymphedema, yes. An evaluation by a well-trained lymphedema therapist would be a great idea, as treating it promptly can relieve those feelings. Here's information on finding a therapist who's qualified: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm And yes, overworking your arm could certainly contribute to developing lymphedema. But seeing a therapist and having her help you with compression garments, exercises, and gentle massage will allow you to get back gradually to an active job. The hard, hot, swollen breast on the non-operated side is not likely to be lymphedema unless you've had radiation to that quadrant of your body. A port placement might also cause lymphedema, though that alone would be a very small risk. But those are symptoms of cellulitis, which can be either sudden and active or "smoldering" for a while before taking off. So if you or your doctors suspect infection there for any reason (a port, perhaps?) you'll want to get treatment quickly. Tamantha, I hope the lortab is staying ahead of the pain for you and allowing you some healing rest and sleep. Thanks for being a nurse and taking care of those who need you -- do take care of you, though, as you are precious and deserve to be treated with gentleness. Let us know what you discover. Hugs, prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2013 10:14PM Binney4 wrote: Kimber, hello! Really sorry you've had to join our Sorority of Swell. I know this isn't good news, but you really need to do the therapy intensive that your therapist recommended. It's not optional, especially considering how far out of control the stupid LE has gotten. I do get it about your work schedule, but this is a serious issue that needs to be addressed right away in order to get the best and quickest results--and especially to avoid your very real risk of serious infection that goes along with untreated LE. Please do consider this, because you're well worth taking the time to get this under control, and now's the time to do it. Definitely before your surgery, because uncontrolled LE will increase your post-surgical infection risk and slow your recovery time. The lymph system is part of your immune system, and it affects your entire body, so gaining control now will definitely help normalize your strength and healing, which will enable you to deal with the stresses and job and family responsibilities. Please take care of YOU! No pump is a substitute for therapy, but it is a substitute for self-MLD in the "maintenance stage" (once professional therapy has ended). If at a later date you choose to use a pump for part of your self-care, node clearing before use is standard, though a complete self-MLD is generally not needed. (Kicks, the "pump guys" are not authorized to offer medical advice so can only refer us to our therapists for suggestions about pump usage, but your therapist should be weighing in on node clearing before pump use. You might want to have that discussion, as it can avoid some problems over time.) I just completed a therapy intensive for new lower leg LE, a result of the fact that the lymphatics are indeed a body-wide system, so I'm busy trying to fit leg care into my LE routine, and make sense of the new MLD directions and order. Fortunately what's good for arm/truncal LE is also good for leg LE, but there's extra MLD to be done daily, and things like gravity to contend with--ugh! Hugz, my intense empathy for the disappointment of having to struggle with new truncal swelling and to get the stupid arm LE back into control. You can do this! Hang tough, Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 03:59PM Binney4 wrote: Azz, when women are dealing with lymphedema before/during rads, their lymphedema therapists usually recommend compression garments (or special lymphedema wrapping of the arm) during that time, but no lymphedema massage to any area affected by the rads (chest/breast/axilla). The reason is that even that kitten-petting-gentle massage can compromise the skin, which becomes tender and fragile during treatment. If an arm is affected by lymphedema, then some therapists will continue to treat the arm only (though that is not especially effective) and wait until rads is over and the skin well healed before doing anything else. Any massage in the radiation field that was firm enough to break up scars or fibrosis would definitely have to wait. Waiting to heal is so hard! And there's no way around it that I've found. Just keep reminding yourself that rads DOES end, and then you can begin to take back some control of your life. Very gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 08:30PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Chris, Some of the women here use pumps, mostly Flexitouch, which is a sequential pump that does a better job than earlier types of pumps. I believe it's made by Tactile Systems. There's another sequential pump made by BioCompression that I think has the same kind of features. I hope some of the gals will be along soon to share their experiences with you. Pumps are usually covered by insurance, even when therapy and compression garments aren't, because until a decade or so ago MLD therapy wasn't much available in this country, so that was standard treatment, and insurance has never caught up. A pump is not usually necessary, though it's really helpful for people who for one reason or another are not able to do the MLD themselves. Be sure your therapist teaches you to do self MLD effectively, as well as self-bandaging. Those are more portable and adjustable "tools" to use in controlling LE. If you get a pump, you still must do adequate clearing of nodes so that the pump doesn't cause fluid to back up into your shoulder or chest, and always use it with the supervision of a well-trained LE therapist. It doesn't sound like your therapist is in this category, but there are some therapists who use a pump to cut down on the time they must spend with their patients. In that case, it's a shortcut you may want to avoid, as you deserve the hands-on attention which is the only way an experienced therapist can stay aware of possible problem areas. Okay, all you pump users, let's hear from you! God bless you, too, Chris, Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2011 01:01PM Binney4 wrote: Julie, best bet would be to get a referral from any doctor on your team to a well-qualified lymphedema therapist for baseline arm measurements, personalized risk reduction tips, learning a gentle lymph massage that can encourage lymph flow, and fitting for a compression sleeve and glove or gauntlet (fingerless glove) that you can use prophylactically for exercise and travel. When you start back to any kind of exercise you want to begin veeeeery slowly. If it's tennis you're after, start with just the arm, working up to just the racket (no balls), and go from there, over time. If you experience any achiness, heaviness, or just a "strange" feeling in your arm, stop at once and elevate your arm and rest. You can try again the next day, stopping before that point, and continue to work up more gradually. Stay well hydrated, as it helps move lymph fluid. There is no "safe" amount of time after treatment -- the lymphedema risk remains for life. An all-clear from your surgeon or onc only means in terms of incision healing or fatigue. It's a rare doctor who knows enough about lymphedema risk to advise patients on that score. Which is why a well-trained lymphedema therapist is the go-to person for the kind of information you're looking for. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Fifteen nodes out does increase your statistical odds, but even one node is enough to result in lymphedema in some women (me, for one!) You're really wise to be asking these questions. Wishing you a strong recovery and no "swell" days ever! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2008 05:53PM - edited Apr 17, 2008 06:05PM by Binney4 Hello, IL, I'm so sorry about your mom's new diagnosis, and so glad you're there for her. This is a difficult and scary time, but a special time too. This time you're able to really share the cancer battle with her, and you may find some of your roles reversed. My kids were so precious and helpful to me throughout my treatments, caring for me actively in ways I'd always cared for them. It's a privilege, I think, and I hope you'll find the fierce joy in it as the two of you stand together in new ways. The point you're at now is one of the hardest. Before long your mom will start treatment, which at least helps you know that you're doing something about it. In the meantime, please just forgive your dad and put him aside. Anger drains all the creative energy you need to draw close to your mom and tune into her needs. And it can't change the present realities in the least (except to make them even more unbearable for you). Direct that anger instead toward the real enemy: breast cancer. Put all the passion you can muster into your prayers for strength and healing. As to the complications of age and other medications and conditions, I suspect that most of us are in that same category -- cancer in young women is considered to be the exception. With caring doctors we manage to do well. You both will too. I'll be praying for you both, with joy. Take your faith firmly in hand, IL, and go for it! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2014 05:38AM Binney4 wrote: Blood pressure on the leg runs a bit higher than the arm (mine, for instance, is about 10 points higher). I found when I first started using leg bp that it made me crazy and tense because I didn't know if they were doing it right. Once you've recovered you can stroll over to your local fire department and ask them to do a leg bp for you every few days, so you can get a leg bp baseline, since it's different from arm bp. Let us know what you discover. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2016 03:42PM - edited Feb 28, 2016 03:43PM by Binney4 vshowe, does your PT have training in fitting a Circaid Reduction Kit? If so, you sound like the perfect candidate for one. It does make the daily wrapping much quicker, and the therapists I've talked to about it say it works about the same. I don't think it will deal with fingers, though, so those may need to wrapped separately. Once reduction has been stabilized (by whatever means), a night garment like Kicks described is a life-saver for ease of night use. Doesn't work as well as wrapping for everyone, but it sure does work for me. And I, like Kicks, have to be very careful not to wrap too tightly or get garments with too high a compression factor, or I swell. That said, it's still important to learn to wrap yourself, and to continue to practice that skill monthly, because it's a great DIY tool to have in case of a flare. If your therapist isn't good at dealing with hand/finger LE, for goodness sake get a "second opinion" from one who has some experience. Fingers can be harder to manage than an arm, but there are so many options for getting it under control and maintaining it that you don't need to be discouraged about that. Kinesio tape is definitely worth a try. Do let us know how it works for you. Kicks, here's information about the Circaid Reduction Kit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0T85hsb07OA Hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 01:32PM - edited Jun 22, 2010 01:34PM by Binney4 Good morning, CAW! Armpits are the...uh, the pits. (Sorry about that -- got halfway through the sentence before I realized what I was saying.) But they're not impossible, and I'm betting you'll get this under control and that feeling that you're smuggling walnuts under your arm will go away. Just takes some trial and error. Here are a couple of options, depending on how much area you need to cover. On this page, check out the "Kimbe spot": http://solarismed.com/store/cart.php?m=product_list&c=4 You wear it with the inside curve under your arm. It extends several inches in front and in back of your armpit, so if that's all that's bugging you it's probably enough. And on this page, look at the "thora-thigh spot": solarismed.com/store/cart.php?... The curvy place goes under your arm and the two sides extend much further across both front and back. It's especially good for that pesky back swelling that's so hard to cover with any bra or cami. They're both bulky -- this is not an item to wear under a tight T-shirt. I use a Kimbe spot (it was named after Kim B., the designer who came up with it many years ago, BTW) and I just stuff it under my bra or cami. It tends to migrate toward the front if I'm active, so on one of them I hand-stitched a square of the "hook" kind of Velcro, and that gets a grip on my bra and holds it in place better. I haven't tried the thoro-thigh spot, but I'd bet it wouldn't move around at all.  At night you might be more comfortable holding it all in place with a breast binder (get the lined kind -- more comfortable). The Expand-A-Band ones come in pretty colors and patterns: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_binders_lymphedema.htm On the swell spots, the site I gave you is the manufacturer (Solaris). Sometimes they're cheaper from bandage supply places like BandagesPlus, so look around before you order. If your insurance will cover them you'll need to order them through your DME supplier. I haven't ever looked into insurance for swell spots, but I think I will next time I order one. Not sure how they'd write the prescription! The whole point of controlling the swelling is to keep the lymphedema from progressing. Controlling it helps to prevent infection (which causes further damage to the lymphatics) and to keep the excess protein in the stagnant lymph fluid from doing it's damage (which includes fat deposits under the skin, fibrosis caused by tissue inflammation, and skin changes). So the answer is yes, you can prevent it from getting worse. Whether you can keep it out of your arm or hand depends more on the kinds of risk reduction strategies all bc patients can use to hold off LE. It is definitely NOT inevitable. Here's' page of them: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_lymphedema.htm Never apologize for asking questions about LE, CAW! The more we all ask, the more likely we are to be heard and to spur more research and better care. Without all our very loud and persistent questions there will never be any answers. Onward! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 07:45PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Leah, There's no way you can add a silicone band to a compression garment. The whole thing has to be fit perfectly and with the right degree of stretch, so if you sew something onto it you've altered it and could cause lymph blockage. What you can do is order a bottle of It-Stays, which is a brush-on skin adhesive that works well for keeping garments in place (assuming you aren't allergic to adhesive, of course!) Bandages Plus stocks it and ships internationally. http://www.bandagesplus.com But nowdays most brands of sleeves do come with silicone, so I'm betting it won't be a problem. Do ask your fitter to be sure. People with leg lymphedema are the ones who generally have problems keeping their garments in place, due to all the walking and the steady effects of gravity. We've rarely heard anyone here complain about garments slipping down (assuming, of course, that they were well fitted in the first place -- a too-big garment will slip, for sure.) Let us know what you discover! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 12:08PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Mimi, I'm really sorry your mom is dealing with the stupid truncal lymphedema (LE). Please give her a hug from us "Sisters of Swell" and tell her we send our best wishes. I know your question is about the safety of treating LE in the presence of cancer (which, by the way, is up to the doctor, not the therapist -- it's long been assumed that treatment that moves lymph fluid is not a good idea with metastatic cancer, but recent research evidence is finding it to be safe). But I just have to tell you that Deep Oscillation is not standard treatment for any kind of LE. The treatment for truncal LE is Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD), a kind of gentle massage that a therapist performs daily for two to five weeks (or more) until the swelling is reduced, followed by fitting for a bra, cami, or compression vest that will control swelling, ease any pain or discomfort, and help prevent the threat of infection that goes hand in hand with LE. Many of us have had difficulty finding proper and adequate LE treatment, especially for truncal LE, because there are no states yet that mandate training standards for LE therapists. So we have to be our own advocates. And what we should insist on is a therapist who has had at least 135 hours of specifically LE training beyond her PT or OT certifictation, and preferably at least a year's supervised experience treating LE. You'll want to ask about the amount of experience treating truncal LE too, since it's less well known than arm LE. Here's a web site where you can find a fully-qualified LE therapist near you. Click on the Therapist Locator and follow the links: www.mylymphedema.com In other words, since you and your mom are both "a little nervous about that," I'd suggest that you go by your gut feelings and look around for at least a second opinion. The National Lymphedema Network has a couple of Position Papers that might help, one on Therapy and another on Therapist Training: www.lymphnet.org Mimi, thanks for your advocacy and care for your mom. I wish you both comfort and confidence as you search out the very best care for her LE. Please come back and ask if you have any questions going forward. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2008 03:48PM Binney4 wrote: Doe, I'm so sorry. It's a roller coaster, for sure. Don't move to a different house unless you want to for some really good reason (the dream job? a huge pay raise? or the dream house?) Why grant this rotten condition that much control? Go ahead and set some goals. Short-term, long-term, and everything in between. Make them realistic for the degree of depression you're feeling, but otherwise as wild as you like. Want to go kayaking for two weeks along the wild Canadian coast? Start now to get your body toned and in shape, plan the supplies you'll need to pack along, get some swimming time in. In between, take a look at Jane's compression pics and choose one to try. Order whatever thing you decide on and then forget about it until it gets here. Back to the salmon and the Sitka deer and the pine forests dipping their roots right into the surf as you paddle past. Order a bear bell from an Alaskan supplier. When the compression thing comes, try it on. Wear it for an hour or a day, or sleep in it at night. Make a decision on it and either order a couple more or toss it and try something else. Then go check out a few library books about edible plants of the Northwest Coastal forests, or the healing properties of the Devil's Club plant and how to harvest it. Order a hand-knit quiviut scarf or shawl from one of the Native craft cooperatives, to snuggle into as you sit beside the campfire in the evening cooking fresh halibut fillets and a pot of wild dandelion greens.  You're so right -- this is grief. And grieving is hard work. You're doing just fine with it, but it still takes time. Make whatever moves you can toward whatever you think of as wholeness. Go easy on yourself, and do celebrate every small step forward. Chocolate's good. It'll be good! Hugs, prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 12:05PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Leah, That's a matter of personal taste, but my experience is -- I hate the strap. Uncomfortable and pesky. My sleeves stay in place well anyway with just the silicone-studded top band, but you might want to ask your fitter if the sleeve brand she's ordering has a band to help it stay in place or not. Hopefully some strap-users will be along shortly to give us a more positive take on it. Once you have your sleeve and glove, do make sure the fit is good. Here's a page about making sure the fit is right: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_lymphedema_garments.htm Wear them for short periods at first and gradually work up to wearing them for longer times. They're also useful for when you're packing, since that involves a lot of tugging luggage around -- or for any time you're exercising, traveling, changing elevation, or doing any unusual activity. Leave them on for an hour or so after you land so your system can adjust. Also, do stay well hydrated on your trip, take some deep abdominal breaths at intervals, and do simple exercises with your arms (and legs too!) throughout the trip to encourage lymph circulation. Have a great trip! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2015 02:38PM - edited Aug 26, 2015 02:41PM by Binney4 Swede, I'm so sorry for this new worry--bummer! I agree with Nordy and would encourage you to get to your doctor (or critical care) right away. The risk of infection is high, and you don't even want to think about not treating it immediately. Please do let us know what you discover. That said, it sure is possible that what you're seeing is "truncal" lymphedema, which can occur without any arm involvement. It can also cause redness and warmth in the breast (because lymphedema is an inflammatory condition). Generally those symptoms are treated first as an infection, since that's an emergency. If the antibiotics have no affect, then the treatment would be lymphatic "massage" (Manual Lymph Drainage) by a well-trained lymphedema therapist, and gentle compression. Here's information on breast (truncal) lymphedema: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunck... And here's information on infection (cellulitis): http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Med... Hoping you have real help and answers soon. Keep us posted! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2012 12:47PM Binney4 wrote: Tomatojuice, do you feel ill? Flu-like? Lymphedema is an inflammatory condition, and sometimes (especially with truncal LE, frequently on breasts) it can cause redness that looks like infection. Since it can be hard to differentiate it from an infection, it's best to treat first with antibiotics. But if that doesn't clear it up it might be time to consider it as in inflammatory reaction and treat it as such (antiinflammatories, MLD to reduce the stagnant fluid that is aggravating the area and causing the inflammation).  This is tricky because with an infection you wouldn't want to do MLD, but it's actually the most effective treatment for inflammation. Something to ask your therapist about, at least. Keep us posted, and get well quick! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2010 09:48AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, all, Hope it's okay if I just jump in here for a minute to respond to Lisa-at-the-shore, as I happened on her post about laser hair removal. Lisa, you might want to re-think that idea. Here's why: you want to avoid not only skin breaks, but pain, because pain draws lymph fluid to the area and could cause a back-up in your already-compromised lymph system. And since some of our gals who have done laser hair removal report some irritation and pain to the area, that's a lymphedema risk as well. Here are some lymphedema risk reduction guidelines, including a link to suggestions for safe ways to shave under your arms: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_lymphedema.htm Also, the "Lymphedema After Surgery" forum here at bc.org has lots of posts on this subject that you can find by searching "shaving" under the Lymphedma forum. Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 11:59AM Binney4 wrote: LindaLou, I'll try to answer that, and hopefully Kira and OneBadBoob, who are following this more closely than I am, will correct any misperceptions I've picked up along the way. Dr. Mei Fu at New York University is doing some studies concerning this problem of measurement of LE, since it's so basic to ANY lymphedema research for all the players to be on the same page regarding standards for diagnosis and measurement -- otherwise their results indicate little about the reality, and studies can't be compared to one another to gain further insights. So she's looked at and compared bioimpedence, perometry, water displacement, and tape measurement, as well as various scales for patient reporting of early LE symptoms. What she's discovered is that bioimpedence is most frequently inaccurate, missing a majority (I believe) of the actual confirmable LE. In order to continue her LE research, in fact, she's had to purchase a perometry unit, which is extremely expensive and only measures limbs, not truncal LE. So there are limitations with everything we currently have available. She now recommends using all those techniques in combination for the most accurate approach to both clinical diagnosis and research. Along with that, though, is the LACK of research to confirm the accuracy of bioimpedence measurements. But I'm not sure how they'd set up a study to do that, since it's the ONLY method put forth to detect sub-clinical levels of fluid accumulation. Mei Fu is busy (understatement!) but accessible, so your former therapist might want to contact her regarding her findings (which have not to my knowledge been published).  Or she'll be at the Conference in September, if your therapist plans on going. Frankly, I'm bummed. (So is Mei Fu, for that matter.) A reliable measuring technique for early detection was an idea that held soooo much promise. Hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 10:30PM Binney4 wrote: Hmmm. I can't answer all of your questions, but I can sure tackle the last one. It used to be believed that ANY lifting, or even any use of the affected arm could bring on lymphedema, which is swelling caused by damage to the lymph nodes and vessels that normally carry lymph away from the cells and back into the circulatory system. (The lymph fluid is there because it's the body's garbage truck, bathing the cells and carrying off any nasties, to be dealt with severely -- it's part of our immune system. Which is why stray cancer cells end up in our lymph nodes.) Anyhow, that's not the belief anymore. Research has proven that exercise (even weight-lifting) is actually helpful to both preventing and controlling lymphedema. In fact, the April "Ask-the-Expert" on-line conference here at bc.org will be about Lymphedema and Exercise. Great! Okay, but there are precautions, and picking up an angry 25-pound dog five days after a mastectomy is, as you suspect, pretty much over the top. Still, it sure is understandable, so don't waste too much energy beating yourself up. What you need to do going forward is avoid straining the arm or tiring it, always. So as you recover, take it real easy, but do keep on exercising (preferably starting with the post-mastectomy exercises you got from your surgeon or the nurses at the hospital). The "no pain, no gain" philosophy is a thing of the past for all of us. For more information on lymphedema Risk Reduction, Exercise, and Air Travel check out the Position papers on those subjects at the National Lymphedema Network web site: www.lymphnet.org. Once you've read those you'll have more updated information about lymphedema than your friend's doc does! Of course that's not what you were asking about -- more like, could it do damage to the surgery. So I trust others will be along shortly to address those concerns. Be well! Binney
