Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2014 01:37PM Binney4 wrote: Welcome, both of you "stars"! I can just imagine what a struggle it would be to convince a doctor that you're dealing with abdominal LE, when so many of them can't identify garden-variety arm LE, not to mention upper truncal. It is rare with bc treatment, but certainly not unheard of. I have some abdominal LE too, also mostly on my right side (my LE is bilateral in both arms and trunk, but worse on the right). It's hard to make suggestions without knowing what you've already tried. Do you both have well-trained LE therapists? Have you been taught to do Manual Lymph Drainage with emphasis on the abdomen? Are you clearing neck and groin nodes at all throughout the day? Do you wrap your arm? Has your therapist taught you other practical helps, like staying really well hydrated, using deep abdominal breathing, or doing simple LE exercises at intervals throughout the day? I can manage my abdominal LE with just those measures (and I wear a WearEase cami called a Slimmer that also adds gentle abdominal compression), but many people with abdominal LE use biking shorts to control swelling. It's also possible to order custom abdominal compression garments, but I'd sure try the other methods first. Lots of things can affect abdominal LE, just like arm LE. Barometric pressure changes, extreme temperatures, lack of exercise, the wrong sort of exercise, weight gain, and for some people salt intake and alcohol. If you can identify triggering mechanisms, that can help your therapist design a self-care program that will help you take control of this and get your life back. If you need a new therapist, or even just a second opinion, here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified... There are a couple of suggestions here for abdomen/upper leg compression--they'll give you an idea of what kinds of garments you can look for: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Compression_camisol... And here's a discussion of Swell Spots and other garment inserts--the one on this page are specifically for upper body truncal LE, but they are designed as well for use with abdominal swelling: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/foampadding_swellsp... StellaStarr, LE is lymph fluid that is trapped all over in the tissues, not pooled like the fluid in a seroma that can be drained. The way to drain the lymph fluid in LE is to clear nearby nodes and gently move the fluid out of the area and toward the nodes by the manual technique of Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD). A well-qualified LE therapist will be able to design a personalized flow pattern for your situation to effectively move that fluid out. Then compression garments keep the fluid from building up again. None of this is easy, because LE is chronic, but practicing some self-care does give us back control. Insist on getting the great help you need! Gentle hugs, and please, both of you, tell us how we can help, Binney
Posts.Title: Abdominal Lymphedema Only StellaStarr Bcky

Posts.Content: May 13, 2013 12:45PM Binney4 wrote: Tresa, hello! Good question! And it has a good answer: cancer spread is far more complex a process than that. Good thing, too, because if exercise and the gentle lymph massage were a danger to moving cancer cells, we'd have to sit absolutely still for the rest of our lives to avoid trouble! Any movement of our muscles moves lymph fluid. The superficial lymph vessels lie between the muscles and the skin, and the pressure of those muscles moving against the lymph vessels is the major way that lymph moves, since it has no pump like the heart. So anytime you move, you're stimulating lymph flow. Which is what you want, since it's a crucial part of your immune system. Hope that helps. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2007 05:43PM Binney4 wrote: Lynn and all, It's a problem with our medical professionals that they often have little or no experience with lymphedema and may seem to misdirect us. (The medical professionals responsible for the diagnosis, prevention and treatment of lymphedema are specially trained lymphedema therapists, to whom your oncs and surgeons should refer you, since their own training does not include this area of expertise.) The type of bandages to safely wrap an arm at risk for lymphedema looks like an ACE bandage, but it's entirely different and acts very differently. Lymphedema bandages are "short-stretch," meaning they don't have anywhere near the elasticity of an ACE bandage. They're specially ordered from a lymphedema medical supply provider. They must be applied over a layer of stockinette specially cut to fit over the arm and hand, and a layer of thin foam or soft, strong cotton wrap, and the wrapping of the short-stretch bandages must then be done with the firmest compression distally, gradually working proximally with decreasing pressure. Generally at least three layers of varying widths of short-stretch bandages are applied over the stockinette and foam base layers. It takes most of us a couple of weeks of practice, supervised by a specially trained lymphedema therapist, to learn to do it safely and effectively. If you are already used to dealing with medical applications of bandages you might be able to learn it more quickly, at least if you are also already familiar with the action of the lymph vessels. The specific gradient wrapping technique for lymphedema allows the muscles underlying the lymph vessels to act as a lymph pump by applying gentle pressure and pushing the lymph in the proper direction, as determined by the gradient compression of the bandages. Applying an ACE bandage to your arm has a different action. It actually cramps the lymph vessels shut and blocks flow in exactly the same way that a blood pressure cuff does, overloading the already-compromised lymph system and quite possibly resulting in lymphedema. Or to put it simply, never apply an ACE bandage to your at-risk arm. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2008 02:16PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Jill, Actually I just today got the latest issue of the National Lymphedema Network newsletter, with figures on the incidence of BREAST lymphedema following various treatments, and I was shocked to find out how much company we have in this. Here's what it says: "The incidence rate of breast lymphedema after a lumpectumy alone is 6%. This rate drastically increases with nodal dissection and radiation therapy. The incidence of breast lymphedema after sentinel lymph node biopsy and radiation therapy is 23%; with axillary lymph node dissection and radiation therrapy it is 35% in node negative patients; and 48% in node positive patients." (There are footnotes for each of those statistics that lead to substatiating studies. I'm guessing the difference between the node negative and node positive rates is because with positive nodes they do more fields, and therefore irradiate more lymph nodes.) Who knew?! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2015 03:58PM - edited Jul 20, 2015 04:00PM by Binney4 exbmxgrl, how disappointing! But, hey! there's hope for both reduction of the swelling and on-going good control. But you need a plan, and just wearing compression and staying off your feet (impossible when the new school year starts!) are not all the strategies available to you. If you don't have a great lymphedema therapist, now's the time to find one. I too have LE in one leg, and a "toolbox" that includes lots of possibilities for keeping it under control. I wear a properly fitted stocking daily (and I have an Ez-As donner to help me get these things on. For difficult days I use a Juxta-fit leg garment that has Velcro closures, and for nighttime a custom Solaris leg garment that pads my hip as well (extra comfort). For REALLY trying days there's a leg garment for the Flexi-touch pump that helps drain the abdominal area as well. And I learned self-MLD for my leg from my therapist--easier for me than arm self-MLD because I have both arms free to do it! I do keep my leg elevated at night with a pillow, but you can also just elevate the legs of your bed on a two-by-four--even those couple of inches can make a difference. As for "vanity" (I'd call it simple self-confidence!), you can purchase day garments that are panty hose and come in several attractive shades. They can look "normal" and control swelling at the same time. Please do let us know what you discover. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 01:44PM Binney4 wrote: Good morning, Jennifer! I'm not quite sure what you mean, but I'm assuming you're noting two different things: the Position Papers at NLN. And various other LE boards The Position Papers were developed by the board and advisors of the NLN, after a complete review of the available credible research. It's a consensus paper, and they're all subject to change as new research becomes available. As for LE forums, you're right about that. The ones there are on-line are not specifically bc-oriented, and they're often slooooow boards. How about if I start a list of the LE boards I know about with a strictly personal brief review, and all of you add others that you know of as well as your opinions of all of them that you're familiar with? Here are a few, in no particular order. As always on-line,  it's Buyer Beware! LymphNotes http://www.lymphnotes.com This site has lots of very readable articles about all aspects of LE. I don't trust their Resource pages because I think some of their sources (who pay to list) are hokey. Just MHO. Their discussion boards are interesting but very slow.There are a few women there who have BC-related LE, but mostly they seem to be primary LE or lower limb. Still interesting. people like that, though, who have waited years for a diagnosis of their LE and have been told to lose weight or take diuretics all these years, are often understandably discouraged and unmotivated, or searching for quack "cures," so it's not always encouraging or helpful. But for me at least I still find it valuable. LymphedemaPeople http://www.lymphedemapeople.com This is Pat O'Connor's website. He’s had long-time primary LE and cancer, and he's a fountain of information. He relies on research for his information base and he has an amazing network of people he can call on to help answer any baffling questions. His website too offers an abundance of articles, and these are updated continuously. Advocates For Lymphedema http://health.groups.yahoo.com/group/AdvocatesforLymphedema This Yahoo group includes a number of LE advocates and therapists as well as patients who are interested in influencing legislation or simply awareness of all kinds of LE, not just cancer-related. This is my favorite site for keeping up with new research and discussing its implications Lymphland http://health.groups.yahoo.com/group/lymphland/ This active Yahoo group includes all kinds of LE and it’s chatty and friendly, but not research oriented so it can get off track at times Komen http://apps.komen.org/forums/ Komen has message boards, but none devoted specifically to LE. There are fairly frequent mentions of LE, but there’s no particular organization or expertise here. Association of Cancer Online Resources http://www.acor.org/ The LE discussion group here includes only cancer-related LE, but from all kinds of cancer, so it includes leg LE. You can ask anything and expect a fair amount of discussion. There are some advocates and experts here who hold the line where unfounded treatment ideas are concerned and keep people abreast of new developments Johns Hopkins Avon Foundation “Ask an Expert” http://www.hopkinsbreastcenter.org/services/ask_expert/ This board generally directs folks to treatment at JH. A number of people in the LE community have vocally questioned the accuracy of their “answers” on the LE board in the past, so at least now they're more accurate, but they’re very scanty in their detail and tend to direct you to treatment rather than answer specific problems BC Support http://www.bcsupport.org This site has a specific discussion board for LE, but it’s slooooow, with little discussion on any given post and little information available. No oversight regarding accuracy. Please add others that you frequent, all. Jinky, I know you have your finger on some others… Thanks! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 01:46PM Binney4 wrote: Yikes, cbr! That's a whole lot of pain to deal with! I sure hope you can get relief soon. Oof! I wonder if you've seen a well-qualified lymphedema therapist? The problems you're having, both with the carpal tunnel and the elbow, are often associated with lymphedema. Before any swelling is visible or measurable, there can be as much as a 30% increase in lymph fluid volume in your arm, and this extra pressure on your nerves and the extra weight on your joints and connective tissues can all add up to real problems with carpal tunnel and tennis elbow. In that case a more conservative approach to treating it all is Manual Lymph Drainage therapy done by a lymphedema therapist, which will move the excess fluid out of your arm and relieve the pressure. It's well worth checking out. Unfortunately, the lymph system is not much taught in U.S. med schools, so our doctors are often not aware of these options. A consultation with a well-trained lymphedema therapist will both diagnose any fluid build-up that may be unmeasurable, but also give you help (and consultation with your  doctors) with any surgery that may be necessary. for help finding a qualified therapist near you, check out the links on the Therapist Locator at www.mylymphedema.com. I pulled up another thread for you called "Carpal Tunnel Syndrome with Lymphedema, anyone?" Though you have not been diagnosed with lymphedema, the advise there and the articles that are linked will apply to an arm at risk for lymphedema as well. I also sent you a private message. Be well, and keep us posted! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2014 10:59AM Binney4 wrote: Lia, please don't apologize for your great post--it's not too long and not out of place in any way!  The lymph system is a whole system, for sure, but it's also divided into quadrants in terms of how it drains. The quadrants are like chicken quarters, and in our case it's a wing quarter that's involved: hand, arm, shoulder, and front and back of the torso from the waist up, and as far over as the center of the body. Manual Lymph Drainage works the nodes in the neck first, since they accept fluid from this quadrant, and it works the nodes in whatever part of the body the therapist plans to send the lymph to--in the case of a unilateral mastectomy that would be the opposite axilla; in the case of bilateral surgeries, that would be the groin. Then the therapist works within the quadrant that's affected, moving the fluid toward the nodes. So, no, it's not necessary to work the entire body in order to treat LE. And yes, that would be great and it sure wouldn't hurt anything! Next best is to do the necessary MLD to the involved quadrant and then also do some targeted exercises that help the whole system to flow better. Sherry Lebed has an exercise DVD and some Youtube videos available that are specifically designed for that purpose. I quit doing them daily for awhile and just started up again because for me it's really important to controlling my LE. You can order a DVD here: https://www.gohealthysteps.com/shop/ As for the general ignorance about LE among our healthcare providers, here's information written specifically for them by a doctor who has LE. You might want to make some copies and pass them out to your array of nay-sayers. We shouldn't have to educate our doctors about a serious medical condition like this, but then again it really is our privilege to do so--the women who come after us deserve better! www.stepup-speakout.org/essent...… Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 07:18PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Kim, I'm really sorry about the lymphedema worry, and the expectation that you have to diagnose this all by yourself! But I have to say that your experience sounds a lot like mine -- that sense of "imagining things" and not being able to get it confirmed one way or another. I went around for months fearing it was "all in my head." Very unsettling! There's no way to measure breast/chest lymphedema, because we breathe and that changes the measurements. Arms are a different matter, of course, but when it's in our chest instead there's no standard criteria to use for diagnosis. Which leaves us with having to trust our own sense of what's going on. In your case the fact that the bra fitters mentioned it to you is actually significant. I'd trust them on that and go for treatment. I can't tell from your post whether you were evaluated by the therapist or just talked to her. If she did a physical exam she could likely tell from the feel whether there's lymphedema there or not. But that's still a somewhat subjective judgement call. The proof of truncal lymphedema is sometimes only in the treatment: if Manual Lymph Drainage helps reduce swelling and the sensations you're experiencing, then it's lymphedema. (There's a test called lymphoscintigraphy, but it's invasive and not available everywhere, and since you've had bc surgery there's already a basis to believe that what you're dealing with is lymphedema). All that just to say, yes, I could see why a therapist might tell you that. More helpful would be to ask her how much experience she's had treating breast lymphedema, and what treatment she would offer you if she determines that's what you're dealing with. Does any of that help? Do keep us posted! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 08:00PM Binney4 wrote: mcgis, hello! I didn't do herceptin, so I'm sorry I can't answer your question. But I will say we don't hear about that happening here on the lymphedema board, so at least we can say it sure isn't something that happens always. Radiation can make lymphedema worse, or at least harder to manage. Do you have a good lymphedema therapist? If so, do talk to her/him about this. Do you have well-fitting compression sleeves and gloves that you wear regularly, or can wear regularly during rads? That helps to keep the swelling in control throughout. Staying well hydrated is essential too, and now that the weather is generally cooler (in the northern hemisphere at least) it can be hard to remember to keep drinking lots of water. Plan to elevate your arm whenever possible, even at night on pillows. If you know how to wrap, consider wrapping more often during rads. If you don't, do insist on learning how to do that--it's a great tool to have in your lymphedema tool-box for anytime you travel or experience a flare. You're right--this is a really crummy accompaniment to bc treatment, and it adds a lot of frustration to an already-difficult situation. We're all here for you--please tell us how we can help. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 02:28PM Binney4 wrote: MOTC, Dr. Stanley Rockson at Stanford conducted a survey of U.S. medical schools just a couple of years ago and found that the average amount of time spent teaching the lymph system in a doctor's entire educational career is 15 minutes. That's an average, of course: some schools (he found) don't teach it at all. I mentioned that to a friend here who's a doctor and she told me that was not at all accurate for her own training. In fact, she said, at her school they spent a lot closer to 20 minutes on the lymph system -- nearly a third more time than the average! Dreaming, I hear you on the frustration of dealing with uninformed doctors, but if we all fired all the surgeons, plastic surgeons, oncs and PCPs who don't know squat about lymphedema we'd lose almost all of them, even some of the very best in their fields. The standard CDT treatment for lymphedema has been practiced in parts of Europe for a very long time, but it's much more recent in the U.S., and it's taken a lot of re-gearing to develop training programs for lymphedema therapists (who are the only LE specialists we have in the U.S., since there is no recognized physician specialty in lymphology here.) Even now there are no training requirements mandated for LE therapists in any state, so plenty of untrained and undertrained PTs, OTs and MTs accept LE patients they really haven't got the skill to treat. But they're free to call themselves LE therapists, and the referring doctors don't know to check out their training (even if they had the time to track it down, which they don't). Even accupuncturists have to meet certification standards, but not LE therapists -- so how's a doctor to know that? Unless, of course, we patients tell them. Some doctors will listen to us, some won't. Research has also been nearly non-existint until very recently -- at present we're experiencing something of a LE research Renaissance, so hooray for that, at least! MOTC, your surgeon is definitely the exception -- next time you see him take him some brownies and tell him we all salute him! As for the rest of us, onward! We're our doctors' last, best hope for educating them on this CRUCIAL subject! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 09:11PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Tina, Welcome to the sisterhood of Wrapped Wonders! Wrapping is not anybody's idea of comfortable but, no, it shouldn't hurt more than it did before. On the other hand, it's heavy and may be causing grief from the unaccustomed weight, so before you unwrap try elevating it on something soft and comfortable for a bit and see if that helps. If not, you sure wouldn't be the first person to ever take the wraps off! You didn't mention Manual Lymph Drainage massage, but hopefully your therapist did that for both chest and arm before wrapping, yes? That would be the accepted and necessary protocol, although some therapists shortcut and neglect to do it. If she's been properly trained she should know how to do that, and you should expect it. For what to expect from therapy, you might want to see the Position Paper on Therapy at the National Lymphedema Network here: www.lymphnet.org And this page about therapists from the StepOut-SpeakUp site: www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Wrapping the chest or breast is usually not done. Instead, massage is followed by wearing a compression vest or bra. Some options are here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Hope some of that helps, Tina, and that you manage a restful and painfree night. Enjoy the snow for me -- I'm a desert rat! Very gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 07:07PM Binney4 wrote: Manatee (not sure how you chose that screen name, but I love manatees), we can only do what we can do--beyond that we make our own compromises. But even then we give ourselves the best possible chance for a good outcome. If you're going to use your LE arm, it's better to use it for blood draws (where you're not adding anything) than for IVs (where you're adding fluid to an already compromised system, which may not even be able to deliver the IV contents predictably or effectively). Feet and neck can be used for IVs (as you seem to have experienced), and if you use them right off the bat instead of trying your "good" arm first, the whole process will be less painful and stressful. Keeping your LE in excellent control will make using that arm for any purpose less of a potential problem. Afterward, keep a close eye on it for infection (even delayed infection, as cellulitis can "percolate" before making itself known). Elevate your arm, stay extremely well hydrated--basically, follow all the guidelines for a flare even before you have one.  Plan to visit your LE therapist as soon as possible after any "insult" to your LE arm, for extra treatment and evaluation, as well as management tips. If after using your LE arm you do develop an infection, or even intractable new swelling, then you'll need to reconsider. But for now, considering the distress you've had to deal with, please don't beat yourself up for trying less-than-ideal ways to manage your healthcare needs. LE is bad, but it's not all we have to deal with, and sometimes it just needs to take a back seat to other considerations. JMHO. Please keep us posted. Gentle hugs, Binney
Posts.Title: IVs and other sticks manatee64 Binney4

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 10:41AM Binney4 wrote: As long as we're discussing bloodwork prep that makes blood draws easier, I'll mention my routine. Surgery's a special case, since you go into it already thirsty. For that I don't take their "No water after bedtime" or "after midnight" at face value but check with the surgeon about EXACTLY how many hours before surgery I have to stop drinking. Not only do I guzzle water the two days prior, but I set my alarm for the specified time and get up and drink all I can hold then. Otherwise it can be waaaaay longer than is actually necessary, especially if you're not scheduled first thing in the morning. For blood draws, I checked with my doctor about taking aspirin beforehand--thins the blood and really helps it flow. Since I'm bilateral, I have a footdraw order too. I make sure to exercise (walking, jogging--gets the blood flowing) before going, wrap my foot in a microwave heating pad (being careful not to get it to hot) for the trip there, and in the waiting room keep walking or bouncing my leg up and down--everybody looks at me like I'm crazy, but it really helps. Legs stagnate when you're just sitting there. I always ask to lie down. For some reason they don't always think of that themselves, but it's much more efficient for them than bending over my foot and trying to reach all their supplies. They can lay everything out right there. I switch the heating pad from my preferred foot to the other, just in case the first draw fails and they need another foot. Then, for some reason, I've found that deliberately relaxing all my muscles makes the whole process much easier. Not only hurts less, but it seems to make the vein access easier, too. So I concentrate on slow abdominal breathing and relaxing. Don't know how much of that is actually physically effective and how much of it is just a ritual that soothes me, but...whatever helps! Donna, were your sports teams called the Manatees? They're such noncompetitive creatures it would be about like one of our community colleges here whose athletic teams are The Artichokes. Goooo, Manatees! Goooo Artichokes! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2012 04:31PM Binney4 wrote: Mimi, the videos from NW Lymphedema Center (the first link that djls gave you) are good for reviewing what a therapist has already showed and taught, but each individual's actual massage direction and order needs to be developed with their specific conditions considered. Scar tissue, type(s) of surgery, location of fibrotic areas, and other health conditions all need to be taken into account. Still, they're good basic instruction for self-massage. Youtube has a number of videos, many of them aimed more at spa-type lymph treatments. Of the two above, the first one is a fair introduction to at least the order of a lymph drainage routine, but it leaves out most of the actual process. I do like its emphasis on slowness and light touch, though. The second one it simply misleading, and I'd suggest you avoid it. Calmness, relaxed muscles, and a very slow, very light touch are all important. It should be relaxing! Hope some of that helps! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2010 06:37AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Montrial, Sorry you had to join us "swell" gals, but glad you found us. Dozens of the women here have contributed to the Lymphedema StepUp-SpeakOut.org site, so it's full of practical information about living with lymphedema. When you have some time you can browse the site, and it sure helps to know you're not alone! On the "Lymphedema Garments" page at StepUp-SpeakOut you'll find links to lots of garment makers. Since fitters and therapists usually deal with only one or two brands, it helps to know what others are available so you can introduce them to other brands they may not be familiar with. each brand will have its own special strengths, so you should be able to find some with features you need. For instance, some (like Bio-Concepts, Barton-Carrie, and Gottfried) come in a wide range of colors. Others offer fabrics with different features -- either softer or firmer -- or one manufacturer may have a variety of fabrics. My own favorite is Gottfried, both because the fabric is soft and comfortable and because they offer an elbow lining that cuts down on elbow irritation (and feels wonderful!). My fitter likes them because they have great customer service, which is another quality to look for in the brand you choose -- if the garments are not working for you, you need to be able to return them for adjustments or a remake. The page at StepOut-SpeakUp about "Proper Fitting of Compression Garments" will help you understand how to "shop" for sleeves and gloves that will work for you. All the brands suggest replacing them every four to six months, and you'll find out what works best for you as you try them out. Partly, it depends on how much you wear them. I need mine daily, all day, so I replace them every six months -- but I do find the old ones go on being useful for "dirty" activities like re-potting plants or working with paints or marking pens (I'm sorta piggy!), or even for large-scale cooking adventures. So don't toss the old ones when your new ones arrive! Some of the women here wear their garments only when they're having trouble -- on hot days, say, or when they're exercising or traveling or doing something tedious like cutting with a scissors, or after a salty meal of pizza. Whatever bugs them individually. Others have to wear them all the time. With the help of your therapist, you'll discover what works best for you. Nighttime is a different matter entirely. The daytime garments should not be worn when you're sleeping, because they're designed to work with your moving muscles to help keep the lymph flowing. So most of us wrap our arms at night or wear special night garments that are quilted fabric stuffed with foam chips. These are not sexy, as you can imagine, and they're toasty (unless you store them in the refrigerator during the day -- seriously!), but they're reasonably comfortable and they're easier to put on than wrapping. Again, your therapist should be able to help you determine what you need to do at night. The garment page on StepUp-SpeakOut.org includes night garments as well, so you can get an idea of what they look like. I'll leave the video suggestions to others who I'm sure will be along. Your therapist is the one who should teach you to do these things, so jog her on that if she isn't doing it yet. Videos can be good memory refreshers, but the actual skills can only be learned in person, as there are so many factors to be taken into account. A good book with illustrations and instructions for both wrapping and massage is "Lymphedema: A Breast Cancer Patient's Guide to Prevention and Healing" by Burt and White. Again, it's good as a reference, but your therapist should check out your skills at both before releasing you. As 3jaysmom suggests, it's important to learn to wrap your own arm and to do self-MLD massage, so that you have the tools to control your lymphedema wherever and whenever it needs extra attention. The learning curve is steep, and it can be really frustrating to learn it all, but in the end it really pays off in independence and taking charge of your life again. Glad to have you aboard for this crazy ride! Be well, Binney
Posts.Title: New at Lymphedeme montrial kcshreve

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2010 03:49AM - edited Jun 23, 2010 03:50AM by Binney4 Estepp, I'm so sorry you've had to join our "sorority of swell." It gets easier, honest. Nobody ever told us we had a lymph system, much less what would happen to us if it got wrecked. And for most of us, our doctors don't seem to know much about it either. (Like you, my onc told me I was not at risk because I was thin, so apparently that's another of the myths that have made the rounds of the med schools.) According to Burt and White in their book "Lymphedema: A Breast Cancer Patient's Guide to Prevention and Healing," (which is a great little reference book to have on hand, BTM) the short stretch bandages help in several ways. + they form a semirigid support that the muscles can work against, which improves the muscle's pumping action that causes the lymph vessels to contract and move lymph fluid + they influence the movement of fluid in the teensy spaces between cells so it will move into the lymph vessels + they increase the total pressure on the tissues, which makes the tiniest lymph vessels take in more fluid, and which also causes the tiny artery capillaries to dump less fluid into the tissues in the first place -- great double whammy! + they prevent fluid from reaccumulating in the tissues + and, even though they're as ugly as sin, they actually have a cosmetic function (who knew!), because they improve and maintain the shape of the arm by keeping the amount of compression consistent throughout treatment So, lots of good things going on out of sight (and certainly out of our comprehension!) while we wear the stupid bandages. And moving your muscles while wrapped improves all those functions even more. Estepp, the more you can wear them the better and quicker your results will be. Hang in there! Tell us how we can help! Real gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 05:59PM Binney4 wrote: Ooh, shrink, how lovely! Where are you cruising? Hmmmm. The food is a serious consideration, for sure -- VERY likely to cause swelling, but not necessarily in your arm -- yummm! My guess would be you'll be fine on the cruise. The compression garments are not meant to reduce swelling you already have -- that's what the therapy is for. So unless the sleeve and glove are now too tight, you might still get some value out of wearing them, as they'll help prevent further swelling. If you're cruising somewhere hot, try to stay as cool as possible. Stay out of hot water, as in a spa or hot tub, but swimming is great and may even bring some of the swelling down. Eat hardy! But do try to stay away from too much salt. Stay hydrated (that'd be water -- no, margaritas do not count!), and while you're lounging around on the deck it won't hurt to keep your arm elevated. Let somebody else do the heavy luggage lifting (how hard is that!) And enjoy! Bon voyage! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2011 09:10PM Binney4 wrote: Computermouse, that is not a dumb question, but I can't say the same for the conclusion they offered you. You're right -- with the L-dex bioimpedence device they put the little gadgets on your arm. Painless, quick. The only problem with it is that folks who are using it don't "get it" about what it is they're measuring. It measures the amount of tissue fluid volume. Not the lymph flow, not the stage of LE, not even whether you have LE or not. It is NOT a diagnositic tool, but a monitoring one. There are no standard numbers that show that you do or do not have LE, but only (over time) whether you have more or the same amount of tissue fluid volume. The way it SHOULD be used is to monitor your arm consistently with every visit. The first reading tells them nothing, it's the trend they're supposed to be looking for. If the next few visits show gradually increasing tissue fluid levels, then it's a good guess you have LE. Or if you have LE already, it can tell you how you're doing with control of stagnant fluid. Here's a danger that we're all going to be facing if this method of measurement becomes popular: if they try to diagnose LE using this machine, some of us with LE (especially well-controlled LE) may no longer be eligible for insurance coverage -- especially if they start telling us our LE is not LE but causd by scar tissue and blockages. Scar tissue can create blockages that cause LE. The fact that the blockage is caused by scar tissue doesn't make it some other kind of swelling -- if the lymph fluid is blocked, for whatever reason, you have LE. That, in fact, is what a lot of truncal LE is, and some of the arm LE too. Of course there CAN be other kinds of swelling -- like swelling caused by blood clots, for instance, or kidney failure. But that's another whole diagnosis. Please, c-mouse, NEVER think any question regarding LE is stupid -- you're one smart lady to be asking questions! Hugs, Binney
Posts.Title: New LE Position Paper NatsFan lalisa

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 05:36PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Guitargal, If you're in Phoenix today (I am!) then you're sweating it out in more ways than one! It's 108 at the moment, heading higher as the afternoon drags on. As Beesie so aptly says, you can't know until you know. And as Lisa says, the waiting is aaaaaaaugh! I can SOOOOO understand your wanting to hear happier resolutions than a cancer return. (It isn't often anyone thinks of lymphedema as a "happier" anything, but in your situation it's sure understandable!) At any rate, nothing you describe so far would rule out a lymphedema diagnosis. Ultrasound is not diagnostic for lymphedema, nor does it show as fluid if (as you might expect it to) if lymphedema is present. That's because in lymphedema the fluid doesn't pool into pockets (like it does in a seroma or even a cyst). Instead, it disperses among all the cells. That's also why it can't be aspirated like seromas and cysts can. Basically, there's no diagnostic test for lymphedema (or I should say, there aren't any that are commonly used), so with your symptoms the doctors are really trying to rule out everything else it could be. And since we're cancer veterans, one of the things they try to rule out is more cancer. Don't be surprised if their next recommendation is a doppler or CT scan to rule out a blood clot, which can also cause swelling. "Very swollen, tender, and warm to the touch" can all describe breast lymphedema (which is actually called truncal lymphedema, but that always reminds me of elephants.). Unfortunately, they can also describe the beginnings of a cellulitis infection that's often associated with lymphedema. So if there's new or spreading redness, or if you develop even a slight fever (you might start taking your temp a couple of times a day if you aren't already doing that), you'll need to get help immediately. No "wait and see" with that. Geesh, I'm so sorry you're having to suffer through this waiting time. We sure don't ever get used to it, do we?! Sending you big, very gentle (((((hugs)))))), and prayers for quick and happy answers, Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 12:57PM Binney4 wrote: Rosered, hello, I have palm swelling, but no problem on the top of my hand. My therapist says it's unusual (she told me jokingly that my lymph system must have been installed upside down!), but it's certainly not unheard of. I do find the Solaris Palmar Spots really helpful, inside my wraps or inside my gloves. The worst thing for making my palms swell is leaning on my arms -- as in riding a bike or just standing next to a table and leaning on it with my arm straight, or kneeling on the floor and supporting myself on one arm while I clean up a spill. Even resting my elbow on my desk and then resting my head in my hand. Boom! Practically instant palm swelling -- <sigh!> The MLD massage for palm swelling adds another step. Because the top of the palm drains to the back of the hand, take the fingers of your opposite hand and gently run them up your palm and between the fingers of your affected hand. Do that several times before clearing the back of your hand and hopefully you'll see some reduction. Another idea besides the Palmar Spot is, when you are ready to order gloves, it helps if the person fitting you adds a bit of "give" to the measurement around the palm. Otherwise, the way our hands are made, too tight compression pulls the sides of your hand inward and the fabric doesn't even touch your palm when your hand is at rest. If the measurement there is a bit looser it results in greater compression in the palm area. Hope that makes sense -- works for me so I usually don't have to use Palmar Spots, which make my hands sweat in the summer. The Palmer Spot is used for back-of-the-hand swelling too, by the way, because it tightens the fabric across the back of the hand as well. Hope I didn't just make this more confusing! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 10:30AM Binney4 wrote: LindaLou, thank you! I sooooo agree that it would be so much better if we had research evidence to help us make all these impossible decisions. There has been an explosion of LE research in recent years, but even with that there are way too many unanswered questions. Risk rates for various triggering events would be especially helpful, but they're so complicated. What our lymph system is like even before bc is undoubtedly a large factor, but at present we don't even have a way to determine that. So much more to learn -- really glad we have such a wealth of researchers now who have a passion for LE. Onward, all of you research heroes! One thought occurred to me in reading your post, LindaLou, and that is that an at risk arm may in fact be at serious infection risk as well. Before any swelling is visible or measurable by our current means there can still be up to 30% more lymph fluid stagnating in the tissues than is normal due to the compromised lymph system. If we could find a way to accurately detect that early LE we'd be way ahead in terms of making these kinds of decisions. Bioimpedence has been touted as a way to do that, but in practice it's proving to be unreliable, so we're back to Square One on knowing what's really going on in our at-risk arms. <sigh!> KC, if you go with the leg bp during surgery, the calf is a whole lot more comfortable than the thigh. Keep us posted! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 07:04AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Bradswife, What you're describing sounds like "cording" (it's also called Axillary Web Syndrome or AWS). It's a thrombosed (plugged up) lymph vessel that's actually fairly common after breast cancer surgery. It can run from your armpit to your thumb or anywhere in between and can sometimes even be seen or felt in places along its length as a tight cord. It can be treated with gentle stretching exercises and usually resolves in a few months. It sometimes returns, so you'd need to do the exercises again. A knowledgeable therapist (preferably one fully trained in treating post-breast cancer lymphedema) can help you with the stretching and easing of the tightness. Here's a page about cording from the StepUp-SpeakOut site: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Cording_and_Axillary_Web_Syndrome.htm Hopefully that'll at least give you another idea to pursue.   Sure hope you get complete relief soon! Hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2010 06:31AM Binney4 wrote: Montrial, I hope lots of others will post with their preferences so you'll be able to "shop" with confidence. I have night garments by both Solaris and JoviPak. They're similar. I like Jovi's fabric better, but the Solaris fit is better. Solaris will also put a full arm zipper in my sleeves, which Jovi won't (I've never been able to find out why not -- for me, with bilateral LE, the zipper is a huge help with donning and getting out of it all in the morning, but it's not a feature everyone needs, for sure.) Both companies will make either a one-piece sleeve/glove combo or separate sleeves and gloves. I prefer the one-piece, partly because I hate losing gloves and I'm too oblivious to keep track of them when I slip one off to do something. The other thing I like about the one-piece is that it's more comfortable at the wrist.  Jovi will sew a special pad into the palm of their gloves, and I don't know if Solaris will or not because I've never asked. I'm not especially crazy about the customer service with either of them, but my fitter really likes dealing with Solaris (although she's learned not to deal with one person there -- why is this all so complicated!!!) Jovi has some innovative designs and will listen to your fitter's ideas about what you need (but won't talk to you because you're a patient -- wha'?!!). Solaris is a bit less adventurous, but their basic ideas are sound and, for me at least, they always fit well. In actual use, they both last about two years (even if the warranty is only for one year). Neither is adjustable like the Circaid, though both companies will make adjustments for a fee. Their fees are not very cheap. On the other hand, both the Jovi and the Solaris are soft and will fit in your refrigerator on summer days so they're nice and comfy-cool when you put them on. They're both washable and dryable, too, which is very handy, especially if you tend to wear them around the house during flares or when traveling and are sorta piggy like me. There's another company called Peninsula Medical (which for some reason isn't on the StepUp site -- we should fix that) that makes a stiff, adjustable-type sleeve called a Reid Sleeve, and a soft, directionally stitched foam one similar to Solaris and JoviPak. (They also send out free lymphedema alert bracelets for the asking, either one for yourself or a couple dozen for your bc support group. Their employees fill those bracelet orders on a volunteer basis, on their own time -- I think that's incredibly kind. Kudos, Peninsula!) I hope someone who uses one of these will come along and tell us about them. They're here: http://www.lymphedema.com All of which was probably more than you even wanted to know. Sorry -- got carried away! Have a great trip anyway, even if you have to do the stupid wrapping! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 09:31AM Binney4 wrote: Montrial, that's really interesting that he would insist it's okay to wear day garments at night. I'll second Bobbie's advice about clarifying -- and perhaps considering another therapist. Day garments need movement in order to have their good effect, and when you're sleeping they can slip out of position and bind and cut off lymph flow. (I've napped with day garments on and I woke up with a very swollen hand and lower arm.) Night garments are quite different. They're made (by companies like JoviPak, Solaris, Telesto-Medtech, and ReidSleeve) to work on your arm while you're not moving around. They have the same kind of action as the bandages do. Most therapists consider wrapping the arm at night better than using night garments, but realistically the night garments are much easier, and therefore much more likely to be used. You can look them up here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Lymphedema_garments.htm Most night garments are washable, fairly easy to get on and off, and they can be chilled during the day so they're ready to keep you cooler on warm nights. With good care they last a couple of years (as long as YOU don't change sizes). Some women use them for travel too, with the ease of getting them on and off being one helpful feature. Do keep us posted! Hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2010 08:18AM Binney4 wrote: Oh, good point, Jane -- thank you! So, Montrial, this could be a good therapist, but one who seems to advocate this particular practice which now seems to have a bit of a following. In that case, though, it's still up to you what you choose to do about it, knowing it's not standard practice. There's a "work in progress" called the American Lymphedema Framework Project that is drawing together medical professionals from all specialties (since the lymph system affects all the systems of the body) to detemine best practices in treating lymphedema. We really need this, so I hope they get it off the ground before too long. Once we have that in place we can refer to it for guidelines on treatment, and all these disagreements and controversies will be easier for us patients to navigate. In the meantime, the UK has already published their Lymphedema Framework document, and anyone interested can find it here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/ In the right-hand column, click on "International Concensus: Best Practice for the Management of Lymphoedema". Way to go, UK! , Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2008 04:12AM Binney4 wrote: Thanks, Rolniak and Linda, We've had some discussion of this on the surgery board, where the idea of lowering LE risk has proved very popular!  Linda, I wondered too about whether truncal LE would be affected, so I emailed the research people with these questions: "I'm a breast cancer veteran with bilateral lymphedema, so the  prospect of sparing other women this diagnosis is exciting to me. I  have a couple of questions that have come up on one of the BC on- line discussion boards regarding the ARM procedure and this trial in  particular. I would really appreciate your help in answering them. 1. Besides looking at the development of arm LE after breast surgery,  are you also looking at the development of truncal  LE? We are  wondering if by limiting the damage to the arm lymphatics, that may  ease the strain on the trunk lymphatics as well and result in a  decrease of chest/breast LE. 2. How is this study taking into account the added stress and damage  to the lymph system caused by reconstruction surgery, radiation  treatment, and possibly certain chemo drugs?" To which I promply received this reply: "Thank you for the interest in our protocol.  We, too, are excited about the prospect of reducing the risk of lymphedema. To answer your questions, at this time, we are only studying the development of lymphedema in the arm after surgery.  We have no plans to study truncal lymphedema. We are following the patients for a minimum of 4 years after surgery and during this time we will keep track of their treatment (chemotherapy, radiation, hormonal therapy, reconstruction), but we will not be including these factors in the final data analysis. We wish you the best and please contact us with further questions. Laura" So we aren't going to find out about the truncal. Maybe next time! And if those other factors are not to be included in the analysis, how will we know what's really going on? Odd. Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 11:00PM Binney4 wrote: Oh, Dawn, hooray! Kudos to the surgeon who affirmed your risk and sent you to a great therapist! Ugh, dirty gloves! Here are some glove hygiene tips from StepUp-SpeakOut -- some of us got freaked out over the hygiene issue during the swine flu scare and we contacted manufacturers and therapists for advice, only to discover they'd never even thought about it. If you don't wear 'em, you just don't get it!: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/How_You_Can_Cope_with_Lymphedema.htm#GLOVES_AND_HYGIENE I take mine off to eat, but have to warn you that the scrungy things are way too easy to lose once they're no longer attached to your hands. So I have ONE PLACE where I always put them when I take them off (on my desk at home, in a pocket of my purse when I'm out) and I have to concentrate on not setting them down wherever it's handy. I once put them in my lap while eating out. When I got to the car and discovered I didn't have my glove on I had to return to the restaurant -- only to find another party seated at the table -- and crawl around among their legs to retrieve the wretched thing. There is NO explanation you can give them, so I just turned beet red and fled with it. Hope the stress test results are an A+! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 04:30AM Binney4 wrote: Denise, I'm sorry for the multiple injuries -- yikes! Sounds like you're being careful to treat them promptly. I'm not sure about a sleeve over the burn as it could irritate it, and certainly you don't want to wear day garments at night. But you could keep your arm elevated (with support), even at night on pillows. Stay well hydrated; take a few deep abdominal breaths when you think about it. And keep an eye on everything. Here's information on infection so you know what to look for: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm If you don't have a well-trained lymphedma therapist, now's a good time to get a referral to one. Treating those early symptoms promptly makes it easier to manage over the long haul, and it can keep it from progressing. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Not sure what you're asking about the glove as opposed to a gauntlet since your work entails a potential for burns. If you're asking whether a glove would provide more protection, garments are NO protection from burns -- my own experience is that they melt (don't ask!), which is not an especially good thing. Please keep us posted on how you're doing! Be well, Binney

Posts.Title: Measuring during PT GoodMommy RIV54

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 02:14AM Binney4 wrote: When I only had LE on one side she only measured that side (after the initial evaluation). There's always going to be some fluctuation in measurements due to heat, atmospheric conditions, weight loss, etc., and some error due to drawing the measuring tape looser or tighter. But the idea is to gauge the trend in the arm she's working on. Is it generally going down or up or staying pretty much the same? Definitely not an exact science, but can for sure tell you information that's difficult to eyeball. There are new technologies available to measure volume and intracellular fluid accumulation, and with those we'll have a much more accurate assessment of how well the treatment is working. Better things on the horizon!

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 04:16PM Binney4 wrote: SpecialK, you're right that both arms are at risk, so risk reduction is definitely called for. The issue is to make sure the fit is good so there's no constriction anywhere. Once you have them, check with your therapist to be sure the fit is right, then start gradually with them (no more than an hour the first time you have them on) to be sure they're not causing redness, aching, purple fingertips() or chafing. Any doctor on your team can write the prescriptions. I get mine from my MO. My therapist, like yours, doesn't do the fitting herself, but it's up to her to decide on the compression level and any other special considerations. If you're not buying custom garments, don't let the DME company sell you just whatever they've got on their shelf -- if you don't like the fit and they don't have the size/style you need, they should order it, not push off the wrong garment on you. (Voice of sad experience!) Ask you therapist if there's a fitter she trusts at your DME supplier. Let us know how it goes. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2013 05:41PM - edited Apr 21, 2013 05:53PM by Binney4 Tammie, I just wrote you a post on the Lymphedema board, then came here to see your original post. Your post on the Lymphedema board didn't mention the area was warm to the touch, but that sets off a lot of alarm bells. A compromised lymph system (from the rads in January) means there can be lymphedema present well before any swelling appears. And stagnant lymph in the tissues creates a very high risk for a kind of infection called cellulitis. Sudden unexplained swelling and warmth to the touch are two possible symptoms. Cellulitis needs immediate attention!! It can spread very, very rapidly and become systemic, which requires hospitalization, but if treated early you can be on top of it with oral antibiotics. Please don't wait for Monday morning if you have any question about this being cellulitis--just head for the ER and say the words "lymphedema" and "cellulitis" to everybody who sees you (I'm not kidding--they can overlook this waaaaay too easily!) Here's more information: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Be well! And gentle hugs, Binney
Posts.Title: Swollen leg? Now swelling in rib area???? tammie Mzmerz

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2013 07:50PM Binney4 wrote: FaerieQueen, good for you! It's hard to get good information about LE, but you really persevered and found ways to help yourself--brava! Here's more information if you're interested: http://www.stepup-speakout.org I know it seems counter-intuitive, but drinking LOTS of water actually helps lymph flow. In fact, it's one of the basics of self-care. It dilutes the thick, protein-rich lymph fluid so the compromised lymphatics can be more efficient at removing it. Since staying well hydrated is good for so many other reasons as well, you might want to experiment with increasing your fluid intake and see if that works for you. Just a thought. Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 11:33PM Binney4 wrote: Sespebadger, do consider requesting a referral from any doctor on your team to a well-trained lymphedema therapist for evaluation and individual risk-reduction strategies. Here's how to find a well-qualified therapist near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Since you have had bilateral surgery you're at risk for lymphedema on both sides, nodes or no nodes. While the risk is somewhat lower for the non-cancer side, it would still be a poor idea to move fluid toward the opposite axilla, as Teka describes, since that could overwhelm the compromised lymph system on that side and create a greater risk of lymphedema. Teka's massage routine is specific to her, taking into account her individual surgery history and any scar tissue in the area (lymph fluid can't readily cross scar tissue). You need a prophylactic massage routine specially suited to your own situation, and a lymphedema therapist can design and teach you that. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 06:34PM Binney4 wrote: 2t, lymphedema will always be a risk. The current guidelines read under 15 minutes and: "Avoid placing limb in water temperatures above 102°Fahrenheit (38.9°Celsius)" The idea is to avoid heat directly to that quadrant of your body, and to avoid raising your core body temperature (which happens when you soak even part of you in a hot tub for very long -- which is why they say 15 minutes.) Personally I wouldn't risk it myself, but all I can actually offer is the NLN guidelines, which are written and updated by their (very impressive) medical board. Some women turn down the heat to the recommended 102 degrees and continue to enjoy it at their leisure, and that seems to me to be more reasonable than even the 15 minutes at higher temps. We all make our own compromises! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: May 28, 2013 06:37PM Binney4 wrote: Sher, hello! Long time no "see"! I have zippers in my sleeves. Solaris will put a full-length zipper in, wrist to near the top (Jovi will not--only a zipper on the top or the wrist). For some reason I don't understand a lot of therapists think zippers are a no-no. My guess is they consider it might irritate your skin or provide less compression along that seam-line. Or maybe they're afraid we might catch our skin in it when pulling it up. I have no clue. I love my zippers (well, as much as I "love" anything to do with LE in general or night garments in particular). They make it so much easier to get on and off for bathroom trips and other, uh, night-time activities. And of course they spare my jaw, where I'm inclined to bash myself when pulling up the zipperless variety. They also are much easier after a shower or on a warm summer evening, when being damp can make getting into the stupid thing a real challenge. My sleeves don't slip down. I suspect yours might be either too loose at the top or just getting saggy with age--two years is about it for night gear, though they're really comfy when they're old and worn-in. Ask about a pull loop when you order. Might not need one at all if the new sleeve fits better at the top. If you're paying for it out of pocket check out what they'd charge for a pull loop, because these "extras" can get ridiculous. Let us know what you decide and how it goes! What color are you getting? Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 06:52AM Binney4 wrote: Liz, breast/chest lymphedema is actually called "truncal lymphedema," and it's pretty darn common, though rarely diagnosed because our doctors and other healthcare providers don't always know about it. I just read a paper this morning that estimated between 40 - 80% of women who currently undergo bc treatment will develop truncal lymphedema (though nowhere near all of them will ever be diagnosed). Undiagnosed and untreated lymphedema can lead to serious and repetitive infection and to further lymph blockage, and it can also be a source of pain, so it's not a harmless condition at all and deserves attention and treatment. Here's information about it: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Glad you have your first appointment coming up -- soon, I hope! Please keep us posted, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2016 07:12PM Binney4 wrote: paintThesky, definitely see a well-qualified lymphedema therapist, because with that trauma history you could for sure expect your LE to affect that side as well. Have you learned self-MLD? Wrapping is not used for truncal LE, but there are several kinds of chest compression bras, camis, and chip pads to help with the swelling. I agree with you about the pain of truncal LE, but reducing and controlling the swelling also controls the pain. See the links at the bottom of this page for some ideas of garments for helping with truncal LE: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunck... Please do let us know what you discover. Gentle hugs, Binney
Posts.Title: Truncal LE spreading to other side. paintThesky Binney4

Posts.Content: May 5, 2016 11:29AM Binney4 wrote: PaintTheSky, if it were me I'd want a well-trained and experienced LE therapist to do a complete evaluation at this point. They're the ones trained to recognize LE as well as address it. Now that you've ruled out the more immediate concerns, LE is the option to consider, and you want to get on it right away before summer hits full on. With the trauma to the left side that you describe, certainly LE is a likely outcome. When LE is bilateral the Manual Lymph Drainage patten is different than when there's only one side involved. The fluid must be moved downward toward the abdomen/groin, rather than across to the opposite side. It's important to clear all lymph nodes in the groin and abdomen beforehand, so the fluid doesn't simply gather there. So, a new routine to learn, but knowing how to manage will keep you much more comfortable through the humid months. If a compression cami is too much for you, you might try a compression bra instead--possibly a bit cooler. I prefer the cami, even through the summer, since I'm bilateral and want to keep the fluid moving downward. Hope some of that makes sense, and that you'll soon have answers and all the help you need. Please keep us posted. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 01:12PM - edited Apr 19, 2011 01:15PM by Binney4 Dawn, for sure, getting flu shots is a bit inconvenient. The rest of the family can go to the grocery store, but all those public clinics have a policy of not doing it anywhere but in the arm. If there's an older nurse there I can usually slip up quietly to her and tell her I've had bilateral mastectomies, and she'll do it in my thigh. But I never have any luck with the younger ones. I get flu shots at my oncs office. Jadeblue, I always get BP on my lower leg and blood draws from my foot. Most labs will tell you they won't do foot draws, but if you show up with the order in hand and the doctor has written "Draw from foot only" on it, they'll find a way to do it. The gal at my lab who does it sometimes brings her colleagues in to see how it's done. Afterwards, one of them said to her, "I don't see what's different about doing it in the foot." And my gal said, "Nothing. It's exactly the same, except that it's easier because the veins are bigger." Go figure! There are a few things I do to make it easier. I take baby aspirin for a couple of days beforehand (check with your doctor first!) and make sure I'm well hydrated. Then I warm up a microwave heating pad and wrap it around my foot before I leave the house (not too hot!) While I'm sitting in the waiting room I keep bouncing my legs up and down to help the circulation. And I ask to lie down when doing the blood draw. Wishing you smooth sailing with your up-coming surgery. Do let us know how it goes! Warm hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2008 12:10AM - edited Oct 31, 2008 12:19AM by Binney4 Hi, Lainey, That sounds like bioimpedance measurement testing. Takes about five minutes and measures the interstitial fluid (fluid between the cells) in your arm. Bravo for your PS! By monitoring your arms before surgery and at three-month intervals afterward he can tell if fluid is accumulating even before you can see or measure it. If so, you can be fitted for a compression garment early on and may be able to avoid the long therapy where your arm has to be wrapped for days and weeks in layered bandages. Yes! Painless, quick, safe -- and it shows a real awareness and concern on your BS's part for your long-term well-being and quality of life. The devise is made by a company called Impedimed, and you can read about it here: www.impedimed.com . There are already several studies that substantiate the use and effectiveness of this for early intervention for lymphedema. Lots more information about lymphedema, including a position paper on Risk Reduction at the National Lymphedema Network here: www.lymphnet.org . Can you tell I'm a real fan of this? Do come back and tell us how it goes, yes? Hooray! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2012 05:29PM Binney4 wrote: Crystal, technically both arms are at risk because you've had bilateral surgeries. For flying (or any travel where change of altitude would be a factor) a low-compression sleeve and gauntlet or glove would be advisable for that arm as well, but it would be important to be sure the fit was good. It's a controversial issue in the LE world, but in my case my LE started on the prophylactic side, with a plane trip, so I take a pretty conservative view of precautions. On the other hand, I don't think this new study shows that if your mom has LE from a single groin node removed that proves a genetic link. Some primary lymphedema is genetic, some is not, so even if her lymph system is less than adequate, it doesn't prove yours is.  So caution yes, but despair, no. Hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2011 02:41PM Binney4 wrote: Cookie, no breasts here, but I have similar problems with chest LE. Best help for me is Lebed exercises. I wish I just did them every day, but I'm not that consistent. When it bugs me, though, I get right back at it and it helps enormously, and right away. I've tried the Bellisse and didn't like the fit, though some women find it helpful. Best help for me during the day is either the bra or the Slimmer from WearEase. I wear the Slimmer inside out as it's easier to access the prosthesis pocket, and it cuts down on "bridging" from the height of the prosthesis, but they're so well made you can wear them comfortably either way. For night, the Expand-a-band chest wrap works, but I'm more comfortable in a Solaris vest -- gentle compression, wide shoulders so it covers the area behind the axilla too, but you can have it designed any way you want. It's hot, so I stow it in the fridge during the day and put it on cool. Not having breasts anymore, I can also use a between-the-ribs finger massage my therapist taught me that stimulates the deeper lymphatics, and that helps too. When I'm having trouble I also resort to clearing neck nodes and chest (MLD) several times throughout the day. Like you, my arm swelling seems to be related to the truncal swelling. If the top of the sleeve is too tight it causes a chest flare (and pain -- yuck). I don't know why that is. It doesn't make sense to me as far as how the lymph system operates, but nothing about LE makes much sense. Can't use kinesio tape because of severe skin sensitivity in the chest area to adhesives. I use either "chocolate bar" hard foam pieces or a kimbe swell spot to control flares, depending on how aggressive I need to be. Weather affects this for me. Barometric pressure, heat, and humidity all complicate my life. Also overuse of my arm. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2007 07:55PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, elliegurl, I'm sorry you're having to deal with the pain and the uncertainty. We bc veterans don't tolerate uncertainty very well, for sure! So I hope you get quick and clear answers and real pain relief. What you're describing might be Axillary Web Syndrome, which is fancy-talk for "cording." It can occur anywhere from your thumb to your axilla and from your axilla down across your chest to your waist. It usually can be felt with your fingers as a cord-like structure, but sometimes it can't be felt distinctly (especially if there's excess weight in the area). It hurts when you extend your arm and limits how far you can extend it. It's not dangerous and it's usually treated by gentle stretching of your arm, either by yourself or with the help of physical therapy. If that's what it turns out to be and you stretch it yourself, try it when you're standing in a warm shower by gently reaching your arm up the wall toward the shower head. Cording itself is not LE, but it is related to LE. The "cord" is made up of tissue, some of which is lymph tissue, and women who experience cording do often go on to develop LE. There's lots of information about LE and especially about lowering your LE risk at the National Lymphedema Network, www.lymphnet.org  Do let us know what you discover. And get better quick! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2015 12:38PM Binney4 wrote: Day and night garments reduce or contain swelling by different methods and on different principles of physics. Day garments depend on muscle movement to help pump lymph fluid and thereby control swelling. Night garments are less restrictive, act even when the muscles are still, and may actually reduce swelling rather than just contain it. I've napped in my day garments and woke up with pain and some swelling, so I don't do it anymore, but LE's not the same for everyone. Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: May 9, 2009 10:43PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, MOTC, Those are good questions. The compression sleeves can keep the swelling from progressing, but they're not able to reduce it or to break up the fibrotic areas that may have formed. Wrapping with layered compression bandages creates a graduated compression with enough of the right kind of "give" to it to both increase the pumping action of the lymph vessels (which of course have no "heart" like your blood vessels do to move things along) and to actually cause a reduction of the whole area. It also allows for proper padding of troublesome areas of extra swelling, tough fibrosis, or extra sensitivity to pressure. In trying to visualize how your lymph system was compromised by treatment, you can see readily enough that the damage was done up near the axilla during surgery and/or radiation. In other words, even if the only swelling is in your hand, that is NOT where the damage is. It's some distance from there, in fact. If you successfully move the accumulated lymph fluid out of your hand it still has a long way to travel in order to get pushed past the area that's "broken down." So if you don't treat the entire length of the arm you run the risk of moving fluid out of the hand only to have it collect higher up in your forearm, elbow, or upper arm. So wrapping is standard practice, usually 23/7 (you remove it to shower and go back to therapy), until the whole thing is reduced to pre-lymphedema proportions (or until it reaches a plateau period). Usually that's a couple of weeks, but it will depend on your therapist and the way your body responds. Then you switch to a compression sleeve and glove during the day, and usually (though not always) wrapping at night (or wearing special night garments which are more comfortable -- and bulkier -- than day garments.) There are therapists who skip some steps, but trust me, you don't actually want that because it just drags everything out and makes it harder to gain control. Here's our page about wrapping: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/wrapping_bandaging_for_lymphedema.htm And here's one about the massage part of treatment: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/manual_lymphatic_drainage_massage_lymphedema.htm As you can see, lymphedema is not for wimps (so what am I doing with it?!!) But you can do this, and we're all here to help. It'll be good -- honest! Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2010 07:26PM Binney4 wrote: KC, when it gets painful I resort to swell spots under whatever compression I'm wearing. Solaris has a "Kimbe spot" that works really well to cover the axilla and a bit of the side and direct the fluid flow out and down. My WearEase comes up very high under my arm, so with the Kimbe spot that really eases things. I also have night vests custom made by Solaris and JoviPak to come up high under my arm and across the back of my shoulder. The custom night sleeves snap onto it so it covers everything. I sometimes have to resort to that during the day if the swelling and pain are bad, but they really do bring me relief. Layering compression can be a problem because a second garment of the same compression class won't double the compression, so it's not very predictable and may be uneven or cause binding. If you try it don't wear it more than an hour without giving it a rest and seeing how it's going. If you know how to wrap your own arm, I'd sure do that for now until you can see about a sleeve that's not so tight at the top. The trick is to get it tight enough not to fall down your arm, and loose enough not to constrict the flow at the point where it should be loosest. I can understand why a too-tight sleeve-top would theoretically make my ARM swell, but that's not what happens for me -- it makes my armpit and the top of my chest swell instead. But then, my therapist insists my lymph system was installed upside down... Maybe a second opinion would be helpful? If so, the StepUp-SpeakOut page about finding a therapist might help. Hopefully OneBadBoob and others will be along with some suggestions -- we need all the options we can get!   There is, by the way, a new garment company just starting up that makes a sleeve that goes clear across the shoulders and ends in a short sleeve on the other arm, so there's compression high under the arm and around the shoulder as well. I'm anxious to try it, but at present have no idea how well it works. Their brand-spankin' new website (still under construction) is here: http://www.thelymphedemasleeveco.com/ Be well, KC! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 06:56PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, seabreeze (nice screen name -- aaaaaaah!) Most of our body parts are pretty standard: ten fingers and toes, two ears, one heart and so on. The lymph nodes are the exception, as any number of variations is possible. They're located all over our body, but mainly in the neck, armpit and groin. Nobody can say how many any one person has or how many may be in any one area. (Which always makes me wonder if the number that are left might be a more important factor to developing lymphedema than the number that were taken. But nobody knows that either.) Sort of a maddening puzzle, isn't it? Lymphnotes (which is at www.lymphnotes.com ) offers a very helpful free Lymphedema Alert wallet card which you can order like so: "To receive a free 'Lymphedema Alert Wallet Card,' e-mail your name and mailing address to ann@lymphnotes.com." Nice to have handy! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2013 09:43PM Binney4 wrote: Lisa, the UW Madison website does indicate they have trained LE therapists: http://www.uwhealth.org/orthopedic-surgery-rehab/lymphedema-and-venous-edema/13987 At least, they indicate they have "advanced training." If you call and find out that they have at least 135 hours of specifically LE training beyond their PT or OT certification, that's what you're looking for. The "CLT" title usually applies to therapists who are "certified" by the Lymphology Association of North America (LANA), but all they have to do in order to gain that certification is to prove they've already taken the 135 hours and then pass LANA's written test. They don't have to demonstrate any clinical ability, and they don't have any obligation to continue to treat LE in the approved manner once they're certified--LANA does not have a review committee or a way to deal with patient complaints about therapists. So the LANA certification only tells you they took the training, not that they're any more competent than any other therapist who has the training but not the LANA membership. So ask about their hours of LE training, and don't worry about the "CLT". If that doesn't make sense, let me know and I'll try to explain to it better.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2016 03:29PM Binney4 wrote: Bluepearl, the study you cite about Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD--the lymphedema massage routine) being ineffective is unfortunately seriously flawed. Sigh! But one problem with verifying the effectiveness of MLD is that there are not good studies to show its effectiveness, much less which particular aspects of standard LE treatment are most effective. LE research is not well funded (no surprise, right? Grrrrr!!) Slowly but surely, LE research is moving forward anyway. Not fast enough, of course. The whole lymph system has historically been ignored (the fact that most of it is invisible didn't help throughout the ages when all the other bodily systems were being "discovered" and studied.) Here's a brief history of the study of the lymph system that might be helpful in understanding why we're so far behind: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/History_of_Lymphede... Onward! Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2012 05:10PM - edited Nov 9, 2012 05:10PM by Binney4 Karina, I'm jealous! Your resources are awesome! It is possible for the swelling of LE to be limited and not make itself known except occasionally, while the disease is still progressing within the tissues. There are several processes involved in LE, among them an abnormal fat deposition beneath the skin and an accumulation of fibrotic tissue as a result of the inflammatory aspects of LE. As these progress (without treatment) they can result in skin changes, limitations of strength and range of motion, possible leakage of caustic lymph fluid through the pores, and sometimes a kind of cancer called lymphangiosarcoma. LE does not progress rapidly, so without pain or constant swelling it can be easy to ignore it, but definitely best not to. Do keep us posted! Gentle hugs, Binney
