Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 03:55AM Binney4 wrote: Hope, NO! There is nothing NORMAL about what's happening with your therapy, new or old or anywhere in between! You do to look around for a new therapist, or if that's impossible, sit down with one of the ones you've already tried, show them the National Lymphedema Network position paper on treatment (Kira posted a link to it above), and tell her you want her to follow that protocol: daily wrapping until the swelling is reduced, teaching you to wrap yourself -- and then maybe think about going to another fitter who can actually fit you properly. (Have you checked out all the links on the StepUp-SpeakOut therapist page? http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm) If you are not swelling at night, for goodness sake don't accept a night garment. The swelling should be under control with wrapping before you order ANY garments, and if you accept the ones she's offering you now your insurance may not pay for another anytime soon, when you arm is in better shape. Wait until your arm is well and truly reduced and you have the skills to keep it that way. Many of us wrapped our arms at night for weeks or months after therapy ended and THEN decided if we wanted night garments or not. Don't let her push you into that. As for her using a pump, she should only use it AFTER she has done Manual Lymph Drainage on you herself -- it is not a substitute for the hands-on lymph drainage that she is getting paid to do. NEVER let her use a pump on you if she has not first manually cleared your nodes herself, and she should also clear your nodes again when the pump session is over. And for goodness sake don't let her sell you a pump yet. It may be at some point you'll want to look into that (or maybe not), but now is not the time. Don't calm down just yet! You may not have a ready supply of great therapists close by, but you sure don't  have to settle for this one's definition of your new normal. You're going to be just fine -- hang in there! Tell us how we can help. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2012 05:27PM Binney4 wrote: fredntan, the relationship between cording and LE is not clearly defined. Cording is generally thrombosed lymph vessels, so there's some potential damage there which may be related to triggering LE. (How's that for vague!) Another one of those "more research needed" areas, for sure. There also seems to be good reason to believe that "popping" the cords (as some therapists are prone to do, because it produces instant relief) is probably not a good idea. Better to massage it gently, and if the cords pop on their own that's considered less of an issue. Why, I do not know. As someone with bilateral lymphedema despite having only a single lymph node removed on my cancer side, and no lymph nodes purposely removed on the prophylactic side, I'm a strong believer in leaving both arms alone where blood pressure, blood draws and IVs are concerned. (Mine was triggered on one side by a blood pressure reading--sigh!) I sure hope the pain resolves quickly for you. Let us know how you're doing! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2018 01:15AM Binney4 wrote: Leesa and Jessica, that is a fun analogy. But research shows it's actually a bit more complicated than that. Just for starters, the number of toll booths is arbitrary--there is no set number of lymph nodes, so some of us have more, some less. If there were 20 tool booths and you reduced it to 2, that's a whole lot more congestion than if there were three and you reduced it to 2. So it matters what your starting point is, and there's no way to determine that. Recent research indicates that not only do we have different numbers of nodes, but the lymph system itself may be more or less efficient in different women (or men). There's even some indication that those people whose hands swell, for instance, when we hike, or whose feet or legs swell during plane trips may be experiencing a less efficient lymph system (though that's certainly not conclusive yet). But to make it even more complex, we may also have individual experiences of "trauma" of any sort to our chests or arms. Secondary lymphedema (the kind we're talking about with bc treatment) can happen to football players who get repeated blows to their chests, to people who have been thrown forward in traffic accidents, and to anyone who has suffered a crush injury to their arm or leg (one major example was the earthquake in Haiti some years back, when huge numbers of people developed lymphedema as a result of injuries from falling buildings.) Women who have had any breast surgery, regardless of cancer, are at risk. The repetition of even less dramatic trauma over time can eventually add up to developing lymphedema. So it's impossible to predict at present. There are a number of women here, myself included, who have developed lymphedema with a single node removed , or no nodes removed during a simple prophylactic mastectomy. There are others with large numbers of nodes removed who buck hay bales on a daily basis and have never had a problem. The bottom line is to be aware of the possibility of developing lymphedema, and to seek prompt treatment from a qualified lymphedema therapist at the first indication of a problem. Early signs of arm lymphedema include heaviness, achy feelings, or just "feeling strange," or changes in the way a ring or cuff fits. Truncal lymphedema (breast, chest, back, side or underarm) indications include heaviness, pain that is hard to pin down and doesn't respond to OTC pain meds, and longish-lasting marks in your skin where the straps or bottom band were when you take off your bra. Of course visible swelling is also a possible sign, but it is often not the first one. The earlier you seek treatment, the easier it is to reduce any swelling and to keep it in control over time. Whew! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 03:54AM - edited Apr 30, 2009 03:56AM by Binney4 I didn't puncture mine, but one of mine sprung a leak a couple of years ago. Once I realized it was leaking I could see where the joint between the front and back pieces was wrinkled and didn't quite close -- it just hadn't been made right. But it took me several days to figure it out. The first thing I noticed was a streak of "dirt" down my abdomen. I couldn't imagine what it was, but when I took a shower and tried to get it off, I had to scrub at it. The next day in the middle of the afternoon I felt something stiff on my skin below my bra, and when I looked, there was a streak again. I washed it off again (with some effort) and wracked my brain trying to think what it could be. The next morning when I was putting the prosthesis in the pocket it suddenly occurred to me it might be that. I checked, and sure enough. Of course I returned it with no trouble, and the fitter told me she'd never seen that either. Like the rest of us, she was really curious and tried squeezing it to see what would happen, but not much did. So I agree with Barbara that we're not likely to have any dramatic surprises from our prostheses. Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2014 09:45PM - edited Oct 29, 2014 09:46PM by Binney4 Spookiesmom, it's your call, but putting a gauntlet on when there's swelling in the wrist could very well push the swelling into your fingers and trap it there, where you definitely don't want it. An Isotoner or Imac glove (from the drug store) that has at least partial fingers would be a better bet. And ACE is generally not a good idea with LE because it's too stretchy and will allow the layers of wrap to shift and be hard to control. With LE involved you want gradient compression that will move the fluid upward, and ACE can't do that. Better to use some gentle cold--for no more than 15 minutes at a time, and with a layer or two of cloth between the ice pack and your skin. Elevation, as often as possible, even on pillows at night. And stay really well hydrated. Some deep breathing at intervals will help too, because it stimulates the largest lymph vessel in your body. Sure hope you get some clear guidance soon! Hugs, Binney Edited to add: Swelling after an injury would be normal and may not indicate a lymphedema flare, so hang in there!

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 01:24PM Binney4 wrote: Aw, Journey, I hear you, and I'm so sorry! This just shouldn't happen. So hard to get our minds around this one, yes? Hey! GOOD thing you were into martial arts before your bilat -- good physical conditioning before this hits makes a lot of difference to what you'll be able to handle now. It sounds like you have a PT, but you don't say what treatment you've had for your lymphedema. Did you do a Therapy Intensive, with two or more weeks of daily massage and wrapping? Have you learned lymphedema self-massage and how to wrap your own arm(s)? Do you have sleeves and gauntlets for both arms (both are at risk if you've had bilateral surgeries, and if you have lymphedema in only one arm, you sure don't want it in the other!) YOU KNOW your body! If your arm feels heavier you need to act quickly to bring that into control and keep it that way. That means, yes, wearing you sleeve and gauntlet every day. But also wrapping at night (or using night garments if you have them), extra self-massage, and paying close attention to whatever might be aggravating it (certain activities, periods of inactivity, heavy salt intake, dehydration, weather changes, travel or altitude changes, etc.) Journey, a PT qualified to treat lymphedema should have at least 135 hours of specifically lymphedema training beyond her/his PT certification and preferably at least a year of supervised lymphedema experience. Unfortunately there are no state laws mandating this preparation, so there are plenty of underqualified therapists out there. If you'd like a second opinion on your therapy there's information on finding well-trained ones near you -- and what you should expect form therapy -- here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm (You're in a good spot -- Atlanta is home to a lot of really good therapists!) You do need to be sure your lymphedema is in good control (no new swelling or feelings of heaviness) before you return to training, but once you've got that taken care of the good news is that exercise is excellent for controlling lymphedema. You'll need to take it extra slow, though, build up slowly and attentively. Punching a padded target with force is, unfortunately, not likely to be real helpful for your lymphedema, but that's just something you'll have to experiment with once you've got everything well in control, and see how it goes for you. Since you already have lymphedema in one arm, that arm might be better protected during aggressive activity if you wrap it, rather than wearing compression garments. Wrapping promotes lymph flow as you exercise and may make things possible that wouldn't be doable otherwise. BUMMER! But, Journey, it gets easier. Please keep us posted and let us know what you discover. Hugs, prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 02:55PM Binney4 wrote: Journey, I'm sorry about the surgeon. Like we're making this up for the extra attention, right? I don't see mine anymore, fortunately for both of us. Scheduling LE into your day is (fortunately!) highly personal. I exercise in bursts throughout the day rather than all at once, which may not be ideal but it works for me. (I saw an interview with a very sensible PT on TV once, and when he was asked if it was true we shouldn't exercise right before bedtime he said if that was the time you were most likely to do it, then that's when it should be done. Makes sense to me! Same thing for all the other aspects of LE care.) Lymphedema starts out being completely overwhelming, taking over every thought, ruining every plan -- and then gradually you manage to take change of it and sort it all out, and it starts to come together into something you can actually control. We learn everything we need to know, and then we decide on the compromises we're willing to make. There are "tools" -- skills, really -- you need to have so you can manage on your own:  Self Manual Lymph Drainage massage (designed specifically for your needs) Self wrapping in layered short-stretch bandages An understanding of what needs exercising, how much and how often A small emercency kit that you keep with you that contains - antiseptic wipes antibiotic ointment bandaids your medical history, including LE precautions (no bp, IV, injections, etc.) A list of LE supplies showing brand and size you use and where you can order them, as well as a time-table for when to replace them. Since you're bilateral you also need well-fitting garments (sleeve and glove both) for your other arm too, to use for travel, exercise, and unusual or strenuous activities (shoveling snow, cleaning closets, etc.) All in all it's a steep (and expensive) learning curve, but it's finite. The problem is, as Kira points out, that we have to do so much for ourselves, and we're used to having more-or-less expert help with our medical needs. That's okay -- this is chronic, so the more we can depend on ourselves the more freedom we have. It's the only way to take back control of our lives. You'll get there, Journey! It'll be good! Estepp, to put it shortly, symptoms do include swelling, of course, but before that's even noticeable or measureable there can be as much as 30% more fluid in our tissues than is normal. So lymphedema begins welll before the swelling appears. Early symptoms include tingling, aching, heaviness, and feelings of fullness. In the chest or breast, pain is often the first symptom, but usually outright pain is not a factor in arm LE. If you experience any of those symptoms, get a referral for evaluation by a fully-trained lymphedema therapist. (In fact, getting a referral BEFORE you have any symptoms is really smart -- gives you your best shot at avoiding it!) There's a page about finding a qualified therapist further up on this thread -- it talks about therapist training too. Hope you never have to join our "swell" sorority! Be well, all! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2018 03:27PM Binney4 wrote: Mps, hello and welcome! I'm really sorry about the worries that have brought you here, but hope you'll find both help and encouragement on the boards here. You are smart to insist on a biopsy for IBC, because you need the peace of mind in order to get your life back. But the truth is that peau d'orange is indeed a sign of breast LE. The redness you describe can indicate infection, which is why your doctor put you on antibiotics, but it too is a sign of breast LE even when there is no infection present. Lymphedema is an inflammatory condition, and in the breast in particular it can present as redness that does not go away with antibiotic treatment (simply because it's not an infection, its inflammation). That said, if you have LE present, the risk of infection is high (bacteria thrive in the warm, protein-rich accumulation of stagnant lymph fluid--sigh!) So, especially since you're doing rads which can compromise your skin, you need to keep a sharp eye out for infection on top of everything else. The kind of infection most commonly associated with LE is cellulitis. Here's information about how to recognize it: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Med... Okay, so what you need to know is that treatment of breast LE (which consists of Manual Lymph Drainage massage and wearing some compression) can not be done while you're doing rads, or until your skin heals following rads. So you have a way to go before you can begin to get that in order. But once the LE is treated it will both reduce the swelling and restore the skin texture and color. (Some women have a bit of lingering pinkness to the skin even once the LE is controlled.) Here's more information about breast LE (which is also referred to as truncal LE): http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunck... While you wait for LE treatment, there are some things you can do to help control it: 1. Stay really well hydrated--this helps keep the lymph fluid flowing. 2. Stop throughout the day and take a few deep abdominal breathes--this stimulates the largest lymphatic vessel in our bodies, which runs from shoulder to abdomen and can be pumped by the diaphragm. 3. As much as possible, take good care of the skin on your breast--ask your rads doc for help with any skin breaks or burns. 4. Gentle exercises act as a pump for your entire lymph system (there is no "heart" to pump lymph fluid through your body--muscle movement plus the structure and function of the vessels themselves do the pumping), so gentle arm stretches throughout the day will help. Just remember, no pain! 5. Speaking of pain, if you are having pain from the rads, do ask for help controlling it and stay on top of it--as a response to pain our bodies send emergency supplies of lymph fluid to the area. Just what you don't want! Other women will be along soon with further suggestions, I'm sure, and to share their experiences. Hoping some of this helps to relieve your anxiety! Please keep us posted and let us know how you're doing. Gentle hug, Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 12:15PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Darya, Well, bummer! Who needs another thing to worry about? I'm really sorry. Swollen nodes don't occur from LE, but they can from cuts and burns, especially three at once! Do watch for any sign of infection from any of the injuries, as even slight lymphedema in your hand indicates lymph fluid stagnation in the tissues, and that really increases the infection risk. Even from a paper cut. (Before any swelling from lymphedema is even visible or measurable, there's already more than 30% more lymph fluid in the tissues than is normal.) So your nodes (part of your immune system) may well be working overtime due to the extra infection risk and resulting epic battle going on to stop it. Keep your whole hand clean, use a topical antibiotic, and if you note ANY sign of infection (redness, new swelling, itching, pain, warmth to the touch, fever) in your arm or hand, get medical help at once. ER if need be. Don't wait. Swedish massage includes deep tissue work, yes? You'd be better off avoiding that on your entire affected quadrant (arm, breast, back, side -- like a chicken wing quarter) since the whole area's at risk, and you can trigger full-blown LE at any time. Doesn't matter that it hasn't happened up to now. So massage could result in worsening of your LE, but I don't see how it could contribute to a swollen node. Glad to hear it seems to be reducing, at any rate. Prayers for that continuing, and no further problems. Keep us posted! Big (((hug))), Binney (grateful to you still for helping me with LE fashion advice!)

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2018 09:57PM Binney4 wrote: ksusan, I'll agree with Denise on this, that if you have well-fitting garments they'd be helpful at that altitude. More compression is not necessarily better for reducing your LE risk, so if you've been using the Juzo garments and the fit is good, you might be better off sticking with that than trying something new. Use them for the trip up as well, whether you're flying or driving, because the change of altitude is a challenge to our lymph system. Generally, though, once you're at altitude for several hours you should be fine using them only when exercising, traveling or engaging in any activity you're not used to. Wear them again for the trip back down, as anytime you change altitude you'll want protection. Happy travels! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2009 06:41PM - edited Apr 4, 2009 06:45PM by Binney4 LOL! Actually, all of us talked it over, but I was the one who contacted the company. The oversleeves are cool, and even affordable. When I wrote to the company, though, they couldn't assure me that they would not be so tight as to cause constriction. They have an endorsement on their site from an MD, but as we all know (unfortunately) MDs are not always the best judges of smart LE choices. They couldn't tell me that their design process had been overseen or vetted by knowledgable LE professionals, either. Also, adding an elastic-type oversleeve runs the possibility of increasing the compression of the sleeve, without increasing the compression of the glove -- not a good combination. But I think if you tried the oversleeves and found them evenly loose enough all up and down the length of your arm, that wouldn't constitute a problem. The constriction danger would be if they were tighter at one place along your arm than at another (which of course depends on the shape of our individual arms), or if you bought a size that was tight all up your arm and added compression. Our other concern was that this might encourage women to wear only a sleeve (which could be covered with this oversleeve) and not their glove or gauntlet (which is still going to stick out and look like a stupid glove or gauntlet, after all). It's already plenty hard enough to have to wear our garments in public at times, so we didn't want to add to the temptation not to use hand protection. (Note that the picture in the ad doesn't show a model wearing a glove or gauntlet.) So we decided to list on the site the garment makers who make sleeves AND gloves or gauntlets in colors or patterns, rather than getting into all the guesswork of oversleeves. Besides, we have this discussion board for alerting us all to new products and developments like this one, so thanks, Jinky! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2008 08:56AM - edited Oct 3, 2008 08:59AM by Binney4 Hi, Doe, Tingling and numbness are frequently a symptom of lymphedema. Sometimes the first symptom you notice. And I've found that early in my LE, hand weakness was also a major symptom. My hands are still weaker than they used to be, and my grip it further compromised by the stupid gloves. Pain in the chest, back, and even neck can go along with truncal LE (just ask bygrace), or even arm LE, though most often LE treatment eases that pain eventually. And shoulder problems are common just from the bc surgery itself (not to mention the AIs). RIBP is a very rare side effect of bc treatment these days, due to improvements in radiation delivery. On the other hand, RIBP is obviously an alarming diagnosis, and the earlier you catch it the more possibility there is of arresting it (though those possibilities are at the present time pretty iffy.) So if you're concerned about this, do ask your docs to check it out for you. LE is lonely -- as Kira mentioned in another post today, it's considered an "orphan" condition by the medical community, and as we're all aware the general public (and even our bc sisters) are not aware of it and slow to pick up on the suffering involved. But RIBP is far lonelier. There is no support group on the web for this specific condition, and nowhere doctors can refer them for help or even more understanding of the condition. Too many doctors ignore our LE, but we still have therapists and a few dozen companies offering us innovative interventions. But with RIBP even the therapists throw up their hands and walk away. I do hope and trust what you're dealing with is not RIBP, Doe. But I really value your empathy for our Sisters who are dealing with this. Those with RIBP who have been posting here on bc.org take my breath away, and I feel so privileged to know them. Their thread was just moved here to the LE board last week from the "Young Women" board (where Erica started it some time ago) in the hope that other women of whatever age who are facing this alone will be able to find the thread and join the conversation. And also that with all of us fellow lymphers working together, hopefully we can find ways to ease the RIBP path, and maybe even unlock a cure for it. We're all in this together. Let us know what you discover, Doe! (((((Hugs))))), prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 04:37PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Sue, I'm with Hope on this one. Definitely need to check it out. It isn't impossible for this to be due to lymphedema, but it sure isn't typical. Sudden swelling can have other causes that need to be addressed promptly, especially considering the amount of pain. Insist on it. Once other causes are ruled out you'll want to see a really good therapist. Wrapping is a trial, for sure, but it's not forever (just seems that way! ), and it's a really important tool to know how to use. When lymphedema swelling gets out of hand garments won't fit correctly and may cause more problems, but wrapping can be adjusted to any amount of swelling. It's also important for traveling, for when you're sick in bed and not moving around much, and generally just to give you back control of your life. I'm really sorry about this lousy development, Sue. Get good help promptly so you know what you're dealing with and can get completely on top of it. Please keep us posted! Very gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2016 08:36PM Binney4 wrote: Pricilla, welcome to the discussion boards here at BreastCancer.org. I'm so sorry for the reasons that brought you here, but glad you found us. Lymphedema is a scary diagnosis for most of us--it's chronic, and it's hard to get good information about it, and sometimes even to find a well-qualified lymphedema therapist to treat it. I'm not sure where you heard that diet was a significant part of lymphedema treatment. It helps some of us if we avoid salt or alcohol, but aside from that there's little about diet that can affect lymphedema (except weight gain, but that doesn't sound like a problem you're having). The surgery you mention--moving lymphnodes from one site to another, or connecting lymph vessels to blood vessels for more effective draining--is still very much in the experimental stage and is certainly not standard lymphedema treatment, so please don't worry about the need for further surgery. Briefly, standard lymphedema treatment involves Manual Lymph Drainage, which is a kind of very gentle massage that helps to stimulate the lymph vessels (which are close to the skin) to move lymph more efficiently. Some special exercises help with that as well. And adding compression to the arm or other swollen area to help reduce swelling and maintain the arm in good condition. That compression at first is usually a special kind of layered bandage, applied by the lymphedema therapist. Later, when the swelling is reduced, you will be fitted for thin compression garments to use as needed (some of us need them all the time, others just for exercise or travel. All of that will be worked out with the help of a well-trained lymphedema therapist. Here's how to find one near you--any member of you medical team can write you a referral: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified... I hope some of that helps to calm your concerns at least a little. With gentle treatment and time to learn the "ropes" of managing this new challenge, you'll soon be on top of this. Please ask away if you have other questions, and do keep us posted on your progress. Gentle hugs, Binney
Posts.Title: Lymphedema Treatment 101 - Questions from a Newbie guitarhero25 glennie19

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 06:01PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Dassi and all, Several of the gals here use rebounders/mini-tramps as part of their LE routine. No studies that I know of, at least not for arm or chest LE. If you use one for this purpose the bounce is a very gentle one, and your feet do not leave the mat (so it's not JUMPING, just bouncing). It's not something you do for long periods--just five minutes or so at a time. Putting your arm above your head part of the time would be a good idea, as is getting the kind with a safety bar attached so you don't take a tumble. Some women feel bouncing gently on an exercise ball has the same effect, so if that's easier or more convenient it's another option. Whatever, it's no replacement for self MLD and compression, exercise and great skin care, which are the standard self-care protocols. Hope that helps! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 03:45PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Chris, You might want to go the the National Lymphedema Network web site at www.lymphnet.org. Along the right-hand side of the page is a list of their Position Papers. If you read the one called "Therapy" you'll see that wrapping is part of the protocol for ANY LE treatment. Make a copy for your therapist and tell him in no uncertain terms that you want the full CDT (Complete Decongestive Therapy) treatment. Early stage LE is the easiest to control, so for goodness sake do EVERYTHING you need to to keep it that way. Even, as Amy notes, if you get the pump, you definitely want to know how to do an effective MLD (Manual Lymph Drainage) self-massage and wrap your own arms as well, so make sure he teaches you those skills. A pump doesn't help on an airplane, and it isn't the sort of thing you want to be tied to for the rest of your life. Wrapping and self-massage are portable and convenient, and they give you all the tools you need to manage your own life. Wouldn't he be trembling in his boots if he knew we were all sitting around here planning his next couple of weeks for him?! With our big ol' wrapped arms we're a formidable bunch, and we're unanimous on this -- so don't let him forget it!  Let us know how it goes, okay! Gentle (((hugs!))) Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 08:39AM Binney4 wrote: Mary, use it in good health! If you find the vest part is a bit loose across the shoulder, ask for complimentary velcro tabs that can be attached across the shoulder to tighten things up.  Note: when putting it on you can put on the leg section and then turn on the machine -- it works the groin area while you finish putting on the rest and climbing (lumbering?) into bed. I didn't know that at first, but I like it because then I don't have to fumble around trying to turn it on when I'm all settled. Also, hopefully your therapist gave you a node clearing routine to use before using the pump, yes? The Flexi folks can only refer you to your therapist on that issue, but it's important to take the few minutes to do it before each treatment. Ask everything you can think of, and get her contact information. Also the contact info for your area rep. I've found them very helpful, but the area rep generally knows more than the fitting person, so when in doubt you'll have two people to contact. No short-cuts! Make sure the fitting person stays with you long enough to assess the fit throughout the routine. There are things a trained eye and an extra pair of hands can help with that you just can't see or do for yourself. Do let us know how it goes! Binney

For a while when it was really bad I kept a couple of cold packs (stuffed with flax seed instead of water or gel so they didn't get ice-cold) in the freezer and stuffed one into my cami ("between" my missing breasts), changing them out as they lost their cool. Nasty business! Juzo has a new Cool-Vent glove out that I'm experimenting with. I find it keeps my palm and back of hand cooler and dry, though the fingers are still a problem. LE stinks. Hot flashes stink. The combination takes some maneuvering to manage. Sure hope others come along with some thoughts! Gentle hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2009 11:23PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, all, Maybe we could suggest a list of questions about this surgery that MomsDaughter could take with her to the meeting and get answered for us from the surgeons point of view. (MomsDaughter, are you going, and could you bring us back word, please?) Just a brief overview: Dr. Marga Massey has very recently joined Dr. DellaCroce's Center for Restorative Surgery in New Orleans, where they're famous for post-bc recon surgery and premium patient care. Dr. Massey has lately been working with a French doctor named Corinne Becker, who has been doing a lymph node transplant surgery for many years in France. Unfortunately Dr. Becker has not produced any studies large enough or objective enough to demonstrate the rate of positive outcome, the long-term effectiveness, or the safety of the surgery, so at this point in time we have little (or no) real understanding of outcomes. Dr. Massey and company are proposing to do a "real" study of their patients who undergo this procedure, so kudos for that! Hopefully their research will eventually help us understand more about not only how workable this procedure is, but even about how our lymph systems function. Love it! I'm a hopeless optimist! Okay, so what would we all like to know about this? Here are a few questions to get us started. Please chime in, all -- this affects all of us. Who are candidates for this surgery? Must women with LE have tried standard treatment (Complete Decongestive Therapy) and have found it unworkable to qualify? How about women who have had LE for many years? Women with Stage III LE? Women newly diagnosed who have not tried other therapies? Women with bilateral arm LE? Women with truncal LE? People with leg, abdominal and/or genital LE? How will research subjects be selected? What criteria will be used, and how long will they be followed for effectiveness and possible side effects? What possible side effects will you be specifically looking at? What method(s) are used for measuring and recording limb size for this study? Tape measure? Water displacement? Perometry? Bio-impedence? Limphoscintigraphy? Self-reporting? At what intervals will measurements be taken? QOL-specific testing? What aftercare specific to lymphedema will be used? Manual lymph drainage? Bandaging? Compression garment use? Specific or directed exercises? None? What guidelines for limb care will be given, and how will they be delivered and tracked? What variables of treatment will be considered and figured into the research? For instance, chemo and rads as previous treatment? Type of surgery? Node involvement? Current drugs (including tamox and the AIs)? Use of Avastin (bevacizumab) and other drugs that inhibit the regrowth of vascular tissue? Weight gain or loss? Diabetes or other conditions that affect vascular function? Age? Stage of bc? Number of nodes removed? What provisions will be made in the study for tracking and recording possible development of LE from donor site involvement: leg, abdominal, genital LE? Other thoughts? Thanks, MomsDaughter! Really important subject for all of us. Hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 03:40PM Binney4 wrote: Dancingneedles, early LE comes and goes. That's called Stage I. A well-trained LE therapist can tell by the feel of the congestion if it is LE or not. Unfortunately there is no well-defined diagnostic measurement, either in amount of swelling or time it has to be there to qualify -- and truncal LE in particular is very difficult to quantify anyway. A variety of standards are used, which makes determining the percentages of LE occurrence impossible. If you're asking how long before Stage I LE moves to Stage II LE (which would involve fibrotic formation beneath the skin, more consistent swelling, and the beginning of the possibility that the swelling could not be permanently reduced), that too varies from one individual to the next. Could be a couple of months or a couple of years. LE can be present with NO visible swelling at all. That's called sub-clinical (or Stage 0) LE. It means the lymph system is compromised and lymph fluid is not being efficiently eliminated from the tissues. There may (or may not) be discomfort or feelings of fullness with Stage 0 LE. (As much as 30% more fluid than normal can be present in the tissues before any swelling is visible or measureable). The stagnant lymph fluid is protein rich, so it both irritates the tissues (causing a gradual build up of fibrosis and subcutaneous fat) and creates a heightened risk for serious systemic infection. Untreated, Stage 0 LE will eventually progress through the stages. It may be very gradual, though. Sub-clinical LE can be effectively treated with specialized massage, proper compression, exercise and skin care. If it's treated at that stage it's far less likely to progress or to result in serious infections.  So the amount of time that needs to pass before edema is considered LE may depend entirely on who's doing the considering. A well-trained LE therapist could call it accurately much earlier than someone without the specialized training.  I hope that helps some! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 03:22PM Binney4 wrote: Okay, I feel better now. rrs, you need a custom sleeve, because the off-the-shelf sleeves are too big for you. Have you tried Bio-Concepts? Perhaps if you gave your measurements to Lari-Ann there she could help you get the garments you need. 800-421-5647 Or try talking to some of the bandage suppliers. BandagesPlus and LymphedemaProducts both have fitters you can consult with by phone. I'm trying to figure out what the therapist is saying, and at least the part where she asks you why you're there sounds familiar -- PTs and LE therapists always try to clarify that so you and they are all on the same page. It doesn't mean you shouldn't be there, just that you both need to have the same goals in mind. Which at the moment you clearly don't. As for the business about scar tissue stopping LE flow, that's usually the case. Fibrosis from rads is the same, but not all of us develop fibrosis from rads, so that would be an individual matter. In my case, being bilateral, I can't move lymph to the opposite arm pit, and I can't  move it past the mastectomy scars. So ABOVE the scar I massage upward to the spot above the clavicle by the side of my neck. And BELOW the scar I massage downward clear across my waist to my groin. Does that help any? There are no books or DVDs showing this direction of massage and I don't know why, since plenty of us have had bilateral mastectomies. Just another of life's little mysteries! Did she show you how to massage around it? I sure wouldn't be discouraged about reaching a place where you can take some days off from the compression. Therapists are purists by nature, and one of their biggest frustrations is "lack of compliance." But in your case, where you're obviously doing everything you can to stay in control, the usual somber warnings about straying from the straight and narrow don't apply. Perhaps she just doesn't have enough experience to trust that each individual is different, and that when we have the tools we need to take control of our LE we can afford to experiment a bit with the stated limits. As for the "isn't that just gross?!" scare tactics, try to take that as nothing more than a challenge to continue to advocate, not just for ourselves, but for all those with LE who have been undiagnosed and untreated for so long by the medical community. We need to get the word out so people suffering from untreated (or undertreated, or mistreated!) LE can get the help they need from trained therapists, insurance companies, Medicare, and legislative justice. Hmmmm. Maybe I'm still a bit worked up after all. Too bad! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2010 11:42AM - edited Jan 25, 2010 11:45AM by Binney4 Just wanted to respond to Typhoon/Janet in particular, but this applies to post bc-treatment breast/chest pain in general. Doctors are so unfamiliar with truncal lymphedema that they don't readily recognize it, and even in the presence of some swelling it doesn't pop into their minds, so I'm bringing it up again here. Early stage lymphedema does NOT show visible swelling, but tingling, new numbness, stabbing pains and intense nerve pain are all likely symptoms. Delayed resolution of swelling post-surgery is very likely to be lymphedema. Trying a very short course of diuretics may be okay, but if it's lymphedema a diuretic is contraindicated, as it leeches out the fluid and leaves behind the larger protein molecules present in lymph fluid. Protein is irritating to the tissues and will lead to fibrosis formation or outright inflammation that is often mistaken for infection, so treatment of the real underlying cause is delayed and overuse of antibiotics can go on for months. Meanwhile the lymphedema progresses, making later treatment longer and on-going control more difficult. A prompt referral to a well-trained lymphedema therapist experienced in treating truncal lymphedema can solve the swelling and the pain with non-invasive and non-drug treatment. It can also contain possible spread of the lymphedema to the arm. Like all of you here, I spent months looking for relief from the life-altering pain, and a good therapist had me feeling better in a matter of days. I'm not saying this is the solution for all of us, just that lymphedema can cause these symptoms, and our doctors are not going to call this one correctly. If you'd like to pursue that possibility, here are pages on truncal lymphedema, on cording (Axillary Web Syndrome) and on finding a well-trained lymphedema therapist near you. Hope it helps, and we all find a way back to a pain-free life! http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Cording_and_Axillary_Web_Syndrome.htm http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Gentle hugs, Binney Edited to add: my lymphedema started on my prophylactic mastectomy side, with no nodes purposely removed, so ALND is not a prerequisite for either long-term pain or lymphedema.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2012 03:29PM - edited Nov 20, 2012 03:33PM by Binney4 Lburwell, much of what you're describing sounds like truncal lymphedema. It can affect breasts, chest, back--even the side and axilla. It can be extremely painful, and over-the-counter pain meds don't touch it. Without treatment, bras are intolerable and it's very limiting to activities that involve the arms in any way. The pain may even move around from spot to spot and be hard to pinpoint, making the entire breast (or even the whole trunk) miserable. The infections you mention are also indicative of possible lymphedema, both because infection can trigger or make lymphedema worse, and because the presence of untreated (or undiagnosed) lymphedema makes infection more likely and harder to treat effectively. The medical professionals who evaluate and treat lymphedema are well-trained lymphedema therapists. You can get a referral to one from any doctor on your team. Treating truncal lymphedema with Complete Decongestive Therapy reduces or eliminates pain and greatly reduces your risk of further infection. It's also non-invasive and actually quite comfortable. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm And here's more information about truncal lymphedema: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Please stay in touch and let us know what you discover. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2011 01:07PM Binney4 wrote: Grrr is right! But it gets better, honest! MLD is Manual Lymph Drainage, a very gentle directional massage technique that stimulates sluggish lymph vessels and clears fluid from the area. It needs to be done by a well-trained therapist, but s/he will also teach you to do it. Since you've already seen a LE therapist, she may have done it during your session with her. It begins with node clearing at the neck, axilla and groin, then clearing the chest/breast, and then the arm and hand. It's one aspect of Complete Decongestive Therapy, or CDT, which includes proper use of compression (garments or wrapping), exercise, and special skin care. More about CDT, including MLD, here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/treatments_for_lymphedema.htm In the meantime, while you wait for your insurance to kick in (grrrrrrrr again!), a lot of women find some relief my wearing a sports shirt (like UnderArmor), in a size smaller than you'd usually wear (but not so small it's uncomfortable), and inside out so the seams don't irritate your skin. Might be worth a try. Target has a brand that's more affordable than the UnderArmor. Also, stay REALLY well hydrated and pause whenever you think of it for a few slow, deep abdominal breaths. Both help move lymph fluid.  Keep us posted! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2017 04:04AM Binney4 wrote: Glennie, don't know if you know and use self-MLD, but if so you'll want to consult with a good LE therapist about how that routine will change now. You'll need to learn to redirect fluid from your left side downward, not across to the right axilla. If you haven't been doing self-MLD recently, now's the time to brush up on it, since it will be your best method of keeping things stable when you can't use the binder. Yeah, keep your arm movements below shoulder level for the first 10 days or so. That gives the delicate, insulted lymphatics their best chance to heal. Elevation of your arm when you're lying down and staying really well hydrated are important too, along with some deep abdominal breathing throughout the day. Make sure both arms are protected during surgery and following. A couple of bright pink LE armbands or those Lymphedivas alert sleeves might be in order! Free from the ReidSleeve people: http://www.lymphedema.com/alertband.htm $40 each from Lymphedivas: https://lymphedivas.com/hospital-sleeve/ (And of course, you'll need a supply of chocolate to have on hand for recovery!) Please keep us posted and let us know how you're doing! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 07:47AM - edited Jun 18, 2011 07:49AM by Binney4 Dawn, yikes! I'm really sorry you're dealing with this. Strawberries, huh? And they look so innocent! This is one of those times when it's a nightmare to be without a doctor you know and trust. Aaaaargh! Good for you for keeping up with the hydration and deep breathing! Elevation will help too. If you know how to wrap, that would be the place to start with compression, adjusting the whole thing a bit looser than usual to see how it's tolerated. Short of that, I'd think the daytime compression garments might be kind of hard on your skin, yes? Have you got some old, kind of loose ones you could try for 15 minutes or so at a time and see? On the other hand, if your arms are swollen at all the garments won't fit correctly, so be aware of that and skip it entirely if the fit isn't right. Where MLD is concerned, you might start with just node-clearing several times a day, if it doesn't aggravate anything, and gradually move on to gently clearing your trunk, then trunk and upper arm, then eventually the whole arm -- as it's tolerable. It's tempting to do the MLD too hard and too fast in an effort to get that puppy back in shape, so take your time and relax before you massage, and think about "kitten-petting gentle." Scratching is a danger here, so keep your hands and fingernails super clean and wear something with soft long sleeves if you can, so your skin stays covered and you can't accidentally scratch yourself. Watch for signs of infection (keep track of your temp, or any sudden new swelling or redness), and if you suspect that then you DO have to head for the ER. This would be a good time to start checking out the Therapist Locator for a new therapist near you. It might be reassuring to have some help getting everything back down. http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm If it was me I do know I'd be in a panic and convinced that my arms were never going to be in control again, but happily that's not the case. Once the rash is gone you'll regain the ground you've lost to this rash. That doesn't actually answer your question, does it? At least keep us posted and please know we hear you! Real gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 06:12PM Binney4 wrote: KS, I think self-MLD is a good tool to know. If you aren't getting good results from it you could either ask your therapist to observe your technique and make suggestions for improvement, or you can use other means to keep control. We're all different, so what works for one may be much less helpful to someone else. The bottom line is keeping the lymphedema in control and the tissues well drained. There are several ways to do that, and what works for you is what matters. For myself, self-MLD has lately been less effective, and I suspect it's because I'm getting rusty on the technique and need to check in with my therapist. She's Vodder trained and goes to re-training every two years, and she tells me she always finds her technique needs tweeking every time she goes for re-training, so it's no surprise if we need up-dating from time to time too. As Kira notes, the neck and chest clearing seems to me to be the most effective part of the routine, especially if I'm fairly active and using my arms throughout the day, and it's reasonably easy to do several times a day. I also find that if I do the Lebed exercise DVD, that's almost as effective for maintenance as self-MLD (though it's not as effective for flares). But that's just me. We need to know ourselves where LE is concerned. Kane, brava! All the ups and downs you've had to deal with have at least helped you learn a lot in a very short time. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2016 10:34AM Binney4 wrote: bfmomma, the bad news is that a lot of doctors know little about breast/chest lymphedema (also called truncal lymphedema). So the idea that your chest is not at risk is not entirely accurate, as any number of women here with truncal lymphedema can verify. And the good news is that MOST women do not ever develop lymphedema. Which sure doesn't guarantee that a tattoo to the breast area would not trigger lymphedema. So if you're determined to do this (and I can certainly understand why you might be) do be VERY certain that the artist you see is extremely cautious about your infection risk. Here's why: all of us who have had bc treatment are at risk for both arm and truncal lymphedema, and it can be present in the tissues before any swelling is visible (called pre-clinical or Stage 0 lymphedema). When there is excess lymph fluid in the tissues from this condition, the risk of cellulitis (infection) is greatly increased. In fact, you might want to check with your medical team for a prophylactic antibiotic for a few days surrounding any tattooing. Lymphedema is for life, so do give it careful thought. Hugs, and be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2007 02:36PM Binney4 wrote: Hi Brando, Trigeek and Jaybird, and wecome! You've all hit on a couple of LE truisms here. First, exercise is good for LE. Bc.org's November Expert Discussion will be on the subject of LE, and the Expert is a researcher currently studying the effects of bench pressing on prevention and treatment of LE. Naturally, because exercise stimulates lymph flow and this is a carefully supervised study, the results so far have been positive. So, yes, careful exercise can help prevent LE as well as help maintain control when used with other strategies once it develops. And secondly, you're right that to some extent it's a crap shoot, at least at the moment. That's because the more they study LE causes, the more complicated it appears to be.  When they developed the SNB procedure it was hoped that would reduce the incidence of arm LE following surgery to just about zero. While it has reduced the incidence some, the actual rate of reduction has been much less than hoped. (In fact, the incidence of BREAST LE among women who have had a SNB and rads is nearly 25%). What we do know is that overweight (and especially weight gained since treatment began) adds to the risk factor, as does diabetes. And women whose dominant hand is on the affected side (in other words, surgery on the right side if you're right-handed and vise versa) are much more likely to develop arm LE. So are women who have had past trauma or surgery to the chest. But there are other factors no one is sure of yet. Some researchers believe LE is a response to an inflammatory condition. Others are trying to explore the theory that not all lymph systems are created equal, and perhaps those with fewer nodes or lymph vessels to begin with are more at risk. It's probable that some women are far more likely to develop LE than others, but at the moment we still can't identify which are which. Another promising direction of LE prevention research is in EDUCATING post bc women about their risk and the simple life-style steps they can take to lower it. These steps include exercising -- in fact, exercise is encouraged, but so is stopping at the first sign of strain or aching, then going back to it later and building up to it very carefully. So far this approach has been remarkably effective in reducing the incidence of LE among post-bc women. Brando, in answer to your question, many, many women ignore all the warnings and don't develop LE. But there's a catch to that too: it is starting to appear that the damage done by overdoing it with a compromised lymph system is cumulative. In other word, the first time you move that heavy bookshelf may not trigger the LE, or the second time you let them use that arm for an injection, or the tenth time you fly cross-country without a sleeve and glove. But all of those are damaging events, and in some women it's the accumulation of them that finally triggers LE. In fact, there can be up to 30% more fluid in the tissues of your arm than is normal before you can notice any swelling. So at least in some cases LE is present without your being aware of it, and a single "last-straw" event will then make it known. Which is why we sometimes have women show up here with LE 5, 10, or 14 years (or more) after treatment. When I went through bc treatment there was no reason to believe I was at risk for LE. I 'm small, gained no weight with treatment, it was my left side and I'm right handed, I was in good shape physically and strong. Only one node was removed on the cancer side, and the other side was prophylactic. I took precautions anyway at first, but as time passed and nothing happened I got careless. I now have LE in both arms and all over my trunk--side, back, chest. I wish I'd been wiser, but I didn't know. Whew! All that just to say that I hope you'll all take another look at the risks you're running that are unnecessary. Of course this is an entirely personal decision and you must make whatever compromises work for you. But I want you to know that the steps to risk reduction are simple and not intrusive. If you're concerned because they'll remind you of your cancer journey and you'd rather forget that and move beyond, I just want you to know that once LE develops you will NOT be "moving beyond" your cancer experience, ever. MUCH happier to do everything you can to head it off. Here, for starters, is the National Lymphedema Network website, where you'll find Position Papers on Exercise, Air Travel, and Risk Reduction: www.lymphnet.org  As your Sister on this journey I just gotta tell you, do what you need to here. While I would never presume to tell you how to handle your own decisions, I CAN tell you for sure that you don't want LE. Be well, all! Binney

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 06:49PM - edited Dec 9, 2008 06:51PM by Binney4 Hi, Skigirl and all, A couple of thoughts: If you wear a compression sleeve, be sure to wear a compression glove or gauntlet (fingerless glove) as well, so that any swelling doesn't get trapped in your hand. If you don't have time to be well-fitted, don't settle for a poor fit, which can do more harm than good. For some hints on how to tell if the fit is right, check out the "Proper Fit" page at StepUp-SpeakOut.org: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_lymphedema_garments.htm The National Lymphedema Network has position papers on Air Travel, Risk Reduction and Exercise here: www.lymphnet.org Since you can't get a sleeve and glove before you go, there are a few things you can do to help prevent lymphedema. Drink plenty (helps dilute the lymph fluid), exercise your arm throughout the flight (arm up, and do cat-clawing motions in the air), and take deep abdominal breaths several times throughout the flight (stimulates the motion of the lymph). To provide some gentle added compression, you can buy a leotard or long-sleeve sports shirt in a snug size and wear it inside out so the seams don't irritate your skin. Get a snug isotoner glove and pack it along in your carry-on in case you develop any swelling, tingling or achiness in your hand. Some women fly without any problems for a long time and then suddenly a flight will trigger lymphedema, so a history of no problems is no guarantee of the same thing in the future. Rose, do check with a lymphedema therapist about the chest compression thing. Actually, an especially supportive sports bra or cami can help prevent chest/breast lymphedema, which can also be affected by pressure changes from flying. Lymphedema's complicated! But the fact is less than half of us will develop it in our lifetimes, so its certainly far from inevitable. Skigirl, have a great trip! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2008 08:06PM Binney4 wrote: Aw,bsnevada, I'm so sorry, and I'm sure hoping what you're dealing with is nothing more than normal post-surgical swelling. But the best way to know for sure is to ask for a referral to a well-qualified lymphedema (LE) therapist. You can find one near you (well, at least in Carson City ) by using the Therapist Locator at www.mylymphedema.com. Click on the Locator, then follow all the links (a couple of them ask for your zip code and email and will send you a list, others are listed on-line by entering your state.) A LE therapist will measure both arms, do a gentle physical exam, and evaluate your swelling. If it's LE, then she'll set you up for some therapy, which involves a couple of weeks of gentle massage (called Manual Lymph Drainage, or MLD), wrapping in special compression bandages, exercises and skin care. She'll teach you to do the MLD and wrapping yourself, too. Then when the swelling is down, she'll fit you for a compression sleeve and glove that you can wear to keep it that way. Here's a web site with lots of information about LE, the National Lymphedema Network at www.lymphnet.org. Their Position Papers are especially helpful. The pump is sometimes used along with the MLD, bandaging, garments, exercises, and skin care, but it is not a substitute for them, so you'll want to see a well-trained therapist and work out with him/her the best treatment for your needs. Please stay in touch here and let us know how we can help. Gentle (((hugs))) and prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 06:48PM Binney4 wrote: WNYnurse, I'm so sorry! Bottom line is, there's help available. Truncal lymphedema can follow any breast/chest surgery. It's treated my well-trained lymphedema therapists. Treatment involves a very gentle directional massage, careful skin care to avoid infection risk, exercises that help move fluid in the way you want it to move, and compression (not wrapping like arm lymphepema, just the use of gentle compression from such options as a breast binder, a well-fitted bra that offers good coverage, acustom-made vest, or a lymphedema bra, sometimes with the addition of special "swell spots" that target problem areas). Additional helps include staying very well hydrated (dilutes the lymph fluid) and stopping from time to time to do some deep abdominal breathing (stimulates the thoracic duct, our biggest lymph vessel). Here are pages about truncal lymphedema (near the bottom of the page are some compression options), and about finding a fully-trained lymphedema therapist in your area. You need a referral from any one of your doctors. http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Getting treatment promptly means quicker response and easier management, so you're in a good position now to get quick reduction and relief, and to be able to stay on top of it, too.  I hope that helps ease the path a bit. Please keep us posted. Very gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2008 12:17AM - edited Oct 31, 2008 12:21AM by Binney4 Oh, whoops! In my enthusiasm for bioimpedance testing I forgot you asked about hyperbaric therapy too. It's not showing particularly good results and it's a major grind to be confined to that chamber every day. It's still in the early experimental stage for very early lymphedema and doesn't seem to work at all for lymphedema that's been around more than 24  months. It's not a cure, at any rate. Just reduces the swelling some, but there are other methods that do that too, with less stress -- specifically lymphedema therapy, called Complete Decongestive Therapy (CDT) that includes compression, a specific gentle lymphedema massage, skin care, and exercise. If your BS uses a bioimpedance devise regularly and detects fluid accumulation early you can probably skip all of that. Which is why I get so carried away about bioimpedance. Hope that helps, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2007 03:03PM Binney4 wrote: What a refreshing thread! Thanks, Diane, for starting it. The spina bifida is indeed a very sad and difficult thing to have struggled with through 15 years. And this endless treatment for BC is so draining of everything we have in us. All of it threatens the future. As much as I love the women on these boards and sharing their experiences, sometimes I think that in coming here and seeing so many women dealing with BC -- and inevitably some of them worse off than I am -- it takes something away from me. It makes me think my own situation is common, and that I'm not doing a particularly huge thing in dealing with it. So why am I so wiped? After 15 years of dealing with the spina bifida it too has probably lost its shock value for you. Sometimes I think we need to take a hard, honest look at all we're dealing with and recognize how huge it is. That way, when we try to talk to God we can bring the entire muddle to the discussion, instead of just our sense of defeat and loneliness. We can say, "You bet I'm wiped! Look at all I'm dealing with here!" That helps me because I'm finally seeing it the same way God does -- as something enormously sad and difficult and waaaaay too much for me (or anybody, for that matter) to handle. That way it can be God's problem too, instead of just mine. That's your beautiful daughter in your avatar? We have a couple of disabled adult kids still at home too. Getting through cancer treatment with them was so difficult, but they sure did help me make sense of it. And along the way they gained so much self-confidence, because they "helped Mom live." Do look for those small gains, Diane -- maybe they'll help you see God still at work in all you've been given to deal with. Shrink, I appreciate what you're saying, and especially your honest seeking. I'm a seeker too, and I'll happily take the opportunity you've offered to pray for you -- tumor and seeking and all. I love the quote, it's spunky and up-beat. Do go ahead and speak to Whoever-Is-In-Control -- maybe you'll start a discussion that makes sense to you. In fact, maybe you wouldn't mind praying for me too. I'd appreciate it, and God knows, I need it. AKDeb, thanks for the reminder that God loves me. Nothing could be more important than that. Especially now. Hoping,  Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 12:24AM Binney4 wrote: AWB, yes! Definitely a dilemma for lymphedema risk. Thanks for pointing that out. PinkShirt, I have lymphedema, and I broke my leg. I could not use crutches or a walker. I used a knee walker, but if your upper leg is involved even that is not going to be a possibility. My suggestion would be to get the help of a well-qualified lymphedema therapist at once. S/he will take baseline arm measurements for future reference, give you tips and suggestions both for general lymphedema risk reduction and for your specific needs, fit you for a compression sleeve and glove to use prophylactically, and teach you a gentle lymph massage to help keep your lymph system functional. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm S/he may also be able to wrap your arm (a special lymph-stimulating wrap technique that supports lymph function) before surgery, or even immediately following. See if you can get your surgeon to coordinate with the therapist in your pre- and post-surgical care. Your situation is certainly unique (and I'm sooooo sorry about it!), and the care you receive should be too. Gentle hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Binney4 wrote: Hi, all, As many of us are aware, every one of us with LE owes a huge debt of gratitude to Pat O'Connor, who has been advocating for LE patients for over 20 years. He's the originator of the LymphedemaPeople website as well as a dozen yahoo and google discussion boards for specific LE populations (kids with LE, men with LE, women with lipodema, advocates for LE, etc.) He himself has had LE since childhood and has been dealing with both lymphoma (cancer) and lung problems for many years. But he continues to update his website as he's able with current research information, in order to make it available to us patients free of charge (unlike the National Lymphedema Network, which charges membership fees for access to most of their information). He has supported and inspired those of us who advocate for awareness among medical personnel and the general public. Anyhow, he suffered a serious fall last week, has stiches in his face and a couple of broken vertebrae, and also pneumonia. He's now out of the ICU, but because of the nature of his injuries he's unable to use a computer. So I'd like to suggest that we all take a moment out of our day to shower him with cards and get-well wishes, the old fashioned way--by snailmail. For all those who can remember how to address an envelope, and which corner to put the stamp in, here's an address where cards and notes will reach him: Pat O'Connor c/o 1361 Hillside Rd Monroe, GA 30656-4521 This is our chance to give back a bit of that encouragement he's been dishing out for all of us for years. THANK YOU! Binney Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 12:55AM Binney4 wrote: Vivo, you're an inspiration, you know that? Haven't "seen" you in a while and missed you! Kira covered things really well. I'd add to stop often throughout the day and do some deep abdominal breathing. It not only promotes lymph flow, but it aids relaxation, and that helps in so many ways! Another thought is to sleep with the head of your bed raised a bit, to aid lymph flow out of your neck area where they will be radiating (gravity helps!) Either raise the head of your bed a few inches on bricks or boards, or use pillows to elevate your upper body comfortably. Sleeping on your back would probably be the best bet, but if you're a side-sleeper at least avoid the radiated side for sure. You have a good lymphedema therapist, yes? See if s/he can help you with designing a self-massage routine that will drain the radiated area toward the other side of your body without actually massaging the left neck and shoulder area, by clearing nodes on the right side and the groin, then gently directing the fluid down and/or to the right.  Oof! Long journey, Vivo! Prayers for smooth sailing through this next phase. And lots of very gentle cyber hugs! Please keep us posted, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2010 03:33PM Binney4 wrote: Cynthia, I use my Jovi for long car trips also. I layer some shortstretch bandages over them for extra protection when we're making altitude changes. Looks weird, but it works. Also especially important to avoid caffeine, stay REALLY WELL hydrated, and do arm stretches every so often. In fact, more frequent rest stops are really a help, to walk around a bit and keep your arm moving, take some deep abdominal breathes and remember to drink some water at every stop (and in between, too). It is SO DIFFICULT to stop frequently, but we're talking about arriving in good shape, and it does take more time to do that -- sigh! Packing to move is a whole mine field. All that hefting and lugging stuff around. And it's so hard to just delegate it all. So do think through what to wear while packing too -- maybe best to wrap for that too. You still have to be careful, though, even if you're wrapped. Vary the activity, ask somebody else to do the heavy lifting, take your time (yeah, right!) Getting good rest is important for keeping the stress to a low boil. And once you get there, unpacking is yet another worrisome time where you'll need to be aware of what your arm needs by way of a change of activity and some down-time. Accepting these limitations is maddening, especially when you've got a goal to reach, but actually all those suggestions would make good sense for anyone moving across the country, LE or no. So maybe the LE just makes it more likely we'll take good care of ourselves even in the midst of very difficult circumstances. I'm so sorry about the unfortunate circumstances -- seems to be way too many of those lately. Glad you have somewhere to land, though, and I hope the landing is a soft one. Please keep us posted. Bon voyage! Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 11:19PM - edited Mar 30, 2009 11:20PM by Binney4 Hi, Vivo If your doctors never told you about lymphedema, it must be pretty scary for you! I'm really sorry. There's a lot you can do. I'm not sure where you live, but you need to find a well-trained lymphedema therapist who can help you. The treatment is called Complete Decongestive Therapy, and it includes a very special, gentle massage to help move the lymph fluid out of your arm, along with layered bandaging with special lymphedema bandages. When the swelling is reduced, you will be fitted for a compression sleeve and glove to keep the swelling from coming back. Without this treatment it can become more swollen, and it can also cause hardening of the arm, infection, and loss of arm strength and range of motion. Here's a web page with information about finding a well-qualified therapist near you. The listings include therapists all over the world: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Please know that this can be treated and controlled, and the treatment does not mean any more surgery or drugs. (Accupuncture is used by some women along with the Complete Decongestive Therapy, but you shouldn't use it alone, and not at all on your swollen arm, because infection is a very real problem with lymphedema.) Please tell us how we can help, Vivo! We're here for you. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2013 01:09PM - edited Apr 22, 2013 01:12PM by Binney4 Thanks, Hildy! Carol, the abstract is here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23439658 The article I downloaded by PDF after a google search was another risk reduction myth-buster rant called "Setting the Record Straight: Exercise and Lymphoedema" that was more than a bit over the top. Just don't get this agenda. Exercise is of course helpful--for a lot more than LE--but when exercise pros skip over the top of the precautions to make such wide claims we're back to Square One with educating doctors (not to mention patients). So I'm grateful all over again for your work on the exercise documents for both patients and professionals. You rock! The acupuncture study concludes that it may be helpful for women who have access to no other therapy interventions, which I consider a strange conclusion indeed. It's unfortunately true that there are too many women with little or no access to treatment, but then where are they going to get acupuncture? Better to focus on improving provisions for treatment for everyone who needs it. And on that front we have a LONG way to go! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 03:11AM Binney4 wrote: Tina, I send along the Women's Health and Cancer Rights Act of 1997 which specifies coverage for LE, but doesn't specify just the limb. I also send along the NLN Position Paper on Treatment, and whatever else I can find. Kira's long piece above should interest them! I don't send just the pertinent parargraphs, I send it all -- nothing quite like the whole context to educate them! BUT! You need to have YOUR DOCTOR fax all that, along with the letter of medical necessity (or yet another copy of the letter of medical necessity if she's already sent one), because if an MD sends it they have to read it. If you send it (and possibly if Solaris sends it) they aren't obliged to read it all. My onc's office always takes vindictive pleasure in sending them pages and pages of faxed educational material, so hopefully yours will find it just as satisfying. I've found the manufacturers to be very good at this sort of thing, so that's a good place to start. It's important for you to keep track of when anyone faxes material and then call the insurance people and be sure they received it. I don't know how many times they've claimed they "never got it"! So call, get the name and title of whoever you talk to and the date and time of the call. If they ever say, "We never got that," you whip out your little notebook and give them the whole run-down. It's like herding slugs, but you can get the job done! Yes! Go, fax, win!!! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2018 04:54PM Binney4 wrote: Hello, hapa, and welcome, These are all good questions, and I'll try to answer them. My lymphedema is complicated by the fact I had surgery on both sides, so it's bilateral. I also had trouble getting it diagnosed and properly treated, so it had progressed before I could get it under control. You will not have that problem, because you're already aware there's a risk, and you'll be alert and able to get help promptly. Getting treatment early means you will have an easier time of controlling it going forward. By far the best plan is to get a referral to a well-qualified lymphedema therapist NOW, for baseline arm measurements and personalized risk reduction suggestions. Here's how to find a well-trained therapist near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified... And here are some suggestions for lowering your risk of developing lymphedema: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_l... Because of the BMX, you are already at risk to develop lymphedema. Adding the radiation may increase the risk somewhat, but if that provides you with a way to beat the real beast of breast cancer, it will be more than worth it. There is no comparison. No one here will tell you lymphedema is easy, but it is not life-threatening, and even with bilateral arm and breast-chest lymphedema I'm living a very full and creative life. Bottom line is, we're here to help any way we can. Please keep us posted, and tell us how we can help. Hopefully others will be alone to share their thoughts. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 05:46AM Binney4 wrote: Esther, for sheer up-to-the-minute helpfulness and accuracy, the Lance Armstrong site is currently  the best for a brief lymphedema overview. It was written by Dr. Jane Armer, who is a leading researcher in lymphology and the director of the American Lymphedema Framework Project, which is defining the Best Practices for lymphedema for the medical community. Just a few words of caution about the NCI lymphedema information pages. There are some misleading points under the sections on signs of lymphedema, tests for diagnosis, and staging. The section on Exercise is similarly misleading. For a fuller and much more accurate understanding of the recent research regarding lymphedema and exercise, see the National Lymphedema Network website at www.lymphnet.org . (Or see StepUp-SpeakOut.org, for that matter!) This kind of carelessness with lymphedema information is unfortunately not unusual within the medical world, so staying informed about new research into causes, diagnosis, and treatment of lymphedema is well worth the effort. We've contacted the NCI in the past about these misrepresentations, but they've chosen to ignore us.  Neither the first such snub nor the last! Onward anyhow! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 08:08PM Binney4 wrote: Meg, I can just taste that panic, and I sure hope by now you've connected with your medical team. Yes, some of us here have had back swelling that turned out to be lymphedema. When it's lymphedema it can happen at any time after surgery, even years later. And yes, the swelling goes away, but you have to have help reducing the swelling and learning how to keep it under control. It's completely doable. Honest! I can tell you not to panic, but I'm not a patient person myself, so when I've had panicky things happen to me I haven't been very good at waiting for answers. This is an especially busy day for the docs, since it was a long weekend, but that doesn't help with your need to KNOW, so I'm really sorry for the delay in getting help. If there are signs of infection, or if you're having difficulty breathing (which could happen with a blood clot), then you need to act immediately. But otherwise they're not likely to view this as an emergency on such a busy day (because, strictly speaking, it's not). I hope in some small way that is reassuring. You really will have answers before long, and whatever is causing the swelling and pain will be addressed. Deep breaths, Meg! Hugs and prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2013 08:53PM - edited Sep 26, 2013 08:55PM by Binney4 RCT = Randomized Controled Trial f/u = follow up  In other words, it's a well conducted study, published in a well-respected peer-reviewed medical journal, despite the low number of patients and the short follow up, so it will be taken as strong evidence by our doctors. I can't help noting that one of the functions of the therapy period is educating us in the workings of the lymph system, standard self-care measures, and the more intensive skills (wrapping, self MLD, etc.) needed when we experience a flare. Or when we travel. Or when we exercise. Or when the weather changes. Or when our kids are sick and we overdo it. Or... In other words, what they're ignoring (no surprise there!) is that we're dealing with a chronic disease that we will have to self-manage for life, and the help they're suggesting is to pop in and see an under-trained fitter and get ourselves a sleeve (not even a glove or gauntlet). Good luck and good-bye. Something like handing a newly diagnosed diabetes patient a bottle of insulin and telling them to go ahead and use it. Hmmm, does it seem perhaps I'm a bit ANGRY!!!! Binney, steamed

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 06:32PM Binney4 wrote: Summergirl and Vivie, if you're thinking of getting compression garments to reduce your lymphedema risk while traveling, it's important to make sure the fit is good, because a poorly fitting garment can cause constriction and be worse than no garment at all: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_lymphedema_garments.htm And it's also important to wear hand protection, a glove or gauntlet (fingerless glove) so that any swelling doesn't get trapped in your hand: http://lymphedivas.com/lymphedema/gauntletandsleeve/ There are other every-day risk reduction steps you can take as well: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_lymphedema.htm Most of us get little help with this kind of information from our medical team, so it's one area where self-education is especially important! Be well, Binney
