Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2014 02:36PM Binney4 wrote: Glennie, robotic laproscopic surgery is not the same as traditional laproscopic surgery, and the angle is typically 30-40 degrees to accommodate the robotic arms and camera and assure that positioning does not have to be changed during the surgery (because it can't be done with the equipment in place). That angle is more extreme than with normal laproscopic surgery, as Sassy so brilliantly explained, and requires careful positioning. And it does result in swelling to the upper body, including face and neck. The swelling is normally temporary, but with LE you may need help from the therapist to move it out successfully, so you might talk to your surgeon about how soon after surgery you can set up appointments with the therapist. If the surgeon uses the traditional approach you would not likely experience the added swelling (as Sassy said). So you might want to talk to your surgeon about the options available to you. It's not real likely that a surgeon would take LE consequences into account when planning procedures, as that's generally below their radar, but perhaps bringing it up to her would result in a reassuring discussion and insure that your post-surgery needs are met promptly. I think what you want is a plan that takes into account likely scenarios, so that there are no nasty surprises waiting for you. Discussing the angle of positioning and the options available for surgery, as well as aftercare, will give you the ability to strategize and feel comfortable with the outcome. LE sure does complicate life!

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2014 08:02PM Binney4 wrote: Hello, icemaster, You've certainly had a rough go of it, and I'm so sorry! It's frustrating to have to stop working, but for sure pain is both exhausting and debilitating. So I'm really glad to hear that has been some better lately. I use a WearEase camisole called a Slimmer to hold the Swell Spot in place under my arm. It's not foolproof, but it works well enough. Like you, when I'm dealing with pain I find the padding of a Swell Spot helps it for a while only. Then I have to switch it out for another kind of "padding." I have a Kimbe Swell Spot from Solaris and a chest/side pad from JoviPak, as well as a stockinette-covered Medi Lymphpad (cut into a longish rectangle), and I switch out among them as needed. Here's the Medi, in case you're not familiar with them: http://mediusa.com/product/view/257/Finely+Napped+... I've had both Solaris and JoviPak night garments, which are the foam-stuffed sort, as well as a Velcro sort made by Circaid called Juxtafit. I like the Solaris best, but we're all different. They're hot in summer, and the foam-stuffed ones can be pre-chilled in the refrigerator, which makes getting to sleep easier. In winter, of course, they're more comfortable--just bulky. A lot of LE therapists don't like putting zippers in them (I'm not sure why), but I find the zippers make donning and doffing so much easier that it's well worth it. Solaris will put a full-lengh zipper in a sleeve/glove; Jovi only provides a zipper for upper arm OR the lower arm. Again, I have no clue why that is. As far as neuropathic pain is concerned, foam-stuffed night garments are WAY more comfortable than day garments, so there's hope out there! Basically it's a trial-and-error process to find what works best for YOU. Not easy, but there are so many choices now that we all have a better chance of finding garments that really work for us. Have you gotten PT help with the neuropathic pain? Mine improved considerably with a slow desensitization process. It's worth pursuing, anyway. None of this is easy, that's for sure, but I'm looking forward with you to some real relief and answers! Please keep us posted. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 08:00PM Binney4 wrote: Yikes, Chicago! If the sleeve is causing your hand to swell, by all means don't wear it again until you speak to your therapist. I've never heard of recommending a sleeve without a glove (or gauntlet) for the very reason you've discovered -- it can cause swelling in the hand.  What's the compression of the sleeve, 20-30 or 30-40? Since you're just dealing with pre-clinical LE it really needn't be more than a 20-30, and greater pressure than that is not necessarily an advantage. Aside from that, it could be a good fit but you need to wear hand protection whenever you wear a sleeve. Here's a page about correct fitting of garments: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_lymphedema_garments.htm Actually, your garment should not be anything like a rubberband around your arm. The compression is graduated: more pressure at your hand and less as it moves toward your armpit, in order to encourage lymph flow toward your body and away from your hand. (Which is why the idea of running with just a sleeve and no hand compression makes no sense.) If you don't have a therapist and are just operating on the doctor's information, then by all means call him and let him know what you're experiencing. Be sure to stay very well hydrated always, but especially when you're exercising. Whenever you experience any swelling, stop what you're doing, elevate your arm and do some deep abdominal breathing. Do some VERY GENTLE manual lymph drainage massage, and if you've been taught how to wrap you can do that as well. Wrapping is always an advantage when flying, so if you know how to do it that would be the way to go for your trip as well. Please keep us posted! Gentle hugs, Binney
Posts.Title: Is sleeve too tight? chicago-37 Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 04:32PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Mary, and welcome, I hear you on the dread of wearing compression garments, and the worse dread of never getting it under control. We want this FIXED, not dragging on and on! This is a nasty surprise for you 5 years out, and I'm so sorry you're struggling with it. It does sound like your therapist has been able to get things reduced. Has she taught you to do self-manual lymph drainage massage? Are you able to wrap your own arm? Those are both difficult skills to learn (especially since we never wanted to learn them in the first place!), but it's so important to know how for ourselves. It really helps to give us back some control over our lives. In answer to your question, the same thing happens to me if I don't maintain some compression. My arm can go an hour or two without a sleeve if I'm not doing anything with it, but my chest begins to swell within half an hour without compression. You were right to remove the wrap last night if you had pain (pain makes us swell more, and it just should not be happening). If you're able to wrap yourself, after this you can re-wrap when you remove it, adjusting the bandages and foam so that there's no pain. If you haven't learned how yet, let your therapist know that it's a top priority! Once you're through with therapy and ready to be fitted for compression garments, there are special night-time garments you can get that are much easier to put on than bandaging, and a lot more comfortable too. If you're not familiar with them, look at JoviPak, Solaris, and Telesto Medtech on the garment page here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Lymphedema_garments.htm But of course that doesn't solve the grief and frustration of having to deal with this chronic condition. The good news is that you really will get better at the skills you need to take care of yourself, and gradually it becomes less of a focus in your life. A lymphedema diagnosis is a kind of grief, and grieving is hard work. Do be gentle to yourself while you regain control. I'm glad you found us, and I sure hope you'll feel supported and comfortable here.  It gets better, honest! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2013 07:13PM Binney4 wrote: Tami, really sorry for this new development! But you've gotten prompt help and have a concerned PS keeping close watch on you, so whew! Here's information on cellulitis: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Cellulitis is a skin infection that can occur without any nodes removed, and in fact it needn't be connected with breast cancer at all. It does have a complicated relationship with lymphedema, though. First off, a cellulitis infection can trigger lymphedema if the lymph system is already compromised. And secondly, lymphedema (whether diagnosed or still undiagnosed) results in stagnant lymph fluid in the tissues. It's protein rich and warm, which makes it a perfect bacteria breeding ground. So any skin break (even micro-breaks from dry skin) that allows bacteria to enter can result in cellulitis. Sometimes cellulitis happens with no known break, though--it's a sneaky bugger! Lymphedema can occur with any breast surgery, nodes or not, though node removal raises the statistical risk. Even women without cancer who have breast augmentation or reduction surgery can develop lymphedema. And it can be present initially with no swelling. So, while I have not had cellulitis on my prophylactic side, I do have lymphedema on that side as well as the cancer side. And lymphedema can predispose us to cellulitis. Or cellulitis can trigger lymphedema. Or (and hopefully this will be your case!) cellulitis can just happen and have nothing whatever to do with lymphedema. Hope that helps some. Rest and no therapy for now sounds like a good plan. Be sure to stay really well hydrated, and remembering to take a few deep abdominal breaths every so often will help too (it stimulates the largest lymph vessel in our bodies). Elevate your LE arm with pillows, rest up, stay in touch with the doctor, and GET WELL SOON! Keep us posted! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 12:24AM Binney4 wrote: Cowgirl, I'm so sorry! Been there, done that, and it's no fun having this happen when you're nowhere near your own healthcare team. So, a few quick suggestions, starting with: don't ice it. Temperature extremes cause the body to send extra lymph fluid to the area, and you don't want that. Elevating is good, every chance you get. Tonight on a pillow while you sleep. Also drink LOTS--sounds counterintuitive, but it dilutes the lymph fluid and helps it flow. Deep abdominal breathing whenever you think of it--helps stimulate the largest lymph vessel in your body. Try not to use that arm/hand for much, especially nothing heavy. You don't say how you traveled, but both air travel and long car trips can aggravate lymphedema. Any chance you could get a long-sleeve sports shirt (like UnderArmour) before your trip home? Get it in a size smaller than you'd normally wear, and wear it inside-out so the seams don't irritate your skin. Try it on and be sure it's not digging into your arm pit. For your hand, an isotoner therapeutic glove can help, or even those "craft gloves" they sell at craft stores for women with arthritis. Anything that adds some compression to your hand without irritating anything. NSAIDs aren't good for lymphedema, as they encourage swelling, so no loss there. Since there's pain involved be sure to watch for any signs of infection and GET HELP AT ONCE. Obviously you don't want to make an ER trip at this point, but if you suspect infection DO IT ANYWAY. Here's information about infection with lymphedema: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Oh, and in answer to your question, yes, many of us have had trouble with flares when we're sick. Get well soon! Please let us know how you're doing, and tell us how we can help. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2013 09:32PM Binney4 wrote: Shira, this soon after surgery there are a number of things that could be going on. A seroma is a possibility--a pooling of fluids. These can be drained (usually painless) when you get in to see your new doctor. (Really sorry about the change of doctors, BTW--that's always so frustrating). The "fat caterpillar" incision is possibly just normal healing for now. Cording runs down the arm, from axilla to the base of the thumb, though it may only be noticeable in the axilla or elbow. Another kind of "cording" called Mondors can run from under the breast down the rib cage. But yours sounds like neither of those, so that's a good thing. You'll want to watch for redness, pain or continued rapid swelling, any of which could indicate an infection. If you suspect that, please don't wait for Monday, just take yourself to Critical Care or the ER and get started on antibiotics. Go easy with your arm through the weekend until you can be seen. In case it's lymphhedema, don't use hot or cold compresses, which can draw more fluid to the area. Stay well hydrated. Rest up! And please keep us posted. Gentle hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 12:27AM Binney4 wrote: Just want to pop in here for the sake of newbies reading this thread, and note that Dr. Becker has indeed been performing this operation for around 20 years. But because she has not followed her patients over that time, she in fact has no way of ascertaining whether any of them have developed "referrant lymphedema" (lymphedema in the lower extremities, abdomen or genitals as a result of removing nodes from the groin). She did publish a small and short-term study early on with a few selected patients, but the validity of that study is naturally in question for all those reasons (and others): small, short-term, selected participants. Just as my own breast surgeon still insists none of his patients has ever developed LE from his breast surgery (?!), so any surgeon can make claims of total patient safety and surgical efficacy as long as they don't look at their actual patients. Just a thought. Bottom line is, we're fortunate to have Trisha posting her experience here so we can all follow her process and outcome. That (along with solid research) is an amazing way to learn what we can expect from new treatment ideas. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2012 10:13PM Binney4 wrote: PinkHeart, that's not a stupid question at all, it's an important one. The answer is yes, definitely. Head and neck cancer has a very high risk of lymphedema in the face and neck. Any damage to the neck nodes would carry some risk, though whether a surgeon would know whether their patients developed it is questionable. It would depend on who the patient saw about the swelling, which might well not be the surgeon (especially since the surgeon couldn't do anything about it). One thing to be aware of with head/neck LE risk is that the swelling can be internal as well as external, in the mouth and epiglottis, interfering with swallowing, eating and talking--sometimes even with breathing. The results of a recent study of LE following treatment for head/neck cancer showed a rate of around 75% who developed some form of it, either external or internal or both: Prevalence of secondary lymphedema in patients with head and neck cancer: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21802897 Considering such statistics, and the devastation of a head/neck LE diagnosis, you have to wonder why these surgeons are so willing to dismiss the risk. It's treatable by CDT, just like arm and truncal is, but not every LE therapist has experience with head/neck LE and obviously it would be helpful to find one who does. There are both day and night garments available for head and neck LE. Here, for instance, are some nighttime neck and face swelling solutions: http://www.jovipak.com/head.html Hope that helps. Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 01:40PM Binney4 wrote: Christine, a warm bath is a fine thing (for all kinds of reasons!). Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2008 03:34PM Binney4 wrote: Aw, Betty, this should be nothing but delightful -- but I can sure identify!! LE (and the fear of it) can sure dampen an otherwise glowing occasion. The garments don't protect from either insects or sun. So use a gentle sunscreen that you've already tested on your other arm to make sure it agrees with you. There's a new bug spray that goes on dry ("Off!" maybe?) that ought to work well OVER the sleeve and glove. Haven't tried it. Avon Skin-so-soft directly on your arm works too. To tell you the truth, I find long-sleeved shirts a whole lot easier and less messy, so that's my plan of attack, but then fancy occasions aren't exactly long-sleeve-shirt friendly. (Don't just go without the garments, though, as the warm weather will aggravate the swelling and make you crazy.) Whichever, pick something and you'll be as prepared as you need to be, so hopefully you can put this concern aside and get into the spirit! Bon voyage and ole'! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 12:51AM Binney4 wrote: That's it -- a G-sleeve is a pink (or blue) stockinette "sleeve" that covers your arm from about your wrist to above your elbow, and it says to leave the arm alone. It looks very official to medical personnel (who unfortunately seem to ignore the alert bracelets--why is that???!!!) It's here: http://www.g-sleeve.com It was developed by a nurse, bless her -- and I agree, she's really nice to deal with.  It does make them ask questions, and if you think of it as a "teaching moment" you can help make it easier for the next BC Sister who has to deal with them. So I try to go to the hospital with handouts about LE, and the staff have always been appreciative -- nurses aren't TRYING to be stupid about LE, they just haven't been taught. So if you smile nicely and hand them information they'll actually read it -- sometimes right there on the spot. Here are a couple of things you might copy off to hand out: The Risk Reduction position paper of the National Lymphedema Network is here: http://www.lymphnet.org/pdfDocs/nlnriskreduction.pdf The StepUp-SpeakOut information page just for medical professionals  is here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/what_we_need_healthcare_providers_to_know_about_lymphedema.htm Happily, the American Journal of Nursing has just published the first installment of a two-part article about lymphedema -- YES! It's widely read by nurses and will introduce them to the specific needs of women with post-bc lymphedema risk.  Here's a link to the article, also a good one to copy off and hand out to anyone who may have missed it: http://bit.ly/3c7r7F Okay, I'll climb down off my soapbox now. Just had to get that word in about advocating whenever we have the opportunity. Together, we can make a real difference! Be well, heal quick! Binney

Posts.Title: Manual Lymph Drainage Wilsie2 carol57

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 10:24PM - edited Apr 7, 2009 10:26PM by Binney4 Hi, Hope, and welcome! Sorry about your mom's new worry that brings you here, but glad you found us. Yes, many of us here have truncal lymphedema. Here's a web page about it: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Near the bottom of that page you'll find lots of options for breast compression, so hopefully your mom will be able to find something more comfortable. It's true that pain can make her condition worse (since pain causes our body to send more lymph fluid to the area), so a poorly fitting bra can definitely cause trouble. But what your mom needs most is to get an appointment with a well-trained lymphedema therapist, who is the medical professional that treats lymphedema. Doctors often know very little about this (it's outside their field of specialty), so it will probably be up to you to locate a qualified therapist. Then a referral from and one of your mom's doctors should have her on your way to some real relief! Here's a page about finding a well-qualified therapist in your area: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm The therapist will do measurements, evaluate the stage of the lymphedema, and begin treatment, which includes a couple of weeks of very gentle daily massage (called Manual Lymph Drainage) of the neck, breast, arm and back to move fluid out of the area. Then the gentle compression of a well-fitted bra or cami (and perhaps a "swell spot" or two if needed) will keep the swelling, pain and infection risk under control. The therapist will teach your mom (and you too, if you're able to attend with her) to do the massage herself, so that she can use it daily to keep the swelling down. Hope that helps. I sure do hear you about your mom being discouraged -- bet you are too. But it'll be good, Hope. Tell your mom we're all here for her! Very gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 12:52PM Binney4 wrote: Being a fiber nut, I'd never use Woolite on anything (especially not on wool -- way too harsh). I wear Gottfried also, and wash them on the gentle cycle in a mesh bag, with a load of towels, then hang-dry them in the bathroom. Using the washer is a compromise that may not be ideal for the garments, but it's ideal for me -- all my life I've believed firmly that anything that had to be handwashed could not possibly belong to me. KEEPING the dang things clean throughout the day is another issue. We did a whole section at StepUp-SpeakOut on glove hygiene, because when we asked manufacturers about it they were all completely stumped. It's here (please feel free to add any ideas you've discovered!): http://www.stepup-speakout.org/How_You_Can_Cope_with_Lymphedema.htm#GLOVES_AND_HYGIENE Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: May 28, 2010 03:17PM Binney4 wrote: 3jaysmom, brava for you! Go for it! A poorly fitting garment is useless -- worse than useless because it can cause new swelling. This is not about comparisons to other clients. Any company you deal with should be treating you as though you're their most important, most serious client. That's just basic. A statement like that about them dealing with "more serious" problems is maddening, but they simply have no notion how serious a medical problem LE is -- and how much their incompetence can mean to it. Don't mail it back, TAKE it back. You're right that mailing is a waste of time you need. The reason Gottfried can't help you is because it was the fitters' error -- if they take it back from you and fix it, they won't get paid for the extra work the fitter created for them. If the fitter sends it back, then the company he works for has to eat the full cost of their error. And they should. One thing you CAN do is let Gottfried know about your experience with this fitter, and ask them to recommend one near you that they trust. Not only should your dealer (and your insurance company) fix the fit, but they should also fix the color. These are EXTREMELY expensive little accessories, so there's absolutely no excuse for you to have something you didn't order. Black in important; their lying about that being the only color doesn't make it so. That said, are you sure your garments are Gottfried? There are other makers whose garments do not come in colors, and if they ordered from one of them the maker won't be able to help with color. BUT if you ordered black when they fitted you, and they didn't tell you they didn't come in black, then you might be able to get them to start over with Gottfried. I just wouldn't let them get away with anything. The fitter pays about 1/3 what the insurance company does, so remind your case worker that you're saving her a bundle by making them get this right. Otherwise they're paying big bucks for something that will not control your condition. Wish I could say you're the only one who's run into this problem, 3jaysmom, but unfortunately it's all too common. A good fitter is a real gift -- if you have one, bake her/him brownies! Keep us posted! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 07:32PM Binney4 wrote: I'll second what Kane and Suzybelle said. Clean, moisturized skin and daily checks for any skin deterioration are important for all of us, but especially for fragile skin. I also agree that wrapping would be easier on her skin than garments, but what would be easiest of all for both of you would be a Solaris sleeve with full-length zipper. BUT you have to be very careful zipping it --keep your own fingers between the zipper and her skin. JoviPak makes a night sleeve in an extra-soft fabric, and if you request it they'll put a partial zipper in it, but they won't do full-length zippers (they'll put them either on the upper or lower arm, and I'd guess the upper arm would be the best place for it.) If she's wearing it night and day, order two so you can wash one. Since it's summer, both the Solaris or JoviPak can be refrigerated when not being worn (put it into a plastic bag and stuff it into the frig), so when it goes on it's cool, and the foam chip stuffing holds the cool for a few hours. If, though, she's insistent on day garments, Bio-Concepts makes garments for elderly patients (and neonates) from a fabric called "Soft". It runs easily, but a dot of Fray-chek from JoAnne's will stop any runs as soon as they start. Bio-concepts will also make them with a full-length zipper which has an underlining so it won't catch the skin. There is one donning devise she could also try for day sleeves that lays the fabric down on the skin rather than having to tug it all the way up. It's called Ezy-As. There's a video of it here: http://northernliving.tv/ezyas/view.php?ser=6 And for you, there's an amazing book called Lymphedema Caregiver's Guide: Arranging and Providing Home Care by Kearse, McMahon, and Ehrlich. It's available through the National Lymphedema Network or the LymphNotes website, or you can order it from any book store or Amazon. At 400+ pages it's comprehensive, well illustrated, and it gives step-by-step directions for everything you need to know. It also lists resources and has an excellent index and appendix. Loads of information and encouragement. Give her a hug from all of us, and keep one for yourself as well! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2017 08:02PM Binney4 wrote: Jackie, sure am sorry you're getting this run-around. Lymphedema comes in stages, and what's called "Stage 0" is actually a pre-clinical lymphedema--which means, no swelling is visible or measurable by most measuring methods, but there is excess fluid piling up in the tissues. This fluid back-up must reach a certain percentage before it becomes visible. BUT!!! This is the very best time to treat your lymphedema, because with proper care it can be kept from progressing. The symptoms of pre-clinical lymphedema include heaviness, throbbing, and/or tightness--or as some women say, even just a "funny feeling" in your arm. You can get a referral to a qualified lymphedema therapist from any member of your medical team, and here's how to find a well-trained therapist near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified... Do not back down or let anyone deny your reality--advocate for yourself and get the best help you can. You're worth it! Gentle hugs, Binney (P.S.-Just as an aside, I find there's no use wasting energy lamenting the fact that you have to fight for great lymphedema care. Better to spend the energy patting yourself on the back for being proactive and competent. And also, chocolate helps!)

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2012 03:56AM Binney4 wrote: Foreverhopeful, NOT a fool! Not even close. We all do the best we can with the information we have. Pat yourself on the back for your courage and for getting through yet another surgery. We're all joining you in being "forever hopeful" about this. (It's a great screen name, and you might as well claim it for this as well!). The study I cited above is for head/neck cancer patients, which is what PinkHeart asked about, and that's not a category you fall into. There aren't any studies about head/neck LE from VLNT using the neck as a donor site because it's a brand new procedure and there hasn't been any follow-up, but certainly your surgery was nowhere near as extensive as would be needed to treat head/neck cancer. As for risk reduction techniques, I don't know what they'd be, except that I suspect a bit of daily face and neck self-mld would be prophylactic. There are instructions on-line, but this is not a do-it-yourself situation, so do find a LE therapist with head-and-neck experience (if yours is not already experienced) and ask for an appointment to discuss risk reduction and to learn a personalized mld routine. Here's how to find LE therapists near you that you can call and ask about their experience: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Here's the good news: the facial/neck mld routine is incredibly relaxing and delicious. Done slowly at bedtime it'll put you into a charmed and relaxed sleep. Ahhhh!  Please don't waste any energy beating yourself up--you don't deserve it and it sure doesn't help. Go for joy instead. Gentle hugs, Binney

Physician Intensive: Lymphedema Management for the Practicing Physician This Physician Intensive brings together leaders in the field of Lymphology and related areas to provide a concise review of the principles of lymphedema care. Topics addressed include: anatomy and physiology, differential diagnosis, wound care and lymphedema, and more. The video runs 3 hrs 30 min on VHS. It is ideal for in-service presentation during a week of lunch breaks. The original Price was $45.00 The Remainder Sale Price is $22.50 for non-NLN members The Adjusted Price is $17.50 for NLN members. Order it on the NLN web page www.lymphnet.org while stock lasts. Bob Weiss" At last! A firm but gentle way to say "Smarten up, doggone it!" to all those clueless medical types. Binney  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 10:39PM Binney4 wrote: DiamondGirl, do you have a lymphedema therapist? If so a lunchtime drop-in just to check the fit would be helpful. If not, then it seems to me you'd be better off without it. Can you get a long-sleeved sportshirt like an UnderArmor before you fly? If so, get it snug but not irritatingly so, and turn it inside out so the seams don't irritate. Isotoner therapeutic gloves can also be helpful so that fluid doesn't end up in your hand. Before and throughout your trip stay VERY WELL hydrated. At intervals do some deep abdominal breathing and exercise your arms with gentle stretches. Cat-clawing over your head (or make a fist and release it slowly and steadily while holding your arm above your head) is good. Also holding your arms straight out in front of you and bending at the elbows to touch your finger to your nose. Will your fellow-travelers think you're nuts? Possibly, but you'll never see them again, so ignore! While packing and at the airports, be careful about jerking suitcases around. Get somebody else to lift them in and out of the overhead bins and off the carousels. Whenever possible, elevate your arm -- on pillows at night too.  When boarding, I stop and tell the smiley flight attendants that I have a medical condition that requires that I drink a lot of water, and they've always been good about making sure I stay well supplied. Don't be bashful, because you want to be in great shape when you arrive, since you'll be in a stressful situation. Continue to wear the UnderArmor if you're going to be doing any heavy lifting while caring for your mom. I'm so very sorry about the reason for your flight. Prayers for a really precious time with your mom and family. Please keep us posted! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 12:35AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Lisa! What a harrowing tale! You've really been through it with this. I'm so sorry, and I hope it's quickly resolved and your mind put at ease. What a puzzle! There are several reasons for swelling besides either lymphedema or seroma, and your doctor will want to check them all out, just because that's what they do best. If he's comfortable going ahead with the surgery it'd be real wise to start a prophylactic antibiotic a day or two before the surgery, so call Monday and ask about a prescription. That's because both seromas and lymphedema are, sadly enough, great places for bacteria to breed, so you'll need the extra protection to avoid serious infection. In case this were to turn out to be lymphedema, what you'd want would be some professional help lined up for as soon after surgery as possible. And the professional who diagnoses and treats lymphedema (LE) is a specially trained lymphedema therapist. So when you call for the antibiotic, ask if he'll give you a referral for a LE evaluation as well. Since there are as yet no state-mandated LE training standards, you need to make sure the therapist you go to has at least 135 hours of specifically LE training beyond his or her PT or OT certification and at least a year of supervised LE experience. Here's a web site for locating such a person near you: www.mylymphedema.com. Follow all four links on the Therapist Locator to the grad lists of four fully-accredited therapist training schools. In the meantime, do you have any sort of bra or cami that will give you gentle compression without any of the seams or straps cutting into the swollen area? If not, either a leotard or a sports shirt (the "body armor" type that bike racers wear, y'know?) may be helpful in controling any further swelling and providing you with more comfortable support. Try it one size smaller than you'd normally wear, and turn it inside out so the seams don't irritate your skin. Stay well hydrated, avoid using the arm on that side for much, or doing anything heavy or strenuous (gentle stretches are okay, and slower is better), and do some deep abdominal breathing several times a day (whenever you think of it actually--it helps stimulate your lymph system to move fluid.) Avoid hot water, hot weather, or hot compresses, as that draws fluid. Cold is okay if it gives you some relief, but not too cold and not for too long at a time. As to why your PAs didn't think of LE, that one's easy: because the lymph system is not taught much in any of our medical training programs in the U.S. (A recent survey of medical schools found that our doctors have an average of 15 minutes of instruction in the lymph system in their entire medical school curriculum. ) Obviously you're going to have to be your own advocate here. Always an adventure is right! Hope this leg of your adventure goes smoothly, and that you get the help and answers you need. (((((Hugs!))))) and prayers for a successful and un-stressful surgery next week! Keep us posted, Binney
Posts.Title: Seroma->->BreastLE?!?What about StageII Recon? LisaSDCA sccruiser

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2008 09:42PM Binney4 wrote: Aloha, Beachflower! I hope someone will come along who's more familiar with the latest in SLNB than I am, because I thought you couldn't do it after a mastectomy. To some degree it's true that the greater the number of nodes removed, the higher the risk for lymphedema (LE), but there are several other factors that influence your individual risk. Some we know, like radiation therapy, diabetes, previous chest/breast surgeries or trama, weight gain or obesity, and seroma or infection following surgery. Others we're still guessing about, like genetic predisposition, inflammatory process, and possibly certain chemotherapy drugs. Essentially, we're all at risk for this and the risk is for life, but in reality less than half of us will ever develop it. You can do all you need to to fight the cancer and still reduce your risk by following a few simple life-style guidelines. The National Lymphedema Network lists them in their position paper on Risk Reduction here: www.lymphnet.org You'll find their position papers on Exercise and Air Travel helpful as well. Since you've had bilateral surgeries you'll want to follow the guidelines for both arms One good idea is to get a referral to a well-qualified LE therapist. That would be someone with at least 135 hours of specifically LE training beyond her/his PT or OT certification, and preferably at least a year's experience treating LE. You can use these two sites to find some near you: www.mylymphedema.com  (Click on the Therapist Locator and follow all the links.) www.clt-lana.org  (Their menu on the left-hand side of the home page has a page for locating a therapist.) A therapist can do baseline measurements of both arms for future reference, teach you a prophylactic massage you can do yourself, discuss risk-reduction strategies, and fit you for gloves and sleeves you can wear for exercise, travel and any strenuous or unusual activity. S/he can also reassure you about LE and be available for any questions that might arise. And of course we're all here for you, too! Be well! Binney

Home and recuperated, I sent a letter off to the hospital naming names of helpful nurses who treated my arms with the respect they deserved, and I trust that message got back to those nurses and encouraged them to "go and do likewise" next time. It REALLY shouldn't be this way. But it REALLY is. At least a colonoscopy gives you adequate time to prepare for your starring performance as a LE advocate -- emergencies are a whole lot trickier! Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 09:08PM Binney4 wrote: Alison, what a nasty surprise! Good for you for acting on it quickly! There's information about lymphedema emergencies here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Until the infection is clearly getting better, DO NOT do any self-MLD or use compression garments, as that can spread the infection. You should see improvement within the next 24 hours, and if you don't -- or if it gets worse -- be sure to hop back to the ER real quick, as you may need IV antibiotics. It can help to circle the reddened area with a marking pen so you can see if it's spreading or getting better. Do you have a well-trained lymphedema therpist, and have you done a Therapy Intensive (MLD, wrapping, exercises, skin care, learning to do all those things yourself, and fitting for compression garments?) With excellent lymphedema control you'll have a good chance of avoiding any reoccurance of the cellulitis. So if you haven't had good help you might want to get a referral for that. If you have a therapist you trust, make an appointment with her to review your self-care routine and see if there are ways to improve your control. Cellulitis can worsen lymphedema, and your therapist can help you reduce the damage. How it affects your working depends on how sick you are and what kind of work you do. Cellulitis can spread rapidly and necessitate a hospital stay, and that affects work, for sure! Hopefully with your prompt ER visit you'll soon be well enough to resume all your activities. At any rate, do plan to get plenty of rest, stay very well hydrated, and elevate your arm. I hope you'll feel welcome to join us "swell" Sistahs over on the Lymphedema forum, where there are lots of women who can offer shared experience and encouragement. Real gentle hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2010 09:39AM Binney4 wrote: Tam, hello, Your post reads like an ad, y'know? I hope it's not, and that you're just here to share your bc and LE journey with us, right? Since we have other threads regarding colored and patterened sleeve covers, I'll just reinterate the warning that if you use a cover of any kind -- whether one of these or the WarriorWear sort or whatever -- order it big and have your LE therapist check the fit before you wear it. At least two possible problems with sleeve covers: The first is that this will add overall compression to the arm, increasing compression in your arm but not your hand and running the risk of trapping fluid in your hand. And secondly, that you'll add compression unevenly, creating a tourniquet effect like a blood pressure cuff somewhere along your arm, which will cause a flare (or with repeated use, fibrosis). Nobody needs that, so check it out first! Lunakin, thanks for the tip on the Target brand sports shirts -- I'm gonna look into that, for sure. Hopefully a bit more affordable than UnderArmor? Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2008 06:34PM Binney4 wrote: Little-G, where lymphedema is concerned there are NO stupid questions. In fact, one of the women here awhile back called it "Breast Cancer's Dirty Little Secret," because it's so hard to find any good information about it. So: LE is lymphedema, which is a blockage of the lymph system that usually causes swelling when the lymph fluid backs up and accumulates. It doesn't form "puddles" like a seroma, but oozes between all the cells, where it can cause infections because bacteria love it. There can be quite a lot of oozing lymph fluid before any swelling can be seen, so a feeling of fullness or heaviness or "thickness" may be the first symptom you notice. In breast cancer veterans, the blockage in the lymph system happens because surgery or radiation damages the nodes or the tiny vessels that carry lymph. The whole lymph system (nodes, vessels, lymph fluid) is all part of our immune system, so it dumps lymph fluid anywhere that our bodies are injured (which is why your sprained ankle swells, for instance) and then carries off any damaged cells or nasty intruder cells, to be disposed of. Sort of like a garbage truck. Any member of your healthcare team can refer you to a LE therapist. But since there aren't yet any legally binding requirements for LE training in any state (we're working on it!) you have to call first and make sure any therapist you see has had at least 135 hours of specifically LE training, and at least a year's experience treating LE. In my case, my surgeon wanted to "wait and see" if the swelling got worse before he gave me a referral, so I went to my PCP, who sent my onc a note requesting that he refer me(?) I sure hope you don't have to see that many people to get the help you need! Did any of that help? Hope so! Binney
Posts.Title: Symptom Question Little-G Little-G

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2014 07:08PM Binney4 wrote: KimberlyAnn, lymphedema is an inflammatory condition, and that inflammation can present (especially in the breast area) as redness that is unaffected by antibiotics (since it's not, after all, cellulitis). This condition baffles surgeons and oncs on a regular basis, but when the cause is lymphedema, then it responds to both a topical anti-inflammatory and to Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD). The topical meds would be a temporary "fix" that would not remove the causative agent, which is stagnant lymph fluid. The MLD would remove the cause (although temporarily--you'd have to keep up with the self-mld and probably some compression as well). The peau d'orange is also possible with lymphedema. Again, that should respond to MLD, especially at such an early stage. Truncal lymphedema can affect the entire affected upper quadrant, so certainly it could be the cause of the areas of fullness and pressure you mention.  On the other hand, besides the IBC you're concerned about, cellulitis is something to consider. It can "percolate," sometimes for a couple of weeks, before it suddenly becomes a raging and obvious infection. So if you experience rapid new swelling, redness or pain, get to your doctor or the ER at once. How frustrating! Please keep us posted--we'll be thinking of you for sure! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 09:45PM - edited Jan 25, 2008 09:47PM by Binney4 Hi, Kick, Yes, there sure is a way to undo that damage, and any damage that may happen in the future, too. Learning how to do that gives you a lot of freedom you don't have right now. But it's important to act quickly to get the help you need. Lymphedema (LE) is staged, just like breast cancer, and it progresses if it's not treated. This progression may not mean that it grows bigger, but that there is damage being done INSIDE, whether it gets bigger or not. The damage includes fibrosis (hardening of the tissues) that can further block lymph flow and eventually limit your strength and range of motion. It also ups your risk of serious infection that can lead to hospitalization, and in the later stages it leads to permanent swelling that can't be reversed. On the other hand, I sure hear you about the idiot insurance situation. Perhaps, since there was NEW damage done by the massage, you can ask your doctor for a NEW referral for therapy. It's worth a try. If the two therapists you saw before were not responsive to your need to learn self-care quickly so your insurance won't run out, try the www.mylymphedema.com link above to contact another therapist. Ask whatever therapist you choose how she can help you with your insurance. Perhaps an appeal or grievance will help. That's how I got the treatment I needed, but it took pages of documents (mostly copied from the www.lymphnet.org site above and faxed by my onc) to educate them about LE in general and my needs in particular. Also, plan how you will work together with your therapist to learn both the entire massage and the proper way to wrap your hand and arm to bring down the swelling and keep it under control YOURSELF.  Ideally you should be able to complete 20 or more sessions of massage and wrapping 23/7 with a therapist, but if that doesn't fit your financial and insurance reality, then you have to work together to speed up the learning process and also apply some major self-discipline to follow through on the self-care plan you create together. That's a tough route, but doable. It helps a LOT if your DH or a friend can go with you, take notes, learn along with you, even video-tape the wrapping and massage so you can review it later. (If you tape the wrapping, have your friend stand behind you and shoot over your shoulder so you get the same view you will have when you're wrapping yourself -- that hint comes from Andy, who used to hang out here a lot but is now moving on and reclaiming her life - yes!) Does that sound daunting? (Sure does to me. ) But it's SO NEAT to gain these skills and be able to use them whenever you need to. Gives you back the control over your own life. Kick, whew! LE is a lot to handle. When your insurance won't cooperate it's maddening, to say the least. How can we help? Please let us know! Binney
Posts.Title: Massage/Risk With Lymphdema Katiejane OLBinNJ

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 05:24PM - edited Sep 29, 2008 05:30PM by Binney4 Oh, dear! Isn't this a rat's nest, though?! I keep asking these people why I should know all this, and where I was supposed to learn it, and why they DON'T know it, but they just mutter something and leave it at that. Once in a while I do run across an insurance person who knows all this stuff, but that's only after showing up at the insurance office with my lunch and assuring them I'm not budging from that spot until they straighten it out. Once they're sure I mean it (usually not until I'm half-way through my peanut-butter sandwich) they call in the mysterious person who actually knows how to get the information. But next time I need that person, they've vanished. Odd business, insurance. Hopefully someone will be along soon who's worked in the field and can lead us through this mine field. In the meantime, a few items I've managed to gather that might help. Or might not. For me, it's a perpetual fight. Anyhow, factoid #1: sleeves and gloves are both called "compression stockings" in insurance lingo. (Their willingness to settle for inexact language may be one of the reasons they never make sense when they talk to us.) So when I turn in a prescription for two sets of sleeves and gloves for each arm, I eventually get a letter of approval from my insurance company on which they've typed the words "1 compression stocking" eight times. And I'm not making this up! Item #2: Medicare doesn't cover garments, as you discovered. They DO cover them if you've neglected your LE long enough that the lymph fluid is leaking through your pores and causing skin lesions, because then with the open wounds the garments fit the criteria of "secondary surgical dressing", see? (I'm not making this up either -- I wish I were!) I actually know two bc Sisters in my town who have no options other than this, so they wait until their skin fails and then they can go get new garments. I hope you all appreciate the calm way I'm writing this, because it's taking tremendous restraint on my part. Item #3: Our friend and lymphedema advocate Bob Weiss is working hard to change these things, but...well, this is not a day when I need to explain to anyone why getting new regulations past Congress can be difficult. He has made some progress, as you will note in this notice on the National Lymphedema Network web site: http://www.lymphnet.org/lymphedemaFAQs/legislation/legUpdates/legUpdates_Feb2008.htm He has also offered his help in filing for reimbusement from Medicare and offers the following explanation of the process: "FILING A CLAIM FOR REIMBURSEMENT FOR COMPRESSION GARMENTS * Garment supplier fills out an ABN and gives Beneficiary a copy. Beneficiary pays garment fitter and gets a receipt. Make sure that this is the latest version of Form CMS-R-131. I have the version dated (03/08). This is important since the Section (G) Options were in reverse order from earlier versions. The option to be chosen is the only one which states in bold "I can appeal to Medicare". * If the Supplier should choose to file the claim for the beneficiary, they will file on a Form 1500. Ask that they fill out Item 27 Acceptance of Assignment with a "NO", and further place the note "Beneficiary refuses to assign benefits" in Item 19. (see note below why Supplier may not be motivated to file for the beneficiary). * Beneficiary submits CMS form 1490 Patient's Request for Medical Payment to Medicare requesting reimbursement for the garment listed on the ABN, and attaches receipt. Block 6 Authorization says "... and request payment of medical insurance benefits to me." just above beneficiary's signature. * Medicare sends a denial directly to the Beneficiary. Denial appears on the quarterly Medicare Summary Notice (MSN). After the headers on this form, the sentence "This is a summary of claims processed from ... to ...". Following this there should be a section labeled "Part B Medical Insurance-Unassigned Claims". In the last column "See Notes Section" there will be a series of code letters denoting the reason for the denial. There will also be detailed instructions for appealing the decision. There is a 120-day appeal period after which no appeal will be allowed. * Beneficiary consults Bob Weiss [LymphActivist@...] to proceed further, i.e., several more denials will come down the pike before it goes to an administrative law judge... At this point I will need a copy of the MSN and I will either guide the beneficiary in the first appeal, or I will file it on behalf of the beneficiary. This first appeal to an "independent" Medicare Contractor is called a "Redetermination", the next appeal to a "Medicare Quality Independent Contractor" or a "DME MAC" is a "Reconsideration", and the next appeal is to an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ). None of these appeals costs any more than the cost of making copies and postage. There is a 60-80% chance of a favorable determination by the ALJ. In the event that the ALJ renders an unfavorable decision then we will appeal to the Medicare Appeals Council, where I run about a 50% favorable rate. IF the Beneficiary gets reimbursed after 2 years or so, the ABN states that "If Medicare does pay, you will refund any payments I made to you, less co-pays or deductibles." This puzzles me. Does this mean that Medicare will reimburse the garment fitter directly? (That's crazy because it is definitely not in a garment fitter's interest to go to the trouble of submitting an ABN for a Beneficiary only to have to refund their money at a later time). You are correct that the Supplier has little incentive to file your complaint. The supplier receives a reduced amount of reimbursement from the retail price of the item, and if they are a Medicare Supplier they are required to file a claim for something they know will be denied. So they will ask for payment in advance. So as long as they are filing on behalf of the beneficiary it is important for the beneficiary to refuse to assign benefits on the Form 1500. That way there will be no refunds necessary. (Thanks to therapist Kevern Hartmann for providing the framework for this piece and forcing me to research the appeal process. I would ask any reader who discovers any errors or changes to the process to contact me immediately. Please remember that I am not allowed to provide medical or legal advice. All I can do is to read the appropriate regulations and policies and tell you what my understanding is.) Robert Weiss, M.S. Lymphedema Patient Advocate LymphActivist@aol.com" So if you have Medicare please appeal, as it helps provide a basis for Bob Weiss to bring to his lobbying efforts. Thank you from all of us! Okay, Item #4: Here's Pat O'Connor's LymphedemaPeople page on insurance codes and various insurance practices: http://www.lymphedemapeople.com/thesite/lymphedema_insurance_billing_guidelines.htm And finally, Item #5: Here's an article that may save you some pennies at year's end -- or at least next April. It's not about garments, exactly, but it is about medical deductions: "Maximizing your medical deductions By Kay Bell Medical costs seem to increase every year. There is a way to get your Uncle Sam to foot some of the doctor bills, but you need to make sure you know and follow the rules. The Internal Revenue Service lets you deduct medical costs as long as they are more than 7.5 percent of your adjusted gross income. This percentage may seem unattainable at first glance, but with a little tax triage you might just meet it. Don't overlook the medical expenses of everyone listed on your tax return. Medical and dental bills for you, your spouse and your dependents count toward reaching the allowable deduction limit. You might be able to count some medical expenses you paid for a parent (www.bankrate.com/brm/itax/tips... , even if Mom or Dad isn't considered your dependent for exemption purposes. And while it's not something we want to think about, don't forget about medical bills you paid for a deceased dependent in the year they were paid, whether before or after the person passed away. Overlooked medical costs Once you're confident you know just whose costs are covered, make sure you don't miss one. Some allowable, but often overlooked, medical deductions include: * Travel expenses to and from medical treatments. The IRS evaluates the standard cents-per-mile allowance each year, so check its Web site for the current rate (www.irs.gov/newsroom/article/0... . * Insurance payments from already taxed income. This includes the cost of long-term care insurance, up to certain limits based on your age. * Uninsured medical treatments such as an extra pair of eyeglasses or set of contact lenses, false teeth, hearing aids, and artificial limbs. * Costs of alcohol- or drug-abuse treatments can be counted on your Schedule A. * Laser vision corrective surgery is a tax-allowable procedure. * Medically necessary costs prescribed by a physician. That means if your doctor told you to add a humidifier to your home's heating and air conditioning system to relieve your chronic breathing problems, the device (and additional electricity costs to operate it) could be at least partially deductible. * Some medical conference costs. You can count admission and transportation expenses to the conference if it concerns a chronic illness suffered by you, your spouse or a dependent. Meal and lodging costs while at the seminar, however, are not deductible. * Health-conscious taxpayers also have a friend in the IRS. Weight-loss programs in some instances now might count as a deductible medical expense, joining the stop-smoking programs the agency OKd earlier. But don't try to cheat on your calorie intake or the IRS. The diet program must be medically necessary. Acceptable situations include, for example, when a doctor recommends the regimen to reduce the health risks of obesity or hypertension." i That's all I know, and it's not much. Sorry! Insurance coverage of LE garments in the U.S. is in need of advocacy and awareness, and nobody's going to do that for us (well, except Bob Weiss, and he could use our help), so if anyone has some thoughts on how we might help fight this, let's hear it. Jinky has been fighting this battle in Canada, Bahons in the UK, and others in other parts of the world. I hope they'll both share their experiences here too, as we all need each other. Lots to be done! Be well, all! Binney

Posts.Content: May 3, 2013 02:35AM Binney4 wrote: I'm one of those who thinks these are often great opportunities to educate. I feel indebted to those women before us who made BC a subject that could be discussed instead of whispered about, as though it was shameful, by speaking out about it. And I'm convinced that the only way to make LE less humiliating for all of us is to be candid. I love the joking answers (my favorite is "Trapeze accident") and I use them at times, but after the laugh I unload as much information as I can before their eyes glaze over and they retreat into end-stage boredom. If I'm mad at them for saying something stupid, their squirming boredom is my revenge. But more often than not I get, "I never even heard of that!" amazement. They won't forget it, that's for sure. I'm not advocating that everyone goes around spouting LE--we're not always up for it, and some women never are. That's understandable, and it's fine. But I do advocate that we work hard at never feeling humiliated by our garments and the public's ignorance about it. I sure didn't know anything about it before my first "swell" experience, and there are plenty of times when I still can't believe what a SECRET this rotten condition is. Denise, that teller really threw some crummy lines at you, and I'm so sorry. I can feel your rage! I thought your line about this being for the rest of your life was simply perfect. You could have just repeated it, louder, until she got the point. People just don't know what to say. Hoping you're feeling a bit better this evening, Denise. Chocolate helps! And hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2014 07:23PM Binney4 wrote: trr, if you go with compression, be sure the fit is right, because a poorly fitting sleeve can cause more problems than it solves: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_l... Also, if you use a sleeve, you'll want to use some hand protection too--either a compression glove or a gauntlet (fingerless glove). Here's why: http://www.lymphedivas.com/handprotection.asp Test out your compression garments before you travel so you know they fit well and you can manage them. Leave them on for an hour or so once you've arrived. Other strategies that help with air travel include being careful with heavy luggage, stay REALLY well hydrated before and during your flight, pause occasionally to take a few deep abdominal breaths, and do some gentle arm and hand stretches throughout the trip. Happy travels! Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 06:16PM Binney4 wrote: Pam, give your mom a big hug from me! I hope she's had therapy as well as just the sleeve. A good lymphedema therapist should be able to reduce the size of her arm, even now (though it will likely never likely be back entirely to normal). Reducing the amount of trapped fluid in her arm will reduce her risk of infection and further tissue damage, increase her range of motion, and feel a whole lot better, so if she's never done a "Therapy Intensive" for her lymphedema, now's a great time to start. (Like the denial she faced with diagnosing lymphedema, there are still docs around who prescribe compression sleeves without ever dealing with the underlying problem.) If she needs help finding a well-qualified lymphedema therapist near her, check out these two sites: www.mylymphedema.com   Click on the Therapist Locator and follow all the links www.clt-lana.org   Click on "LANA certified therapists" As for you, Pam, we all make our own compromises with the risks we're willing to take. Only you can make those decisions. The suggestions for protecting yourself can be found in the position papers on Risk Reduction, Exercise, and Air Travel here: www.lymphnet.org Exercise is good for both prevention and control of lymphedema, but care and patience are needed to move forward with it while still protecting yourself--no straining your arms, working up slowly, paying attention to your arm and chest for any signs of strain, tightness, or swelling. Better yet, why not ask for a referral to a well-trained lymphedema therapist yourself as well? She can do baseline measurements for future reference, give you tips for managing risk, and fit you for compression sleeves and gloves to wear prophylactically when exercising or traveling. The good news is that -- bottom line -- there's treatment for lymphedema that makes it possible to control it, and the sooner its treated the easier and more successful it is. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2018 07:02PM Binney4 wrote: Good advice about using arm and hand protection for exercise, flying and travel. OTC is fine, but it needs to be an excellent fit or it can actually cause problems instead of preventing them. So rather than searching the racks at a pharmacy, do find a fitter at a medical/mastectomy supply outlet. Also nice to have the lymphedema PT check out the fit or you. Since your surgeries were bilateral, both arms are at risk, not just the side that had nodes removed, so you'll want to consider protection for both arms. Once you have them, get used to them gradually--an hour the first day, and work up to however many hours you'll need them on for flying or travel. Here's information about buying and proper fitting of compression garments, so you'll have an idea if they're right for you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_l... Once you know what size, compression level, and brand you like, you can order online. More ideas for reducing your lymphedema risk here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_l... Hoping you never have to join our "swell" sisterhood! Binney

Sorry it's such a to-do, but wishing you great good fortune with it! Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 03:12AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Mary, Yes, I heard of this from a couple of plastic surgeons at the NLN Conference in August. It makes a weird sort of sense. It seems that any surgery stimulates "angiogenesis," which essentially means your body gets busy repairing the busted up veins and lymph vessels by producing special protein factors that make them regrow. Lymph vessels don't have as much ability to repair themselves as blood vessels do (and lymph nodes can't ever be regenerated). But still, SOMETIMES a recon surgery like DIEP can actually improve LE because of the stimulation of that special protein. BUT! It's also possible for recon surgery to worsen LE because more lymph vessels are damaged and more scar tissue created that can block lymph flow. (And it's even possible for surgeries like DIEP to result in abdominal LE as well.) The trouble is, nobody can predict which of those outcomes any one person will have. So as a way of dealing with LE, recon isn't something you can count on, and it sure isn't a LE treatment option! Does that help any? Hope so! Are you considering recon? If so, I hope it goes smoothly and successfully! Hugs! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2013 04:38PM Binney4 wrote: SpecialK, it sounds like you have a marvelous trip planned! To fully enjoy it, make sure all your LE supplies are with you in a carry-on so they're not delayed or lost in transit. LE unfortunately never takes a vacation, so plan time daily for your regular self-care and some extra self-mld as needed. Travel usually involves different activities than our usual routine, which can also affect LE and may mean wearing bi-lat garments more often than you normally would. If you're outdoors more, take extra care with insect and sun protection. Talk to one of your doctors about having oral antibiotics (Rx already filled and in hand) in case of infection--along with the usual first-aid supplies of wet-wipes, topical antibiotic and bandaids for quick application in case of nicks, scratches or insect bites. Traveling can entail a change of normal diet too, usually involving more salt and/or alcohol than usual, so make an effort to stay extra-well hydrated. As for the change of elevation itself, leaving garments on for an hour or two after you land gives your body time to adjust, but be vigilant about symptoms of extra heaviness, achiness or swelling and act on it quickly. A couple years back one of our gals went to Machu Picchu, which is at some unearthly altitude, stayed there several days and walked and climbed all over, and she did just fine, so no need to worry that you won't be able to handle it just fine. Enjoy! Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2014 01:31AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Alycallie. All good questions! Here's some� information about lymphedema risk reduction: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_l... Generally the number of lymph nodes removed is correlated to the risk of lymphedema, but actually some of us with only one node removed (or even with prophylactic mastectomy and no nodes purposely removed) may develop lymphedema as well. Recent research indicates that some of us have robust lymph systems to start with, others not so much, and that plays an important role in the development of lymphedema. Unfortunately, we don't currently test for that, so it would be impossible to say what any person's actual risk might be. Obesity seems to be a factor, as well as age and a history of previous trauma to the breast/chest area. In other words, we're all at risk, so some simple life-style changes can be a wise way to lower the risk. As some have already suggested, the numbness on the inside of the upper arm is common following surgery and doesn't seem to have anything to do with lymphedema development. The sleeve and glove should fit you well in order to be effective. You can check that out here: www.stepup-speakout.org/proper...… Exercise and travel are two good times to use them, or any time you're doing unusual activities (like moving furniture, for instance).   Hoping you never join our "swell" sorority! Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2013 10:18PM - edited Mar 23, 2013 10:18PM by Binney4 Cookiegirl, welcome! I'm excited about your up-coming trip, and with all the care and information-seeking you're doing beforehand, it will be just what you're hoping for! I'm one of those who developed LE on a flight--AZ to AK. Only to discover that AK is not a really good LE resource. Kinda ruined the trip (well, not entirely, since I have grandkids there...). So I'm strongly in favor of seeing a good LE therapist and insisting on being fitted for a compression sleeve and glove for the trip. If you never need them, it's all good. If you do, no hospital in all Florida is likely to be much help with the LE itself (but of course they would be if you had a problem with infection). So it's just best to be prepared to deal with swelling yourself, and that means well-fitting garments, plenty of water and deep breathing, and your delightful sense of humor. Many of our women do start with a LE therapist during rads, and I heartily recommend it. They can't do the entire treatment because of the fragility of the skin in the radiated area, but they sure can treat the extremities and keep the lymph system functioning. When our doctors clear us for travel they're thinking in terms of their specialty--the healing from surgery or rads, say. They are almost never thinking of LE, because there is no specialty that "owns" this condition. The professionals in LE are the well-trained therapists. A referral wrung from any doctor on your team will do the trick. (Many therapists have a waiting list. If that's what you find, call them up and tell them you're travel plans. Beg shamelessly!) Can I just say that I think with your knowledge and attitude you have nothing to fear, for this trip or any trip in the future. The key is being prepared, and you can do that. It'll be good! Do please keep us posted and let us know what you discover! Hugs, and bon voyage! Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2009 07:24PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Naturelover, Key word: CAREFUL! Start slow, just a few reps and see how it goes.  Work up slower than you would have before. (We can't do the "no pain-no gain" thing -- pain is bad because it draws lymph fluid to the site.) You're watching for swelling, of course, but even better to STOP at once if you feel tiredness, achiness, fullness, tingling, numbness, or just "something odd." Stop and elevate your arm until the feeling goes away. You can try again the next day, but stop again if you experience any of those things. After exercise, check in the evening for any new swelling or other symptoms.  If you haven't been fitted for a compression sleeve and glove, that's a good first step. Wear it when exercising, traveling, or doing any strenuous or unusual activity. Stay VERY well hydrated, and stop at intervals to do a few deep abdominal breaths. Those, anyway, are the recommendations. The reality is that it's really hard to stop in the middle of a set. "Only four more to go -- what can that hurt?!" So try to be alert not only to your arm and breast, but to the excuses it's too easy to make! If you mean you have lymphedema and a hematoma in your breast, you might want to talk to your therapist about breast compression options and the simple lymphedema exercises you can do to help. She did teach you to do the massage, yes? That can also help before and/or after exercise sessions. Antibiotics before dental work aren't usually advised, though some people do that. Best, though, to be alert to the possibility of infection all the time (lymph fluid breeds bacteria really fast), and get help quickly at the first sign of it.  Here are a couple of pages on exercise and lymphedema: http://www.lymphnet.org   (See the Position Papers on Risk Reduction and Exercise) http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Exercise_and_lymphedema.htm Healing prayers for you too, NL! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 08:03AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Becky, What causes the lymphedema is breast cancer treatment: surgery and radiation certainly, but some of the chemo agents may also play a role. There are some researchers and lymphologists who now believe that anyone who has been treated for breast cancer has lymphedema, though it may be in a very early stage that is unnoticable (that is called Pre-clinical, or Stage 0). But what you seem to be asking is what triggered everyone's noticable symptoms of lymphedema. You sure have gotten a variety of answers! There is some current on-going research looking at lymphedema triggers, but it probably won't ever be conclusive because the triggers are not always immediate, so tracing them accurately is anybody's guess. There are some things that have been found to increase our risk: over-weight or weight gain; previous trauma (or surgery); post surgical complications such as seroma, infection or cording. Possibly also surgery on the dominant side, and there's some hints in new research from the UK that there may be a genetic pre-disposition involved as well (though we still have no reliable way of telling if we're predisposed!) Lymphedema risk reduction sounds complicated and limiting, but Dr. Mei Fu, a lymphedema researcher who is studying risk reduction measures, has reduced it to two concepts that are simpler to visualize and hold in our chemo-brains: PROMOTE lymph flow, and PROTECT the at-risk area from injury or infection.  Details here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_lymphedema.htm The idea is not to limit your life but to be aware of possible triggers, take the precautions you need to, and then get on with your life. A good lymphedema therapist can help by taking baseline arm measurements for future reference and giving you the skills you need to move on without fear. Find a well-trained one near you here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 05:41PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Keryl, and welcome! Sorry for the scare you're dealing with. We're all entirely paranoid when we're going through this bc journey, so you sound perfectly normal! Gosh, you're so on top of this -- that's pretty amazing. Do take a moment to pat yourself on the back -- well, or as close as you can get to it! Do take it a bit easier. Helping your daughter pack for college a week after AND should probably be limited to giving orders and making suggestions. Keep that water glass handy and keep on sippin'. And DO call and get a preventive visit with a well-trained LE therapist. S/he can do baseline measurements for future reference, teach you a bit of preventive LE massage, give you some hints for risk reduction, and fit you for a glove and sleeve to wear when traveling or exercising. Or packing, for that matter! With an AND there's some insult to your nerves, which alone can cause the symptoms you describe. But to be on the safe side, try keeping your arm elevated whenever you can (including on a pillow at night), drink plenty of water, exercise gently but often, and stop from time to time to do some deep abdominal breathing (helps stimulate lymph flow). If you have a tightish long-sleeved leo or sports shirt (the body-armor type), wear that (inside out so the seams won't irritate your skin) to add a bit of gentle compression if it's comfortable and doesn't bug your incision site. Either cool or warm showers, with gentle stretching, can help. But avoid anything hot (including being outdoors in the middle of the day if you live where it's summer). Hooray for your daughter who's off to college! Is this her first year? Hope it's not TOO far away. What an amazing adventure to be lauching her on -- give her my best. And the same to you too! Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 07:03AM - edited Mar 28, 2008 07:06AM by Binney4 Oof, Jeanette, bummer! From your description it's not sounding like a numbness or nerve tingling from regeneration problem, yes? As Ann suggests it sounds a whole lot like truncal lymphedema. The cording is also an indication of possible lymphedema, as cording is yet another risk factor for it (the cord itself is made up in part of lymph tissue). Good news: there's treatment, and it relieves both the puffiness and the pain. But the therapist that treats it has to be well trained in lymphedema (LE) therapy. That'd be at least 135 hours of specifically LE training beyond her (or his) PT or OT certification and at least a year's experience treating LE. And you'll have to ask, because those standards are not yet legally mandated in any state. In case you have trouble finding someone qualified, check out the Therapist Locator at www.mylymphedema.com. Doctors often don't recognize truncal LE, so you might want to suggest (read that "insist" ) on a referral for an evaluation to a qualified LE therapist. If it's not LE, great, but even so she'll be able to take base-line measurements for future reference, teach you risk reduction techniques, and fit you for a compression sleeve and glove that will help protect you when exercising or flying. Win-win! JMHO, of course! Lots more information about lymphedema prevention and treatment at the National Lymphedema Network: www.lymphnet.org.  Big, real gentle (((((hugs!))))), Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 12:57AM - edited Mar 13, 2009 01:00AM by Binney4 April, we're all different, but the Flexi and the support camis may well be all you need for most days. Keep the vest for tough days when your LE flares or just feels like it needs more compression. What are you doing for night compression? A Jovi-Pak or Solaris night vest is comfortable for sleep and is especially good at reducing swelling rather than just containing it like a day vest does. In the summer I put mine in a plastic shopping bag in the frig, so it's cool at bedtime, and the foam inside holds the cool for a long time. I also use it during the day when I'm sick, when my swelling gets out of hand, and when I travel. It does not look "normal" for traveling and I always end up getting wanded at airports (it does have an uncanny resemblance to a suicide bomber vest), but it's possible to wear a biggish blouse over it and not be entirely conspicuous. I wear my WearEase in the evenings with no prostheses, and the compression is fine. I don't know if the Bellisse requires prostheses to work, but I sort of doubt it. Why not ask them? Their contact information is near the bottom of this page: www.bellisse.com Some of the binders may be workable for you too, day or night. Some are light and easy to wear -- and fairly cheap -- like these: http://www.breastbinders.com/Store/catalog/Traditional_Breast_Binders-1-1.html It's definitely hard to find information about truncal lymphedema, which is a lonely and frustrating feeling. But there are a lot of us here who have it, so lots of experience with assorted arrangements for dealing with it. Others will no doubt be along soon. Those of us like you and me who have had no recon are fewer, but even we can work out ways to live in reasonable comfort from the options available. Hugs, prayers, Binney Edited to add: the Bellisse site has a page of links to information about truncal LE, studies and articles. Just remember they're trying to sell you a compression bra! But otherwise it's useful information.

Posts.Content: Binney4 wrote: Night vision goggles as the inspiration for a new tool for visualizing lymph flow in real time. How cool is that! Binney http://www.wkowtv.com/Global/story.asp?S=11686213 Mapping the Body Using Night Vision Technology Julia Cox had the lymph glands under her left arm removed as part of a mastectomy. Now, she suffers from lymphedema. "It means that I have got fluid built up in my arm in this case because I don't have the lymph glands to remove it," says Julia. When something goes wrong with lymphatics, disastrous things happen. Things like infection, which a compromised lymphatic system has trouble fighting. "If it gets a little too swollen, my elbow joint hurts," says Julia. So Julia is taking part in a clinical trial, testing a device using night vision technology developed during the first gulf war. It's called "near-infrared fluorescence" and can help map what the human eye can't see deep within the lymph system. "We put a little bit of dye underneath the skin. And with the camera system that we have, we actually watch it as it propels the lymph nodes and then it ends up going into the bloodstream," says Dr. Eva Sevick. The device allows doctors to image the lymphatic system in real time. "You could actually see the dye moving up the arm on this side and it kind of sat in a lump on this side but they said it did move here," says Dr. Sevick. It's helping them better understand the disease and how the lymphatic system works, which may help with a cure for lymphedema. If it proves itself in tests, it may also help others thanks to a new use for some old gulf war technology. Even with this night vision technology, it's hard to see clear lymphatic fluid. That's why doctors first have to inject that fluorescent dye beneath the skin. This technology could eventually help doctors identify problems in the lymphatic system before symptoms develop.
