Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2018 09:18PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Lynn, I've never heard anything about LE affecting BP, no studies I know of--though I'd guess it could be possible if the LE led to stress (which it certainly does at times), or if it limited normal activity. But in that case the BP increase would be secondary to the LE, and I take it that's not quite what you're asking. Really good question--wish I could be more helpful. Do talk to your therapist about your up-coming cataract surgery. Since your LE is bilateral both arms/hands are certainly at risk--for both LE In the lower arm and hand, and for cellulitis when the skin is compromised by needles. So you need a plan for how to handle both the IV and the necessary BP during surgery. If the eye surgeon can arrange to do only manual BP, that's at least better than the automatic cuffs, since they often overdo the pressure needed for measuring BP. Measuring BP on the lower leg is a possibility, as is an IV in the foot or neck (not as grim as it sounds). IV and blood tests in the foot are contraindicated if you have had blood clotting problems, but otherwise can solve the LE risk issues. Your therapist should be able to recommend the best personalized plan for you, and s/he may also be able to consult with your surgeon. Please do let us know what you discover, and how your surgery goes too! Amazing how this "swell" diagnosis can complicate our lives, no? Grrrrr! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2008 08:24PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Deb, Boy, is that for sure! At least we're not alone -- seems like the LE researchers feel the same way! You've got the right idea about the deep breathing. It's a matter of expanding the abdomen, something we ladies always try not to do. Hmmmm. Takes a bit of relearning (and some privacy!) Deep breathing actually helps with a whole bunch of things. Eases stress, helps people with asthma, etc. Can be done as often as you remember it, no prescription necessary, no co-pay. Love it! The reason it helps LE (at least as much of the reason as I can understand) is that our main lymph vessel, the thoracic duct, which my therapist tells me is about the diameter of a garden hose, runs smack down the middle of us, right past the diaphragm. Since the lymph system has no pump to propel the lymph fluid through the vessels, the flow can be sluggish unless something (a muscle, actually) moves against the lymph vessels and stimulate them. When you take a deep breath, the movement of the diaphragm stimulates that big old garden hose, and you move a whole lot of lymph. With a single breath! Power! Binney

In the meantime, I can see why you're needing to be on the ibuprofen, but just so you're aware, the non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen can temporarily worsen lymphedema because they inhibit the rhythmic contractions of the lymph vessels that move the lymph fluid along. Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2013 03:41AM - edited Jul 17, 2013 04:07AM by Binney4 Hello, Charanya, and welcome! I'm really sorry to hear about your mom's new difficulties. As Marple says, there's much she can do to both reduce the swelling and maintain her arm in good health. But it will take some real work to find the resources you need in India. You might try calling some people in other parts of India who are involved in lymphedema treatment, even though they're very far from you. They may know someone in your area who can help, or they may be able to help a local Physical Therapist learn what she needs to know to work with you and your mom. Unfortunately the only people I know about are in Delhi and Punducherry, but I'll give you their names in case you want to call them and see if they can help. Here's a therapist in New Delhi: Seema Grover, PT, CLT Batra Hospital & Medical Research Centre, Physiotherapy Telephone: 11-29958747 #3068 And here's a study about Complete Decongestive Therapy from the Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education in Pondicherry: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22293250 On that page you'll see the names of the researchers. If you contact JIPMER and ask to speak to them they may be able to tell you who their therapists were, so you can call them too. You might also want to copy that study and show it to her doctor. Perhaps he would be willing to contact them himself. And at any rate, he would learn that there IS treatment available, and hopefully he'd want to see that kind of treatment available in Hyderabad as well. Here's an article on ayurvedic lymphedema treatment that combines traditional and modern medical techniques, and may be more comfortable for your mom. You can contact Dr. Narahari to learn more, and to find out if such treatment is available near you: http://www.lymphovenous-canada.ca/shleepadaregieme.htm In the meantime, it will help your mom if she elevates her arm (with support) as much as possible during the day, and at night on pillows. She should drink plenty of water (because it dilutes the lymph fluid and helps it flow better) and pause to take a few deep abdominal breaths throughout the day (because that stimulates the biggest lymph vessel in our bodies.) Please let us know what you discover, and do come ask any questions you or your mom may have--there are lots of women here with a lot of experiences like your mom's, and we'd all be happy to help her. Thank you for working so hard to find her the care she needs! Gentle hugs to both of you, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2011 02:45PM Binney4 wrote: Grannydukes, there is no such thing as "a very slight case of lymphedema." That's like being "a little bit pregnant"! Lymphedema is a progressive condition -- if it's not treated it WILL progress. By progression they don't necessarily mean that it will swell more, but other things will begin to happen to the tissues inside. Stagnant lymph fluid will cause our bodies to develop fibrosis (hardening) as a way to fight it off. Eventually there will be skin changes -- roughness (like an orange peel) and even leaking of caustic lymph fluid through the pores. The biggest risk, though, is that the lymph fluid there (which is warm and rich in protein) encourages the growth of any bacteria that find their way into your body, and can result in a rapidly-spreading systemic infection that often requires hospitalization for IV antibiotics. You don't want to go there! INSIST on a referral from any doctor on your team to a well-trained lymphedema therapist, who can reduce the swelling (and the infection risk!) and teach you to manage it with gentle skin manipulation, well-fitted compression, special skin care, and specific exercises. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm And here's information about truncal (breast or chest) lymphedema: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/breast_chest_trunckal_lymphedema.htm Finally, here's information you may want to print out and give to your doctor, as they receive little or no training about it in their medical school careers and often know little about what our treatment needs are: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/essential%20informat%20for%20healthcare%20providers.htm Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2009 05:52PM Binney4 wrote: Aw, Deborah, geesh! I'm really sorry you woke up to yet another unwelcome "surprise." Sure does sound like it could be lymphedma, and the reduction with elevation sounds about right. Besides elevation, stay very well hydrated (it dilutes the lymph fluid). Every so often stop what you're doing and take several slow, deep abdominal breaths (stimulates the largest lymph vessel in your body), and raise your arm as high as is comfortable and slowly open and close your fist several times (your muscles moving against the lymph vessels near the surface of your skin help pump lymph fluid, and gravity helps move it downward toward your axilla). Keep your arm elevated as much as you can, and try elevating it tonight on pillows. Until you can get help, avoid heat, tiring your arm, or any nicks, insect bites or burns. It's not uncommon for lymphedema to start in your hand and fingers or thumb. With good help you'll see good reduction, and catching it so early will be a big help to getting it under control and keeping it that way. This is not an emergency and can wait until your doctor is in UNLESS there's any sign of infection (rapid uncontrolled swelling, pain, redness, warmth to the touch, fever, flu-like symptoms, itching). If you see any of those things develop do get help at once, because infections in an area with lymphedema can spread and become serious very rapidly. What you'll want from your doctor (any doctor on your team) is a referral to a well-trained lymphedema therapist. Here's a page of information about finding one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Please let us know how we can help, Deborah. Cheering you on! Binney

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2018 12:49PM - edited Jan 7, 2018 12:53PM by Binney4 Angela, please don't worry about overwhelming us with frustration or fear--been there, done that! It gets better as we find good and caring treatment and start to see how we can take control of it all. There has long been a fear of using Manual Lymph Drainage (lymphedema massage) with active cancer, the rationale being that the cancer could spread through the movement of lymph fluid. If cancer spread were that simple (which it's not!) and we could stop the spread by not moving lymph fluid, then you'd have to lie flat and perfectly still for the rest of your life, because the main lymph pump is muscle movement--it is going to move with every movement of your body, whether or not you engage in Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD). The MLD just makes it more efficient and easier on your body. If fact, the lymph system is part of your immune system and acts to destroy invasive cells, so stopping all lymph flow (even if it were possible--which it's not!) would be counter-productive. So the current thinking is that lymph massage is not going to spread cancer, and may even improve our chances of knocking it out, since it moves lymph fluid to the nodes for cleansing. Still, those who were trained earlier may not be comfortable treating lymphedema in the face of a cancer recurrence. Some of them compromise and do lymph massage but avoid the area of the recurrence, and that's probably a reasonable strategy. All that just to say it's not unusual to find a lymphedema therapist who will not treat a patient with active cancer. I am not a doctor and would not suggest going against your doctor's recommendations, but just want you to be aware of what the current thinking and practice is. Learning to wrap yourself is a great idea--always a helpful tool to have in our self-care toolbox. But it's tricky and a steep learning curve, and you definitely want hands-on instruction for that. The glove and gauntlet are a good idea, but they need to fit well. Hopefully the shop measuring and ordering them is knowledgeable and can check the fit. Here's information that can help you make sure the fit is a good one: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_l... Hoping some of that helps! Please keep us posted and let us know what you discover. Hugs, chocolate, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2018 08:01PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, hapa, Yes, I have bilateral lymphedema, so I wear sleeves and gloves on both arms, and since I have lymphedema in my chest and back as well, I also wear a special compression camisole. I do 15 minutes of special exercises most days, and I'm careful with any kind of cut or scratch--prompt cleaning and use of an antibiotic ointment--because the risk of infection is greater in an area with lymphedema. My right arm is worse than the left, so I use a left-hand-only keyboard with my computer. But we are all different, and what I need will be different from what anyone else might need. Especially if you catch it early, managing lymphedema is easier. Lots of women only use their compression sleeves when they're exercising or traveling, and how much anyone can do with their lymphedema arm differs too. Generally, exercise helps with lymphedema, because the lymph fluid is moved by muscle movement, as long as you start gradually with new kinds of exercise and work up in strength. Swimming is especially good, as the added compression of the water is helpful in controlling it. Some women find salt intake affects their lymphedema, but it doesn't seem to bother mine. I don't want to make it sound like it's nothing, because it is. Buying garments, learning self-care, remembering to be careful about bug bites or hang nails, arguing with uninformed medical folks about not using your affected arm, finding clothes that look good with your compression garments--none of that is a walk in the park. Feeling out of place with compression garment, or even the fact that our lymphedema is a constant reminder of our battle with breast cancer can be difficult to deal with. But it's all doable. Honest! Does any of that help? Hope so! Hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 02:52PM Binney4 wrote: Hello, all, Just wanted to drop in to give you some websites for your lymphedema questions. Here's information on risk reduction strategies that are simple lifestyle adjustments: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_lymphedema.htm Here's how to find a well-qualified lymphedema therapist near you. Any doctor on your team can write a referral for an evaluation and personalized risk-reduction tips: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm And here's the website to order your free neon-pink lymphedema alert bracelet (or two if you've had bilateral surgeries, even prophylactic): http://www.lymphedema.com/ Click on "Free Lymphedema Alertband" on the left-hand side of the page to order Wren's idea of a medicalert bracelet is a great one--helps remind YOU not to offer that arm for blood draws or BP too! Nance, low risk is only a guess. Recent research shows that number of nodes removed is only one part of our risk assessment. Others include excess weight, previous surgeries or trauma to the chest or axilla, and--here's the clincher--a genetic pre-disposition. Some of the women who show up on the lymphedema board here have developed it as long as 26 years after treatment, so the bit about 6 months is inaccurate. Next time you have a procedure, you might want to get the surgeon to write into his orders that your at-risk arm is not to be used. Here's information about lymphedema written for doctors by a doctor who developed lymphedema: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/essential%20informat%20for%20healthcare%20providers.htm You can copy it off and pass it along to all your treating doctors, or use it to support your insistence on leaving that arm alone. Being informed about lymphedema should give you some peace of mind. More than half of us will never have to deal with it, but knowing what steps can be taken to lower your risk is just smart. Also, please know that if you do notice any signs of early lymphedema (arm achiness or heaviness, visible swelling, or tighter fit of jewelry and clothes), prompt treatment keeps the swelling in good control and makes that control much easier going forward. Hope some of that helps. Be well! And may none of you join our Swell Sorority! Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 10:20PM Binney4 wrote: Betsy, we're all so different, so it's hard to know what will work for who. In the Orient acupuncture has long been a sort of standard treatment for edema of any sort. There are two studies that I know of that are presently going on in the U.S. to determine how effective and safe it is (or isn't.) But at present there's no evidence either way. I met a Chinese doctor, now in the States, who believes acupuncture can help relieve the swelling in LE and she's started one of those two studies. She doesn't think U.S.-trained acupuncturists are "safe," because she finds their training lacking and their practice lax, but I have no way of judging the validity of that belief. She was adamant that when done properly, and with the proper sterile precautions, it would not cause infection in a LE limb, but she was also quick to point out that no needles need ever be placed in the area with LE in order to treat it adequately. I'm very interested to see what the current studies show, but they won't be published for a while yet. I think what might concern me more, personally, would be the suggestion of eliminating daytime chest compression. Maybe you'd want to try that for only an hour or two at a time and see what happens, extending the time gradually if you see it having no effect on the swelling.  There are many factors that can influence swelling, from the weather to activity types and levels, so while you're experimenting with the reduction of compression use, you'd want to keep a close eye on whatever triggers most influence your own swelling, and perhaps be more conservative about using compression during those times when swelling is most likely. We all love the idea of freedom from compression, but getting things back into control if they flare is no fun either, so slow and easy, and one experiment at a time, would be the way to go. JMHO! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: May 9, 2013 12:26PM - edited May 9, 2013 12:29PM by Binney4 Inde, welcome! We sure do hear you on the difficulty of trying to wrap your mind around the complexities of LE. It works best to take one issue at a time. 1. Never wear a compression sleeve without some kind of hand protection, either a glove (where only the fingertips are uncovered) or a gauntlet (which is a fingerless glove). The reason is that when you have any swelling without compressing the hand, it can get trapped below the cuff of the sleeve in your hand, where it's harder to get out. 2. If your arms are the same size, the sleeves are interchangable, though you may want to have two since both arms are at risk. Even prophylactic mastectomy creates a LE risk (in fact, my LE started on my prophylactic side, and remains hardest to handle on that side--no nodes purposely removed, but there's still scar tissue and just general trauma). 3. Training of LE therapists can vary widely. You want one with at least 135 hours of specifically LE training beyond her/his PT or OT certification. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm 4. LE can start anywhere in the affected quadrant (in your case and mine with bilateral surgery, anywhere above the waist and below the neck, either side). It can stay in one small place or affect the entire quadrant, so you want to see a therapist soon for evaluation and possible treatment. Trust yourself on this: you're not imagining things, and you need to get them checked out. Fullness, achiness, tightness, or tingling are all indications of early-stage LE. Treating it promptly means it will remain easier to treat and control. 5. You'll want to consider prohibiting blood pressure, blood draws, IVs and injections in either arm. Many of us use our feet for blood draws, hips or thighs for injections, foot or neck for IVs and lower leg for blood pressure. Your call! Please do let us know what you discover. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 03:58PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Diana--so sorry about this burn! You want to treat the burn promptly. If it's bad you need to get it seen today. Adequate medical care at this point is your best defense. Lymph accumulates at an injury site because the lymph fluid is the body's mechanism for hauling away dead cells and bacteria. One signal for sending in the lymph is pain, so you want to not only treat the burn but treat the pain. Burns are an infection risk, so you'll need to watch carefully throughout the healing period for any sign of infection and get help for it promptly. Here's information about what to watch for: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm To help reduce your lymphedema risk with this injury, besides the above, elevate you arm as much as possible--on the back of the couch if you're sitting, on pillows at night. Drink LOTS of water (helps dilute the lymph fluid and keep it flowing--and it helps with healing too). Pause often throughout the day to take some deep abdominal breaths (stimulates the largest lymph vessel in our bodies to assist with lymph flow). Take it easy, and keep us posted! Sure hope you were baking something chocolate so you can relax and enjoy it while you heal! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2014 02:56PM Binney4 wrote: By the way, Kimberly, there are dozens of videos online demonstrating MLD, sort of--and almost none of them are anything you'd want to learn from. Way too many are made by maverick therapists who prove yet again that a little knowledge is a dangerous thing. It's definitely a hands-on learning experience, and the technique, when properly done, is valid for encouraging the flow of lymph by stimulating the lymphangions to pump and move the fluid along. It is effective because the lymph vessels lie so close to the skin surface--but it's also critical to use a very gentle pressure for the same reason. Lymph movement is slow and rhythmic, so it's also crucial to match the speed of the system in the movements--hard to do, actually, because we're always in such a hurry. The lymph system is a beautiful thing, however invisible it remains. As you learn more about it I'm betting you'll find it fascinating (and you'll no doubt wonder how come the medical world has been oblivious to it for so long!)  Looking forward with you to getting solid answers and a real "fix"! Binney

Posts.Content: May 19, 2009 02:48PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Laura, I'm assuming you haven't ever had a visit with a lymphedema therapist to learn about lymphedema risk reduction and all. Kimberly is referring to a special technique of wrapping with layered stockinette, foam, and several sizes of short-stretch compression bandages. But if you haven't been carefully taught and supplied with the right kinds of bandages, any other sort of wrapping would create a risk for lymphedema instead of helping it. As Kimberly says, staying well hydrated is very important, but it can be difficult on a plane, so make a point of asking for water regularly throughout. Plenty of water helps to keep the lymph fluid dilated so it flows more easily. Deep breathing from your tummy helps to stimulate lymph flow, because it pumps the fluid through the largest lymph vessel in our bodies. Exercising your arms and hands (and legs too) can also help. Raise your arm above your head and slowly make a fist and open it several times in a row. Do "cat claws" by bending your fingers into "claw" position and clawing at the air. Stretch your arms out in front of you and bend your elbow so you can touch your nose with your fingertips. Some light compression might help too -- a tight long-sleeved leotard or Body Armour-type sport shirt for your arms, and keep a pair of therapeutic Isotoner gloves handy to pull on if you have any problems with feelings of heaviness, achiness, or tingling in your hands or fingers. Be careful when you're packing, boarding, and retrieving your luggage not to tug or heft bags with that arm -- ask others to help if necessary. As soon as you can find the time, do check out some of information about simple risk reduction practices on the sites listed below, and ask any doctor on your team for a referral to a well-trained lymphedema therapist for an evaluation and training in how to manage the risk. http://www.lymphnet.org   Look for the Position Papers on Risk Reduction, Air Travel, and Exercise http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_lymphedema.htm But for now, BON VOYAGE! And be sure to come back and tell us all about it! Binney

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 08:03PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, CS, Using a wrist cuff is a risk for lymphedema as well, since it limits lymph flow to the hand on the at-risk arm. LindaLou, who mentioned using one on her at-risk arm in the other thread you mentioned, has figured in the risk and is willing to chance it. Having lymphedema in both my arms, I have to say that I don't think the risk is worth it, and I wish someone had warned me about that before mine developed. So -- maybe somewhat less of a risk, but still a risk. And hand lymphedema can be especially hard to deal with. We all have to make our own decisions on the compromises we can live with. Leg bp readings do run higher than arm bp. In order to establish your normal leg bp you need to have it taken frequently for a while. It is more accurate if you're lying flat and have been still for five minutes or so before it's taken. My cardio and his nurses are comfortable with this and don't have any trouble with it. If you want to have it checked on your leg often to establish your own "normal" leg reading, you can ask one of your doctors to let you come in (No Copay!) several times just for that, or call your local fire department and ask if the EMTs will do it for you. Then the twice-a-year arm bp won't be necessary, as you'll know from the leg reading whether it's in the right range or not.  For surgery situations I've never had any problems with lower-leg bp readings, as the anesthesiologist in more concerned with the trending numbers than with a concrete number -- but I do still like to be able to tell him what's normal for me. Your call, CS. There are no studies that confirm our risks in these matters, just anecdotal evidence from women who have developed lymphedema. We need more research, to say the least. In the meantime, my personal preference would be to avoid the arms altogether. Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 03:50PM Binney4 wrote: Good thought, Bob! I emailed Michael Bernas last night (LE researcher at the U. of Arizona) to ask about the circadian rhythm, and here's what he said (I posted this earlier today on another thread but thought you might not see it there): "There is no information that I know of concerning the daily cycle. You will hear people speak about the effect of gravity and I think everyone would agree that over the course of a day, swelling does enlarge in areas that are more dependent (and conversely areas tend to somewhat improve at night when the body is fairly flat). There has also been some reports concerning the monthly cycle and how that influences ebbs and flows of swelling. Unfortunately, I don't think any of this is documented and I would bet that the individual variation would make a study extremely hard to do unless you had thousands of patients to overcome the individual differences. It may be interesting to ask your colleagues if the appearance of swelling changes, say, if they were outside in the humid summer all day or if they were sick and stayed in bed all day which may be more severe variations of their routines."  Bob, as always, you and Pearl are an inspiration! Be well, both of you, Binney

Posts.Content: Binney4 wrote: Fellow lymphe-ladies, have any of you read the article about Elizabeth Edwards that's posted up on the Moving Beyond board? Here's a quote: "In the steamy room, Mrs. Edwards doesn't shed her suit jacket though sweat is running down her beet-red face. Mrs. Edwards is hiding her swollen arm that's filled with liquid from past cancer treatment on her lymph nodes." Even excusing the reporter's somewhat bizarre description, this whole thing continues to rankle with me. Okay, she's gutsy and gritty and brave and loyal and all those other good things, but then how do you explain "Mrs. Edwards is hiding her swollen arm..."? Especially considering that by hiding it in her suit jacket on a muggy afternoon she's making her own LE worse. We all understand and appreciate both denial and the rigors of this political campaign season, but I want to reach her with the message that: a.) she needs to take care of her LE before she ends up in the hospital with a serious systemic infection, and; b.) there are lots of us out here who don't have the luxury of hiding our swollen anything, and we'd all be happy to support her damaged self-image if she'd be wise enough to acknowledge that she's unfortunately one of us Sisters of Swell. I'm thinking awareness, you know? For us and for all those with LE, especially those with primary LE who typically wait years or decades for a proper diagnosis and the opportunity to benefit from treatment. Because nobody knows about LE, and with EE's attitude it's going to remain that unmentionable, humiliating, shameful, hide-it-the-best-way-you-can legacy of BC treatment. Okay, climbing down, wounded, off my soapbox. (And bracing for the inevitable rush to her defense by ALL here, because of course we do all feel a connection with her.) But if any of you know how we can reach her to plead with her about this, please let me know. (I've tried going through her publisher, but no response). Whew! Thanks for listening (and for not jumping on me TOO hard ), Binney Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 10:36PM Binney4 wrote: Laura, what a struggle you've had with this! I'm so sorry. Am I understanding that you have both arm and truncal LE? Have you been through a Therapy Intensive at all (daily Manual Lymph Drainage massage, wrapping, and specific exercises)?  If not, you might want to try that before surgery, as breast and back LE can definitely cause tightness, and proper therapy might be enough to decrease the swelling and loosen up the area, as well as improving your range of motion (not to mention your general well-being!) If you need a good therapist, here's information about how to find one near you, what questions to ask, and how to judge proper protocol: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Before any surgery in an area with lymphedema it would be really helpful if the LE were as well-controlled as it could be -- that would greatly reduce the risk of complications, especially infection and wound healing. So again, even if you plan to go ahead with the surgery shortly, careful LE therapy will be important. If you have a competent LE therapist, you can request your PS to consult with her/him as well. Here's a section on surgery when there's LE present: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Medical_Care.htm# And here's information written by a doctor to help other doctors understand and deal with LE: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/essential%20informat%20for%20healthcare%20providers.htm You might want to copy it for your doctors and present it with a confident smile -- and maybe a plate of home-made brownies! As Anne suggests, Dr. Marga Massey has been fully trained as a LE therapist and is quite thorough about preparing her patients prior to surgery. From what I've seen of her work, she will insist on good therapy before surgery and following as well. Should you decide to go with her (and assuming you can get your insurance company to agree) she may be able to suggest a therapist in your area. She's been known to call therapists and interview them on behalf of her patients before surgery and set up with them a schedule for treatment. So certainly that would be a comforting choice. But the good news is, with some care and preparation you can do well with your own local resources, as long as you can get their cooperation in working with you on this. This is already long, and I'm sorry, but I just have to add that I can taste your frustration and so hope we'll all be able to help you feel less alone and less stressed. Please tell us how we can help. Very gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Title: Getting through the weekend mason204 sushanna1

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 08:46AM Binney4 wrote: Liz, I'm with you in hoping it's just some sore muscles! But you're really smart to be looking into this now. We have women here on this board who have developed lymphedema more than 20 years out -- sadly, there's no "statute of limitation on this particular treatment side-effect. (And on the other hand, congrats to them for being 20 years out!) In the past three or four years there's been research that indicates that women who seek treatment for lymphedema when their arm starts to feel achy and heavy, and don't wait until there's visible swelling, have a much easier time of it with both therapy and long-term control. So NOW is definitely the time to get a referral from any member of your healthcare team to a well-qualified lymphedema therapist. Here's information about how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Aching and heaviness without swelling is called sub-clinical or "Stage 0" lymphedema. There can be up to 30% more fluid in your tissues than is normal before any swelling is visible, so treating it now can reduce that build up and help you learn how to keep it in control. Let us know what you discover -- hoping it's sore muscles! Big, gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 06:44PM Binney4 wrote: Mimikitty, what a struggle! If the sleeve is causing you skin issues, for goodness sake don't wear it. There are things you can do when traveling by plane besides wearing a sleeve. Be really careful about hefting your luggage around--used wheeled bags and ask for help as needed. Stay VERY WELL hydrated both before and during travel. Exercise often on the plane. Arm over head, make a fist slowly and slowly open your fingers. Claw the air like a cat. Bend the elbows and bring your finger to your nose. Rotate your wrists both directions, and up and down. Everybody will think you're nuts, but you'll know you're not, and besides you'll never see them again. In answer to your question about cellulitis, here's a page about it: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Have a great trip, and stay well! Let us know how it goes. Kawee, I can't wear Lymphedivas either. If your wrist and the bottom of your hand swell you need a glove, not a gauntlet, or you may end up pushing swelling into your hand and fingers. It might also be really helpful to move to custom garments rather than off-the-shelf. Any chance you can look around for a therapist who will listen to you? Gentle hugs all around, Binney

Posts.Content: May 22, 2010 12:17PM - edited May 22, 2010 12:22PM by Binney4 <sigh!> If I hadn't been trying for several years to get Lillie Shockney to stop posting dangerous misinformation about lymphedema on the Johns Hopkins "Ask an Expert" site, I'd be urging patience and dialogue here. But, for those who wonder, awhile back a number of us who are affected by lymphedema emailed Lillie with our concerns. She brushed them aside. A prominent Advocate from the National Lymphedema Network wrote to Lillie and offered to vet her lymphedema answers for accuracy before she posted them, with no charge to her for his services, just to make sure the information was not inaccurate or risky. She declined. We have offered her the names and email addresses of lymphedema experts she could contact and even, two years ago, registration information for the National Lymphedema Network's "Physician Intensive," an excellent day-long seminar for MDs and RNs to bring them up to speed on lymphedema management, differential diagnosis, and research advances. She did not choose to attend. Moving right along, I contacted the people at Avon who are responsible for the site and expressed how dangerous this misinformation could be to women with breast cancer; they were surprised and assured me they'd look into it. Nothing changed. I emailed several Johns Hopkins lymphedema therapists to ask them to read Lillie's posts and tell me if they agreed with her advice -- they never answered (though for a while it appeared someone else was actually writing the LE responses, and they temporarily improved in accuracy). Shortly, though, Lillie was back at it, offering her opinion based apparently on her own individual experience as though it were actually sensible advice for everyone. While I'm aware Johns Hopkins uses the "Ask an Expert" gimmick as an advertising ploy, that in no way excuses their long neglect of our concerns about accurate information. Nor do their disclaimers about not offering medical advice on their site excuse this gross misinformation posing as exactly what they're disclaiming: expert medical advice. Despite their disclaimer, it does make me wonder about the liability of both Johns Hopkins and Lillie on this issue, since a lifetime of chronic disability contracted by following this advice is certainly an unfair price for any woman to pay for Johns Hopkins' advertising opportunity. So I want to register my strong agreement with Kira (and others) that Lillie needs to be relieved of her "expert" designations where the long-term side effects of breast cancer treatment are concerned. As for "coaching" us breast cancer patients here at bc.org -- until she is able to steer the newly-diagnosed to early arm measurements, risk-reduction education, and consistent follow-up surveillance for early signs of LE, she is not worthy of either the title or the responsibility. The last thing we need is yet another medical "expert" denying our reality as breast cancer veterans. Lillie, if you're listening, we're here -- all of us with lymphedema from our ALNDs and our SNBs and our prophylactic mastectomies. We'd all be happy to help you understand our reality and find the resources you need to become a real leader in advocating for us. In fact, we'd look forward to it. Please let us know how we can help. Short of that, though: bc.org, mods, Dr. Weiss and all, PLEASE help us clean up this dangerous and distressing act. Hopefully, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2009 06:12PM - edited Oct 4, 2009 06:14PM by Binney4 Hi, Abojenn, I'm wondering if you've seen a lymphedema therapist yet? If not, that's an important place to start, even if you're in the middle of rads (are you? I seem to remember you were talking about starting not too long ago? forgive me if I have that confused!) When you're going through rads a therapist can't massage the breast area (which is part of the total massage) because of the risk of irritating the skin. But s/he should still be able to help you clear nodes in your neck and do some lymph draining in your arm, depending on what areas are being radiated. S/he will also be able to fit you for a compression sleeve and glove to use while you're doing rads (though you may need a new set once full reduction is possible after you've healed from the rads.) Flares happen. They can be caused by something we do (go without compression, get overheated, overdo some exercise or activity, forget to use sunscreen and get a burn, fall on the arm, whatever). For some, it happens when we eat salt or drink alcohol or take certain drugs (though that's a very individual matter). Or it can be caused by changes in altitude or air pressure (before and/or after a storm, for instance). Also, a weight gain can cause new or incresed swelling. Any one of those might be a trigger for you. There's some experimentation involved, so it pays to keep track for a while until you know what's likely to bother YOU. The most important thing is to know how to deal with flares, so you can regain control as quickly and efficiently as possible. Here are some skills you need to learn from a well-trained lymphedema therapist: *Self Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD) massage *Self wrapping *How to judge a good fit of compression garments *How/where/when to order new supplies, bandages, garments *Not to panic (hard to do -- flares can cause an emotional reaction of frustration and grief) It's a steep learning curve, but mastering those things will give you back control of your life. We've even had women here who admit that it's a lot less stress to manage their lymphedema once they have it, than it was trying to do everything they could not to get it. I feel the same way -- we're not waiting for the other shoe to drop, because it already has. All we have to do now is put those shoes back on and get truckin'! It gets easier, honest! Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 10:24PM Binney4 wrote: Summergirl, learning about lymphedema -- how to recognize it, what to do if you develop problems -- can really help reduce the fear. How about asking for a referral from any doctor on your team for an evaluation by a well-trained lymphedema therapist? Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm A visit with a therapist will give you baseline arm measurements for future reference, personalized risk reduction tips, instruction in a simple prophylactic lymph massage, and fitting for a sleeve and glove or gauntlet for travel and exercise.  One of the problems we face as bc veterans is that medical professionals often lack training in lymphedema and accurate information. While it's true that weight gain can increase risk, it is only one of many risk factors, many of them unpredictable. Many of us on the lymphedema board here are small, trim and fit. There just are no "safe" assumptions about risk, which is why a trained lymphedema professional can be so helpful. Deodorant use has no relationship to lymphedema risk that I know of, though anything that irritates your skin can be a risk. Gentle hugs, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 10:05PM Binney4 wrote: Yow, frogger, you've had a heck of an April! I'm so sorry about the blitz you've been through. How's the chemo going? I'm not sure why you're worried about the abdominal LE -- have you also had abdominal surgery for recon? If not, it's not a bit likely to affect your abdomen. The lymph system is divided in our body into "watersheds," with the lymph from each quadrant of our bodies draining in a different direction. Usually only the quadrant affected by your cancer treatment is at risk. The "watersheds" are straight down the center and right around your waist, so the areas likely to be affected are generally only the arm, chest, side and back (above the waist) on the affected side. (Sort of like a chicken wing quarter, y'know?) I'm also not sure why your therapist was so thoroughly negative about your job prospects. With a Therapy Intensive to bring your LE into control and on-going self-care (self Manual Lymph Drainage massage, compression garments, appropriate exercises, and careful skin care) you should be able to work out ways to continue working. As bygrace said, you'll need to proceed with caution and care, building up gradually and paying careful attention to your body. And you may need to make some accomodations or adjustments in the way you work. But I sure wouldn't throw everything over just yet. If your LE therapist is not an OT, perhaps a consult with one who is would be helpful at some point for suggestions on how to proceed. Frogger, I can't even imagine having to "wrap my head around" the LE with the surgery and chemo still so fresh. Mine was diagnosed well after treatment ended, and I still struggled to learn the MLD, the wrapping, the whole concept of the lymph system, and I had more than a few crying fits and bandage-flinging episodes. So I can tell you from my own very messy experience that no matter how hopeless and endless it seems at the time, it all comes clear later. The fog lifts and the sun comes out again. It'll be good, frogger! In the meantime, how can we help? Stay with us, Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 09:02PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, dancingneedles, I'm really sorry for this "swell" hassle. The medical professionals trained to evaluate and treat truncal swelling following bc treatment are well-qualified lymphedema therapists. Even if it's not lymphedema, a good lymphedema therapist can for sure help your lymph system "sort itself out." Actually, our lymphatics do have some capacity to regenerate, but it's much more limited than, say our circulatory or nervous system. So it can definitely use all the help it can get. Any doctor on your team can give you a referral for an evaluation. The therapist will do a physical exam, give you personalized tips for dealing with this swelling, teach you a gentle lymph massage you can use prophylactically, and take baseline measurements for future reference -- all great stuff whether or not it's lymphedema. And if it does turn out to be lymphedema, then you'll be acting early enough to get and maintain good control, limit fibrosis, and greatly reduce the risk of serious systemic infection. Win-win! Do let us know what you discover. Very gentle hugs Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2010 04:28PM Binney4 wrote: KC, that's a tough question. The first session is to introduce each step and discuss it as she applies does it. You'll want her to explain: how it works to reduce fluid (because once you understand how it works it's easier to judge if you've done it correctly); what supplies to use and how to order them and care for them; what layers to use (order, compression gradient); and the actual technique. Some women have their DH or a friend come along and make a video of the process (if you do that, have them stand behind you as they record it so when you view it you'll be seeing it from the same perspective as when you do it yourself.) Others have someone come along and take notes and learn along with them. If you have neither, then don't be embarrassed to ask her to stop at intervals so you can write notes. Then go home and practice it, re-wrapping a couple of times a day for a few days. It's a steep learning curve. Give yourself plenty of time to wrap, have all your supplies set up before you start (including several pieces of tape cut to the right length and stuck onto the edge of your dresser or table). Sit where it won't unroll all across the room if you drop it (I wrap sitting in the middle of my bed.) Be prepared to take any given layer apart and redo it -- this really does get easier with practice, but when you're learning it seems impossible. When therapists do this it looks easy: remember they have loads of experience and they are using two hands -- and that there was a first time for them too, and it wasn't pretty! Tears happen, so keep some tissues handy. If you reach the point of heaving a bandage roll across the room (been there, done that), be sure you've vacuumed up the pet hair off the floor first, or you'll face the additional frustration of picking cat hair off the stupid bandage by hand. It's harder to learn to wrap your dominant arm with your non-dominant hand, so if this is your situation, just keep chanting "This CAN be done!" Then you'll need another appointment to ask all the questions that came up when you were practicing and to have her check your technique and the wrap. Maybe that's all you'll need, but if you need more don't be ashamed to ask. Once you learn it, keep your skills sharp by wrapping your arm at least once a month (I try to do it on the first of every month), even if you don't need to. There is nothing more frustrating than to have to re-learn it all in the midst of a flare. Above all, cultivate your sense of humor! It really does get easier! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 04:43PM Binney4 wrote: Wow, thanks, Jane! Gee, it looked so great, too. I'm still having trouble finding the ideal compression solution for my bilaeral mastectomy, no recon, high-under-the-arm and back/chest swelling. I tried the Bellisse bra and it just didn't hit the right places, and nothing we added to the assorted pockets seemed to help. The fabric, though, was to die for. I've had custom garments made by both Jobst and Bio-Con, from the same fabric as their sleeves. If you don't need to breathe much they're just fine , but even then they won't make them with prosthesis pockets, and the idea of wearing a bra OVER a compression garment is not even to be thought of. I even had Solaris make me a vest (foam stuffed, like a night vest) for day wear. It works, it's comfortable, but I have to buy clothes a size larger to wear it, it's boiling hot, and I look like a suicide bomber. I tried this CuddlDuds cami, and it's deliciously comfortable and actually pretty. But the smallest size is too big for me, so compression it ain't. Even if it fit, though, it'd be a very light compression. But at $16.90 maybe worth a try: http://www.sockcompany.com/cudusedvca.html Some of bygrace's Annette items look like real possibilities too, but they're a bit expensive to order with the hope they'll work: http://www.senselingerie.com/m-3-annette-shapewear.aspx And here's one that might be worth a try: http://www.womanspersonalhealth.com/products/887/Anita-1095-Compression-Bra.htm I'm currently using this Maidenform Control-It cami, which has been on sale at some of our AZ Costco's lately for two of them for $22. https://www.maidenform.com/catalog/thumbnail.jsp?categoryId=82&parentCategoryId=3&index=4 Sturdier compression than the CuddlDuds, comes up nice and high under my arms, which I need, and the straps are wide enough to be really comfortable. I wear this one inside out so the gathering strip in the front doesn't bug my skin. Other than that it's seamless so it works well. My problem with it is not being able to devise a prosthesis pocket for it. (Sigh!) So for a really sturdy cami that it's possible to sew a pocket in, I use Sassbax Torso Trim: http://sassybax.com/torso_trim.php Very pricey, but it looks great on and it's comfortable. Main problem is the straps are a bit too narrow to work perfectly, so I use one of those shoulder thingys you can clip on over the strap to widen it (got it from the TLC catalog. I'm currently considering this breast stabilizer: http://www.senselingerie.com/pm-516-3-breast-stabilizing-band.aspx Not because I have breasts to stabilize (sigh again!) but because I think a thing like this might be all I actually need to control the swelling under my arms and along both chest and back. If I make it myself I may even be able to include prosthesis pockets. We shall see… In fact, being breastless presents some real challenges for chest compression. I'm even looking at men's compression vests like so: http://www.makemeheal.com/mmh/product.do?id=33302 But then I still have to solve the prosthesis problem, and not sure how to do that. Maybe an outside drop-in type pocket. In short, if anyone has any ideas that work for them, please do post. This is clearly an area where we could use some product development. Thanks again, Jane, for joining the battle of the bra! Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 08:19PM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Okie, It's no fun being new to LE, that's for sure! But new garments are always a bit of an adventure, even after a few years of LE, so you're at least in good company here . I'm not sure about the order of events you've mentioned here. You got your sleeve and glove on Friday, but then do you mean that by evening you had new swelling in your hand? And by Saturday morning the swelling had gone down? If that's it, did you elevate your arm at night, or did the swelling just go down by itself (I'm assuming you didn't wear the sleeve and glove at night, right?) I've had trouble with numbness from new gloves, and as long as my fingertips don't get icy or turn blue I've tried wearing them for just a short time at first, working up to longer periods of time. Also, as you suggest, I've tried doing frequent hand stretches and exercises while wearing them. Sometimes those two strategies work and it all straightens out in a few days, but other times it's a bust and I take them back and have them remade. In other words, I think sometimes it's a matter of our arms and fingers adjusting to the compression, which is certainly anything but normal ! And other times it's a matter of the fit just being plain wrong. I hate making fusses, so it's always hard for me to go back and have things redone. If that feels awkward to you, too, maybe it'll help you to know that that happens a lot, and it's important that the fit be something we can live with. Heaven knows we've got enough other stuff to deal with that we don't need our fingers going numb on us! If your new garments make any part of you swell, don't wear them again and call your therapist on Monday. If you try using them for short periods and exercising your hand more and your fingers are still numb, ditto. If your fingertips are red again, or blue, or icy cold, or they look like Little Smokie sausages when you take your glove off, same thing. Don't hesitate to get what you need! Let us know how it goes Big new-to-LE (((((HUGS!!))))) Binney

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 11:31PM - edited Mar 13, 2008 11:32PM by Binney4 Hi, Casey, Good to see you! I use Solaris-Tribute night gear, which is similar to JoviPak and some of the Peninsula Medical gear ("Opera" sleeve, for instance). Mine can be refrigerated during the day in the summer, and the foam holds the cool for several hours. My insurance covers it (with a prescription, of course) as DME, and they last around two years or so. It's machine washable and dryable, and I believe the JoviPak is also (though I don't know about Peninsula's). I also use mine sometimes for travel. You can order an oversleeve that adds compression. Some women use the oversleeves all the time, but I use mine only when I'm having trouble keeping things in control, or for travel. You can also wrap with short-stretch bandages over them, but that doesn't seem very convenient to me. All in all they're MUCH more convenient than wrapping and MUCH more likely to be used.   Mine actually help reduce swelling, much like bandaging, but none of the companies that make them make that claim for everyone. And of course there are purists who believe only wrapping will reduce LE. Please tell her for me that not wearing a glove with the sleeve is what precipitated LE in my hand, and I can guarantee her she doesn't want this stupid stuff in her hand. It's downright debilitating. Hindsight, y'know? I also pulled up another thread for you called "So how do you cope??!!" that is a collection of practical ideas for making it all easier. Perhaps some of them will help. Love your big ol' dog. Simply awesome!  Thanks, Casey, for all you do. Binney

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 11:47AM Binney4 wrote:  Good morning, all, I'm sorry about the new cancer, Resiliant. Prayers for great results and no complications! The National Lymphedema Network had some recent newsletter articles about surgery on a LE or at-risk arm. Basically, they said if you already have LE you of course have to make sure the swelling is as reduced as possible before surgery, and use compression as soon after surgery as your doctor will allow. If you don't have it yet and are wishing to prevent it, you might talk to your doctor about a prophylactic antibiotic, starting a day or two before surgery. After surgery keep you arm elevated on pillows. (Don't let a nurse tie it to an IV pole to elevate it, as tying it compresses the lymphatics in your wrist.) Then elevate it as often as you can for a few days after surgery (and at night on pillows). Avoid salt, stay well hydrated. Watch carefully for any signs of infection and report them immediately.  Heal, rest, pamper yourself, eat chocolate. (Hmmm. Not sure that last suggestion was from the NLN ) Be well, Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 02:00PM Binney4 wrote: Ah, Beth, as the "mom" of an 80lb Goldendoodle puppy, I hear you! (Sure are cute, though, aren't they?!) Ouch! Nasty business, but there are things you can do that will help. The compression is a good idea (as long as it fits well). The icing isn't so good -- temperature extremes can cause you problems with this. Cool is okay, cold is not. DON'T wear the sleeve (and glove or gauntlet, yes?) to bed. They're designed to work with the movement of your muscles, not when you're lying still. They can also become twisted or slide out of place while you're sleeping and create a tourniquet effect on your arm -- definitely not what you're after. Keep your arm elevated as much as you can over the next few days (on pillows at night too). Don't stress or strain your arm. Keep it out of hot water (or extended time outside on a hot day). Stop from time to time and take a few deep abdominal breaths (stimulates the movement of the lymph system). And stay VERY WELL hydrated (helps dilute the lymph fluid.)  Beth, relax! Chances are good you'll be just fine. Crate the pup when he's out of control, get somebody to help when he's out on a leash, and do sit down with him (her?) and enjoy all the health benefits of petting that beautiful fur. Keep us posted, and be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 12:50PM Binney4 wrote: Lori, ouch! You really hit hard! Glad it's already showing signs of healing well. Icing could be a problem, because any extreme of temperatures, high or low, can put you at risk for lymphedema. So cooling is good, but add an extra layer of cloth or towel to keep it from being really icy cold. (You know how if you're outside playing in winter and the snow gets into your mittens, then when you go inside your hand and fingers swell up as they're thawing out? You don't want to encourage excess fluid to accumulate there by either very hot or very cold temps.) The elevation is a great idea, as long as the arm is well supported, and with no restrictions around it (jewelry, cuffs, tight bandages). Other helps are taking occasional deep abdominal breaths (it stimulates the largest lymph vessel in our bodies), and staying VERY well hydrated (helps dilute the lymph fluid so it can flow more freely). Here's a page of information about dealing with medical emergencies, trauma, and surgery to an arm with lymphedema or, as in your case, at risk for lymphedema. http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Emergencies_and_Medical_Care_lymphedema.htm Goodness -- be well! (And please keep us posted), Binney

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 06:15AM Binney4 wrote: Hi, Dejaboo, Sometimes I think this whole LE board is completely whacked out ! Where else would grown women be discussing how to towel-dry ourselves and whether or not to rub our poor, sore arms when they ache?!  Among our other prime topics for discussion: how to shave our arm pits, what emergency measures to take in case of a mosquito bite crisis, and how to wave while wrapped in bandages. Why, we're practically a finishing school! Anybody who already has a massage routine should clear their neck nodes before a shower and then wash and dry in the order and direction of their massage. For those who don't yet, it goes sorta like this (and I hope others will come along and offer their suggestions and routines). First, start with a few deep abdominal breaths, in through your nose, out through your mouth. The easy, casual way to do your neck is simply to do some gentle stretches: standing up straight (under the shower is fine), bend your head forward slowly until your chin touches your chest, and raise it slowly. Then bend your neck to the right until your ear touches your shoulder (keep your shoulders relaxed, though) and slowly raise your head. Bend your head to the left and up again. Do that 4 or 5 times like you've got all the time in the world. (Don't bend your head back - just forward and to each side.) Then standing up straight TURN your head slowly to the right and again slowly to the left a few times. Okay, neck clear. Take a few more deep breaths. When you soap up (or dry off, or apply lotion, or SOFTLY rub your aching arms) you can then use this order: First chest: if you're bilateral dry UPWARD above the scars to the shoulder and DOWNWARD below the scars to the groin. Dry your side and back in a downward direction from top to bottom. If you've only had surgery on one side, you dry front and back in the direction of your unaffected arm pit. (My therapist tells me it's a bit of a trick to learn to towel yourself sideways across your body, but since I'm bilateral that's one trick I didn't have to learn! ) Dry your arm like so: front of upper arm UP toward shoulder, then back of upper arm toward front of arm, then up to shoulder again. Elbow, from back to front, then up the front of the arm to the shoulder again. Lower arm, same as upper arm. Wrist and hand, upward toward arm and then clear up to shoulder again. This takes longer to explain than it does to do it, but I gotta say that drying UP my arm took some getting used to -- guess it's just natural to go down. Do a couple more deep breaths and slow neck bends, and you're good to go. It's fine to rub your arms when they ache, but again it's best to start at the top, going up, and work your way down your arm, always rubbing up toward your shoulder. And the rubbing needs to be gentle, like petting a kitten, in order to be effective in terms of moving lymph fluid. The lymph vessels are very near the surface, so heavy pressure squishes them rather than encouraging lymph flow. If you need firmer pressure to relieve the ache, that's fine. It won't do any particular damage (as long as it's not deep tissue massage) but it won't move lymph. Clear as mud?! If you don't get it, ask again and maybe I can clarify, or somebody else can. Next lesson, ladies! How to open a jar of olives with your slippery, stupid glove on...

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 12:53PM Binney4 wrote: Artemis, good morning! There are other things you can do as well to protect your arm. (Knowledge is power!) Like wearing your well-fitting glove (or gauntlet) and sleeve while you pack, since hefting suitcases around can be a strain. Stay VERY well hydrated throughout (helps dilute the lymph fluid), exercise your arm gently throughout the flight (simple stretches, reach up and "cat claw" the air, hold your arm above your head and "pump" your fist slowly open and closed), and ask for help tugging your luggage out of overhead bins and carousels. Wear the garments (or stay wrapped) for an hour or two after you land to allow your body to adjust to the pressure changes. Pause from time to time to take several deep abdominal breaths (stimulates the lymph system). If it's a vacation destination, use sun protection and insect repellent when you're outdoors, and if you're doing unaccustomed activities wear your compression garments for extra protection. We all need our lives back, and flying is not something we need to eliminate from our lives. Knowing how to protect yourself is important, but once you've taken the precautions it's just as important to ENJOY! Bon voyage, and let us know how it goes! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 07:57PM Binney4 wrote: climber, you're trying to decide about doing rads, yes? The enemy here is the breast cancer beast, not the lymphedema. Do everything, EVERYTHING you need to in order to assure the bc will not come back, and after that decision is made it's time enough to worry about the lymphedema. Here are a couple of reasons why you really can't afford to make lymphedema a factor in your rads decision: First, lymphedema can be treated. Especially if you're aware of the possibility and catch it early, lymphedema can be controlled and managed. And the treatment is not grueling -- no drugs, no surgery. It's a matter of gentle (even delightful!) massage, gentle exercises, skin care, and compression. Secondly, there's absolutely no way anyone can tell you what your indiviual risk for lymphedema might be. Presumably, you've already had some sort of surgery for your bc, so you're already at risk for lymphedema -- even if it was only a prophylactic mastectomy. Some things increase your risk, but no one knows how much, or even what all the risk factors are. Rads is only one of them. Third, there are A LOT of other things you can do yourself -- with or without rads -- to lower your personal risk. You'll want to learn about them and do them all, whether you decide on rads or not. You'll find some guidelines among the Position Papers at the National Lymphedema Network web site, here: www.lymphnet.org Last but not least, MOST women who are treated for breast cancer, even with rads, do NOT develop lymphedema. The percentages may be higher than we're led to believe, but they're not near fifty percent, by anybody's estimate.  I have lymphedema. It started on my prophylactic side, not the side with rads. I hate lymphedema, as you perhaps already know since I tend to yelp about it all over these boards. But it's got NOTHING on breast cancer. climber, don't fear the lymphedema -- there's help for it, and it's not going to destroy you. Do what you need to do to fight the real beast. Big hugs, and prayers for peace with your rads decision -- these things are so difficult! Binney
Posts.Title: Lymphedema after Rads climbergirl sccruiser

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 11:45PM - edited Jan 25, 2008 12:50AM by Binney4 Hi, rottenrottie, and welcome!  I'm sorry your problems with diagnosis have brought you here, but glad you found us. A lot of us have had trouble getting this diagnosis straight, so you're not alone! Our doctors often don't know much about lymphedema, as it's not their field of expertise, and unfortunately it's not a subject that's taught much in our medical schools. The medical expert you need to see in order to get a straight diagnosis would be a well-qualified lymphedema therapist. You can find one near you by following the links on the Therapist Locator, here: www.mylymphedema.com. You'll need a referral from any one of your doctors: your onc, rads onc, PCP, surgeon, or plastic surgeon, so find the one most able to help you with this. The therapist will measure your arms, take your medical history, and do a physical exam to diagnose it, without any invasive tests being required. The test that Tina mentions, lymphoscintigraphy, is not usually used for routine diagnoses like those following breast cancer treatment. The injected dye can cause temporary problems with lymph flow that can worsen swelling, and of course any injection into areas affected by lymphedema presents an infection risk. The test is more often used when the diagnosis is unclear because the swelling in a limb has no clear causative factor such as breast cancer, or when standard lymphedema therapy doesn't work. So your first step needs to be a referral for evaluation by a trained and experienced lymphedema therapist. And the sooner the better! I'm sorry all the doctors' waffling has caused you so much stress, but hopefully you'll soon have the information you need. Please let us know what you discover. Be well! Binney
Posts.Title: lymphedema in the left arm sheila542 NPat

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 10:38PM Binney4 wrote: makingway, hello, I'm sorry you're having to struggle with all this. As a woman with lymphedema I can agree with you that it is a quality of life issue. Of course you're fearful of it -- we all were. But there are two other factors you'll want to take into consideration. First, even with ALND and rads, the fact is that most women never develop lymphedema. It is not currently possible to predict who will and who won't, but even if you needed extensive node removal and several fields of rads, that's no guarantee you'd ever have to cope with it. And second, any bc treatment creates a lymphedema risk. It's a fact of our lives from here on out, all of us. There are plenty of simple life-style adjustments you can make that will significantly reduce that risk without affecting QOL. I wish I'd known about them and been warned to take those simple precautions. But the fact is, if you do develop lymphedema as I have (both arms, both hands, both sides of my chest, with a single node removed on one side and a prophylactic mastectomy on the other), it's still entirely possible to live fully, gratefully, and well. Those, too, are choices we have the right to make for ourselves. You must feel so trapped and paralysed -- I remember that feeling and the grief that overwhelmed me as I tried to make the best decisions for me. Please know as you tussle with this that you're not alone. Hugs, prayers, Binney

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 05:48PM Binney4 wrote: 1.)  SOME people I know and meet are actually interested both in what I'm dealing with personally and with lymphedema as a subject they've never heard of. They ask a million questions about the lymph system and why they never learned about it, and why doctors don't know anything about it. They're fascinated to think that this silent, invisible system exists all over their own bodies, doing all the life-giving things it does, and they never even knew it existed. 2.)  I value the solidarity I feel both with others who deal with chronic conditions, and with others whose struggles go unnoticed by the larger community. I've been able to relate easily to people who were distant to me before, and I like the people I've gotten to know in this way. 3.)  I love being able to communicate with researchers, product suppliers, therapists and others in the relatively small LE world, and be the one who KNOWS what it's like to live with this because I'm a LE patient. There are some incredible people out there who have truly devoted their lives to solving the problems we face, and they actually care to listen to us. 4.)  Shoot, sure there are limitations to what I can do that I'd like to do, but I also get out of doing a lot of things I never liked doing anyway. Like lugging the dirty laundry out to the shed (DS does that now), scrubbing the really grubby, greasy pots and pans (DD does that now), digging the mulch into the garden plot when the temperature is 101 degrees (DH does that now), hefting luggage around when we travel (team effort now). In fact, the forced division of labor has been good for everyone in the family, pushing some responsibility onto the kids that I wouldn't have thought to give them before. We're all growing up! 5.)  I can't believe my great good fortune in knowing all the women I've met here on this LE board. We're a strong, positive group that's out to change this cramped little corner of the world that LE has shoved us into.  Look out, medical world -- we're a force to be dealt with! Be well! Binney

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2009 04:23PM Binney4 wrote: It is an interesting hypothesis. A year ago I spoke to Dr. Barbara Pockaj at Mayo here in Phoenix about a trial she was doing strictly for bc treatment, using Avastin immediately following surgery in women with early stage bc. She's a surgeon, but unusually savvy about LE, so I asked her if in their study they'd be looking at rate of LE development, since Avastin inhibits growth of vessels (both blood and lymphatic, according to her and to the scientists at the U.of A. who concern themselves with VEGF). Compared to blood vessels, lymph vessels apparently have a limited ability to regenerate, and the time period for regeneration after trauma is also limited, so immediate use of Avastin could theoretically raise the incidence of LE, though later use of the drug may have no effect (or even a beneficial effect for the reasons hypothesized in the study outline). For that reason she worked out some extra funding to add rate of LE development to their study, but it'll be some time before we know the outcome of that. The anecdotal experience with Avastin having a positive effect on LE is compelling, and I'm glad they're planning to study it (though I haven't volunteered) So perhaps the timing here is crucial, giving time post-surgery or post-rads for whatever regeneration will take place before starting the drug. (Of course none of this has anything to do with bc treatment -- if use of Avastin immediately after surgery saves lives, the LE is beside the point.) That said, it's not Mayo that's conducting this particular study, and I my familiarity with the group in Scottsdale that's doing this is limited. They've been trying to get this underway for quite a long time, but local scuttlebutt has it that they're strapped for volunteers. Since everything from dosage to long-term side-effects is virtually unknown, you can see why. This one will definitely be really interesting to watch. Binney

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2012 04:23PM Binney4 wrote: barsco, welcome! Of course you're not imposing. We're all fanatics about wanting our Sistahs who are at risk to take all the precautions they can to avoid joining our Sorority of Swell. Good for you! The bad news first: we're all at risk, and it's for life. But the good news is that there are some simple life-style changes you can make to help reduce that risk. Here's some general information about it: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/riskreduction_for_lymphedema.htm More specifically, the issue of what to do about flying can be controversial. Some people advocate using well-fitting compression garments (a sleeve and hand protection), while others argue that a poorly-fitted garment could cause more problems than it solves. Since your flight is short, you may want to avoid the controversy altogether and take other precautions. Like these: When you're packing, be careful about lifting loaded suitcases onto the floor or into your car. Get someone to help.  Luggage with wheels is better than hefting it with your arms, but you still need to be careful with all the tugging and hefting involved in air travel (at check-in, TSA screening, boarding and deplaning, carousel pick-up). Plan to stay VERY well hydrated--no caffeine. This helps dilute lymph fluid and keeps it moving. Pause from time to time to take a few deep abdominal breaths. This stimulates the largest lymph vessel in your body. Do some arm (and leg!) stretches at intervals. Don't worry about what other passengers think--you'll never see them again! Especially helpful: reaching your arm above your head and rhythmically opening and closing your fist. At your destination, if you'll be outside, avoid both sunburn and insect bites. If you'll be engaged in unusual activities on your trip (beach volleyball? kayaking?), pay attention to your arm and stop at once if you experience aching, tingling, or tightness. Elevate your arm, and stay well hydrated. As soon as you're able, even after your trip, ask any doctor on your team for a referral to a well-trained lymphedema therapist for evaluation, personalized risk-reduction tips, and baseline arm measurements for future reference. Here's how to find one near you: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Have a wonderful trip, don't swell, and be well! (Let us know how it goes!) Binney
Posts.Title: Thinking about flying cookiegal barsco1963

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2012 07:18PM Binney4 wrote: Crystal, here's infomation about proper garment fitting: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_lymphedema_garments.htm A poorly fitting sleeve can cause trouble in the same way that a blood pressure cuff can--by creating a tournaquet effect, "squishing" the lymphatics in one area and blocking lymph flow. For instance, a sleeve that's too tight at the wrist can trap fluid in the hand and not allow it to return up the arm. A sleeve that's too tight at the top will trap fluid in the upper arm or elbow. If your garments are working well for you on the days that you use them, then that's not a worry. Our day garments last about six months if they're worn daily (actually, every other day, because you'd have two and alternate them). They hold up better if they're washed daily. If you're wearing them only occasionally they'll last longer, of course. Barsco, lymphedema therapists can be hard to locate, as sometimes even our doctors are not aware of them. Hopefully following all the links on Therapist Locator on the page I listed above will come up with some surprising finds closer to home. But the fact is, some of the women here do have to travel long distances for help. A good lymphedema therapist is worth gold! Let us know what you discover! Binney
Posts.Title: Thinking about flying cookiegal barsco1963

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 07:28PM Binney4 wrote: Liefie, don't cancel! Right, a poorly-fitting sleeve is worse than no sleeve, because an area that's too tight above one that's not-so-tight can trap any swelling in your arm or hand. There are some helps for assuring a good fit here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/proper_fitting_of_lymphedema_garments.htm But it really isn't a do-it-yourself deal, and it's always best to check with someone knowledgable. BUT, if you can't do that there are still precautions you can take to reduce your risk. Be careful when packing and traveling not to heft heavy luggage around. Use good body mechanics if you have to lift either the suitcase or piles of items you're packing in it (use your unaffected arm or both arms, and keep the weight close in to your body, not way out in front of you). Use wheeled luggage and don't jerk it up over the curbs. Get someone to help you lift it into the overhead areas or off the carousels. Don't carry heavy bags over your affected shoulder. Stay really well hydrated, starting the day before you leave at least--that helps dilute the lymph fluid to keep it moving. (It may mean more trips to that tiny stupid airplane bathroom, but at least it'll get you out of your seat and stretching your legs!) On the plane, plan to do arm stretches often to help keep lymph flowing, and do periodic deep, abdominal breathing to stimulate the largest lymph vessel in your body. When you arrive, be mindful of any unusual activities you may be doing (kayaking, mountain climbing?!) and if you're outdoors use sunscreen and insect repellent. Have a great trip, and do let us know how it goes! Binney

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 09:50AM Binney4 wrote: Ooh, true -- both arms. Chest too. It gets claustrophobic. Katiejane, I can tell you a strange story about this, but it may be just me, because I've never heard anyone else mention it. Wearing bilateral compression 24/7 made me cry. Literally. Cried a lot, and there wasn't a reason I could think of. I wasn't sad, or depressed, I just cried. My DH also noticed I was "blanking out." I'd sit and do nothing, think nothing for minutes at a time. Naturally I worried that it must be brain mets. And then I read an article in the NLN newsletter about little kids with LE. They had to have a few hours a day without wraps or garments because they're just learning about their environment and need the sensory stimulation or they develop learning problems. Bingo! I started studying sensory deprivation, and my symptoms eerily matched. So I immediately started leaving the garments off for a couple of hours every evening, and that fixed it. When I'm not wearing garments I can't do much or I start to swell. I can read or watch TV or sew something simple, but I can't write notes or work on the computer or knit. I do rub my hands and arms on different textures -- the couch fabric, my desktop, my clothes -- to get some stimulation. Sometimes one hand or the other will feel like it's starting to swell, and I'll slip a glove on just that hand, but for the most part this works fine for me. If I want to do something more vigorous, though, I have to put the garments back on. See? Told you it was weird! I think I must be an extreme case or something. I do know that texture has always been very important to me (I love all the fiber arts), so walking through a fabric store, say, and not being able to reach out and feel the fabrics as I walk by has been very hard. (So I also remove a glove when I go through such places. If you do that, though, be sure to put it someplace secure -- these gloves are very pricey accessories to drop and lose!) Sure hope that helps, KatieJane. If you try it I'd be interested to know how it works for you. Sending you "stimulating" thoughts! Binney
